The troops mobilize and go in for the attack and Johnnie joins them and trips over his sword and pratfalls and blah this is getting tiresome.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;The Union men reach the bridge which is on fire, and the General tells them the fire hasn&#39;t sufficiently damaged the bridge and they can still cross it. The train goes along the tracks over the bridge and--the entire thing collapses and the train goes into the water about fifty feet below. &amp;nbsp;And it&#39;s real. Not models. Not CGI. A real train on a real bridge goes boom and it is awesome. The Confederate men show up and make quick work of the surviving Union soldiers.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;And slavery lives on for yet another day. HURRAY!&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Johnnie waves the Confederate flag proudly and wears his &lt;b&gt;Ron Paul &#39;12&lt;/b&gt; button and is finally allowed to enlist as a Lieutenant. The recruiter asks him his occupation and Johnnie proudly stands up tall and says,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Solider.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Nothing left to do but wait for Sherman to come and burn everything to the ground. (Spoiler).&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Maybe before there were &lt;i&gt;Star Trek &lt;/i&gt;people and &lt;i&gt;Star Wars &lt;/i&gt;people and &lt;i&gt;Beatles &lt;/i&gt;people and &lt;i&gt;Elvis&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;people, there were Buster people and Charlie people. If so, count me in Buster&#39;s lot. He&#39;s far and away more talented and just flat-out funnier. He&#39;s just as gifted physically, but the slapstick is more...I wanna say &quot;organic&quot;, but that&#39;s not quite it. It&#39;s more...plausible, I guess. Johnnie never just spazzed out randomly. He got himself into trouble and had to do bizarre/funny physical things to accomplish goals that advanced the plot. Charlie Chaplin just acts like a freak for no reason. Also, the &quot;stone-face&quot; of Keaton is just naturally funny, and more surreal, which is what you want in a silent movie. I was also impressed by how well all the action &quot;tracked&quot;, meaning Johnnie would do X which would effect Y and cause Z and we could watch it all go down in real time, no CGI, no tricks. It reminded me of the Goofy cartoons, where Goofy would get involved in all sorts of complicated Rube Goldberg type slapstick situations that were really quite ingeniously plotted out. Similar to Wile E Coyote&#39;s adventures. But it&#39;s all the more impressive here because it&#39;s live action. That said, there was still a lot of extraneous, boring shit here. And a lot of redundant stuff, and at least 30 minutes of filler. Also, I realize it was 1926, but a story about a heroic Confederate solider? &amp;nbsp;Really? I gotta wonder how that played north of the Mason-Dixon. But I still liked it enough to give it a mild thumbs up, were I Siskel or Ebert or the Other Guy. For my money though, my favorite silent movie on this list is still &lt;i&gt;Sunrise&lt;/i&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;The Graduate&quot; and then another gay-fave that I will hopefully love enough to get me my membership back, &quot;Sunset Boulevard&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1726834229430519630/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2012/01/18-general-1926.html' title='#18 The General (1926)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4848043804414084578</id><published>2012-01-05T20:25:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2012-01-06T09:54:39.313-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#19 On the Waterfront (1954)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_wZOQ1RbQQs/TwZuJ1hJCyI/AAAAAAAAALs/EHwlx0ijEfo/s1600/brando.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_wZOQ1RbQQs/TwZuJ1hJCyI/AAAAAAAAALs/EHwlx0ijEfo/s1600/brando.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;(with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Tough guy Terry Malloy works down at the docks and is very manly and blue collar-y. He approaches an apartment building, and yells up to his friend Joey. Terry is too macho for sissy telephones. Joey comes to the window and Terry yells that he found one of Joey&#39;s racing pigeons, which he then reveals he has palmed in his hands. Joey says he&#39;ll meet Terry on the roof, where he keeps the pigeons. As soon as Joey disappears back into his apartment, Terry lets the pigeon go. The music is all intense and wonky, so we know shit&#39;s about to go down. Indeed, while Terry stares from the ground, several tough guys push Joey off the roof. The music goes apeshit. Like, cymbals and drums and all that.&lt;br /&gt;Terry goes to the guys afterwards and complains that he didn&#39;t know they were gonna kill Joey, he just thought they were gonna rough him up a bit. The guys are like, &quot;what part of &#39;mobsters&#39; don&#39;t you understand&quot;? For indeed, they are union leaders and mobster who control the docks and rough up/kill anyone who gets out of line. &lt;i&gt;You see what happens, Tom Joad, you godless infidel? Not so keen on unions &lt;b&gt;now&lt;/b&gt;, are you?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The next day at the docks, the union leaders are deciding who works that day and who doesn&#39;t. Joey&#39;s sister Edie shows up and starts screaming at everyone, demanding to know who killed her brother. She complains about the workers playing &quot;D and D&quot;, which sounds funny now, but means &quot;deaf and dumb&quot;. Everyone ignores her, except for Terry, who probably feels guilty and that guilt manifests itself by him &lt;i&gt;asking her out.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;You know, like a total sociopath would. And indeed, the go out for coffee and get flirty. We learn Terry used to be an amateur boxer, but missed his chance at the big time when he lost a crucial match early on.&lt;br /&gt;Also moved by Edie, is local priest Father Barry, aka the Most Awesome Priest In All Of Cinema. Father Barry is a tough, angry Irishman. He calls all the dock workers to his church to grill them all what they know about Joey&#39;s death. The union leader, absurdly named Johnny Friendly, sends Terry to the church to act as their spy and find out of anyone squeals. But its all for not, for no matter how much Father Barry rants and raves at them, they all play dumb. Everyone&#39;s too afraid the mobsters will keep them from working again if they name names. Terry goes back to the mobsters, which we learn include his brother Charlie, and tells them no one is stupid enough to talk. Then he goes on another date with Edie, and they open up to each other more and get all schmoopy and stuff.&lt;br /&gt;But then Father Barry has another meeting, and it&#39;s interrupted by some goons who proceed to beat up several dock workers. One of them, Dugan, changes his mind and tells Father Barry he&#39;ll testify against Friendly and his goons. But sure enough, the next day, Dugan is supervising another guy who is moving a pallet full of whiskey with a forklift, and darn it all, the pallet falls apart while in the air and comes crashing down on Dugan, killing him. Father Barry makes another angry, impassioned, totally badass speech calling all the dockworkers cowards while &amp;nbsp;Friendly and the other mobsters literally throw garbage on him from above. Terry watches all this go down, and is moved. It&#39;s a pretty great scene and Karl Malden kills it.&lt;br /&gt;He confesses to Edie, whom he now loves, (because they&#39;ve really fast-tracked the romance stuff) that he lured Joey on the roof that night but swears he didn&#39;t know what they were going to do. Edie races off, terrified and disgusted.&lt;br /&gt;Then word gets out that Terry&#39;s been talking too much to Father Barry and Friendly instructs Charlie to learn from Terry if he plans on testifying or not. He tells Charlie that if Terry seems like he&#39;s wavering at all, to kill him.&lt;br /&gt;Charlie confronts Terry and asks him what he plans to do. Terry says he doesn&#39;t know yet. But then he has some past shit to dredge up. He reveals to we the audience that it was at Charlie&#39;s request that he lost that boxing match all those years ago. He took a dive in order to allow Friendly to beat the odds and get a huge payout. Terry aches, physically aches, with regret and the fantasies what might&#39;ve been. He could&#39;ve been a contender. He could&#39;ve been somebody. If you&#39;ve never said that speech to yourself before, you&#39;ve a lucky soul. Or under 30. Charlie&#39;s as moved as I am, and out of guilt, promises to tell Friendly that he looked for Terry and couldn&#39;t find him, but Terry has to go and hide, now!&lt;br /&gt;But Friendly and the other mobsters don&#39;t buy Charlie&#39;s story, and he&#39;s promptly killed. Terry goes berserk and decides to kill Friendly, or else go down in a hail of bullets. Father Barry gets all Hardcore Badass once again, says the answer is not a gun, you fucking idiot, it&#39;s the court of law! So Terry says he&#39;ll testify. In court he stammers through a confession of his part in Joey&#39;s death, while Friendly and the others glare.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, he shows up at the docks, and none of the workers speak to him. But Edie&#39;s there, looking all proud and radiant and female and supportive. The Crazytown music starts up again, as Terry protests that he did what was right, dammit! The mobsters show up and allow everyone but Terry to work. Terry yells at them. A brawl breaks out, and they all begin beating the shit out of Terry. The other workers start to feel guilty. They demand Friendly stop the beating. Friendly does, then orders everyone in to work. But the workers have finally had enough. They say they won&#39;t work unless Terry does too.&lt;br /&gt;The music is &lt;i&gt;fucking losing its mind again&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;BONG BONG BONG CRASH CRASH COWBELL!!!!&lt;br /&gt;Not since &lt;i&gt;Meet Joe Black&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;has a musical score been so unrelentingly annoying and ostentatious.&lt;br /&gt;Terry slowly gets to his feet, kisses Edie, then walks walks onto the docks, the other men following him. It would&#39;ve been quite touching if I had been able to fucking hear anything.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;There&#39;s definitely some good stuff, here. The general story was pretty interesting, and several scenes stood out as particularly great. The scene where Father Barry is pelted with garbage and the scene where he convinces Terry that vigilante justice is not the answer were very compelling, and the &amp;nbsp;famous &quot;I coulda been a contender&quot; scene earns its place in movie history. But there&#39;s also some boring stuff, like everything between Terry and Edie and their alleged love. Having gotten used to anti-heroes like Don Draper and Walter White, I was legitimately surprised at Terry&#39;s third act redemption and conversion, even though in retrospect, I obviously shouldn&#39;t have been. I think I would&#39;ve liked it more if Terry was the unrepentant bad guy that was still partially sympathetic and Father Barry was the hero. It&#39;s also pretty interesting that the director Elia Kazan is one of the most famous tattlers in American history, ratting on other supposed dangerous Communists in the 50&#39;s and getting them blacklisted. This could easily be scene as his response to people&#39;s perception of him as a rat, even though Terry testified against murderers and Kazan testified against people who attended meetings. Not really the same, Kazan. At any rate, the scenes that were good were really good and the scenes that here kinda boring went by rather quickly, so I can&#39;t complain too much. And as I said, the character of Father Barry is unlike I&#39;ve ever seen a priest portrayed before and Karl Malden does a fantastic job. Brando was also very good, though still my favorite of his is &lt;i&gt;Apocalypse Now.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, silence is once again golden. But this time, it&#39;s not The Little Tramp, but that &lt;i&gt;other &lt;/i&gt;silent film star Buster Keaton, in &quot;The General&quot;, and then Mrs. Robinson tries to seduce us all in &quot;The Graduate&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' background;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;in his past, here&#39;s the tale,&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;He saved his brother from drowning&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;and his boss from jail.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;All his life he dreamed&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;of escaping Bedford Falls&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: swimming&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and she got naked with a bush.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;His father asked him to stay&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br one day George&#39;s uncle&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;went to make a deposit.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He had eight grand&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and accidentally lost gone.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He screamed at his uncle&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;at his wife, kids and mom.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br made the wish come true.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;And when George saw this happen&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;he became very blue.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br too.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;And his brother, oh his brother,&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;was dead. &amp;nbsp;Yes, it&#39;s true.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br for the birds!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;Clarence did as he asked&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and George whooped with joy&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He didn&#39;t care about the money,&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;he was one grateful boy.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He hugged Mary and the kids&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and accepted his fate.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He would soon be in jail&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;it was just too late.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;When suddenly outside,&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;George heard such a clatter.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;He sprang to the door&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;to see what was the matter.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;In came Ma and Ernie&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and Burt and Billy&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and Violet and Sam&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and Annie and Tilly&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;The whole town was there&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and they all chipped in&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;The eight thousand was covered&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;with a wink and a grin.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&quot;We love you, George,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;Merry Christmas!&quot;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;the town all cheered.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;Up in Heaven, Sir smiled&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and the dark clouds all cleared.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;On the tree, the lights twinkle&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;and also the bell rings&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;which everyone knows&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;nbsp;means&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;an angel got his wings.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Pretty cool timing on this one, no? &amp;nbsp;Wasn&#39;t easy busting out so many reviews to make this one by the 12/24 deadline. But I&#39;m awesome like that.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Anyway.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;No, I hadn&#39;t seen this one either. I&#39;ve got no good excuse, except that I thought I had sort of already seen it without seeing it, you know? As it&#39;s been parodied and redone a million times on every TV sitcom from the eighties and beyond. Second only to &lt;i&gt;A Christmas Carol&lt;/i&gt;, this movie has been &quot;reimagined&quot; more than any other. But what I didn&#39;t know was that I only knew the last half hour. I thought that part was the whole movie, I didn&#39;t know it was only the Third Act. I also didn&#39;t know how dark and strange this story was going to be, with level of maturity well beyond what I expect to see in an Olden Times movie.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;I knew what was going to happen in the end with the town all giving him the lost money, and I feared very much that it would be a schmaltz-fest, but the movie earns that moment completely, with a deep and fully realized town of supporting characters that truly seem to live real lives separate from just supporting George in this movie, and with a love story that&#39;s compelling and realistic and with a great villain in Potter. By the end, not only did I not mind a schmaltz-fest, but I actively &lt;i&gt;craved&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;one. There was no other way to release the tension, to breathe again, and to allow George (and perhaps a viewer or two) to make peace with the fact that life doesn&#39;t always go as planned. The movie does such a great job of putting us in George&#39;s mindset; experiencing his frustrations at never getting to leave town, and keeping us from seeing what a truly wonderful life George has, just as he can&#39;t see it, until the end. It&#39;s a great cathartic ending to a truly wonderful and unique movie.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;On the Waterfront&quot; and then, &quot;The General&quot;. But those will come next year. &amp;nbsp;See you then. And, Merry Christmas.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8244530457686285943/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' (1946)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-5633751468215458818</id><published>2011-12-20T20:45:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-21T11:08:12.942-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#21 Chinatown (1974)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-3kT-wNMwgNE/TvFkWM-KL7I/AAAAAAAAALI/3d8VXKhcaQE/s1600/j.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;136&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-3kT-wNMwgNE/TvFkWM-KL7I/AAAAAAAAALI/3d8VXKhcaQE/s320/j.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Jake Gittes. Private Eye. Los Angeles. 1937. Jake has some pictures to show his client, Curly, who hired Jake because he suspects his wife is having an affair. He&#39;s right. Curly leaves the office all broken up and a new client enters, a Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray. Mrs. Mulwray suspects her husband is cheating too, and wants Jake and his partners to find the evidence. Jake takes the case and winds up tailing Mr. Mulwray for a bit. Turns out Mr. Mulwray is the Chief Engineer for the Dept of Water and Power. Turns out he is also cheating on his wife. Jake takes pictures of Mulwray with the girl, and the next day they somehow turn up on the front page of the newspaper. Jake goes back to his office, and his partners do that thing in movies and TV where they try to tell him something and to stop talking, but Jake has a racist Chinese joke to tell, and they let him tell it despite the fact that Faye Dunaway and a Chinese guy are behind him in his office. Faye Dunaway says she&#39;s Mrs. Mulwray, the &lt;i&gt;real&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;Mrs. Mulwray, and she&#39;ll be seeing him in court!&lt;br /&gt;Jake knows he&#39;s been set up. A patsie. A stoolie. He&#39;s determined to find out from who. But soon enough, he finds out Mulwray&#39;s been murdered. He&#39;s called to the scene of the crime by his old partner Escobar, who&#39;s now a lieutenant. Escobar&#39;s interviewing Evelyn Mulwray. She tells him that she hired Jake to uncover evidence of her husband&#39;s affair, and Jake quickly goes along with the lie.&lt;br /&gt;Then Jake goes to the water reservoir where he last saw Mulwray alive to search for any clues. He hops the fence, and starts walking down an empty canal, and is quickly knocked over by a ton of flooding water. He gets out and is cornered by two rough looking goons. One holds him down why the other busts out a knife. He says Jake&#39;s too nosy, then cuts his nose with the knife, because goons love puns.&lt;br /&gt;Later that night, Jake has dinner with Evelyn where she thanks him for going along with her lie and offers to send him a check so it will look legit. She also says she&#39;ll drop the lawsuit. Jake has a hugely comical and distracting bandage on his nose. They do some noir-ish flirting and he wants to know what she&#39;s hiding because dames is always hiding something. She admits she was also cheating on her husband. He tells her he thinks Mulwray was murdered, even though the cops say he was drowned.&lt;br /&gt;Back at the office, Jake gets a call from Ida Sessions, the fake Mrs. Mulwray from before. She says she was hired by someone to fake him out but won&#39;t say who. But because she likes riddles, she tells him to look in that day&#39;s obituary for a clue.&lt;br /&gt;So, cut to it: The plot is immensely detailed and complex and loops around and around in incredibly satisfying ways and everything fits together perfectly like a thousand-piece puzzle of something blue. Jake learns first that Evelyn&#39;s father Noah Cross used to own the Dept of Water and Power along with Mulwray. Cross hires Jake to find the girl Mulwray was cheating on his wife with. Jake learns that someone is using dead people&#39;s names to purchase all the land in the valley, which is where the LA water is being rerouted to. He almost gets killed by the goons again, but Evelyn pulls up in her car and saves him. They race off, and wind up making mad passionate noir-sex. Later, Evelyn receives a phone call and scrambles away, asking Jake to stay there. But yeah, he doesn&#39;t. He follows her to some hideout where he sees her Chinese assistant and the woman Mulwray was having an affair with. Jake wants to know who she really is. Evelyn says it&#39;s her sister, Katherine. &lt;i&gt;(Slap! &amp;nbsp;No wait, not yet). &lt;/i&gt;Then Jake gets a call from Escobar summoning him to a mysterious address. Turns out it&#39;s Ida Session&#39;s house. She&#39;s dead. Escobar thinks Evelyn did it and Jake is protecting her, but Jake laughs in the face of his ignorance. Escobar says Mulwray didn&#39;t drown, either. Salt water was found in his lungs. Jake goes back to Evelyn&#39;s house and discovers the salt-water pond in her backyard and the broken glasses at the bottom. He confronts Evelyn, accusing her of murder, but she denies it.&lt;br /&gt;Stop lying! &amp;nbsp;Who&#39;s the girl?!&lt;br /&gt;My sister! &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;(Slap!)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;My daughter! &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;(Slap!)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;My sister! &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;(Slap!)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;My daughter! &lt;i&gt;(Slap!)&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I really, really like this movie, but this uber-famous scene&#39;s a bit hairy for me. I mean, the slapping in time with the sister/daughter stuff skirts the line of ridiculousness. In fact, probably goes over it.&lt;br /&gt;Evelyn admits her father raped her when she was 15 and Katherine was the result. (Wow, only a totally depraved creep would rape an underage girl. Isn&#39;t that right, Mr. Polanski?) Jake believes her, but he&#39;s already called the cops, thinking she was guilty of murder. He tells them to run they&#39;ll meet at Evelyn&#39;s assistant&#39;s house in two hours. And where does he live? Why, Chinatown, of course. Evelyn also says the glasses aren&#39;t her husband&#39;s because he didn&#39;t wear bifocals.&lt;br /&gt;Then the cops show up and Jake tells Escobar the Evelyn is gone and is probably staying at her maid&#39;s in San Pedro. Escobar makes Jake go with them and says he&#39;ll arrest Jake for accessory to murder if they don&#39;t find Evelyn there. They arrive at what Jake says is the maid&#39;s house, and Jake asks for a couple minutes alone with Evelyn first. Escobar relents.&lt;br /&gt;Jake goes up the house, knocks on the door...and Curly answers. You know, from the first scene! &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s fucking ingenious, I&#39;ll tell you what. Talk about the economy of characters. Jake sneaks out the back with Curly and asks him to meet Evelyn and Katherine in Chinatown and drive them to safety.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Jake goes back to confront Cross for murdering his son-in-law and buying up half the valley with fake names, but Cross&#39; goons grab Jake and force him to take them all the Chinatown.&lt;br /&gt;The final confrontation takes place in Chinatown, where Escobar tries again to arrest Jake, while Evelyn tries to drive off with Katherine. Cross tries to stop Evelyn from taking his &quot;granddaughter&quot; (UGH) away from him, but Evelyn shoots him and drives off. Escobar calls at her to halt and shoots at her. He hits her and she crashes. Everyone runs towards the car and sees that Evelyn is clearly dead. Cross comforts a screaming Katherine (UGH UGH) while Jake stares in shock. Escobar barks at Jake to leave, that he&#39;s doing him a favor. Jake turns to go, then turns around as if to attack Escobar, but his partner holds him back.&lt;br /&gt;Forget it Jake, it&#39;s Chinatown.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;So, as I said earlier, the plot twists and turns in dozens of extremely smart and satisfying ways that are basically too numerous to go into detail. I honestly can&#39;t remember a smarter script, period. And the best part is, at no point, not ever, did I ask myself, &quot;Now why did Character X &lt;i&gt;do that &lt;/i&gt;or &lt;i&gt;go there&lt;/i&gt;?&quot;, which is basically unheard of for this type of genre. Everything makes perfect sense. No plot holes, no fuss, no muss. No suspension of disbelief required, with the lone exception of the dumb scene where Jake&#39;s telling the dumb Chinese joke and none of his partners interrupt him and tell him to shut up and turn around.&amp;nbsp;And despite being extremely plot-heavy and needing a ton of exposition, the script still is able to bring three-dimensional humanity to all the major characters, and have scenes that are thrilling and emotional, as well as informative. The ending is memorably and appropriately bleak, too. There&#39;s a reason why &quot;Chinatown&quot; is now just a metaphor for hopelessly corrupt and depraved. Jack of course is great too, but Jack&#39;s always great.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four and a half out of five.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/5633751468215458818/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/21-chinatown-1974.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/5633751468215458818'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/5633751468215458818'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/21-chinatown-1974.html' title='#21 Chinatown (1974)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-3kT-wNMwgNE/TvFkWM-KL7I/AAAAAAAAALI/3d8VXKhcaQE/s72-c/j.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2821077312295690221</id><published>2011-12-16T11:52:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-17T14:35:51.041-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#22 Some Like It Hot (1959)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-yqsr2bHYkEo/TuuhixcwRwI/AAAAAAAAAK4/cLn4ymQjrrY/s1600/hot.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-yqsr2bHYkEo/TuuhixcwRwI/AAAAAAAAAK4/cLn4ymQjrrY/s1600/hot.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s a period piece. And not just cuz they&#39;re dressed like ladies. HEY-O!&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s 1929 and some cops and robbers are having a high speed &lt;i&gt;Untouchable&lt;/i&gt;s-type shoot out over some bootleg liquor.&lt;br /&gt;Then we go inside a nightclub, where saxophonist Joe and bassist Jerry are playing in a band. They exposit all over each other for a bit while exchanging witty bon mots. The upshot is, they&#39;re poor, but they&#39;ll be getting paid tomorrow. Joe wants to gamble and double their winnings. Jerry thinks that&#39;s crazy, but Joe usually talks him into things. Suddenly, the nightclub gets raided by the cops for selling liquor, and Joe and Jerry barely escape without being arrested. They go to like, a musician&#39;s temp agency and ask for a new job. The only thing available is a job in Florida for three weeks, and they need a saxophonist and a bassist. Great! Except that it&#39;s an all-girl band. If either one of them played the sad trombone, they would surely play it now. Wah. Wah.&lt;br /&gt;Then they go to some parking garage, and stumble upon a bunch of mobsters. Some mobsters have big machine guns while other mobsters have no machine guns. Very quickly, the only mobsters left are the ones with big machine guns. The mobsters see Joe and Jerry hiding and chase after them, but our heroes manage to comically scramble away. They decide they only have one option left.&lt;br /&gt;Comic smash cut to--dudes looking like ladies. Joe and Jerry are in drag, stumbling on heels, walking to the train station. They sarcastically call each other &quot;Josephine&quot; and &quot;Geraldine&quot; and fret about pulling this off. Soon, they&#39;re passed by a sexy blonde with big bazooms and a cute little rear end. Jerry says it&#39;s like she runs on a motor and dames are like a whole different sex! They get on the train with the other girls in the band, and introduce themselves as Josephine and Daphne. Tony Curtis does a double take at Jack Lemmon for using a different name than planned. For some reason, that really tickled me.&lt;br /&gt;So &quot;Daphne&quot; goes to the restroom and sees the hot blonde in the back sneaking some liquor. Her name&#39;s Sugar, and she sings in the band. She&#39;ll even sing to the President if you ask her nice. Sugar says her goal is to bag a rich man once they get to Florida, as a woman should. She complains that in the past she&#39;s always dated regular guys and wound up with the &quot;fuzzy end of the lollipop&quot; which is probably a really clever sex pun I can&#39;t quite figure out.&lt;br /&gt;Once they arrive at the hotel, a rich man named Osgood Fielding III approaches. (Sidebar: I always wanted to be a &quot;III&quot; growing up. It just seemed so regal). But Osgood wants &quot;Daphne&quot;. &amp;nbsp;D&#39;oh! &amp;nbsp;Jerry fights off Osgood&#39;s advances, and slaps him for trying to get fresh, etc. Meanwhile, &quot;Josephine&quot; befriends Sugar and learns of her plans to snag a rich man. The other girls ask Sugar and Daphne and Josephine to join them at the beach, but Josephine begs off.&lt;br /&gt;Cut to the ladies plus Daphne frolicking in the water and Daphne playfully getting the girls to jump up and down and keeps &quot;accidentally&quot; bumping into Sugar. It&#39;s not &lt;i&gt;funny&lt;/i&gt;, per se, but it&#39;s right on the edge of being funny. Jack Lemmon is certainly trying his damndest. Meanwhile Joe hits the beach dressed as a man in a fancy yachting outfit. He manages to get Sugar&#39;s attention and is very rude and dismissive of her while dropping hints that he&#39;s a millionaire and owns a yacht. And he&#39;s totally doing something weird with his voice. Wait..it&#39;s a Cary Grant impression! &amp;nbsp;And I recognized it! This is officially my proudest AFI moment.&lt;br /&gt;So they get back to the hotel room and Osgood calls Daphne asking for a date. Joe answers the phone and Osgood says he&#39;d like to take Daphne out that night on his yacht. Joe says Daphne hates yachts but she&#39;ll be happy to meet him on the shore. He then hangs up and tells Jerry his plan, which is this: He&#39;ll pretend to be a millionaire and take the hot blonde bombshell onto the yacht all night and Jerry will stay in drag and fight off the advances of a horny old man all night. Jerry says, &quot;Oh no, you don&#39;t! &amp;nbsp;I&#39;ll never do that in a million years!&quot;&lt;br /&gt;SMASH CUT.&lt;br /&gt;Jerry&#39;s in drag. Osgood takes him by the arm and leads him to his car.&lt;br /&gt;Joe&#39;s on the yacht with Sugar. Joe tells Sugar he was hurt by a woman once a long time ago, and since then he is essentially asexual. She takes it upon herself to &quot;cure&quot; him through repeated kisses, and crawling on top of him, etc. &quot;Anything yet?&quot; &quot;Nope. Nothing&quot;. This part&#39;s mildly amusing. Not laughing, but smiling.&lt;br /&gt;Sugar&#39;s seduction attempts are intercut with Osgood and Daphne doing the tango on a ballroom floor. Jack Lemmon&#39;s deadpan thousand-yard stare as he&#39;s being dipped and twirled around finally gets me to laugh out loud.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, it&#39;s the next morning. Joe and Sugar kiss each other goodbye, and Joe goes back to his hotel room. Wait a minute! &amp;nbsp;That means...oh, Hays Code, you poor thing. You&#39;re losing it, buddy.&lt;br /&gt;Joe enters and sees Jerry still in drag lying on the bed and humming the tango and looking deliriously happy. Hmm. Jerry says he&#39;s engaged.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Who&#39;s the lucky girl?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Me.&quot; says Jerry.&lt;br /&gt;WHA???? &amp;nbsp;Joe protests that men can&#39;t marry men! &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s just fucking insane. Next will come goats marrying household appliances or something.&lt;br /&gt;Jerry says he plans to marry Osgood and then reveal all for quick annulment and large cash payout. He dances around the room still humming the tango. He reveals the fancy diamond necklace Osgood bought him. &amp;nbsp;Joe says they&#39;ll hock it. Jerry tells Joe that he can&#39;t see Sugar again because she&#39;ll know he&#39;s not rich. Joe says normally he would just hit and quit that, but he feels guilty now. He calls Sugar and tells her that he&#39;s been sent to the other side of the world on business and he can&#39;t see her anymore. She cries because it&#39;s true love or something.&lt;br /&gt;Then the mobsters randomly show up, under the guise of having a &quot;Friends of Italian Opera&quot; convention. Joe and Jerry are all set to leave the hotel, but see the mobsters and go running back into their hotel room and back into drag. But the mobsters recognize them and chase them around comically. Then Jerry and Joe hide under a big table in one of the hotel convention rooms and the mobsters meet there, and different mobsters are mad at the original mobsters for letting two witnesses escape and they shoot the shit out of the original mobsters. Then Jerry and Joe pop back up and run out of the room and the new mobsters chase them.&lt;br /&gt;Jerry calls Osgood and says they&#39;ll get married now, tonight, just meet him at the docks. They run around some more, and Joe and Jerry, still in drag, happen upon Sugar singing with the band. She&#39;s weeping and inconsolable. Joe approaches and tells her not to let any man make her feel this way. He kisses her. She accepts the kiss, and then leans back, shocked. &quot;Josephine!&quot; Joe and Jerry run away, and Sugar struggles with the fact that she was turned on. Ooh, very cutting edge, movie. Well done.&lt;br /&gt;So Joe and Jerry run to the docks where Osgood is waiting in a little motorboat. Jerry introduces Joe as a bridesmaid. Then Sugar comes running up and gets on as well. The mobsters are left in the dust.&lt;br /&gt;Then on the motorboat, Joe takes off his wig and tells Sugar he&#39;s a man. He says he&#39;s not rich, either. Sugar totally goes with all of it, and says she loves getting the fuzzy end of the lollipop after all.&lt;br /&gt;(That&#39;s gotta be a sex pun, right? Let&#39;s workshop this: the &quot;sweet&quot; end of the lollipop is a rich guy, representing the ideal and the &quot;fuzzy&quot; end is a poor guy, representing what you settle for. Hmm. Do you suppose it has something to do with circumcision?)&lt;br /&gt;Then &quot;Daphne&quot; tells Osgood they can&#39;t get married.&lt;br /&gt;Why?&lt;br /&gt;I&#39;m not a natural blonde. I smoke. I drink like a fish. I can&#39;t have children.&lt;br /&gt;Osgood blithely shoots down all these objections with assurances that he loves her still.&lt;br /&gt;Jerry takes off his wig. &quot;I&#39;m a man, dammit.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Osgood doesn&#39;t flinch. &quot;Nobody&#39;s perfect&quot;. Jack Lemmon does a beautiful double take that makes me laugh for probably the third time as credits roll.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Again, we run into my problem with Olden Times comedies, in that they&#39;re not really funny. This was made in 1959, so it wasn&#39;t all that far back, and indeed it wasn&#39;t painfully &lt;i&gt;unfunny&lt;/i&gt;, just not terribly funny either. Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis are fighting tooth and nail through sheer force of will to make me laugh and when it works, it does so despite the painful groaner lines and totally played out scenarios. I mean, there must&#39;ve been &amp;nbsp;a dozen iterations of &quot;What kind of woman are you?&quot; &quot;Oh, if you only knew&quot;, throughout the thing that I guess was hilarious and edgy at the time, but now is just corny. Plus, it has all the cliche moments of the &quot;dudes look like ladies&quot; genre, which is never as funny or as edgy as the movies think it is. Yes, I know, this movie probably invented most of those cliches, but that doesn&#39;t make them any easier to watch now.&lt;br /&gt;However, Lemmon and Curtis are genuinely funny and personable, plus there&#39;s a bellboy I forgot to mention, a teen kid who hits on &quot;Josephine&quot; a few times, and he&#39;s super cheesy and keeps calling Tony Curtis &quot;doll&quot;, and he&#39;s pretty good, too. Marilyn is fine, but definitely not at the caliber of the two guys.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/2821077312295690221/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/22-some-like-it-hot-1959.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2821077312295690221'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2821077312295690221'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/22-some-like-it-hot-1959.html' title='#22 Some Like It Hot (1959)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-yqsr2bHYkEo/TuuhixcwRwI/AAAAAAAAAK4/cLn4ymQjrrY/s72-c/hot.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7791840650471805778</id><published>2011-12-14T19:02:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-15T22:10:21.613-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#23 The Grapes of Wrath (1940)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-U87EMNtjU2U/Tuldg8YIfYI/AAAAAAAAAKo/ma4Jpn1v1IU/s1600/gg.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-U87EMNtjU2U/Tuldg8YIfYI/AAAAAAAAAKo/ma4Jpn1v1IU/s1600/gg.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Better dead than red?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Tom Joad got out of prison. He was put in there for manslaughter. Got seven years, but paroled in four. He hitches a ride home to his family&#39;s farm in Oklahoma. He walks the last few miles, and first encounters an old family-friend, a preacher named Jim Casy. Casy has renounced his religion and thinks that labeling actions as &quot;sinful&quot; and &quot;virtuous&quot; are outdated concepts. There&#39;s only &quot;nice&quot; and &quot;not-so nice&quot;, which sounds kind of weird and vapid, but not when Casy says it.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Casy says he&#39;s broke and homeless. Joad invites him with him to the family&#39;s farm, where at least he&#39;ll get a nice meal and a roof over his head for one night. They arrive at Joad&#39;s house and discover it in a pile on the ground. They find a guy there named Muley, who is hiding out in the hay. He tells the story of how the deed holders of the land came into the fields one day and told everyone to clear out and then promptly bulldozed over everyone&#39;s homes. We see the giant Caterpillars from crazy low angles and in shadows as Muley tells his story in flashback, like they&#39;re evil monsters in a scary movie.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Joad, Muley, and Casy continue onward to Joad&#39;s uncle&#39;s house, where the rest of the family is waiting. Everyone&#39;s thrilled to see Joad&#39;s out of jail, all 11 of them, especially Ma, who tells him that the bulldozers are coming tomorrow to level Uncle John&#39;s house too. The plan is for everyone to go to California and get jobs there. Random Joad family member found a flier that advertised for 800 orange pickers in Southern California, and that&#39;s where they can find their footing and start over. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Why do other people own the deeds to their farms, anyway? Is this an Oklahoma thing?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Anyway, the next morning, they all pack up their big truck and drive onto Route 66, despite getting a marked lack of &amp;nbsp;kicks. Grandpa Joad dies nearly immediately while on the road, so they bury him and press onward, kind of like in the first Chevy Chase vacation movie and just as unfunny.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;On the way, they encounter a campsite where a man tells them he just came &lt;i&gt;from &lt;/i&gt;California, and it&#39;s just a shitty there as it is anyplace else, and he&#39;s heading back to Arkansas where he came from. The Joads don&#39;t believe him, and Tom shows him the flier. The man scoffs and says that everyone has that flier. Tens of thousands of men applied for the job that only needed 800. The Joads are in full-on &quot;kill the messenger&quot; mode, and tell the man to get lost, but they&#39;re privately terrified he&#39;s right.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;After much trials and tribulations, including Grandma Joad&#39;s death as well, the remaining Joad&#39;s arrive in California, where they are promptly told there is no work for them and are directed to the &quot;camps&quot;, which are basically slums. When they arrive, they&#39;re swamped by children begging them for food, but the Joads insist they only have enough for themselves. After they cook their food, the children fight each other for sips of the broth water while the Joads look on this pathetic display, fearing they&#39;re witnessing their future.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Then Tex Richman comes driving up, offering anyone who wants it a job picking fruit. A man asks for how much. Tex Richman says he doesn&#39;t know for sure, but around thirty cents a day. The man wants a contract before he&#39;ll agree to work. He says he&#39;s been burned in the past, and that the Fat Cats hire too many men for the job and wind up paying them far less than promised. Tex says take it or leave it. He calls the man an &quot;agitator&quot; and motions for the sheriff riding with him to arrest the guy. The guy punches out the sheriff, and then runs away. The sheriff shoots at him, and winds up killing a random woman. Joad jumps in and beats the shit out of the sheriff, and the Joads decide they need to leave before more cops show up.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Eventually, they travel north to another camp. They&#39;re offered five cents an hour and lodging in some tiny shack shithole. The Joad men eagerly take the job. After a few days though, the former preacher Casy takes Joad aside late at night and tells him he&#39;s met with some other men and they&#39;ve decided to strike. The men have said the five cent an hour offer is temporary, and as soon as they get more guys, they&#39;ll drop it down to 2.5 cents. He says they need to strike and form some sort of united front, like they&#39;re all, I dunno, merging or joining together in a more perfect...accord, or agreement or amalgamation of similar goals. And maybe those &quot;unions&quot; let&#39;s say, will start out good and pure and save the working man, but then ultimately become just as corrupt as those who came before, leaving no easy answers in the future. &amp;nbsp;Joad says they&#39;re nuts. Last week he had nothing and this week he has a dollar. He&#39;s not going to mess with that. But then the cops descend on them and Casy struggles with them and one of them beats Casy with his nightstick to death and then Joad grapples with him and winds up beating and killing the cop.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;He runs back to the camp. Ma Joad helps him hide. The family decide to leave that night, knowing that the cops will be looking for Joad. They barely get away.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;On the road again, the truck overheats and they stall out and roll down a hill and into another camp. While there, they&#39;re offered work as well as a decent place to stay with indoor plumbing. They&#39;re told Friday nights are when everyone gathers and has a party and dances after a long week of picking fruit. The Joads are awestruck. How is such a thing possible? Who runs this camp? Why, the government does.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;That bitter laughter you hear is the sound of hundreds of thousands of future citizens of New Orleans, pay it no mind.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The Joads make some sort of home for themselves on the government property. but eventually the cops come sniffing around the place, looking for the man who killed one of their own. They&#39;re not allowed to search the camps without a warrant, so they plant interlopers to start a brawl during the Friday night dances. The campers are onto them though, and quietly quell the interlopers without causing any outward signs of fighting. Joad knows that the jig will soon be up, though. He takes Ma aside, and tells her he must go on his own. But he&#39;ll be there in spirit, wherever there are injustices in the world. He&#39;ll be there. Wherever there&#39;s a kitten up a tree, he&#39;ll be there. Wherever there&#39;s a House of Unamerican Activity Committee, he&#39;ll be investigated. And he leaves.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Later, the rest of the Joad men learn of 22 days worth of work up in Fresno, so off the Joads go on their truck once again. Ma Joad says they were almost beat, but she&#39;s hopeful now that one day they&#39;ll be able to stop scraping and starving and have a real life. And that the rich folks will all die one day because they&#39;re no good and their kids are no good but folks like them, the &lt;i&gt;real &lt;/i&gt;people, are the people who will endure.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;It&#39;s more than a little ironic that she pretty much looks like Rush Limbaugh.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Taken just as a story with a strong plot and mood, this is a pretty great flick. They acting is uniformly wonderful, and cinematic shots John Ford takes are haunting and memorable. There&#39;s plenty of artsy stuff going on here, from the decision to have almost no score, to the choice to have many of the scenes take place in the shadows, it&#39;s all very grim and hypnotic. And most of the actors are, to put it kindly, total uggos, which is also depressing. The black and white helps set the mood, too. In fact, I&#39;d go so far as to say that this is the first black and white movie I&#39;ve seen on this list that I&#39;d prefer to not see in color.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;But it&#39;s also a message movie, which I was not expecting at all. (No, I never read it in school, College Boy, I had no idea what it was about except poor people). Specifically, it&#39;s a Pro-Union, Pro-Communist, Pro-Class Warfare, Anti-Religion, Anti-God message movie, that came out just two short years before the start of our nation&#39;s most morally pure and rah rah fun time Capitalist War. There&#39;s simply &lt;i&gt;no way &lt;/i&gt;this movie would be made today, unless it was some indie thing on a shoestring budget that played for one week at the shitty theatre in the big city next to the Gay Adult bookstore.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;I&#39;m really quite surprised it was made even back then, frankly, and the movie certainly doesn&#39;t even pretend to be balanced in its Far Left Agenda, to the point of being a bit off-putting, and I say that as a lefty myself. I have to say, more than any other movie so far, it&#39;s made me reevaluate some of my assumptions about the Olden Times and the movies they made and the values they had back then. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;This movie reminds me of &lt;i&gt;Requiem for a Dream&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;in the sense that I can&#39;t say I really &lt;i&gt;enjoyed&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;it, as it was so unrelentingly brutal, but I feel better for having endured it. Not all art should be pleasurable, I guess.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, the comedy inherent in dudes looking like ladies in &quot;Some Like It Hot&quot;, and then it&#39;s &quot;Chinatown&quot;, Jake.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7791840650471805778/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/23-grapes-of-wrath-1940.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7791840650471805778'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7791840650471805778'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/23-grapes-of-wrath-1940.html' title='#23 The Grapes of Wrath (1940)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-U87EMNtjU2U/Tuldg8YIfYI/AAAAAAAAAKo/ma4Jpn1v1IU/s72-c/gg.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1005476847414643108</id><published>2011-12-10T17:48:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-11T08:34:19.608-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#24 E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-n44QumB6Y5Q/TuQLz4K4dOI/AAAAAAAAAKg/jrk_1YJq5Zw/s1600/et.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-n44QumB6Y5Q/TuQLz4K4dOI/AAAAAAAAAKg/jrk_1YJq5Zw/s1600/et.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Oh...yeah. Still awesome. Phew!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;So an alien spaceship lands on earth, right? And all the Melmacian aliens start scooting around, picking up dirt samples and what not. But then the bad guys come riding in, in their giant metal gas guzzling machines called &quot;cars&quot; and start chasing the aliens! &amp;nbsp;The Man With The Keys pursues on foot. The aliens get on their ship and blast off...but leave one behind.&lt;br /&gt;Mike&#39;s hanging out with with friends at the house. Elliot and Gertie are there, too. And Mary, the mom. They order a pizza and when Elliott goes out to get it from the guy, he hears a strange noise in the shed. He throws in a baseball...and it comes rolling back out.&lt;br /&gt;Everyone thinks it&#39;s a coyote. &lt;i&gt;(But they&#39;re so wrong, you guys!!)&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Later, Elliott goes lurking out into the forest nearby his house, looking around. He deposits little piles of&amp;nbsp;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: black;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #999999;&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Reese&#39;s&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Pieces&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;nbsp;to use as bait. He stumbles into some tall grass...and sees the alien! &amp;nbsp;They both scream. Elliott goes running back home, where he tells his mom and big brother Mike, but they won&#39;t believe him. Stupid old people.&lt;br /&gt;Maybe it was an alligator in the sewer.&lt;br /&gt;Alligators in the sewer.&lt;br /&gt;Maybe it was a goblin or a leprechaun.&lt;br /&gt;It was nothing like that, penis breath!&lt;br /&gt;HA HA! &amp;nbsp;Stupid Mike! &amp;nbsp;(Seriously, why didn&#39;t &quot;penis breath&quot; catch on? So much more clinical and nasty than &quot;cock sucker&quot;).&lt;br /&gt;Elliott says he can&#39;t tell Dad because he&#39;s in Mexico and Mom cries and Mike says stupid Elliott and everyone goes to bed.&lt;br /&gt;But then Elliott sneaks out later. Sits on a lounge chair outside the shed with a flashlight, and waits. Eventually, the alien emerges. It approaches Elliott. Elliott&#39;s terrified, can&#39;t speak or scream.&lt;br /&gt;But it&#39;s okay because he&#39;s friendly! Phew! He holds out his hand, and drops some&amp;nbsp;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: black;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #999999;&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Reese&#39;s&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Pieces&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;nbsp;on Elliot&#39;s chair.&lt;br /&gt;Elliott uses the&amp;nbsp;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: black;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #999999;&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Reese&#39;s&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;Pieces&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: black; color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: x-small; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;to lure ET into the house.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, he fakes sick by putting his thermometer next to his lamp and then everyone leaves the house. He shows ET all his cool toys, shows him how Boba Fett fights Han Solo, the fish, the peanut bank, the trains. They&#39;re both connected, now.&lt;br /&gt;Mike comes home from school.&lt;br /&gt;I have to show you something. Remember, I have absolute power. Say it!&lt;br /&gt;Don&#39;t push it, Elliott.&lt;br /&gt;Mike does a Yoda voice and turns around and sees ET. Then Gertie walks in. She screams. ET screams. Elliott shuffles them all off into the closet. It&#39;s so funny! Mom doesn&#39;t see or hear anything. Phew!&lt;br /&gt;The three kids stare with total wide-eyed wonder. Why didn&#39;t I ever find an alien growing up? &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s just not fair.&lt;br /&gt;They ask ET where he&#39;s from, and he makes Elliott&#39;s models float in the air. He points out the window. Far off into the sky. The tip of his finger lights up. He makes Gertie&#39;s flowers bloom anew.&lt;br /&gt;The next day Elliott goes to school while ET roams around the house. He drinks beer. Elliott gets drunk. He watches a movie. Elliott frees the frogs, stands on the fat kid and kisses the girl. ET discovers my Speak N Spell. I mean, Elliott&#39;s Speak N Spell. He needs to phone home.&lt;br /&gt;Then it&#39;s Halloween, and the kids sneak ET out of the house as a ghost. Elliott and ET go off into the forest with equipment.&lt;br /&gt;He have to get off and walk now, the path&#39;s too bumpy.&lt;br /&gt;No it&#39;s not. ET makes Elliott and the bike fly. HOLY CRAP. They land in a meadow and ET goes about setting up his equipment. But he&#39;s looking bad, like he&#39;s getting sick.&lt;br /&gt;Eventually, mom sits at home getting angrier and angrier. She goes out searching for her kids, but finds only Mike and Gertie.&lt;br /&gt;By the next morning, the police are involved, but Elliott shows up, looking like crap. He begs Mike to find and help ET. Mike rides off into the forest and eventually finds the communication device...and then ET; gray and dying on the ground.&lt;br /&gt;OH NO!&lt;br /&gt;Mike cries out, not even sure how to touch him. He gets him home, and they reveal ET to Mom. She wants everyone out of the house. But just then, the men in masks show up, with plastic and wires and tubes and tests.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;This is my house!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Elliott and ET lay sick and dying in matching hospital beds. The scientists question Gertie and Mike. So Elliott knows what it knows? No, Elliott feels what it feels.&lt;br /&gt;The Man With The Keys begs Elliott to tell him how to help ET. Elliott says leave him be. But soon the connection between ET and Elliott breaks. Elliott starts to feel better. They pull him out of the room, as ET flatlines.&lt;br /&gt;NO! &amp;nbsp;ET! &amp;nbsp;LEAVE HIM ALONE! &lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;(And in 1982, it&#39;s at this point that my grandmother hands me some wadded up tissues from her purse and hisses at me, &quot;get a hold of yourself, it&#39;s just a movie!&quot;)&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;There&#39;s nothing they can do. ET&#39;s dead. Elliott stands over his body, which is in a weird cryogenic-type box thing. He says his final goodbyes, and closes the lid, not noticing ET&#39;s huge red heart lights up right before the lid closed.&lt;br /&gt;WHAT?&lt;br /&gt;HE&#39;S ALIVE!!!&lt;br /&gt;Elliott sees Gertie&#39;s flowers bloom again. He runs back to ET. He sees what we already saw! &amp;nbsp;THIS IS SO AWESOME.&lt;br /&gt;He tells ET to be quiet, just a minute. He runs out and tells Mike. Mike jumps and hits his head. The audience laughs with intense release. I remember the audience specifically laughing there. We were sitting up right, probably the second row. It had been sold out. I remember everything.&lt;br /&gt;Mike and Elliott sneak onto the van in suits while the men load ET. They take off. The men pursue.&lt;br /&gt;Mom and Gertie get in the car.&lt;br /&gt;They drive around into the van to the edge of the forest. Mike&#39;s friends meet them with their bikes. The bad men keep chasing.&lt;br /&gt;Everyone pedals like crazy, but the men make a roadblock, blocking the way, holding their walkie-talkies threateningly.&lt;br /&gt;But then...yes, then...ET makes them all fly. They sail over the heads of the bad guys and land safely in the forest. Mom and Gertie drive up, as the spaceship lands.&lt;br /&gt;ET turns back to them, staring. He tells Gertie to be good.&lt;br /&gt;And his finger glows. He point&#39;s to Elliott&#39;s heart. &quot;I&#39;ll be right here&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;And then he leaves, no doubt late for a congressional session with Senator Palpatine, and there&#39;s a rainbow in the sky.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Yes, it&#39;s manipulative. Yes, it&#39;s schmaltzy. That ET apparently has to die and resurrect in order to communicate with his homeworld is ridiculously absurd. Yes, it&#39;s perhaps sometime a reader of this blog might assume I&#39;d viciously mock. But it damn sure worked for me then, and it even worked for me now. I believe I&#39;ve said before how Spielberg is a masterful, shameless manipulator, but does it in such an insidious way that the viewer becomes a Stockholm victim. &amp;nbsp;You know you&#39;re being shamelessly manipulated, by the beauty and majesty off it is such that you just don&#39;t care.&amp;nbsp;Thank you almost killing and then not killing ET, Mr. Spielberg! &amp;nbsp;You&#39;re so kind!&amp;nbsp;I imagine it&#39;s like the old rich man who knows the beautiful young woman isn&#39;t flirting with him because she finds him attractive but he finds the experience so pleasurable that he doesn&#39;t care.&lt;br /&gt;This movie is expertly crafted, with no slow points or unnecessary scenes. We&#39;re put right into the thick of things immediately, and it perfectly captures the wonder and joy of childhood, and how every damn kid in the world would give their very last Atari Cartridge and GI Joe to be in Elliott&#39;s shoes. The scenic shots are great, the kid actors are utterly believable. Dee Wallace was pretty great, too. Why wasn&#39;t she in more stuff?&lt;br /&gt;Anyways, though Spielberg&#39;s star may have gotten less bright in recent years, there&#39;s no denying his early genius. And this is probably his best. No, I haven&#39;t seen &lt;i&gt;Schindler&#39;s List &lt;/i&gt;yet. It&#39;s coming.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;The Grapes of Wrath&quot; and then then Tootsie&#39;s grandmothers in &quot;Some Like It Hot&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1005476847414643108/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/24-et-extra-terrestrial-1982.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1005476847414643108'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1005476847414643108'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/24-et-extra-terrestrial-1982.html' title='#24 E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-n44QumB6Y5Q/TuQLz4K4dOI/AAAAAAAAAKg/jrk_1YJq5Zw/s72-c/et.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1489614626870556766</id><published>2011-12-09T12:23:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-09T13:31:21.291-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#25 To Kill a Mockingbird</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-1drOz-hSpBA/TuJuIbNv90I/AAAAAAAAAKY/M6rQC1PVq9s/s1600/mock.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-1drOz-hSpBA/TuJuIbNv90I/AAAAAAAAAKY/M6rQC1PVq9s/s1600/mock.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Racism. It&#39;s bad. So, so bad.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s the 1930&#39;s in Maycomb, Alabama. Scout Finch is a young tomboy who lives with her brother Jem, and father Atticus. Atticus Finch lives a life of quiet dignity that comes with being the world&#39;s most perfect human. He&#39;s a lawyer who accepts food as payment for his services, like a pilgrim or Eskimo or something. He tells his children to never fight, under any circumstances. He abhors guns, but is still the best shot in town, even better than the sheriff. He&#39;ll put down a rabid dog for you, sheriff. All you have to do is ask. He&#39;s soft-spoken, wise, fair, non-judgmental, and won&#39;t even glare if you literally spit on him. Jesus once met Atticus and was like, &quot;I&#39;m out&quot;, before getting on His dinosaur and riding away.&lt;br /&gt;So one day, Atticus goes off to work, and his children Scout and Jem play in the trees and dig wells and construct shelters and learn to control fire. They encounter a third child, a boy named Dill, who visits Maycomb in the summertime. Since his name is as equally stupid as theirs, they all become fast friends. Scout and Jem tell Dill all about Boo Radley, the mysterious neighbor who is locked up inside all day by his parents on account of being crazy and violent. They dare each other to run up to his front door and touch it before running away, and other childish pranks. &lt;i&gt;(In my neighborhood, there was an old man whose driveway was on a hill and we would ride our bikes up his driveway and back down again and he would yell at us and tell us to get off his property, so it became a game to see who could quietly carry our bikes up the hill and get on them before the inevitable discovery, whereupon he would hurl open his living room window and scream at us to get out, as we&#39;d jump on our bikes and pedal like crazy down the hill, laughing like maniacs. It was awesome. Hey...we were kind of assholes, weren&#39;t we?) &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, the DA asks Atticus to defend the negro Tom Robinson. Tom was accused of assault and attempted rape of a white woman named Mayella Ewell. Atticus agrees to take the case, and is promptly made a pariah in the town. Scout fights with boys in school who call Atticus a nasty racial epithet, and Atticus tells Scout she&#39;s wrong to fight, no matter what.&lt;br /&gt;Before the trial, Atticus goes to the courthouse and sits vigil outside the jail. When a lynching party of goons, led by Mayella&#39;s father Bob, show up, Atticus tells them to turn around and go home. They&#39;re about to beat the hell out of Atticus when Scout, Jem, and Dill show up and shame the would-be lynchers into going home with their cherubic innocence.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, the trial begins. Ooh, movie trials are usually juicy. Let&#39;s see how Atticus fucks that up. Atticus first questions Bob, who claimed to have discovered and witnessed Tom beating and attempting to rape Mayella. Atticus first ascertains that Mayella&#39;s bruise was on her right eye, which means...wait for it...the assailant was left handed. Even though only 10% of the actual population is left-handed, as we know, a good 80-85% of movie characters are left handed, provided a trial of some sort is involved. Basically, if you want to learn how to get away with any crime, become ambidextrous. Trust me, it will somehow work out for you. So yes, Bob is left handed, just like the assailant would have to be, and Tom not only is right-handed, but injured his left hand in a cotton gin and can&#39;t use it at all. When Mayella is questioned about this, she dissolves into screeching and baseless accusations.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Tom tells his story. He passed by Mayella&#39;s every day on his way to work. She would always have some chore for him. He helped her because he felt sorry for her.&lt;br /&gt;At this, the entire courtroom gasps in disbelief and Atticus knows he&#39;s sunk.&lt;br /&gt;Then one time, she tried to kiss him, but her father caught her and then beat her up.&lt;br /&gt;Atticus gives his labored, lengthy, and deliberate closing arguments that ends with him basically saying &quot;don&#39;t be racist&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;To which the jury responds, &quot;this is Alabama in the 1930&#39;s. What do you want from us? Guilty.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;So, everyone goes home and Atticus is sad but vows to appeal, and Scout says, &quot;Atticus, will you please lecture me for like the thirtieth time about how racism is bad?&quot; and Atticus gladly does so. Then they all take a nap. I think this happens in real time.&lt;br /&gt;Then Atticus learns that Tom was killed trying to escape is despondent.&lt;br /&gt;Then Scout and Jem go trick-or-treating for Halloween, and Bob Ewell attacks them with a knife, as vengeance for Atticus humiliating him at the trial. Scout&#39;s knocked down, and Jem&#39;s arm is broken, but then they&#39;re saved by a Mysterious Man who winds up fighting and then killing Bob.&lt;br /&gt;Later, Doc Old Windmill is finishing up putting a cast on Jem, and the sheriff tells Atticus that he&#39;s going to report that Bob fell on his knife. Which is weird, because it was self defense, but whatever. The sheriff says he doesn&#39;t want to get Boo Radley in trouble.&lt;br /&gt;Yep, it was Boo who saved the kids. Turns out Boo was a nice guy after all, and the stories about him were based on ignorance and prejudice by people who didn&#39;t really know him. Scout wonders if the way they treated Boo could be a metaphor for the way people treated black people, but Jem tells her that&#39;s way too on the nose and obvious.&lt;br /&gt;And then I think they take another nap.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I haven&#39;t read the book since tenth grade. I remember liking it, but now I&#39;m afraid to go back to it. I couldn&#39;t believe how dry and stale this movie was. Every scene is dragged out interminably, the trial in particular was like watching an actual trial in real time, and that is most certainly not a compliment. Of course, the message was probably somewhat radical in 1962, and after sitting through many shucking and jiving black characters in movies on this list, it&#39;s nice to see some sort of atonement for that, but man.
