So much talking about nothing. So much of Atticus patiently explaining the world to Scout, even though we the audience are not actually little girls and don&#39;t need to sit through all that. There&#39;s also plenty of scenes with the kids just fucking around, that don&#39;t advance the plot at all. Stuff like that works in novels, but needs to be streamlined for movies.&lt;br /&gt;On the positive side, I&#39;ll say that the acting was very good, particularly the girl who played Scout and Gregory Peck. And I quite liked the scene where the kids shame the bad guys into leaving Tom alone and the scene where Scout and Jem talk about their dead mother while Atticus overhears them. It&#39;s also filmed well, with a well-established sense of place and time. &amp;nbsp;But most of this movie is worse than the actual South in 1930.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, pure five star joy with &quot;E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial&quot;, and then, &quot;The Grapes of Wrath&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1489614626870556766/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/25-to-kill-mockingbird.html#comment-form' title='1 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1489614626870556766'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1489614626870556766'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/25-to-kill-mockingbird.html' title='#25 To Kill a Mockingbird'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-1drOz-hSpBA/TuJuIbNv90I/AAAAAAAAAKY/M6rQC1PVq9s/s72-c/mock.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2369315950533800504</id><published>2011-12-04T11:05:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-12-05T15:48:01.292-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#26 Mr. Smith Goes to Washington (1939)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-3l_O-d_dPW4/Tt0eBzcu7zI/AAAAAAAAAKQ/vH9M_FmseAg/s1600/images.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-3l_O-d_dPW4/Tt0eBzcu7zI/AAAAAAAAAKQ/vH9M_FmseAg/s1600/images.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;News comes out that the U.S. Senator of...a state...has died. A flurry of phone calls between other senators and the mystery state&#39;s governor ensue. Big corporate guy Jim Taylor tells the governor to appoint his favorite stoolie, but the people of the state want a populist reformer. The governor of the state tries to stand up to Taylor, but Taylor reminds him they&#39;re all in his pocket. Bwa ha ha. Then the governor and the other Senator, Joseph Paine, and talk about the main plot of the movie, even though they should both know it already. The upshot: Taylor wants the government to pay to build a dam on his property called Willow Creek and pocket all the excess money the job will cost and then eventually wind up selling the land to the government for far less than it&#39;s worth. They previously had enough votes to pull this off, but with the Senator dying, they need a new guy in there.&lt;br /&gt;The governor&#39;s kids are all horrible child actors, and they squawk at their dad, encouraging him to appoint a &quot;Boy Ranger&quot; leader (like Boy Scout, but fake), Jefferson Smith, as the new senator. Jeff Smith just saved a bunch of kittens from a fire or something and he&#39;s a local hero. They say he&#39;s the most American man in the whole wide world, and he knows everything about American trivia and history. The governor thinks that his constituents will eat that up, &lt;i&gt;and &lt;/i&gt;the naive Smith will still vote how the others want him to.&lt;br /&gt;So Mr. Smith gets the job and goes to...wait for it...Washington. He&#39;s super naive and gosh-shucky and he tells Sen. Paine that his father used to work for him and he knows he&#39;s a super great guy and totally not corrupt and stuff. Then some staffers pick him up at the train station in DC and tell him to go to his office, but Smith is so in awe of DC that he goes on a tour of the Capitol Building, Lincoln Memorial, Washington Monument, etc and shows up five hours late. What a dick.&lt;br /&gt;So he meets his staff; some guy and also a pretty lady named Claudette Saunders. Saunders is none-too impressed with Smith&#39;s golly-gee attitude and says she didn&#39;t come to DC to &quot;carry bibs for an infant with little flags in his fists&quot;. Heh. Good one, Saunders.&lt;br /&gt;So then Mr. Smith goes to Congress and walks into the floor of the Senate and is totally blown away by how awesome it all is. Yeah, it would be pretty awesome, I must admit.&lt;br /&gt;The press surround him and ask him what he plans to do as Senator, what changes would he like in his state. Smith stutters for a bit in that imitable Jimmy Stewart way, then says he&#39;d like to build a national park for his Boy Rangers. And how much would that cost? &amp;nbsp;Nothing! We&#39;d just borrow the money from the government and the boys would pay it back week after week, with a dime here and a nickel there.&lt;br /&gt;Then red, white, and blue syrup begins oozing from Smith&#39;s every pore and the ghost of George Washington starts frenching him and the press applauds.&lt;br /&gt;Okay, not really. But that&#39;s still a more likely scenario than the Boy Rangers paying back the government with nickels and dimes.&lt;br /&gt;So the press gets him to pose for silly photos and then misquotes him and embarrasses him and basically point out that he&#39;s a minnow in a sea of sharks. So when the papers come out the next morning, Smith goes running around town punching out reporters. Which was...totally acceptable for a Senator to do in the 30&#39;s?&lt;br /&gt;(BTW, I don&#39;t know when &quot;senator&quot; is supposed to be capitalized and when it&#39;s not. Please forgive me).&lt;br /&gt;Smith goes to his gal Saunders and says he&#39;d like help in drafting a bill to loan the money to the Boy Rangers. He says he wants to skip dinner and get it done tonight. Saunders patronizingly asks Smith if he knows what goes into making a bill a law. He doesn&#39;t.&lt;br /&gt;So she tells him to imagine that she&#39;s a bill. Yes, only a bill. And she&#39;s sitting there on Capitol Hill.&lt;br /&gt;She explains about committees and subcommittees and that the House and Senate need to reconcile the bills and have them voted on again and by the time she&#39;s done, he&#39;s completely demoralized. She thinks she&#39;s talked him out of it, but instead he&#39;s like, so we skip dinner then, right?&lt;br /&gt;And just like that, she&#39;s smitten.&lt;br /&gt;So the first draft of the bill is done, and Smith presents it on the floor of the Senate and the land he wants to build on is right next to...Willow Creek! &amp;nbsp;Paine says that they&#39;re already building a dam there, but Smith says he&#39;s confused. He&#39;s been there, and there&#39;s no need for a dam, so Paine and a couple other corrupt senators have a private meeting with Smith and Taylor where Taylor basically tells him to do what he says and he&#39;ll have a long, prosperous life in the Senate, but if he disobeys, Taylor will &quot;break him&quot;. Smith is heartbroken to learn that Paine is bought and paid for.&lt;br /&gt;The next day in the Senate, Paine stands up and says that unfortunately, he&#39;s discovered evidence that Smith owns Willow Creek, and he was trying to get the government to buy it and give it to the Boy Rangers so he could make a profit! Smith&#39;s flabbergasted. Paine unloads a pile of evidence, including contracts signed by Smith when he supposedly bought the land and when Smith denies the signatures are his, Paine produces signature experts that claim otherwise. All the while, Taylor smokes his cigars and goes bwa ha ha in the background and Paine starts to feel conflicted.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Smith is disillusioned and heart broken and Saunders comforts him with her womanly sympathy.&lt;br /&gt;About a week later, the Senate reconvenes to vote to expel Smith. But Smith is rejuvenated by Saunders&#39; faith in him, and vows to fight back. He&#39;s given the chance to speak in his own defense before his expulsion vote and he begs the Senate to give him a week to find evidence to prove his innocence. The President of the Senate (aka the Vice President of the U.S.) denies him, and so Smith decides to refuse to yield the floor. As long as he&#39;s got the floor, no vote can take place. Yes, it&#39;s a filibuster. Smith accuses Paine and others of being in Taylor&#39;s back pocket and exposes the dam building scheme, and from up in the galley, pretty Saunders cheers him on. Paine affects great outrage and says he refuses to stand for this and walks out. Soon, all the rest of the senators follow him. Then Saunders signals Smith to look at rule no 53 in his Being a Senator for Dummies handbook, and Rule 53 states that if senators walk out, those remaining can vote to compel the others to return. Since Smith is the only one remaining, it&#39;s an easy vote. The others are compelled to return.&lt;br /&gt;The media goes wild, but since Taylor/Murdoch owns the media in his state, they&#39;re all instructed to paint the story as if Smith is a guilty man desperately trying to stay out of trouble, and none of his accusations about Taylor are being reported. They also explain the filibuster rules: The speaker can&#39;t sit. The speaker can&#39;t stop talking. The senators compelled to stay can&#39;t leave the room. Man, I&#39;d love to see this shit now in real life. Could you imagine?! &amp;nbsp;So much fun! Saunders encourages Smith to read aloud from the Constitution, which he does. Saunders finds out that no one is Smith&#39;s state is getting the real news, so she dispatches the Boy Rangers to print their own flyers and start passing them around all over the state. This state must be Rhode Island or Delaware, because otherwise this doesn&#39;t seem like a feasible plan. At Pro-Paine rallies, the Boy Rangers try to rush the stage and speak the truth, but are dragged out by Taylor&#39;s goons. A bunch of Boy Rangers in a go cart are throwing flyers out into the wind in town, and are forcibly run off the road by a carload of Taylor guys! Yeesh.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Smith keeps talking. This goes on for 27 hours. Smith&#39;s voice his raw and almost gone. He speaks about truth, justice and the something something something. The other senators are actually listening, now. Some of them wonder why he&#39;s fighting so hard if he&#39;s guilty. Paine says either they believe this new guy or him! They fall in line, but seem to do so reluctantly.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Paine interrupts Smith to bring in what he says are 50,000 telegrams from the people of &quot;my state&quot; (sigh. Just name the fucking state already. What is this, &lt;i&gt;The Simpsons?&lt;/i&gt;) urging Smith to give up. Smith reads a couple and his face crumples in defeat. But then he sees Saunders smiling at him from up in the galley, and he straightens up, and points his finger at a guilty-looking Paine and correctly guesses that the people in &quot;my state&quot; are not getting the full story. And he&#39;ll press on no matter what, until they do.&lt;br /&gt;Then he passes out.&lt;br /&gt;Several senators rush to his aide while Saunders screams and Paine backs out of the room. A senator says he&#39;s all right, he&#39;s just passed out, but then a gunshot goes off. Everyone runs towards it to discover Paine with a gun fighting of a page who&#39;s struggling with him. They wrestle the gun from Paine&#39;s hands and he staggers out into the Senate floor and screams that Smith is innocent confesses to everything.&lt;br /&gt;And then we cut to black.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;No, really. We cut to black right there. No joyful triumphant reunion between Smith and Saunders, no Taylor getting arrested, nothing. We don&#39;t even see Smith regain consciousness. Super strange, but I liked it. In fact, working backwards, the whole last half hour or so, with the filibuster standoff was pretty damn great. Suspenseful and without too much sentiment and really fun to watch and imagine what a real-life scenario like that would be like. I&#39;m quite the political junkie myself, so love political thrillers where everyone is scheming and duplicitous, in real life and in the movies. It&#39;s always like heroin to me. I just want more and more! And this version delivered at the end, but we took a long time getting there. The build up is slow, and Smith&#39;s naivete was at times too ridiculous to be believed. It was also a bit inconsistent. He&#39;s spoken of as a political buff who knows American history inside and out and yet he has no idea how a bill becomes a law. It was also annoying that the words &quot;democrat&quot; or &quot;republican&quot; never passed anyone&#39;s lips, which creates an artificial tone to the whole thing, kind of like with the made-up football teams in &lt;i&gt;Any Given Sunday. &lt;/i&gt;I get that the movie didn&#39;t want to be partisan, but they could&#39;ve resolved that by making the &quot;bad&quot; senators belong to both parties. And don&#39;t get me started on them refusing to name the state Smith is from. Why? What possible reason did they have for that? Is was just clunky and dumb.&lt;br /&gt;Jimmy Stewart and Jean Arthur (Saunders) were both very good in their roles, as was the guy playing Paine, but many of the supporting characters where still doing the Olden Times acting shtick, with the funny voices and the stylized mannerisms. Not sure why Capra would let them get away with that.&lt;br /&gt;In short, there&#39;s a lot to bitch about, but man, that last half hour was dynamite. This is my second Capra film, but already I can see he&#39;s a master manipulator of emotion just like Spielberg. And I mean that as a total compliment.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, is racism good or bad? Find out, with &quot;To Kill a Mockingbird&quot;, and then speaking of blatant manipulation, it&#39;s &quot;E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial&quot;. I hope I manage not to cry this time.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/2369315950533800504/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/26-mr-smith-goes-to-washington-1939.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2369315950533800504'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2369315950533800504'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/12/26-mr-smith-goes-to-washington-1939.html' title='#26 Mr. Smith Goes to Washington (1939)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-3l_O-d_dPW4/Tt0eBzcu7zI/AAAAAAAAAKQ/vH9M_FmseAg/s72-c/images.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8275837113181672557</id><published>2011-11-29T01:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-29T10:03:26.978-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#27 High Noon (1952)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Uz8HEXVPoSA/TtKop6IvdhI/AAAAAAAAAJ4/vS9NSOnwLbA/s1600/images.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Uz8HEXVPoSA/TtKop6IvdhI/AAAAAAAAAJ4/vS9NSOnwLbA/s1600/images.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s the Way Back Olden Times, like 1853 or so, and the marshall of the little town of Hadleyville, Will Kane, is to be married to his lovely long-time gal Amy. Amy is a pacifist and a Quaker and a helluva dancer when she&#39;s acting with Fred Astaire. They get married in the Court House and around about a dozen or so well-wishers, and then they board their horse and wagon, headed off to their honeymoon and then a new life in a new town. Kane feels weird about turning in his badge because the new marshall isn&#39;t due to arrive until tomorrow, but his deputy Harvey Pell (Lloyd Bridges, looking reasonably young) will hold down the fort until then. Harvey says, &quot;I&#39;m sure we&#39;ll all be just fine without you until tomorrow&quot; and everybody laughs and laughs because movies haven&#39;t been invented yet, and they don&#39;t know they&#39;re not supposed to say shit like that.&lt;br /&gt;But then a dude comes running up and says he&#39;s got bad news. The dastardly villain, Frank Miller, just got out of prison due to some technicality thanks to his lawyers Johnnie Cochran and Gloria Allred, and is coming into town on the noon train. His three sidekick henchman are at the train station right now, waiting for him to arrive. They all stare at the clock. It&#39;s 10:40. Only eighty minutes until the train arrives.&lt;br /&gt;Everyone stares at Kane. Harvey tells him to leave right now, as fast as he can. Kane gets on his horse and goes &quot;hi-ya&quot; or whatever you do with the lasso thingie and the wagon takes off.&lt;br /&gt;Then we cut to the three henchman at the station, looking sinister and evil.&lt;br /&gt;But Kane doesn&#39;t get too far when he pulls on the lasso thingie and tells the horses to whoa. He tells Amy he was to go back and fight Frank. He&#39;s the one who arrested Frank and Frank wants revenge. Amy says she&#39;s a pacifist and a Quaker and she&#39;s against guns and fighting and loves PETA and communist China. She says she&#39;ll leave without him if goes back, but he goes back anyway.&lt;br /&gt;He then tries to get his deputy and round up a posse. One dude says he&#39;ll join him, and then runs home to get his guns. Then Kane goes wandering around the town. He goes to a saloon and asks for help, but the bartender says he&#39;s got &quot;a lot of nerve&quot; asking such a thing because he knows that half the people in the bar are on Frank&#39;s side.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, deputy Harvey goes to his girlfriend&#39;s house. His girlfriend is a Mexican woman named Helen Ramirez who used to date Kane and before that dated Frank Miller. When she hears Frank is coming back, she packs up all her shit and says she&#39;s taking the next train out of town. She asks Harvey to go with her, but he won&#39;t. Then Kane shows up to warn her about Frank coming back, and she says she already knows and then it turns out Amy followed Kane to Helen&#39;s house and she begs Kane again to come with her and he says no and they look at the clock and there&#39;s about an hour now.&lt;br /&gt;Hey, this is in real time, isn&#39;t it? Like &lt;i&gt;Nick of Time&lt;/i&gt;, with Johnny Depp, and probably other movies.&lt;br /&gt;So then Kane goes to his friend&#39;s house and his friend sees him walking up and he goes and hides and tells his wife to say he&#39;s not home, which she does. His friend is Harry Morgan aka Colonel Potter. He still looks kinda old.&lt;br /&gt;So then Kane goes to the church and interrupts the sermon and asks people to join him and some are sympathetic but tell him that if he just leaves, Frank will probably not do anything bad. And others say that Frank&#39;s mad at &lt;i&gt;him&lt;/i&gt;, not them, so why should they help?&lt;br /&gt;This is a town full of assholes.&lt;br /&gt;Then Amy visits Helen and tries to get her to talk to Kane, but Helen says Kane won&#39;t listen to her and then they both decide to leave on the train together. It&#39;s like &lt;i&gt;Thelma and Louise&lt;/i&gt;, but uninteresting.&lt;br /&gt;Then Harvey says he&#39;s angry at Kane for not making him the new marshall and outsourcing the job and then he tries to force Kane onto a horse out of town. They get into a fistfight and Kane wins.&lt;br /&gt;The dude from the beginning who volunteered to be part of the posse comes back and when Kane breaks it to him that no one else will be joining them, he says &quot;ah...well..this is awkward&quot;, and then bolts. It&#39;s pretty funny.&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s now about three minutes to noon. The train whistle can be heard in the distance.&lt;br /&gt;Close ups of all the main characters, looking apprehensive.&lt;br /&gt;The train stops, and Helen and Amy get on, while evil Frank Miller gets off.&lt;br /&gt;One of his men hands him a gun. They go stomping off, looking for trouble.&lt;br /&gt;And they just found it.&lt;br /&gt;(I totally felt like an 80&#39;s action movie guy right then. That was fun!)&lt;br /&gt;They&#39;re marching through the main street of town and suddenly Kane whips around the corner from behind them, and shoots one of the dudes. He falls over dead.&lt;br /&gt;On the train, Amy hears the gunshot and feels bad for being the world&#39;s least supportive wife, and gets off the train.&lt;br /&gt;The men chase Kane through town, firing shot after shot. Kane hides in a barn and they light it on fire,. Kane pokes his head out, and shoots another henchman. Two down, two to go. Inside the barn, Kane sets free a whole bunch of horses, and rides one as well. They all bust out of the barn, but Frank gets one good shot off and hits Kane in the arm. Kane goes down and runs off into hiding.&lt;br /&gt;Amy runs into Kane&#39;s office, unseen.&lt;br /&gt;Frank and the last henchman &amp;nbsp;are behind a house, shooting at Kane. One of them backs up along the side of a building, in full view of a window. He reloads his gun, then aims at Kane, who doesn&#39;t see him.&lt;br /&gt;BANG!&lt;br /&gt;Nope, it&#39;s not the henchman shooting Kane, it&#39;s Amy shooting the henchman! Go, Amy! Next up, fur coats and veal!&lt;br /&gt;Then Frank runs into the office and grabs Amy. He takes her outside and demands Kane give up or he&#39;ll shoot her.&lt;br /&gt;Kane comes out of hiding and says he&#39;ll give up, just don&#39;t kill the girl. Suddenly, Amy attacks Frank, scratching at his face. He pushes her away, giving Kane his clean shot. Bang. Frank&#39;s dead, baby. Frank&#39;s dead.&lt;br /&gt;Suddenly, the whole town comes out of hiding, patting Kane on the back, all smiles. Kane throws his badge down on the ground in disgust, glares at them all, then puts his arm around his woman, and gets on a wagon and rides away.&lt;br /&gt;OH SNAP, TOWN! &lt;br /&gt;You just got nooned. &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;High&lt;/i&gt; nooned.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Not bad. The real-time aspect added some suspense to things, and the last twenty minutes or so were pretty great. There was some stalling, though, even at 87 minutes, and some padding and unnecessary scenes. But it was was still fun to see Kane get increasingly more frustrated and panicked as more and more of the town turned their backs on him. Gary Cooper did a great job in the role, fully embodying the character of a men who values dignity and standing up and doing the right thing no matter the consequences. Interestingly, there are many who see the movie as an allegory for the McCarthy Hearings, but I didn&#39;t see that at all. I mean, who is Frank supposed to represent? The American government, and the cowardly townspeople are the one who named names, and Gary Cooper is the brave one who doesn&#39;t?&lt;br /&gt;Okay...but then you could pretty much stretch anything if you&#39;re going to be that vague about it. It&#39;s like a movie symbolism Rorschach Test.&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, noted douche John Wayne hated the movie and called it &quot;unamerican&quot; because the marshall had the nerve to ask people to help him fight and because his woman saved him in the end. That right there is enough to make me like this movie.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Mr. Smith Goes to Washington&quot;, and then it&#39;s 10th Grade English all over again with, &quot;To Kill a Mockingbird&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8275837113181672557/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/27-high-noon-1952.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8275837113181672557'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8275837113181672557'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/27-high-noon-1952.html' title='#27 High Noon (1952)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Uz8HEXVPoSA/TtKop6IvdhI/AAAAAAAAAJ4/vS9NSOnwLbA/s72-c/images.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7932465137478934038</id><published>2011-11-27T19:05:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-27T21:04:55.628-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#28 All About Eve (1950)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--DrQI97iuD8/TtL6b8sFs3I/AAAAAAAAAKA/60cFjVm6uh4/s1600/eve.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--DrQI97iuD8/TtL6b8sFs3I/AAAAAAAAAKA/60cFjVm6uh4/s1600/eve.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So, in LA, there&#39;s a cemetery called Hollywood Forever, where they play old movies. &amp;nbsp;Every Saturday night, people are encouraged to stand in line for hours, then sit on the grass with a blanket and some wine and crackers and watch an old movie projected onto the side of a giant white wall. It certainly adds something to the movie you&#39;re watching if you really luck out and the bodies buried mere yards away are the same ones projected on the wall.&lt;br /&gt;I saw &lt;i&gt;All About Eve &lt;/i&gt;for the first time about a year ago, at Hollywood Forever, and I was a bit tipsy on the wine, was incredibly uncomfortable on the grass, and had forgotten a sweater so that by the time the movie actually started, I was shivering and huddled up against my friends for warmth and only occasionally glancing up at the &quot;screen&quot;. From what I remember, I wasn&#39;t particularly impressed, but who knows, maybe my cozy living room will provide a better environment from which to evaluate:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary: &lt;/b&gt;We open on some sort of acting awards ceremony. It&#39;s a tiny room with a pretty small audience, so we&#39;re clearly not dealing with the movies here. The camera focuses on one fey dude smoking one of those long thin cigarettes from the movies as VO narration says, &quot;that&#39;s me. I&#39;m Addison DeWitt, a theatre critic. But of course you know that if you&#39;ve read anything or watched anything or are aware of the world at all&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;He&#39;s a theatre person, all right.&lt;br /&gt;He introduces the rest of the group. There&#39;s the writer Lloyd and his wife Karen and the director Bill and his new wife Margo. Margo is Bette Davis, and she&#39;s sassy and brassy and Tells It Like It Is and has huge ugly bags under her eyes and tons of gay men love her and I&#39;ll never understand the fascination so many of my people have with rude old women. I mean, don&#39;t get me wrong. We don&#39;t corner the market on the love of ridiculous camp and corniness. The straight guy equivalent is Ahnold and Steven Segal and &lt;i&gt;The Expendables &lt;/i&gt;type crap. That&#39;s just as camp as Ethel Merman, they just don&#39;t admit it. And to straight women who mock, I throw Edward and Jacob and a million shitty romance novels at your feet and shout, &lt;i&gt;&quot;J&#39;Accuse!&quot;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;And the lesbians like...not really sure what the lesbians like that&#39;s crap. &amp;nbsp;kd Lang? Ellen? Ellen&#39;s pretty cool, though. Oh, Rosie! &amp;nbsp;She sucks, right? But does anyone still like her? Hmm. At any rate, everyone likes some shitty stuff and everyone judges everyone else for liking the shitty stuff that they don&#39;t like and that&#39;s just how it goes. Except me. I only like quality stuff. Oh, and Tommy Wiseau&#39;s &lt;i&gt;The Room. &lt;/i&gt;Come on, that shit&#39;s fucking awesome. Also &lt;i&gt;Rat Race.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But I digress.&lt;br /&gt;So the award is for Eve Harrington, a bright new theatre star who is about to make the big move to Hollywood and Addison VO&#39;s that just one year ago Eve was a nobody, and now she&#39;s the biggest star ever.&lt;br /&gt;Flashback. Eve stands outside the theatre, a play that Margo was in, and Karen approaches her. They talk for awhile, and Eve says she has seen every night of the play for the entire run, and that she loves Margo so very much and could she possibly pretty please meet her?&lt;br /&gt;Karen lets her in backstage. Margo is sassy and petulant and bossy to everyone and then Karen walks in with Eve and Eve gushes and curtsies and avoids eye contact and says she first saw Margo in a touring production in San Francisco and she loved her so much she followed her across the country to New York.&lt;br /&gt;Instead of calling the cops, Margo is flattered. Then Eve tells a story about how she&#39;s a poor orphan and her husband died in the war and by the end of it, Margo has invited her to live with her and allowed her to work as a stagehand on the play.&lt;br /&gt;So time passes, and at one point Margo&#39;s younger boyfriend Bill is away on business in California and it&#39;s his birthday and Eve oversteps by sending him a present from Margo and Margo&#39;s maid doesn&#39;t trust her and finally Margo starts to not trust her, even though everyone else but the maid loves her. Then it&#39;s Margo&#39;s birthday party and Margo sees Eve talking a lot to Bill and schmoozing with Lloyd the writer and she starts getting jealous. And hey, Marilyn Monroe is there! &amp;nbsp;You know, she was really quite attractive. Is anyone else aware of this? Then Margo starts drinking and she says the applause line, &quot;fasten your seatbelts, it&#39;s going to be a bumpy ride!&quot; like she&#39;s gonna be so &lt;i&gt;extra &lt;/i&gt;sassy tonight,&amp;nbsp;and then she just proceeds to get all drunk and weepy and insecure. She accuses Bill of sleeping with Eve and he says she&#39;s crazy, then she makes a big drunken spectacle of herself and then goes to bed.&lt;br /&gt;Eve asks Karen if she could be Margo&#39;s understudy, and Karen says yes.&lt;br /&gt;Then a week later, Margo shows up late for the reading of their new play, and Addison tells her that Eve stepped in and was so awesome and everybody loved her and Lloyd in particular was happy to have someone &quot;new&quot; and &quot;fresh&quot; reading his lines. Margo throws another shit fit and Lloyd and Karen get mad at her and walk out of rehearsal. The next day, Margo, Bill, Lloyd, and Karen were all supposed to go out for a day trip in the country, and they go despite the argument, but that night when they head back to the train to get Margo back in town for her show, the car runs out of gas. Margo takes it better than expected, but she doesn&#39;t know that Karen for some reason conspired with Eve to make Margo miss the train, because Karen wanted to &quot;teach Margo a lesson&quot; about being so mean all the time.&lt;br /&gt;By the way, all of this is moving at a fucking snail&#39;s pace. Every single scene is about twice as long as it needs to be, with pointless, circular dialog and self-indulgent pauses that would make Pinter blush.&lt;br /&gt;So it turns out, Eve called every theatre critic in town to come and see her that night, and they all did, and they all loved it. Bill sees Eve backstage and tells her she did a great job, and she hits on him, but he says his heart belongs to ol&#39; baggy eyes and he walks out. The critic Addison asks Eve to do an interview with him, and she consents.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, the article is filled with quotes from Eve bashing Margo and Addison says she&#39;s old and washed up and Eve is the new hotness. Everyone&#39;s sad and Bill fires Eve from the play.&lt;br /&gt;Then they all go out to dinner to cheer up Margo, and the waiter passes a note to Karen from Eve who is in the bathroom and wants to speak to her right away. They all talk for probably ten fucking minutes wondering what Eve could possibly want and then finally Karen goes to the bathroom and &lt;i&gt;they&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;talk for ten fucking more minutes until Eve finally gets to the point: she&#39;s blackmailing Karen. Either Karen convince Lloyd to cast her as the lead in his next play, or she&#39;ll tell Margo that Karen was the one who drained the gas out of the car. Karen goes back to dinner and Margo announces that she and Bill are getting married and she doesn&#39;t even want to be in the play because she&#39;s found her purpose in the world as a man&#39;s appendage. Karen&#39;s super relieved that she won&#39;t have to screw over Margo because that would be an interesting plot line. Then Lloyd casts Eve and she does really well and then one day she&#39;s talking to Addison about how awesome she is and she says Lloyd is leaving his wife for her and Addison says &quot;you belong to me now&quot; and she&#39;s like &quot;Whaaaa????&quot; and he says he investigated her and learned that she&#39;s not an orphan, and not a widow and her whole backstory is a lie and he threatens to expose her if she doesn&#39;t...admit that she belongs to him. Which entails...what? Nothing is explained.&lt;br /&gt;That night, the flashback catches up with the beginning of the movie, and Eve accepts her award and profusely thanks her &quot;friends&quot;, Karen, Bill, Lloyd, and Margo who all stare daggers at her, despite the fact that they&#39;re all professionals and out in public, and then afterwards Eve is all bitchy and despondent, and then she goes back home and a girl is in her house. She screams and the girl&#39;s like, my name&#39;s Phoebe, and I&#39;m your biggest fan...&lt;br /&gt;Ah. The circle continues. Got it.&lt;br /&gt;Oh, wait. The movie&#39;s not done yet. In case you&#39;re not aware that Phoebe is now Old Eve and Eve is now Margo, the movie will hammer that point for another ten minutes with Phoebe saying the same general shit Eve was saying the beginning, and Eve acting like Margo used to, and then Phoebe stands in front of the mirror holding Eve&#39;s dress and award and pretending like it&#39;s hers and DO YOU GET IT YET?????&lt;br /&gt;Done.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I&#39;m sorry, but this is really boring. The pacing is ridiculously slow, the writing is bland, the characters aren&#39;t that great. Bette Davis&#39; performance is pretty good, but even she is hobbled and neutered in the end by the love of a good man, and all the rest of her friends were totally boring. There&#39;s very little scheming, no real surprises, or sudden fun reversals of fate. It&#39;s just bad. I&#39;ll be turning in my gay card, now. Which means I can probably stop watching &lt;i&gt;Glee.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;One and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;High Noon&quot; and then a movie about the goodness and purity of politics, &quot;Mr. Smith Goes to Washington&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7932465137478934038/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/28-all-about-eve-1950.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7932465137478934038'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7932465137478934038'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/28-all-about-eve-1950.html' title='#28 All About Eve (1950)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--DrQI97iuD8/TtL6b8sFs3I/AAAAAAAAAKA/60cFjVm6uh4/s72-c/eve.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1450831340943742161</id><published>2011-11-23T18:07:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-26T11:20:04.141-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#29 Double Indemnity (1944)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-BAWil8d54gE/TtEwCuy1aTI/AAAAAAAAAJw/pyXX_zuQv5w/s1600/ki.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-BAWil8d54gE/TtEwCuy1aTI/AAAAAAAAAJw/pyXX_zuQv5w/s1600/ki.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;A man named Walter Neff staggers into an office building. He walks over to a desk and pulls out of the drawer some sort of suitcase-looking thing with what looks like one half of one of those old-timey looking phones coming out of it. I&#39;m usually being sarcastic when I pretend not to know what some bit of technology from the Olden Times is, but this time I&#39;m legitimately flummoxed. Is it some kind of phone? A suitcase phone? He talks into it, all hardboiled and noir-like and says he&#39;s recording &quot;what you might say is my last confession&quot;. So...it&#39;s like a tape recorder before there were cassettes? Is he recording on a record? &amp;nbsp;Should I do some fancy google-fu or live in ignorance? Hmm...it&#39;s a fair question. Here&#39;s another one: am I stalling because this movie was boring as hell but not bad enough to have fun ripping to shreds like &lt;i&gt;Sound of Music? &lt;/i&gt;Hmm. &amp;nbsp;Another mystery.&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, Walter Neff&#39;s recording a message to his boss, Barton Keyes. It&#39;s a confession. Neff&#39;s an insurance agent. It all started one day on a routine door-to-door visit to a Mr. and Mrs. Dietrichson. Mr. Dietrichson wasn&#39;t home so Walter was going to come back later, but the wife Phyllis said she could listen to the pitch herself, kinda like if she were a fully equal adult in a consenting relationship or something. Sheesh. Dames.&lt;br /&gt;The &quot;witty&quot; double and double and half entendres go flying back and forth for awhile and Walter says will she please take the car insurance offer to the man of the house and get back to him and she says do you sell other insurance,&lt;br /&gt;Sure all kinds&lt;br /&gt;Like life insurance?&lt;br /&gt;Yeah sure&lt;br /&gt;I want to buy him life insurance but as a surprise for his birthday and can I forge his name, I don&#39;t want him to be bothered with all the details.&lt;br /&gt;He calls her baby like ten thousand times and then says he&#39;s wise to her plan and the jig is up and cuckoo-cachoo Mrs. Robinsion blah blah blah and he&#39;s out the door. Then I shit you not in the VO he says that he knew she was no good but she smelled like honeysuckle and &quot;how could I know that murder sometimes smells like honeysuckle?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Well, indeed. A fair point, weirdo. How &lt;i&gt;could&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;you know?&lt;br /&gt;So he goes back home but she shows up a bit later with his hat that he forgot and he says let&#39;s talk more about your horrible plan that I&#39;m still totally against and she says &quot;I&#39;m a girl, I have boobies!&quot; And they passionately press their tightly sealed mouths together in an approximation of a kiss and then Walter VO&#39;s that the Evil Jezebel had her hooks in him.&lt;br /&gt;So they come up with a plan to sell Mr. Dietrichson 100,000 dollars worth of life insurance with a double indemnity clause that pays double if he is killed on a train, which is just fucking bizarre, but okay. They forge his name. Then Phyllis tells Walter that her husband is going away on a business trip on Friday and that would be the perfect time to enact their plan. The husband&#39;s adult daughter from a previous marriage, Lola, lives with the family but Phyllis says she won&#39;t be a problem.&lt;br /&gt;So it turns out the day before he&#39;s supposed to go on the trip, Mr. Dietrichson broke his leg, so Walter and Phyllis says that makes their still-unrevealed plan even easier to pull off. On Friday, Walter sneaks into the Dietrichson&#39;s garage and hides in the backseat of the car. Phyllis sees him and says nothing, and gets in the driver&#39;s seat, while Mr. Dietrichson gets into the passenger&#39;s. They drive to the train station, but suddenly on an empty road, Phyllis stops driving and when Mr. Dietrichson asks why, Walter sits up and throttles him (off-camera). He makes choking noises as the sweet smell of honeysuckle fills the air.&lt;br /&gt;Then they go to the train station and Walter puts on a fake leg cast and crutches onto the train. Phyllis says, &quot;goodbye, my husband, Mr. Dietrichson!&quot; really loud like twenty times and they kiss goodbye and Walter shows the conductor his ticket and gets on the train. He goes to the caboose, which is an &quot;observation deck&quot; that is outside, which is kinda cool. A man is already out there. He tries to engage in conversation with Walter, but Walter won&#39;t look at him. Finally Walter says he&#39;s out of cigars and will the men please go to his car and get him one? The man says yes and as soon as he disappears, Walter jumps off the train. He staggers forward and then Phyllis pulls up. They take Mr. Dietrichson out of the backseat and put him on the tracks.&lt;br /&gt;Ah. That&#39;s pretty clever, actually.&lt;br /&gt;Fade out. Time passes. The police think Mr. Dietrichson got &quot;tangled up&quot; in his crutches and fell off the train, and they&#39;re satisfied all is well. But Barton Keyes, the claims adjuster to whom Walter is currently confessing, was not satisfied. He said the whole thing smelled like honeysuckle and that he suspected Mrs. Dietrichson was hiding something. So he conducts an investigation while Walter sweats it out and feels guilty and gets paranoid and all the typical stuff in this genre. They can&#39;t meet because Keyes is having Phyllis &amp;nbsp;followed. But then they meet anyway in a grocery store but Phyllis is wearing sunglasses so it&#39;s okay or something. Phyllis wants to know why they haven&#39;t paid out on the claim yet and Walter says it&#39;s because his boss suspects something and they have to play it cool.&lt;br /&gt;Then Mr. Dietrichson&#39;s daughter Lola shows up at the office and tells Walter that she suspects her stepmom killed her dad, and that Phyllis&#39; previous husband also died mysteriously. Walter realizes that this is a Red Flag and that he&#39;s a Stoolie and a Chump but he&#39;s In Too Deep now and must Play It Through. Lola says she&#39;s going to the police with her suspicions (with certainly make more sense than going to her dad&#39;s insurance agent) so Walter takes her on a date an encourages her to tell him all her troubles to distract her from going to the police, which somehow works.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile Keyes is like Hank Schrader to Neff&#39;s Walter White, and tells Neff about all his suspicions and progress in investigating Phyllis. He says that he has a witness from the train. In walks the guy on the observation deck. Walter freaks, but the guy doesn&#39;t recognize him, though he does see pictures of the deceased Mr. Dietrichson and says that that guy definitely wasn&#39;t on the train.&lt;br /&gt;Keyes basically figures out the whole thing from that and says that Phyllis must be working with an accomplice who boarded the train. He says that the PI he hired saw Phyllis with a young man at the grocery store. Walter gulps and pulls on his necktie and gets out of there. Then Lola comes to see him and says that her boyfriend is secretly seeing her stepmother on the sly and she suspects they killed her dad together. Walter realizes he&#39;s not that young and the PI caught Phyllis with a different guy. Walter goes to Phyllis&#39; house and confronts her with this and sure enough, the plan all along was for Phyllis and her young boyfriend to kill Mr. Dietrichson and run off with the money but they needed a patsy on the inside to help pull it off. Phyllis then shoots Walter in the shoulder. Then she says she can&#39;t shoot again because right now at this very minute she realizes that she&#39;s in love with him. Sigh. But then Walter shoots her dead. He then staggers back to the office to catch up with the beginning of the movie.&lt;br /&gt;Walter finishes his recording and then Keyes walks in, having been secretly listening. How long had he been standing there? Long enough, natch.&lt;br /&gt;So then as Walter dies he says you figured out everything but me because you were too close to me.&lt;br /&gt;Keyes lights Walter&#39;s cigarette and says even closer than that.&lt;br /&gt;And Walter says I love you, too and then dies.&lt;br /&gt;Oh whatever, movie. Don&#39;t try to win me over by getting all weirdly gay right at the end.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;There&#39;s nothing terribly wrong with this movie. It&#39;s just very simple and straightforward and by-the-numbers in nearly all of it. The plot is very tame (while embarrassingly presenting itself as hardcore) with precious few &lt;i&gt;noir-like&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;twists and no particularly engaging or memorable characters. I know this is another one of those &quot;first of it&#39;s kind&quot; things that AFI likes to honor so much, even if movies that came later are much better. So let&#39;s go with that. But &lt;i&gt;Maltese Falcon&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;was a better film in the same genre and it was three years older, so who knows?&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s just lame.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, we honor our gay forefathers with &quot;All About Eve&quot; and then it&#39;s Marty McFly vs. Buford Tannen in &quot;High Noon&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1450831340943742161/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/29-double-indemnity-1944.html#comment-form' title='1 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1450831340943742161'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1450831340943742161'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/29-double-indemnity-1944.html' title='#29 Double Indemnity (1944)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-BAWil8d54gE/TtEwCuy1aTI/AAAAAAAAAJw/pyXX_zuQv5w/s72-c/ki.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1506302255355144634</id><published>2011-11-19T21:55:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-21T20:31:15.230-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#30 Apocalypse Now (1979)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PSvtMDHjYwU/TsiWOxGhGII/AAAAAAAAAJg/SLpoFhHcCz0/s1600/bald.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PSvtMDHjYwU/TsiWOxGhGII/AAAAAAAAAJg/SLpoFhHcCz0/s1600/bald.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Well, &lt;i&gt;Pulp Fiction,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;I hope you&#39;ve enjoyed your stay at the top of my modified AFI list. It was a good run.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Capt Benjamin L. Willard, special operations, sits holed-up in a shitty hotel room in Saigon, haunted by demons. He smashes a mirror, does drugs, rages and weeps intermittently.&lt;br /&gt;He&#39;s paid a visit by several military higher-ups, including Harrison Ford, who have an assignment for him. He&#39;s to track down a Col. Walter E. Kurtz, of the US Army Special Forces, and exterminate his &quot;command&quot; with extreme prejudice. Kurtz has gone rogue, disobeying orders, forming his own army of followers and committing multiple acts of murder. Willard is intrigued. Charging a solider with murder in this war is like charging an Indy 500 driver with speeding. Something doesn&#39;t add up. But he takes the assignment, anyway. He has no choice.&lt;br /&gt;He&#39;s put on a boat, which will take him to Kurtz&#39;s last known location, in Cambodia.&lt;br /&gt;With him is the boat Commander, Chief Phillips, a crewman nicknamed &quot;Chef&quot;, a young kid named Tyrone &quot;Mr. Clean&quot; Miller (14 year old Laurence Fishburn who lied about his age to get the job), and a famous surfer-turned draftee named Lance Johnson.&lt;br /&gt;They first need to be escorted to the beach that accesses the Nung River, which will take them to Cambodia. They meet up with Lt. Col Bill Kilgore, who recognizes Lance and takes a shine to him, due to their shared love of surfing. Kilgore says he and his men, all helicopter attack pilots, need to take over a patch of land on the beach first before they can take Willard and his crew to their destination.&lt;br /&gt;What follows is the first of many &lt;i&gt;many&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;mind-blowing spectacles, a true marvel in technique and beauty and horror, as Kilgore and his fellow helicopter pilots fly into the Viet Cong-occupied village at low height and begin bombing the shit out of it, while blasting the &lt;i&gt;Ride of the Valkyres&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;at full volume.&amp;nbsp;VC men women and children run for their lives as the copters circle around and around, the men firing machine guns and dropping grenades. Some choppers land and the firefight continues on the ground, with the Americans taking some losses as well, including a women throwing a grenade into a chopper when they&#39;re trying to load up wounded.&lt;br /&gt;Kilgore calls the VC &quot;savages&quot;, then asks Lance what he thinks.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Well, it&#39;s pretty exciting sir--&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;No no, about the surfing conditions. Good waves, right?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;They land, and as the firefight continues around them and an occasional mine explodes in the background, Kilgore orders several of his men to start surfing, then tells Lance to do the same. Willard says that due respect sir, maybe it&#39;s not safe to do that, but Kilgore insists he&#39;s not chickenshit and strips his shirt off, swearing he&#39;s going to go surf, too. The Americans drop napalm, the smell of which Kilgore loves in the morning, and probably anytime. (The line reading here is just fantastic. I&#39;ve heard the line before, but I don&#39;t think I ever saw Robert Duvall actually say it, and it&#39;s not an evil or ruthless delivery, as I&#39;d expected, but a romantic one. He&#39;s&lt;i&gt;...wistful. &lt;/i&gt;Wistful about &lt;i&gt;napalm&lt;/i&gt;).&lt;br /&gt;After the battle, Willard pours through his dossier about Kurtz. If Kilgore is considered an acceptable leader, then how far around the bend must Kurtz be?&lt;br /&gt;That night, the men enjoy a USO show complete with Playboy bunnies, who dance around in skimpy outfits until they&#39;re mobbed by soldiers and have to escape in a helicopter.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, Willard and his men are granted safe passage to the Nung River, and begin their mission proper. Only Willard&#39;s privy to the details of the actual mission. After a time, the men begin to forge relationships. The boat captain Chief is suspicious of Willard&#39;s motives, but keeps his objections to himself. Chef and Mr. Clean fight a lot, while Lance gets more and more withdrawn. He becomes obsessed with applying camouflage makeup to his face in intricate detail. The come across another boat with an older civilian Vietnamese couple in it. Chief wants to inspect the boat, and does so over Willard&#39;s objections.&lt;br /&gt;Chef boards the boat over the couple&#39;s foreign-sounding protests, and begins to inspect it. He reaches down to take the lid of a yellow basket and the woman runs forward, screaming. Mr. Clean opens fire with his machine, gun, shooting them both, then just sort of firing a bunch of times afterwards. He finally stops. Chef opens the basket and incredibly pulls out a small puppy, like maybe a golden retriever or something. Lance grabs it from him violently and holds the puppy and begins petting it, creepily whispering in its ear. They notice the Vietnamese woman is still alive, and Chief orders that she be brought onboard the boat and taken to a nearby encampment for medical care. As Chef and Mr. Clean scoop her up, Willard calmly says they don&#39;t have time for this, then pulls out his gun and shoots her dead.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;I told you not to stop.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Day turns into night as they sail onward. They encounter what looks like the remains of a fierce battle that took place a half a day or so ago. There&#39;s a half destroyed bridge over the river, downed helicopters on both sides, dirty, angry soldiers stranded and lost. The beg Willard and his crew to take them to safety. Occasionally, gunfire can be heard or a flare goes off. Incredibly, what comes to my mind is that it looks like if the &lt;i&gt;Pirates of the Caribbean &lt;/i&gt;ride at Disneyland&amp;nbsp;became real as you were riding your boat through it, and you had to get out and start walking among the pirates. &amp;nbsp;Then Lance reveals to Chef that he just took a hit of acid. &lt;b&gt;Because things are not fucking crazy enough for ol&#39; Lance right now.&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;Willard says he needs to speak with the commanding officer in the area. He takes Lance along with him (who brings the puppy in his coat) and they get off the boat. They encounter a couple soldiers in a foxhole. One is firing repeatedly at what he says is a VC somewhere off in the dark, taunting him. Willard wants to know who&#39;s in command. No one has an answer. He eventually leaves.&lt;br /&gt;They all get back on the boat, and some time later, are ambushed by some natives on land. Mr. Clean is shot and killed. Chef starts weeping. Chief blames Willard and this fucked up secret mission. Lance realizes he&#39;s lost the puppy and starts going nuts looking for it. They continue onward, and some other natives start shooting arrows at them. Chef opens fire with his machine gun, until Willard realizes they&#39;re toy arrows and tells him to stop shooting. Chief&#39;s had it, though, and declares the mission over. He&#39;s turning around. Suddenly, a spear goes sailing through his upper chest. He collapses into Willard&#39;s arms. Willard lowers him gently to the deck, and with his last breath, Chief struggles in vain to pull Willard onto the spear sticking through his chest.&lt;br /&gt;Afterwards, Lance, in full camo makeup and wearing the toy arrows through his head like Steve Martin, gently kisses Chief on the forehead and lowers him into the water, waving goodbye. Willard tells Chef the real purpose of his mission, and says they need to make it to Cambodia no matter what. They sail on, until they reach a large group of boats in the water, blocking the entire river. On the boats are dozens of Cambodian, American, and Vietnamese men and women, all painted white. As Willard, Chef, and Lance approach, the boats part to give them an opening. Willard stares in mute apprehension as they round a corner and see literally hundreds of white-painted cult members, staring at them from the banks of the river, all carrying guns or spears. There are dead bodies everywhere. Decapitated heads, naked bodies hanging from trees, everyone covered in white paint and dirt and shit and blood. It&#39;s fucking terrifying. From the bank, an American calls out to them. He welcomes them vociferously, as they others continue to stare. The American says he&#39;s a journalist, a photographer, but now he&#39;s a member of Kurtz&#39;s Army. And these people here are all his soldiers.&lt;br /&gt;Oh shit.&lt;br /&gt;The photographer says he&#39;ll take them to see Kurtz. Willard instructs Chef to remain on the boat. He tells him that if things go bad, to radio headquarters with this location and order an airstrike, obliterating everyone and everything. Willard and Lance walk onto the land and the natives continue to stare in silence as the photographer chats a mile a minute, going on and on about how great Kurtz is. Soon, the cultist goons have surrounded Willard, and they pile on top of him, carrying him upside-down, stripping him and dunking him in the mud. They leave him in a bamboo cage while the photographer gives him water and a cigarette. He tells him Kurtz knows his mission is to kill him. But good news, Kurtz has allowed him to live, for now.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Willard is brought in to see Kurtz.&lt;br /&gt;In a fantastic moment, Kurtz, mostly concealed in the dark, talks pure fucking insanity about I don&#39;t know what and basically invites Willard to join his crew of fucking crazy weirdos. It&#39;s like staring into a black hole. Willard&#39;s taken away and tied up to a post in the mud and rain. A bit later, Kurtz approaches him and casually drops Chef&#39;s head in his lap. Willard screams, weeps, thrashes about and manages knock the head away.&lt;br /&gt;At this point, Lance is seen casually hanging out with the others, fully emerged and integrated.&lt;br /&gt;Some time has passed. Kurtz speaks to Willard again, tells him about what happened. What happened to make him leave the old world behind. He and his men were instructed to inoculate a group of Vietnamese children, but afterwards the VC showed up and chopped off all the children&#39;s arms where they had been given the vaccine. Kurtz saw the pile of children&#39;s arms and snapped.&lt;br /&gt;Willard is free to go, and seems to be integrated into the cult as well. We see him emerge from the river, naked from the waist up and covered in mud and paint. He approaches Kurtz with a machete. A brief battle ensues, and Kurtz is slain.&lt;br /&gt;The horror...the horror.&lt;br /&gt;Willard leaves the temple and the cultists all lower their spears and bow down to him. Willard slowly walks through them, towards the river. He sees Lance, and takes him gently by the hand and guides him over to their boat. They get on, and sail slowly away, as Army command squawks on the radio, demanding to know Willard&#39;s status. Willard shuts the radio off.&lt;br /&gt;He and Lance ride off into the night, but the horrors continue.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;This is really something amazing. Looking back, I think I&#39;ve wasted so many superlatives on other movies, that any words I use to describe this one will seem inadequate. The sheer &lt;i&gt;majesty &lt;/i&gt;of this undertaking is what&#39;s most enthralling. (Pretty sure I haven&#39;t used &quot;majesty&quot; before). The work that went into this production is mind-blowing. We&#39;re truly a long way off from CGI ever equaling the gutteral, instinctual reaction you naturally have when watching something &quot;real&quot;. The movie would truly be less engaging if the explosions and mass carnage were all glorified cartoons. In fact, the &quot;Redux&quot; version that came out in 2001 has scenes that they didn&#39;t have the budget to do properly in the seventies and have been &quot;enhanced&quot; by CGI, which makes me a little reluctant to see it. Kurtz shot first?&lt;br /&gt;Martin Sheen&#39;s performance is excellent, and it&#39;s almost unreal how much he looks like Emilo Estevez. I&#39;m a little sad he never truly became an A-list actor, though at least he&#39;ll always be remembered for this and President Bartlett.&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s funny how the movie is almost a super macbre version of &lt;i&gt;The Wirard of Oz&lt;/i&gt;, with Willard and his rag-tag crew as stand-ins for Dorothy and her friends, and Kurtz as the Wizard. Kurtz is the same function as the Wizard, too, he represents Willard&#39;s last hope for salvation and escape. And he&#39;s just a bunch of smoke and mirrors, ultimately. &lt;br /&gt;Which brings us to Brando. I fully concede he&#39;s a fucking weirdo, and I&#39;m aware even without yet seeing &lt;i&gt;Hearts of Darkness&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;that he was incredibly difficult to work with and that the fact that he was grossly overweight impaired his ability to play the part originally as written. The final battle scene between him and Willard was basically cut down to nothing because Brando was too fat to fight.&lt;br /&gt;BUT...much in the same way that problems with the mechanical shark in &lt;i&gt;Jaws&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;led to Spielberg&#39;s clever directorial tricks to keep the shark mostly out of sight, the fact that Kurtz is seen mostly in darkness and in close-up really added to his mystique. I didn&#39;t care much for Brando in &lt;i&gt;Streetcar&lt;/i&gt;, but here the fact that Kurtz is crazy and sick and a giant enigma fits in with Brando&#39;s larger than life personality perfectly. I think it was perfect casting. The part I liked about Brando in &lt;i&gt;Streetcar&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;wasn&#39;t his line delivery, but his...&quot;essence&quot;, or gravitas, if you want to be a pretentious douche about it, is undeniable. And here it works so well because Kurtz is all gravitas. Contrast his extremely over-the-top stuff with Sheen&#39;s subtle, nuanced work and you have cinematic gold.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, there was originally a different ending where Willard and Lance sailed away and then there was a overlap scene of Kurtz&#39;s camp getting blown up. Apparently, people quite reasonably took that to mean Willard ordered an airstrike of the camp, which was not the interpretation Coppola wanted to give. To him, it was just a scene like the crashed plane at the end of &lt;i&gt;Lost&lt;/i&gt;, which was completely separate from the movie. So he pulled that ending and replaced it with the fade to black, which I think was the right call to end things with a sliver of hope for humanity.&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, this was great. Can&#39;t wait to see &lt;i&gt;Hearts of Darkness.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Double Indemnity&quot;, and then things get gay again with &quot;All About Eve&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1506302255355144634/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/30-apocalypse-now-1979.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1506302255355144634'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1506302255355144634'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/30-apocalypse-now-1979.html' title='#30 Apocalypse Now (1979)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PSvtMDHjYwU/TsiWOxGhGII/AAAAAAAAAJg/SLpoFhHcCz0/s72-c/bald.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2055395947717600632</id><published>2011-11-18T17:41:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-19T21:47:54.570-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#31 The Maltese Falcon (1941)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-2PWuYCfuOFw/TscJYMQxaYI/AAAAAAAAAJY/ECS1ViwOxPM/s1600/falcon.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-2PWuYCfuOFw/TscJYMQxaYI/AAAAAAAAAJY/ECS1ViwOxPM/s1600/falcon.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;Brick&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;is better.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Private dick Sam Spade and his partner Miles Archer work in their agency in San Francisco and spend the day smoking and wearing nice suits and speaking unnaturally and having their Gal Friday run errands and such.&lt;br /&gt;Into the office walks Ruth Wonderly, a ritzy dame with gams that go all the way up to her unmentionables. She&#39;s got an assignment for them. Her sister&#39;s missing, see. She&#39;s been seeing this man Floyd Thursby, see, &amp;nbsp;and suddenly she&#39;s gone like the Lindbergh Baby. Ruth wants Sam and Miles to track her down. She gives &#39;em a hundred clams and Archer says he&#39;ll tail Thursby that night.&lt;br /&gt;Later, at home, Sam gets a call from the black and whites. They say Archer&#39;s been killed, and his body&#39;s in some alleyway. Sam goes to the location and gets some heat from the fuzz, who wonder if he&#39;s involved. There&#39;s been rumors, see. Rumors that Sam&#39;s sweet on Archer&#39;s broad, Iva. They also tell Sam that nearby another nogoodnick by the name of Floyd Thursby has been found dead, too. Shot, just like Archer. Sam makes like he knows nothing, and when they finally tell him to scram, he rings up Ruth at her hotel, but they say she&#39;s checked out. (Of the hotel. Not like, dead or anything).&lt;br /&gt;The next morning, Sam&#39;s back at his office, and in walks Ruth Wonderly again. Except now she says her name&#39;s Brigid O&#39;Shaughnessy. Sam says he knew her first story was nothing but a boondoggle, and she better fess up now. Brigid says there&#39;s no sister, and Floyd was her partner. They&#39;re tracking down something. Some MacGuffin type thing, and she thought maybe Floyd got it already, because he disappeared without so much as a how&#39;s-your-father a few weeks back. She thinks Floyd probably spotted Archer and killed him, but has no idea who killed Floyd. She gives Sam another 100 greenbacks to take on the case.&lt;br /&gt;She makes like a pier and leafs, and right away in walks some nelly with scented business cards and a phallic cane that he shoves in his mouth mid-conversation. His name&#39;s Cairo, and he pulls a gun on Sam and tells him to empty his pockets, and open all his desk drawers. But Sam gets the drop on him, and punches him in the mug and knocks him out cold. He goes through Cairo&#39;s stuff and then Cairo wakes up and tries another way to skin a cat. He offers Sam 5,000 to help him find a fake &quot;black bird&quot;. Sam says he&#39;ll take the job.&lt;br /&gt;That night, Brigid shows up at his house and Sam tells her about Cairo&#39;s visit. She claims she doesn&#39;t know nothin&#39; about that, but soon after Cairo shows up too, and the two fight like a couple of hens. Brigid tells Cairo that the &quot;Fat Man&quot; is here in San Francisco, too. Then the fuzz show up, but Sam manages to give&#39;em the brush off.&lt;br /&gt;When they&#39;re alone, Sam tells Brigid he&#39;s on her side and playing Cairo for a sap, then later tells Cairo the same about Brigid.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, he goes to Cairo&#39;s hotel, and is held up by a mook named Wilmer. Sam disarms the chump pretty easy, but instead of getting while the getting&#39;s good, Sam follows him anyway. He finds Gutman, the Fat Man. The Fat Man offers Sam a drink, then gives him the crib notes straight up. They&#39;re looking for a gold falcon statue that was made in the 1500&#39;s for the Duke of Malta and stolen by some pirates and probably magic wizards. At some point, someone French put black paint on it to disguise its value, and then it got lost for a time in Middle Earth, and now the Fat Man has tracked it to San Francisco. Cairo, Floyd, and Brigid O&#39;Shaughnessy are all competing with The Fat Man to get their hands on the precious bird. He offers Sam 250,000 to help him find it. Sam sits a bit and tries to make sense of all the tales he&#39;s been told, when suddenly things go tits up, and he goes under. Fat Man slipped him a mickey, see. Then Cairo and Wilmer come out of the side room and they take off.&lt;br /&gt;Sam wakes up a bit later, and goes searching through the room. He finds a newspaper with the name of a freighter circled. He makes tracks to the docks finds the arriving boat on fire. The firemen tell him everyone got out okay.&lt;br /&gt;He goes back to his office and asks his Gal Friday if she&#39;s heard from anyone. She tells him no dice. But then some man carrying a brown paper package staggers in and then immediately bites the big one. Sam takes the package and skips, and tells his gal he&#39;s going to put the package in a safe deposit box and to bring it to him only if he calls her and asks her for it. Oh yeah, and to report the dead body to the coppers, but don&#39;t mention the package.&lt;br /&gt;He goes home and finds Brigid standing in his doorway. He takes her upstairs and inside his place is the Fat Man, Wilmer, and Cairo. He tells them all that he&#39;s got the falcon. But he won&#39;t share until he gets his cheddar. The Fat Man offers him 10 grand now, and Sam says the offer was 250 before, but the Fat Man says they need to sell it first. Sam has another condition. They need a rube to take the fall. Someone has to go down for the murders of Floyd and Archer and that other guy in his office. The Fat Man explains that the other guy was the boat captain who showed up that day with the falcon on his freighter. Wilmer plugged him, but he got away from them. Then when they tried to search the boat, Wilmer tried to light a candle and accidentally burned the boat up. &lt;i&gt;(Um...okay).&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sam says Wilmer should take the fall for all three murders, because he&#39;s not gonna get jammed up by the coppers for this. Cairo and The Fat Man say deal, then Sam punches Wilmer out. He calls his Gal Friday, who real quick-like brings the package. They open it up, and it&#39;s the black Maltese falcon. Everybody grins like a shyster lawyer on payday, and the Fat Man scrapes at the black paint to see the gold underneath. And he scrapes. And he scrapes.&lt;br /&gt;But it&#39;s a phony. A three dollar bill. Cairo screams like a fruit and the Fat Man sulks. Wilmer wakes up, and the Fat Man says they&#39;re taking heel to toe to Istanbul, their next lead. Everyone scrams but Brigid and Sam.&lt;br /&gt;When they go, Sam calls the coppers and says the plan worked. He tells them where to arrest the others. Then, since the movie&#39;s almost over, he tells dollface a thing or three. He knows she&#39;s the one who killed his partner Archer. She confesses, says that she hired them to follow Floyd and scare him away. She wanted the falcon all to herself. But things went sideways and Floyd wasn&#39;t scared of Archer, so she iced &amp;nbsp;Floyd, but Archer saw her, so she had to do him too. She begs Sam not to turn stool pigeon. He tells her no dice. Even though she&#39;s a swell dame and they&#39;re in love &lt;i&gt;(WHAT?!) &lt;/i&gt;he won&#39;t be played for a fool like those other chumps. The cops show up and Sam tells them she&#39;s confessed. They take her away.&lt;br /&gt;A detective sees the black bird and asks Sam what it is.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Frankly my dear, maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, stinking badges&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;It&#39;s not my favorite genre, but it has its charms. The writing is all plotplotplottyplot and you really need to engage to keep track of all the twists and turns and deceptions and absurd convolutions, many many of which I left out above and were total red herrings. That&#39;s fun for awhile, but at a certain point what tends to happen in con movies is that you shutdown and refuse to believe &lt;i&gt;anything&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;that&#39;s happening onscreen, not willing to trust that it&#39;s real. I was pretty engaged until about the forty-five minute mark, then started to zone out a bit. The ending was pretty strong, though. Although it was ridiculous that suddenly we were expected to believe Sam and Brigid were in love and he was greatly conflicted and in pain over turning her in. There was &lt;i&gt;none&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;of that onscreen. None. Also, Sam just totally randomly figures everything out at the end for no reason other than the running time was almost up. The movie was basically a glorified, especially twisty episode of &lt;i&gt;Law and Order&lt;/i&gt;. And while &lt;i&gt;Law and Order &lt;/i&gt;is entertaining and basically the TV equivalent of chicken noodle soup and saltine crackers on a rainy day, no one puts chicken noodle soup on their Top 100 Foods List. Did I just brutally leave that metaphor for dead? Perhaps.&lt;br /&gt;A much much better take on the noir film is &lt;i&gt;Brick&lt;/i&gt;, with stronger writing and a story that simultaneously takes its characters seriously and pokes fun at the noir genre. It&#39;s really pretty great. Stream it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Apocalypse Now&quot;, and then &quot;Double Indemnity&quot;, which is about contract fraud, maybe?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/2055395947717600632/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/31-maltese-falcon-1941.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2055395947717600632'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2055395947717600632'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/31-maltese-falcon-1941.html' title='#31 The Maltese Falcon (1941)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-2PWuYCfuOFw/TscJYMQxaYI/AAAAAAAAAJY/ECS1ViwOxPM/s72-c/falcon.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-5396083485614476873</id><published>2011-11-13T10:34:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-14T09:47:57.956-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#32 The Godfather: Part II (1974)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pYgnDOrpnrk/TsANkZTx0FI/AAAAAAAAAJI/KFWhNB_hEhs/s1600/pacion.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pYgnDOrpnrk/TsANkZTx0FI/AAAAAAAAAJI/KFWhNB_hEhs/s1600/pacion.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;On the last episode of&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Godfather:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;At his daughter&#39;s wedding, Don Vito Corleone did a favor for Johnny Fontane involving a horse&#39;s head. The Sollorozo family tries to kill Don Vito and his son Sonny. Don Vito almost gets killed but survives. Younger brother Michael meets with Sollorozzo and his henchman and kills&#39;em both after fishing a gun out of the toilet. He&#39;s the hero. Don Vito dies of a heart attack in a tomato garden. Sonny gets gunned down. Fredo&#39;s a pussy. Micheal has his enemies killed including his sister Connie&#39;s husband, and ascends to power, closing a literal and metaphorical door in girlfriend Kay&#39;s face. Also, Kurt and Blaine finally did it.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And that&#39;s what you missed!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;&lt;i&gt;In 1901, in the town of Corleone in Sicily, Don Cicco kills a local named Anthony Andolini for some sort of mob-related slight. Anthony&#39;s son Paolo goes into hiding, vowing revenge, but he&#39;s quickly killed as well.
