(1975)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ShOYhJgXVg0/Tr_Uz8fvvVI/AAAAAAAAAJA/7jbwQ2gsEf8/s72-c/laugh.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8719093646311265202</id><published>2011-11-08T21:41:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-09T13:21:21.671-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#34 Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-5KjjcXRz1eY/TrX5DhrF8LI/AAAAAAAAAIY/aMdPgFsaPXw/s1600/dw&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-5KjjcXRz1eY/TrX5DhrF8LI/AAAAAAAAAIY/aMdPgFsaPXw/s1600/dw&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Once Upon A Time:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The Fairy Princess Snow White lived in an empty castle with her Evil Stepmother, The Queen. The Evil Queen had a Magic Mirror, whose power included the ability to definitively rate chicks&#39; hotness according to a complicated algorithm that only he could properly interpret. Every day, The Evil Queen would ask the Magic Mirror, &quot;Mirror, mirror, on the wall, who&#39;s the fairest of them all?&quot; and every day the Mirror would respond that she was the fairest of them all, until Snow White woke up looking particularly fair one morning, and &lt;i&gt;just&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;managed to tip the scales in her favor.&lt;br /&gt;When The Mirror breaks the bad news to the Evil Queen, she flips out and hires a hit man to stalk Snow White in the woods and kill her.&lt;br /&gt;The hunter follows Snow White into the woods, and sees her chatting earnestly with a baby bird who fell out of its nest. He realizes she&#39;s insane, and can&#39;t bring himself to kill her. He tells her the Queen wants her dead, and that she should run away, far far away, and she does. She runs and runs and runs all night and finally crashes in some bushes and sleeps the sleep of the damned.&lt;br /&gt;When she wakes, about fifty deer, rabbits, squirrels, and birds surround her and fret visibly about her well-being. Snow White explains the situation to the most sentient-looking deer in the bunch, and asks it if it knows of a place where she can live. The animals excitedly lead her to a house in the woods that Snow White insensitively refers to as a &quot;doll house&quot;. They go inside, and it&#39;s a mess. Snow White sees seven little beds and decides seven children live here and that she could be their mother. She declares she&#39;ll clean the house and forces her new animal friends to submit to slave labor, washing the clothes and dishes and making the beds, while she sweeps the floor and whistles.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, the &quot;little children&quot; who live in the house are actually seven dwarfs: Doc, Dopey, Happy, Sneezy...um...Sleepy....how many is that? &amp;nbsp;Wait...Doc, Happy, Dopey....&lt;i&gt;Bashful&lt;/i&gt;! &amp;nbsp;I always forget Bashful. &amp;nbsp;Uh...Bashful...Sneezy, Grumpy...did I say Dopey? Hold on...is there a Vanity?&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, the dwarfs dig up millions of dollars with of precious jewels on a daily basis, and as a consequence are quite cheerful about it. Their leader, the near-sighted one with speech problems, declares that it&#39;s quitting time, so they all march in a line and sing &quot;Heigh-ho, heigh-ho&quot;. Once they get back to the house, they see a candle on in the living room and the chimney smoking, and they freak. They get inside and see that someone is upstairs asleep on the bed. They elect the mildly retarded mute one with alopecia to go upstairs and confront the intruder. Classy, guys. But he chickens out, so they all go up and Snow White wakes up and everybody screams, then she tells them she&#39;s a Princess and she needs to hide out for a while because the Queen&#39;s trying to kill her because she&#39;s so pretty. Wow, ego much, Snow White? The chronically depressed one says it&#39;s a terrible idea, but the rest of the dwarfs are down with it.&lt;br /&gt;So Snow White cooks them dinner, but won&#39;t serve it to them unless they wash their hands, and I think the dwarfs are giving their new houseguest too much power. But they wash their hands and then eat and then dance and frolic with Snow White and the woodland animals all night long. The one with severe allergies keeps trying to sneeze, but the others cruelly won&#39;t let him, and the narcoleptic one bows out early and goes to bed in a shelf. It&#39;s pretty much the worst kegger ever.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, The Evil Queen wants to know who&#39;s the fairest &lt;i&gt;now, &lt;/i&gt;bitch?, but the Mirror still says it&#39;s Snow White. The Evil Queen says but that&#39;s like, just your &lt;i&gt;opinion,&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;man, and besides, I&#39;ve got her heart. The Mirror says the hunter tricked her and that&#39;s a pig&#39;s heart (and the pig&#39;s family is shattered beyond repair). The Queen decides she&#39;ll kill Snow White herself with a poison apple, and then concocts a magic spell that that turns her into an old crone, which should really hurt her standings in the &quot;fairest&quot; rankings, but she doesn&#39;t seem to get those implications. Then she reads the instructions on the back of the apple and sees that the one who bites it won&#39;t really be &lt;i&gt;dead&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;dead and will wake up if kissed by a random bland white guy.&amp;nbsp;She heads off into the woods.&lt;br /&gt;The next morning, Snow White sends her men off to work, kissing the one with crippling social anxieties on his bald head, and causing him to turn purple with shame and humiliation.&lt;br /&gt;The Queen shows up in disguise and tries for half an hour to get her to eat the damn apple while the woodland animals race to the mines and get the dwarfs. They run back to the cabin, just in time to see Snow White fall to the ground. They angrily chase the Queen through the woods and up a cliffside, where two evil looking vultures wait. The Queen tries to push a rock on them, but is struck by lightning and falls off the cliff.&lt;br /&gt;But all the dwarfs think Snow White&#39;s dead, so they do the logical thing and build a glass casket for her so they can watch her decompose.&lt;br /&gt;But then a random guy happens by and kisses her and she says see ya suckers, and rides away.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;So as I sat watching ten minutes of footage dwarfs scrubbing each other in a large troth, I came to a realization. There&#39;s a lot of talk nowadays about how modern MTV audiences have short attention spans and need everything to move quickly and how that&#39;s an indication of the dumbing down of society and I think that&#39;s bunk. I think we&#39;re smarter now, not dumber. I think the fact that a modern audience wouldn&#39;t sit still watching three or four minutes of dwarfs sleeping reflects well on us. This movie is 83 minutes and a good 40 of it is filler. And not even good filler. Really boring filler.&lt;br /&gt;And the other thing that occurred to me, is maybe old audiences didn&#39;t necessarily have better attention spans, maybe they just hadn&#39;t seen this stuff before, so watching the dwarfs putter around and do nothing for huge blocks of time didn&#39;t feel like &quot;nothing&quot; because everything they did was entertaining, just by virtue of existing. I&#39;ve used the &lt;i&gt;Avatar&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;comparison before, but I think it really applies well here. At no point while watching that movie did I think it was a good movie. And yet I loved it, because it was visually the most stimulating movie I&#39;ve ever seen. There&#39;s no doubt in my mind that fifty years from now, someone my age now will think it&#39;s boring as hell, because the effects will be outdated and the story itself is terrible.&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, what&#39;s especially annoying about this movie&#39;s inclusion in the list is that some of the other classics around the same era are far far better. &lt;i&gt;Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, Jungle Book &lt;/i&gt;just to name three all have better developed characters, more interesting sub-plots, scarier villains, and far better sense of &quot;world-building&quot;. And then of course &lt;i&gt;The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, &lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;The Lion King &lt;/i&gt;blow the old ones out of the water. Even &lt;i&gt;Robin Hood &lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;Alice in Wonderland &lt;/i&gt;are better than &lt;i&gt;Snow White.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;But much as &lt;i&gt;Toy Story &lt;/i&gt;is in the bottom tier of Pixar films, it gets AFI inclusion based on being first, so we give it to &lt;i&gt;Snow White&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;here.&lt;br /&gt;But to be fair (or perhaps even the fairest), there are a couple good moments. Snow White, the Queen, and the Prince are mind-numblingly boring, but the dwarfs are fun and have some good moments. The songs are catchy. And the Queen&#39;s death scene was very creepy and well-done, easily the movie&#39;s highlight.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, one of my Very Favorite Movies, &quot;One Flew Over the Cuckoo&#39;s Nest&quot; (spoiler: five stars), and then &quot;The Godfather: Part II&quot; (ditto).&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8719093646311265202/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/34-snow-white-and-seven-dwarfs-1937.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8719093646311265202'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8719093646311265202'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/34-snow-white-and-seven-dwarfs-1937.html' title='#34 Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-5KjjcXRz1eY/TrX5DhrF8LI/AAAAAAAAAIY/aMdPgFsaPXw/s72-c/dw" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-5165759486028351821</id><published>2011-11-08T10:37:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-08T10:37:09.866-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#35 Annie Hall (1977)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7C9_B-3eDfg/TrablbhMDUI/AAAAAAAAAIg/0CV1Lkri9q0/s1600/woo.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7C9_B-3eDfg/TrablbhMDUI/AAAAAAAAAIg/0CV1Lkri9q0/s1600/woo.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Alvy Singer is a neurotic stand-up comedian of indeterminate religious background who lives in New York City. He talks to the camera, and has many grievances about his life. He tells us that he recently broke up with Annie Hall, the most fetching boy-woman in all of New York. He starts by telling us how he grew up under a roller coaster in Coney Island and then admits he exaggerates and sometimes can&#39;t tell what&#39;s real. In line at the movies, Alvy fumes at the bloviating pontificating man behind him and fantasizes about confronting him. He remembers when he first met Annie, at a tennis match with friends. She hit on him clumsily, then drove him to her apartment. They hung out on the rooftop, and Alvy pontificated about art and worried she could see he didn&#39;t know what he was talking about, and she worried he would think she was too superficial. Eventually, they fell in love. He encouraged her to pursue her dream to be a singer, and she in turn tolerated his incessant whining. She took him on a virtual tour of her past boyfriends, whom they viewed invisibly in the same way Scrooge and the Ghosts look on past events. He then took her on a tour of his childhood, and his screeching Constanza-esq parents. He complains that she always wants to smoke pot first before sex. I would&#39;ve required something significantly stronger. They break up and then make up and declare their love to each other on the boardwalk.&lt;br /&gt;One day, Annie finally decides to take Alvy home to meet her family. Her parents are WASP-y and cold, her grandmother a racist, and her brother is super weird and awesome. He delivers a movie-stopping hilarious monologue about how sometimes he has an undeniable urge to swerve into oncoming traffic, while Alvy looks on in agony. All I can say is, I envy the 1977 audiences who got to be introduced the beautifully bizarre Christopher Walken this way.&lt;br /&gt;(Okay, would &lt;i&gt;Being Christopher Walken&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;have been an even better movie than &lt;i&gt;Being John Malkovich? &lt;/i&gt;Discuss.)&lt;br /&gt;Annie becomes a popular night club singer, and some people invite her to see some agents in Los Angeles. They both go, and Alvy whines about how it&#39;s hot and sunny in December and how everyone drives everywhere and there&#39;s no culture. He&#39;s exactly right, of course. Except the sunny part is awesome. Of course, I romanticize New York City based on my eleven days there in 1999, and sit in two hours of traffic everyday in Los Angeles in 2011, so I can&#39;t really be trusted to be objective.&lt;br /&gt;By the end of the trip, Annie has made new friends while Alvy has sulked and so she wants to live there. They agree to break up again, quite amicably.&lt;br /&gt;But very quickly, shocker of shockers, Alvy decides he&#39;s miserable again, and wants her back. He flies to Los Angeles. He rents a car. He goes to a restaurant and orders wheat grass, because those stupid hippies in L.A. eat nothing but, and when Annie arrives for a friendly lunch, he begs her to come back. But she won&#39;t, because he&#39;s so damn miserable and physically nauseating. (She doesn&#39;t actually say that last part).&lt;br /&gt;He goes back to New York, and writes a play about his relationship with her, but in the play, she leaves California and goes back with him to New York.&lt;br /&gt;Then sometime later, he &lt;i&gt;does&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;find her in New York. She&#39;s moved back. They have a friendly, bittersweet lunch and then hug and part ways.&lt;br /&gt;And then my review goes up one star because of this final monologue:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&quot;I thought of that old joke, you know...this guy goes to a psychiatrist and says, &quot;Doc, my brother&#39;s crazy, he thinks he&#39;s a chicken&quot;, and the psychiatrist says, &quot;Well, why don&#39;t you turn him in?&quot;, and the guy says, &quot;I would, but I need the eggs&quot;. Well, I guess that&#39;s pretty much now how I feel about relationships, you know; they&#39;re totally irrational and crazy and absurd and...but I guess we keep going through it, because uh, most of us...need the eggs.&quot;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Let me start by fully acknowledging that my review might be a tad biased based on my general dislike of Woody Allen due to his personal life and his myriad of endlessly crappy recent movies, most of which put him opposite increasingly hot women who would never speak to him in real life. I don&#39;t think it&#39;s possible for me to be 100% objective. That being said, I&#39;ve heard this movie is a classic, and I went into watching it with an open a mind as possible. And...it wasn&#39;t bad. There are some beautiful patches of dialog, and that last monologue was fantastic, and Woody and Diane Keaton have tons of chemistry, but for me it just wasn&#39;t all that funny, ultimately. There&#39;s no question that Larry David modeled his &lt;i&gt;Curb&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;character very heavily on Woody&#39;s persona, and throughout this movie I tried to figure out why I find Larry so funny and Woody not nearly as much. I think it&#39;s because Woody&#39;s a victim, always whining about how the world is so cruel, and Larry actively tries to fix what he sees as life&#39;s great injustices, despite the fact that they&#39;re really life&#39;s pettiest inconveniences. Woody fantasizes about confronting the jerk in line at the movies, but Larry really would. Also, Larry&#39;s almost always right but lacks perspective and tact, while Woody just whines some more. Plus, Woody ruined those people&#39;s cocaine, and that&#39;s just wrong.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But it&#39;s not a bad movie. It&#39;s sweet, it&#39;s mildly funny, and it&#39;s only ninety minutes.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, more mismatched lovers with &quot;Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs&quot;, and then my man Jack is back in &quot;One Flew Over the Cuckoo&#39;s Nest&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/5165759486028351821/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/35-annie-hall-1977.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/5165759486028351821'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/5165759486028351821'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/35-annie-hall-1977.html' title='#35 Annie Hall (1977)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7C9_B-3eDfg/TrablbhMDUI/AAAAAAAAAIg/0CV1Lkri9q0/s72-c/woo.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-9222208397836977073</id><published>2011-11-06T20:42:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2011-11-07T14:29:48.623-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#36 The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-oJssBFUNz4k/TrdhsBh0xtI/AAAAAAAAAIo/IpUoAVfY0A8/s1600/df.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-oJssBFUNz4k/TrdhsBh0xtI/AAAAAAAAAIo/IpUoAVfY0A8/s1600/df.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;An epic, nearly three hour war movie from the 50&#39;s? Bleah. What&#39;s next, a John Wayne movie? All right, let&#39;s get this over with.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Western Thailand, in a prison camp run by Japanese Colonel Saito. Two prisoners, an American and and Australian, are digging a grave for a fellow departed prisoner. The American, Commander Shears, says a few respectful words after being reminded of his name, and then they finish the burial. Shears bribes the guard with a lighter he found on the deceased, and begs the guard to let him stay in the &quot;sick tent&quot; for the next few days, and get off work duty. The guard allows it.&lt;br /&gt;From the tent, Shears and the others hear a procession of new prisoners being brought in. They&#39;re marching, proudly, with their shoulders up and their backs straight, like they&#39;re in a parade. And even stranger: they&#39;re whistling. Whistling that camp tune that&#39;s in every third movie about either camp or the army. That tune that I thought came from &lt;i&gt;The Parent Trap.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;They&#39;re being led by Lt. Colonol Nicholson, marching in front. They stop in front of Saito and the other guards at attention, and as one, salute. There are about a hundred and fifty or so of them. It&#39;s exhilarating.&lt;br /&gt;Saito tells them all they&#39;re under his charge now, and that starting tomorrow they&#39;ll be used as slave labor to build a bridge. &amp;nbsp;Where, you might ask? On that river over there. What&#39;s the river called, you might then say? Why, it&#39;s called Kwai.&lt;br /&gt;Saito dismisses the men, but Nicholson stays behind. He politely and respectfully tells Saito that the Geneva Convention strictly prohibits captors from forcing officers to do manual labor. Saito sarcastically says he&#39;ll look into it, but Nicholson has no sarcasm meter, and just salutes.&lt;br /&gt;Later that night, in the prisoner tent, Shears tells Nicholson and some of the other officers about his intention to escape the next day. Nicholson says no thank you, they were ordered by his superiors to surrender, so escape would be tantamount to treason. Um...not sure if I agree with your math there, Nicholson.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, Saito orders the British soldiers again to start working on the bridge. Nicholson reminds him again that the officers can&#39;t do manual labor and provides him a copy of the Geneva Convention rules. Saito takes the copy and swats Nicholson&#39;s &amp;nbsp;face with it. He orders Nicholson and the other officers to join the regular soldiers. Nicholson refuses and tells his fellow officers to stand at attention. Saito sends the enlisted men away, so that it&#39;s only him and Nicholson and the other 10 or so officers. Shears watches from his sick tent in horror as Saito signals a truck with a machine gun in it to pull up. He tells Nicholson he has until the count of three to start working. Nicholson stands his ground.&lt;br /&gt;One.&lt;br /&gt;Two.&lt;br /&gt;Another British solider, a doctor named Clipton who had been in the sick tent, runs forward. He tells Saito that everyone in the sick tent is witnessing this, and it&#39;s murder, and he&#39;ll never get away with it. Saito stares him down for a moment, then tells his guards to grab Nicholson. They put him in a small wooden box in the sun that Shears refers to as the &quot;oven&quot;. The other officers continue to stand at attention.&lt;br /&gt;In all the distraction, Shears and two others suddenly race off, attempting their escape. The other two are gunned down, but Shears manages to jump off a cliff &lt;i&gt;The Fugitive &lt;/i&gt;style, and into a raging river floating downstream to apparent safety.&lt;br /&gt;Weeks go by. The men continue working on the bridge, though pieces of it break and fall into the water periodically. Saito is apoplectic. He has the British doctor Clipton visit Nicholson in his makeshift prison. Clipton begs Nicholson to agree to let the officers work. He tells him that he&#39;ll die in the oven if it goes on much longer, and every day the officers stand at attention all day long in the sun, and one of them has heatstroke and will likely die soon, too. They frankly could use the exercise of working on the bridge. But Nicholson holds his ground. Finally, Saito pulls him out for a late night visit, and Nicholson&#39;s gaunt and pale and can barely walk. Saito tells him that if the bridge isn&#39;t completed by May 1st, his superiors will force him to commit &lt;i&gt;seppuku. &lt;/i&gt;Nicholson is unsurprisingly unmoved. He offers to allow his officers to &lt;i&gt;oversee&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;the bridge construction and make sure it&#39;s done properly, so long as they don&#39;t have to actually do any manual labor. Only the Brits can simultaneously be so brave and so prissy.&lt;br /&gt;Saito again puts him back in the oven, but after another week or so, finally gives into his demands. He frees Nicholson from the oven, and the men cheer and hold him above their heads like he&#39;s a rock star.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, Nicholson holds a meeting with his officers, and one reveals that the location of the bridge makes it impossible to build, because the ground is too soft. Nicholson holds a meeting with Saito and his men and tells him of their new plan to scrap the current bridge and start over a half mile away. He has new plans, and a new tougher work schedule for the men and by God and by the Queen, they&#39;ll get this bridge done by May 1st no matter what, proving the worth of the British military. The other officers look askance at Nicholson apparently heading to some creepy level beyond Stockholm Syndrome, but say nothing.&lt;br /&gt;So finally, we get back to Shears. Turns out, he got picked up by some Thai natives and then rescued by some British troops. He&#39;s recovering in a British-run hospital in Thailand, eating fruits and berries and hitting on a Brit nurse. But then a British Major named Warren wants to see him. Turns out Shears isn&#39;t a Commander after all, but rather an enlisted man. When he was taken prisoner by the Japs, he switched outfits with his deceased commanding officer, hoping to get better treatment as a prisoner. Warren found this out and blackmails Shears with it. He wants Shears to accompany him and lead him back to where he was imprisoned. You see, there&#39;s a bridge that&#39;s being built there. A bridge on a river. Named Kwai. And that bridge will allow the enemy to easily transfer weapons and men by train to key battleground areas or something. And it needs to be blown up. Accompanying Shears and Warren is a cute little Canadian named Lt. Joyce, who is asked if he ever killed anyone in battle, and would he be capable of it? Joyce says he hasn&#39;t and isn&#39;t sure if he would be able to, because it feels like murder to him. Fucking Canadians.&lt;br /&gt;Warren says he&#39;ll get over it.&lt;br /&gt;So they fly over the site and parachute down and encounter several Siamese women and one man who will help them on their mission. All the other men in the area have already been imprisoned by the Japanese. At one point, they&#39;re discovered by three Japanese scouts. Shears and Warren shoot two of them, but the third runs off. The men pursue, and Joyce discovers him by accident about a foot away from him. He can&#39;t bring himself to kill the him, so the scout raises his weapon, but just then Warren comes rushing forward and stabs the scout in the gut, just as he fires his gun, hitting Warren in the foot.&lt;br /&gt;As they continue marching on, Warren eventually can no longer walk, and tells the others to go on without him. But Shears refuses. They make a cot for him and carry him.&lt;br /&gt;And back at the prison camp, Nicholson frets openly about completing the bridge on time. Clipton suggests that maybe that really shouldn&#39;t be their main goal, and then Nicholson tosses off the info that even though the officers are working on the bridge now, it might not get done in time. I&#39;m sorry, what? The officers---you mean, the people who you spent a month in a tiny box just to keep them from getting their prissy little hands dirty, &lt;i&gt;those&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;officers? &amp;nbsp;Nicholson you fucking suck, sir. Jolly well suck. Then Nicholson goes to the sick tent and starts cajoling fevered and injured prisoners that they&#39;re not &lt;i&gt;that&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;sick, and surely they can to some &quot;light&quot; labor to help things along? Several soldiers unsteadily rise to their feet and follow Nicholson out the door.&lt;br /&gt;And finally, after some more time and a fade out, the bridge is complete. Nicholson and Saito walk along it, Nicholson gently touching the railing. He says they did it, dammit, on time, proving the resilience and capability of the British army. And I&#39;m guessing also proving something to daddy?&lt;br /&gt;They have a big homoerotic party that night, completely with shirtless soldiers in hulu dresses, dancing with one another and pretending to kiss, while the rest of the men hoot and holler. Now &lt;i&gt;that&#39;s &lt;/i&gt;the England I know and love. Good show, old chaps.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Warren, Shears and the others arrive in camp the same night. Through intel, they&#39;ve learned that the bridge was just completed and an enemy train with supplies is coming through on it tomorrow morning. They quietly string up explosives underwater, connecting them with a wire hidden in the sand and a plunger thingie hidden behind a rock. They&#39;ll wait until morning, and then Joyce, also hidden at the rock, will set off the explosion just as the train starts on the bridge, thereby getting them two birds with one stone. The quietly swim in the water and set everything up, then proceed to sleep until morning. The next morning, they wake up and see the river water has receded. The wires connected to the bridge are exposed. Shears and Warren are separated from Joyce, and unable to tell him to just blow up the bridge now, forget the stupid train, before they&#39;re discovered! But Joyce doesn&#39;t notice their frantic signaling. And then Saito and the guards stand on the bridge at the ready. Blow it up, Joyce! &amp;nbsp;Blow it up now! &amp;nbsp;God, this is worse than &lt;i&gt;Breaking Bad! &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;Then Nicholson and the Brits come marching onto the bridge. Whistling again. That fucking whistling. Joyce can&#39;t blow it up, now. But the Brits thankfully march to the other side, with only Nicholson staying behind. Nicholson lovingly brushes his hands on the railing of the bridge one last time, then leans on it, looking into the water. He sees the wires. He&#39;s confused. We walks a few dozen feet, then looks down again. More wires.&lt;br /&gt;Blow it up, JOYCE! &amp;nbsp;GOD DAMN IT!&lt;br /&gt;Nicholson: Saito. Something&#39;s wrong. You gotta take a look at this.&lt;br /&gt;I HATE YOU, NICHOLSON. YOU AND YOUR ASS FACE!&lt;br /&gt;And he and Saito get down from the bridge, just as finally, &lt;i&gt;finally, &lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;a train whistle can be heard in the distance. Nicholson discovers the wires under the sand. He pulls on them, following them towards Joyce. He and Saito keep walking.&lt;br /&gt;The train approaches.&lt;br /&gt;Nicholson and Saito are about twenty feet away from Joyce and his TNT plunger.&lt;br /&gt;Shears and Warren keep gawking like they&#39;re in their living room on Sunday night in 2011.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Joyce rushes out with a knife, and stabs Saito before he can turn around. &quot;We&#39;re gonna blow up the bridge, sir!&quot; he hisses to Nicholson.&lt;br /&gt;Blow it up? &amp;nbsp;Guards, help! Nicholson signals to the other Japanese guards on the bridge. They start running down. Joyce tries to run back to the plunger, but Nicholson tackles him. Please sir, let me go! &amp;nbsp;But he can&#39;t bring himself to attack an ally.&lt;br /&gt;Shears finally breaks out of his hiding place and makes a mad dash across the sand, determined to kill Nicholson&#39;s fucking face off. Just as he reaches them, a Japanese guard shoots him in the back, and then kills Joyce for good measure. Nicholson sees Shears as he dies, staring into his eyes. He remembers that American. The one who escaped before...everything happened.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;My God, what have I done? &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He runs towards the plunger.&lt;br /&gt;The train starts to go on the bridge.&lt;br /&gt;Just then Warren fires some huge explosive gun that blows up right behind Nicholson. Nicholson stops in his tracks then falls over dead, right onto the plunger.&lt;br /&gt;The bridge explodes fantastically, and the train crashes down into the river below.&lt;br /&gt;Mission Accomplished.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;WOW! &amp;nbsp;Wowee wowee wow! That was fantastic! &amp;nbsp;And all the more so, for being completely unexpected! &amp;nbsp;Thank you AFI. Never in a million years did I expect to find this movie any more than okay at best, but it was amazing. Starting with the beautiful lush scenery that really established a foreign location and continuing with great performance by all the actors. Each character had a function in the story and influenced the way the plot unfolded. I love that when stories do that. No superflous characters. And Alec Guiness was amazing. He had such a tricky part, this stubborn brave and heroic man who is undone by his own sense of self worth and value. To him, finishing the bridge was no longer about helping the enemy, but about proving that he could. And the way his belief system gets warped by his torture and then victory over Saito after the torture (which functions as a validation of all his actions thus far) is completely believable, even if it was pretty maddening. Shears, Warren, and Joyce were all fully developed characters too, who each had a satisfying and entertaining arc. The movie cover bills this as Shears vs. Nicholson, but that&#39;s not it at all. It&#39;s Nicholson vs himself and his sanity, and Shears, Warren, Joyce, Clipton, and Saito are just supporting players. Also, lots and lots of shirtless dudes building shit. You can&#39;t go wrong with that. Anyway, pretty great. Kudos all around, fifty four years later.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, another tough-guy movie, &quot;Annie Hall&quot;, and then &quot;Snow White and the Von Trapp Children&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/9222208397836977073/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/36-bridge-on-river-kwai-1957.html#comment-form' title='2 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/9222208397836977073'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/9222208397836977073'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/36-bridge-on-river-kwai-1957.html' title='#36 The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-oJssBFUNz4k/TrdhsBh0xtI/AAAAAAAAAIo/IpUoAVfY0A8/s72-c/df.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>2</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2699501089861970932</id><published>2011-11-04T10:43:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-11-04T10:52:30.364-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#37 The Best Years of Our Lives (1946)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KCL905nX7fw/TrCuXBqOEhI/AAAAAAAAAII/L7B_j-k721k/s1600/hands&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KCL905nX7fw/TrCuXBqOEhI/AAAAAAAAAII/L7B_j-k721k/s1600/hands&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This movie and the previously reviewed &lt;i&gt;Sullivan&#39;s Travels &lt;/i&gt;are the only two movies on the list I hadn&#39;t even heard of before starting this project. Good sign or no?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;So, there was the event in the 1930&#39;s and 40&#39;s called World War II, and according to Bart Simpson it was one of only three good wars. (The others being &lt;i&gt;The American Revolution &lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;The Star Wars Trilogy). &lt;/i&gt;This movie takes place immediately after the greatest generation&#39;s greatest war. Three soldiers are coming home. There&#39;s Homer Parrish, a sailor who lost both hands in an explosion, Fred Derry, a man who got married just two weeks before shipping out, and Al Stephenson, an older man with a wife and kids. They all live in the same town, and arrive back home on the same day in the same single-engine airplane. They didn&#39;t know each other before that day, but promise to KIT and be BFFs since they all live within a ten mile radius or so. They all take the same cab home from the airport, and Homer&#39;s dropped off first. His parents, little sister, and girlfriend all race out to greet him with warm enthusiastic hugs and smiles pasted on their faces. It&#39;s at first a bit glurgey and annoying that no one flinches at or even acknowledges his hook hands, but when he turns to wave goodbye to his new friends riding off in the cab, everyone in the family gapes openly at his hooks and looks super sad, and immediately when he turns back, the fake smiles reemerge. Nice moment. Though I kinda wanted Homer to say, &quot;DON&#39;T LOOK AT ME, I&#39;M A MONSTER!!&quot; and start ripping shit up.&lt;br /&gt;Then Fred gets home next. He still lives with his mom and dad, but learns that his wife moved out awhile back and now works at a nightclub. &amp;nbsp;The harlot! His mom and dad don&#39;t know what club, but they do have her new address, so Fred heads over there to meet her.&lt;br /&gt;Then Al gets home, and greets his adult children (Peggy and Rob) and wife Millie with hugs and kisses all around, though there&#39;s also a weird tension there. He wants a drink, but his wife says there&#39;s no liquor in the house, and she wishes she&#39;d known he was coming home today. Al wants to go out on the town anyway, and takes Peggy and Millie with him. He goes from bar to bar getting plastered, as wife and daughter patiently endure him.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Homer tries to pick up a glass with his hook hands and drops it and everyone looks devastated, and finally Homer can&#39;t take all the pitying looks anymore, and leaves the house.&lt;br /&gt;Fred also gets to his wife&#39;s apartment, discovers she&#39;s not home, and starts trolling nightclubs in an attempt to find her whoring ass.&lt;br /&gt;They all meet up at a bar and have lots and lots of drinks and Fred hits on Peggy after asking her her name about five times. Millie drives everyone home, but when Fred still can&#39;t get into his wife&#39;s apartment, they take him back to stay with them. Then there&#39;s a weird and ridiculously long scene where Millie gets her passed out husband ready for bed, by taking off his shoes and socks and pants and putting on pj&#39;s and brushing back his hair and stuff and they show it all in real time and it seriously takes like 2-3 minutes. Who directed this, Gus van Sant? Then Peggy does the same for Fred, and at one point he drunkenly pulls her on the bed with him and paws at her, but she manages to squirm away. Then that night he has PTSD war dreams and wakes up screaming, while Peggy comforts him.&lt;br /&gt;So we&#39;re about one of three hours in, and in the timeframe of the movie, less than 24 hours have transpired. Oh, and nothing&#39;s happened yet. So let&#39;s move this along:&lt;br /&gt;So the next day, Fred finally gets to his apartment and finds his wife, who is thrilled to see him. He immediately demands she quit working because that&#39;s not for girls, silly. Then he gets back his old job as a soda jerk. His wife is mean to him, and isn&#39;t a good cook and is bad. Peggy comes into the soda shop and flirts with Fred and they go out to lunch and kiss in the parking lot afterwards, and then Peggy runs away because Fred&#39;s married and she&#39;s good.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Homer is cold and aloof to his whole family, but especially his girlfriend Wilma. She hints that she wants to get engaged, but he&#39;s not having it.&lt;br /&gt;Al gets a promotion at the bank he used to work at, but when he gives a loan to a veteran with no collateral, he gets bitched out by his bosses. Later that week, when a party is given in his honor, he gives drunken snarky speech about how he remembers one battle where he and his men almost took a Nazi hill, but decided to retreat instead because they had no collateral. Everyone is super uncomfortable and it&#39;s my favorite scene in the movie.&lt;br /&gt;Peggy learns from Fred that he and his wife basically hate each other, and decides to break them up. But after she tells her mom of her plans, her mom talks her out of it. Al meets with Fred and forbids him from seeing his daughter again.&lt;br /&gt;Homer visits Fred at work and encounters some 9/11 Truther who says FDR let the Japs attack us in order to trick us into entering a European Conflict that was none of our business and Homer tells the dirty traitor to get bent and when that doesn&#39;t work, Fred punches him out and gets fired. When Fred&#39;s wife learns of this, she leaves him.&lt;br /&gt;Then Wilma tells Homer she wants to marry him, so he gives her a big speech about how helpless he is and how he needs his father to even dress and undress him and bathe him and all that (and they don&#39;t even get into the scatological stuff, thank God) and wants to know if this is what she &lt;i&gt;really &lt;/i&gt;wants. She does.&lt;br /&gt;Then Fred gets a new job working on airplanes or something.&lt;br /&gt;Then Homer and Wilma get married. The preacher guy says the whole spiel and they say their vows and everyone watches and it plays out in real time. Like, seriously. I timed it. For 4 minutes and 23 seconds we watched fake people in a fake wedding. Even real ones are boring as shit. Then Peggy, at the wedding, approaches Fred and Fred tells her he&#39;s divorced and they kiss and finally we break, a few minutes shy of three hours. They should&#39;ve thrown another wedding in there.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s not all terrible, and it&#39;s not anywhere near as sappy as I expected it to be. And frankly, I&#39;m shocked that in 1946 a movie dared to look at some of the negative side-effects of our most glamorous war. The subject matter is the kind of thing you&#39;d expect a couple decades later, after Korea and Vietnam. And the actors playing Al and Fred were very good, too. You could &lt;i&gt;feel&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;their discomfort, especially when they first got back. Al&#39;s desire to go out and drink and carouse was never underlined as a defense mechanism or a fear of just being alone with his thoughts, but you could tell by his performance that this was the case. The actor playing Homer was a real solider who really did lose his hands in the war, so that was an interesting bit of realism, too, even though his acting was clearly a bit subpar.&lt;br /&gt;But--the pacing is horrible. The scenes go on and on forever. I&#39;m not kidding when I say the movie could&#39;ve been cut in half, easily. There&#39;s no reason for us to have to watch an entire wedding ceremony, or job interview, or dinner date, all of which we saw in this thing, with little or no cutting. It was just such a weird choice. Yes, I know I know, we&#39;re the MTV Generation, quick cuts and short attention spans and yadda yadda yadda. Well I say balderdash to that. Director William Wyler needed to edit that shit. Also, the score was overly dramatic and sappy, with huge overtures and violins and the whole bit. Whatever goodwill the actors garnered with their subtle performances was nearly undone by the extremely unsubtle score.&lt;br /&gt;Ultimately, I&#39;d say the movie&#39;s a failure, but a noble and good-intentioned one.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;The Bridge on the River Kwai&quot;, and then everybody&#39;s favorite Boy Meets Adopted Daughter rom-com, &quot;Annie Hall&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/2699501089861970932/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/37-best-years-of-our-lives-1946.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2699501089861970932'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2699501089861970932'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/37-best-years-of-our-lives-1946.html' title='#37 The Best Years of Our Lives (1946)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KCL905nX7fw/TrCuXBqOEhI/AAAAAAAAAII/L7B_j-k721k/s72-c/hands" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3404605365204027331</id><published>2011-11-01T19:41:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-11-01T19:41:20.735-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#38 The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (1948)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-kHKpbaaeyew/TqooYhv3ZjI/AAAAAAAAAIA/Cm4V2Auv7JA/s1600/tr.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-kHKpbaaeyew/TqooYhv3ZjI/AAAAAAAAAIA/Cm4V2Auv7JA/s1600/tr.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Ol&#39; Fred Dobbs lives in some crappy town in Mexico in the 1920&#39;s, is homeless, and begs American tourists for change. He finally gets an offer from an American contractor to work on an island off the coast for eight dollars a day for the next few weeks. Dobbs agrees to go, having no problem stealing Mexican&#39;s job. While on the job, he meets Bob Curtin, a fellow American who is also in deep southern Mexico for no stated reason, and also broke. But their boss turns out to be a cheat, and when they get back into town, the boss pretends to go get the money, and skips out on them instead. &amp;nbsp;A few days later, Curtin and Dobbs run into him at a bar and proceed to beat him up in an unconvincingly blocked sequence that leads to the guy giving them two hundred bucks each.&lt;br /&gt;So they drink it up, and run into an old prospector named Howard, who tells them what will happen in the rest of this movie, I mean, tells them his past stories as a gold prospector. He says that he&#39;s gone prospecting many times, and every single time he&#39;s fought with his partners, and either he or his partners have gotten greedy and paranoid, and every time he&#39;s lost all of his winnings because he was robbed by his partners or Mexican &lt;i&gt;banditos, &lt;/i&gt;or he spent all his winnings trying to earn more winnings. Curtin and Dobbs decide they want to take their 400 and invest in gold digging, and ask Howard to join them. He immediately agrees. Heh.&lt;br /&gt;So they go hiking through the Sierra Madre, up the mountain and around and around and Curtin and Dobbs are beat and just when they want to quit and go back home, Howard says they&#39;ve found gold!&lt;br /&gt;So they set up all their prospecting doo-dahs and get to work. After a short time, they&#39;ve amassed a few hundred dollars each, with plenty more out there. They decide to split the gold three ways, and each keep track of their own gold, hiding it from the other two. This leads to fun things like Dobbs freaking out when Curtin gets up in the middle of the night to pee, which causes Dobbs to run off to see where he went, which causes Curtin to get back and wonder where Dobbs is, and run off himself. Howard, who&#39;s seen it all and now too old for this shit, just shakes his head and goes back to sleep.&lt;br /&gt;Eventually, Curtin goes into town for more supplies, as Dobbs refuses to leave his gold up in the mountains unattended or risk getting robbed by &lt;i&gt;banditos &lt;/i&gt;if he brings it along. While in town, Curtin meets a Texan named Jack Colby, who sees Curtin&#39;s burros and supplies, and figures out he&#39;s a prospector, despite Curtin&#39;s claims to be a hunter. He follows Curtin all the way back to the camp, about a mile or so behind him. When he shows up, all three men are surly and angry at him, and tell him to get lost. Colby says he knows they&#39;re prospectors and he wants in. He gives them three options: 1) They can kill him right now, &amp;nbsp;(personally, I would&#39;ve buried that option in the middle) in which case whoever does the killing will be forever beholden to the other two&#39;s silence 2) They can send him away, in which case he&#39;ll blab to everybody back in town and there will be 50 more people like him here in a week or 3) They can let him join their group and split any additional profits four ways.&lt;br /&gt;Dobbs, Curtin, and Howard want a moment to discuss it. They walk away from Colby, then decide to all kill him at once, eliminating any problems inherent in option 1. But when they approach Colby to let him know their decision, and also to kill him, Colby points out that &lt;i&gt;banditos &lt;/i&gt;are riding up the hill towards them right now. &amp;nbsp;They all hide and prepare for an ambush. The head &lt;i&gt;bandito, &lt;/i&gt;nicknamed &quot;Gold Hat&quot;, likely on account of his gold hat, spots Dobbs and tells him that he and his men are &lt;i&gt;federales&lt;/i&gt; and that Dobbs is under arrest. Dobbs wants to see some badges, but Gold Hat says that they don&#39;t need no stinking badges. Wow, that&#39;s where that&#39;s from? Cool.&lt;br /&gt;So there&#39;s a gun fight, and the guys manage to fight off the &lt;i&gt;banditos, &lt;/i&gt;and Gold Hat bids a hasty retreat. It&#39;s then that they discover that Colby has died in the firefight, which I guess was Option 4. They go through his stuff, and discover a rather heartbreaking letter from his wife, begging him to quit the gold rush business, and to just come home already and stop trying to strike it rich and be a husband and father instead.&lt;br /&gt;So our trio buries Colby, and then goes back to work. After they&#39;ve amassed about 35,000 dollars each, which I think is over 200 million in today&#39;s money, the mountain is officially out of gold, so they decide to pack up their things and leave. Dobbs has grown increasingly paranoid and distrustful of the other two. On their way back, they encounter a local Indian tribe, who plead in Spanish for help. Howard explains to the other two that they have a child in a coma and are begging for help to save his life. Howard goes with the Indians because if it&#39;s one thing he knows besides prospecting, it&#39;s bringing children out of comas.&lt;br /&gt;And indeed, the kid&#39;s lying on a blanket or some shit in the forest and Howard literally raises the boy&#39;s arms up and down a few times and then rubs some oil or something on his chest and belly, and the kid wakes up. I had no idea technology was so advanced in the 1800&#39;s. Or so laughably arbitrary.&lt;br /&gt;So the Indians want to thank Howard by making him the C3PO of their tribe and have a celebration for a few days. Howard says no thanks, but they insist with spears pointed. Dobbs says tough luck Howard buddy, we&#39;ll meet you back in town in a week. He and Curtain take off.&lt;br /&gt;After just a night of dragging along Howard&#39;s burro, Dobbs tells Curtin that they should run out on Howard and take his gold. Curtin says no way, but then Dobbs accuses him of trying to take &lt;i&gt;all &lt;/i&gt;the gold, and pulls a gun on him. They fight a bit, and then Dobbs winds up shooting Curtin and running off.&lt;br /&gt;Curtin&#39;s not dead though, and he crawls his way back to the Indians and finds Howard. Howard patches up Curtin&#39;s gun wound by...I&#39;m gonna say...doing the hokey pokey, but Curtin still needs a few days to heal and Howard&#39;s not yet allowed to leave anyway.&lt;br /&gt;Back to Dobbs. He&#39;s dehydrated, desperately staggering along, trying to wrangle three burros and all the gold they&#39;re carrying. He stumbles upon a muddy hole filled with dirty water and literally fights the burros to stick his head in first and start gulping it down. As he drinks, he sees a pair of boots in front of him. He looks up to see Gold Hat, grinning crazily. Gold Hat and his gang of &lt;i&gt;banditos &lt;/i&gt;wants to know why Dobbs is out here all alone. Dobbs says his friends are just behind him on horseback, with guns and stuff. But Gold Hat doesn&#39;t buy it. He wants to know what&#39;s on the burros. Dobbs says pelts. (Indeed, there are animal pelts covering the gold bags). But unfortunately for Dobbs, pelts and burros are also worth killing for, and indeed the &lt;i&gt;banditos &lt;/i&gt;shoot Dobbs dead. They ride into town, and discover the gold bags underneath the pelts and mistake them for sand and cut them lose. They try to sell the burros in town, but the burros are marked on their hides, and the buyer realizes they&#39;re &lt;i&gt;his&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;own burros and has Gold Hat and his men arrested and immediately executed by firing squad.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Howard and Curtin show up in town. The owner of the burros tells them what happened, and says their stuff is safely locked up, but when Howard and Curtin go through it, they discover the gold is gone. A random Mexican kid pipes up and says he extremely conveniently saw the &lt;i&gt;banditos &lt;/i&gt;cutting bags of sand lose just outside of town, and Howard and Curtin ride off. But suddenly the wind picks up and the gold is blown all over, back into the land from whence it came. Howard discovers the now empty bags blowing in the wind and shows them to Curtin. They both stare sadly for a moment, then Howard throws his head back and starts laughing maniacally, and soon Curtin joins in, laughing the laugh of the damned. Howard says oh well, he&#39;ll just go back to the Indian tribe and continue to be worshiped as a god, because of that one time he raised a boy&#39;s arms up and down. Curtin says he&#39;ll find Colby&#39;s widow, tell her what happened, and try to make amends somehow. (It&#39;s unspoken, but I&#39;m assuming said &#39;amends&#39; will include fucking. Provided he doesn&#39;t include in the conversation, &quot;we were totally going to murder your husband, but the &lt;i&gt;banditos&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;beat us to it).&lt;br /&gt;As the two men ride off in the sunset, the camera pans down to reveal one last bag of gold, still full.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Lots of fun! Great suspense, lots of action. From what little I knew of Humphrey Bogart, I was surprised that he played the scuzzy villain in the movie. And not even a fun &quot;love to hate&quot; villain, but just a crazy asshole who even dies some twenty minutes or so before the end. I liked that when Dobbs thinks he&#39;s killed Curtin, he justifies it to himself by saying he has to look out for himself in this world, which is something you could imagine the swindler boss saying in the beginning of this movie. Nobody ever sees themselves as the villain. This movie has basically like a stealthy, extremely cynical version of one of my favs, &lt;i&gt;It&#39;s a Mad Mad Mad Mad World, &lt;/i&gt;which is something I didn&#39;t realize until about halfway through and the shit started to hit the fan.&lt;br /&gt;I guess the basic message of the movie &quot;greed is bad&quot; is pretty simplistic and the movie ultimately doesn&#39;t have much to say, but the way the message was delivered was quite suspenseful and unpredictable, with plenty of great dialogue. &amp;nbsp;I think I like this &quot;John Huston&quot; director-guy.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;The Best Years of Our Lives&quot;, and then the unwieldy titles continue with &quot;The Bridge on the River Kwai&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3404605365204027331/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/38-treasure-of-sierra-madre-1948.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3404605365204027331'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3404605365204027331'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/11/38-treasure-of-sierra-madre-1948.html' title='#38 The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (1948)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-kHKpbaaeyew/TqooYhv3ZjI/AAAAAAAAAIA/Cm4V2Auv7JA/s72-c/tr.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4620733169435806431</id><published>2011-10-24T08:25:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-24T08:25:27.238-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#39 Dr. Strangelove or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-8X8RD9K2NCA/TqHQY2a3ZXI/AAAAAAAAAHk/urPI6CW381U/s1600/bomb.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-8X8RD9K2NCA/TqHQY2a3ZXI/AAAAAAAAAHk/urPI6CW381U/s1600/bomb.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;American General Jack D. Ripper gives his executive officer Captain Lionel Mandrake a phone call.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Captain, we&#39;re initiating Wing Attack Plan R. This is not a drill.&quot; Repeat, over, roger, ten four.&lt;br /&gt;Mandrake is stunned, and also British so therefore a big pussy. &quot;Not a drill, sir? Are you certain?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;General Ripper is certain. Mandrake enters in the three letter and three number code into the giant computer-like thing,&lt;br /&gt;Up in the sky, several dozen American planes are hovering near Soviet airspace. They see the code and use their decoder booklet to confirm that indeed, Wing Attack Plan R has been initiated. The pilot of one of the planes is Maj TJ &quot;King&quot; Kong, who is Texan and wears a cowboy hat and says yee-haw and stuff.&lt;br /&gt;So, there&#39;s a big meeting in the War Room. President Merkin Muffley is there, along with Five Star General Buck Turgidson and dozens of other advisors with no lines.&lt;br /&gt;General Turgidson calmly and somewhat lackadaisically explains the sitch to the room as he chomps his gum:&lt;br /&gt;General Ripper suspects the commies are putting fluoride in our water to poison us. As a result, Gen Ripper initiated Wing Attack Plan R.&lt;br /&gt;President Muffley is not familiar with that plan.&lt;br /&gt;Ah well, that&#39;s because it&#39;s a secret plan. You see, the plan is an authorization for a dozen planes circling around Soviet airspace to then enter said airspace and drop their cargo on the twelve targets shown here on the Big Board. This plan has been authorized and said planes are now in Russian airspace.&lt;br /&gt;I&#39;m the President! &amp;nbsp;How come people under me can authorize a nuclear attack without my approval?!&lt;br /&gt;Well, Wing Attack Plan R authorizes any general to initiate it. It&#39;s in case the Russians manage to kill you and the other leading members of your cabinet before you can authorize an attack.&lt;br /&gt;But that didn&#39;t happen! &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m fine.&lt;br /&gt;Well, the plan is not without its faults. And no, they can&#39;t be recalled. Their radios are off, just in case the Russians try to trick them into not dropping their cargo. A three number and three letter code can be entered as a recall, but only General Ripper knows the code. He&#39;s holed-up in his base right now.&lt;br /&gt;Go send in some troops to get him and bring him here.&lt;br /&gt;Yes sir, but that could take awhile, and the bombs are going to drop in 18 minutes or so. Gen Turgidson lays down his plan to turn lemons into lemonade. Since nuclear war is now inevitable, let&#39;s attack with all we&#39;ve got! &amp;nbsp;We have the element of surprise! &amp;nbsp;We&#39;ll only lose 10-20 million on our side, and we&#39;ll be able to wipe them out completely.&lt;br /&gt;President Muffley wants the Soviet Ambassador to join them in the War Room.&lt;br /&gt;But, sir! &amp;nbsp;He&#39;ll know our plans! &amp;nbsp;He&#39;ll see the Big Board!&lt;br /&gt;But President Muffley gets his way. And as General Ripper&#39;s base is attacked by American troops, (and defended by other American troops who believe Ripper&#39;s lies that the attacking American troops are actually Soviet troops in disguise), the Soviet Ambassador Alexei de Sadeski is ushered into the War Room, where Gen. Turgidson fumes.&lt;br /&gt;Muffley gets the Soviet Premier on the phone, addresses him as &quot;Dmitri&quot;, and speaks to him as if they are a long suffering old married couple. &quot;Now then Dmitri, you know how we&#39;ve always talked about the possibility of something going wrong with the bomb...&quot; &amp;nbsp;And the line on the page doesn&#39;t do justice to how hilarious Peter Sellers&#39; reading is. Muffley goes on to tell the Premier exactly where each plane is going to drop their bombs and their flight plans. He ends the call saying he&#39;s sorry, but the Premier says he is even sorrier, and they argue for awhile about who is sorrier, then Dmitri wants to talk to Sadeski, They talk in Russian briefly, then hang up,&lt;br /&gt;Sadeski reveals that the Soviets have a Doomsday Device, which will go off automatically if they&#39;re attacked, and it will destroy the entire world. Muffley wonders how such a device is possible.&lt;br /&gt;A new character, a German in a wheelchair named Dr. Strangelove, wheels himself forward and explains that a Doomsday Device is indeed possible and he become giddy with the prospect. He adds that such a device isn&#39;t really a deterrent if it&#39;s kept a secret, and Sadeski sheepishly reveals that they were going to announce it to the world on Monday, and that the Premier loves surprises.&lt;br /&gt;As this goes on, Maj Kong and his plane are attacked by Soviet missiles. They&#39;re hit once, but manage to stay aloft, even though their cockpit is fried and no longer able to receive incoming messages.&lt;br /&gt;At Ripper&#39;s base, Lionel Mandrake tries to convince Ripper to give him the recall code, while sounds of a firefight occur outside. Ripper goes on at great length about fluoride and mind control and such and Mandrake realizes it&#39;s hopeless. The invading American troops finally take over the base and Ripper shoots himself to avoid being tortured for the codes. Mandrake however, discovers the code on Ripper&#39;s desk, but his held at gunpoint by the troops. He manages to get the leader to allow him to make a phone call to the President. The landline is out though, so Mandrake uses a pay phone. He doesn&#39;t have enough change, tries for a collect call but it&#39;s denied by the White House, so he gets a solider to shoot up a vending machine and grabs the change and finally makes the call.&lt;br /&gt;At the War Room, they celebrate the fact that the recall codes have been transmitted, and all the planes are turning around, except for the four the Soviets shot down. Oh, unfortunately the Soviets lied. They only shot down three planes. One plane was hit, but is still flying, and still headed for its target. Muffley gets on the horn with Dmitri again and tells him where that last plane will drop its bomb and wishes them good luck in shooting it down.&lt;br /&gt;Maj Kong discovers his plane is leaking fuel and won&#39;t reach the intended target, so his crew decides to drop it now. But the bomb doors have jammed. Kong leaves the cockpit and crawls down below. He climbs on top of one of the two bombs and takes a screwdriver to the controls. Finally, he manages to open the doors and the bombs drop, with him on top of one of them. He rides it down, waving his cowboy hat and yee-hawing all the way.&lt;br /&gt;Back at the War Room, Dr. Strangelove addresses Muffley as &quot;Mien Fuhrer&quot; and has trouble keeping his right arm from making a Nazi salute as he advises the President that several thousand people should live down in the mineshafts for the next one hundred years until the radiation from the Doomsday Device clears. The men should be chosen for their intelligence and strength and the women should be chosen for their beauty, and should outnumber the men 10-1, to ensure repopulation goes smoothly. DeSadeski holds a spy camera and surreptitiously takes pictures of the Big Board. Turgidson exclaims that the Ruskies can&#39;t beat us in the upcoming Mineshaft Race and we&#39;ve got to get started immediately. Muffley just sits slumped and defeated, taking it all in. Dr. Strangelove excitedly gets up from his wheelchair while discussing the various women he will procreate with, then exclaims, &lt;i&gt;&quot;Mien Fuhrer! &amp;nbsp;I can walk!&quot;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And then all over the world, the Doomsday Device goes off, nuclear bomb after nuclear bomb destroying everyone and everything as Till We Meet Again plays.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s at times weird and dark but not really that funny, and at other times flat-out hysterical. It&#39;s amazing how well the movie walks up to the line of farce without ever becoming farce. We know these events are ridiculous, but the characters take it seriously, and respond humorously but also &lt;i&gt;in-character&lt;/i&gt;, which is so rare for spoofs and satires. Also, the laws of physics are never broken, we&#39;re never in cartoon land. This isn&#39;t &lt;i&gt;Naked Gun &lt;/i&gt;or &lt;i&gt;Airplane. &lt;/i&gt;This is a tiny step above that, and that grounds the material and makes it real and believable and that much funnier.&amp;nbsp;Okay, actually Dr. Strangelove&#39;s own hand trying to do a Nazi salute against his will might&#39;ve gone into flat-out farce territory, but it was the only moment that didn&#39;t really work for me. Even Slim Pickens riding the bomb to the ground was great. I had seen that image before, and had kinda rolled my eyes, because it&#39;s so on the nose (American cowboy rides a nuclear bomb while waving his cowboy hat around) but I didn&#39;t realize how organic it was to the story. He didn&#39;t ride it down on purpose, after all.&lt;br /&gt;Turns out, everyone who watches movies is right. Peter Sellers is a fucking genius. All three of his characters are distinct, funny, and &lt;i&gt;real&lt;/i&gt;. The one-sided conversations the President has with &quot;Dmitri&quot; are so damn funny they had me laughing out loud multiple times. And the thing is, if you just read it, there aren&#39;t really many jokes. It&#39;s just all situational.&lt;br /&gt;I would also give George C Scott major props, because he&#39;s hysterical as well, but according to wiki, Kubrick tricked Scott into giving this performance by telling him to go &quot;over-the-top&quot; in practice takes that they would never use. And guess what? &amp;nbsp;They used them. Scott apparently was furious and vowed to never work with Kubrick again.&lt;br /&gt;And another bonus, it&#39;s only 95 minutes, which is basically a short film for Kubrick, who for my money, tends to go on way too long in most his movies. This is definitely my favorite Kubrick so far.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;The Treasure of Sierra Madre&quot; and then &quot;The Best Years of Our Lives&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4620733169435806431/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/39-dr-strangelove-or-how-i-learned-to.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4620733169435806431'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4620733169435806431'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/39-dr-strangelove-or-how-i-learned-to.html' title='#39 Dr. Strangelove or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-8X8RD9K2NCA/TqHQY2a3ZXI/AAAAAAAAAHk/urPI6CW381U/s72-c/bomb.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1717627518390343377</id><published>2011-10-23T16:25:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-23T16:34:41.031-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#40 The Sound of Music (1965)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4Sy_WXhDw1w/TqSJ0h0hiVI/AAAAAAAAAHw/RkjAe2QLq8Q/s1600/music.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; She grabs her habit and runs off.&lt;br /&gt;Down below at the nunnery, the nuns talk about how Maria is a problem at the nunnery because she is sometimes late and stuff, and sing about solving a problem like Maria. When Maria shows up, the head nun kicks her out and tells her that &quot;God&quot; (aka her and the other nuns) wants her to work as a governess for Mr. Georg von Trapp and his seven children.&lt;br /&gt;Maria sings about her insecurities at being able to care for so many children, then sings some more about how she has confidence. She goes to the house and Georg von Trapp blows a whistle and introduces her to his seven children. They introduce themselves: Doc, Happy Dopey, Sleepy, Flopsey, Mopsey, and lil&#39; Cottontail.&lt;br /&gt;They&#39;re hardcore mean to her and put a frog in her pocket and put a pine cone on her chair. At night, the eldest girl meets her secret boyfriend Rolfe outside and he sings to her all condescending about how she&#39;s only 16 going on 17 and is stupid and worthless and has a vagina and at the end of the song he kisses her and then runs away like a lunatic and she twirls around.&lt;br /&gt;At night she sneaks into the house through Maria&#39;s window and Maria catches her of course, but doesn&#39;t say anything. Then a storm comes and the six younger kids sneak into the room because the thunder scares them and Maria tells them to think about her favorite things like raindrops on roses and whiskers on kittens, which are actually really lame things. Then Georg comes in and he&#39;s grumpy and stuff. He tells the kids to go to bed, then tells Maria that he&#39;s going away for a month to visit his girlfriend the Baroness.&lt;br /&gt;While he&#39;s gone, Maria makes the children play-clothes out of drapes and then takes them picnicing and bicycling and they prance around she teaches them to sing Doe Rey Mi and they get in a canoe and say this is the bestest day ever in the whole wide world.&lt;br /&gt;Then Georg and the Baroness come home with some random third dude named Max and they arrive and see Maria and the kids rowing up in a boat on the lake and when they see their dad they stand up and the boat tips over! &amp;nbsp;WTFROFL!1!!&lt;br /&gt;Then the children go inside and Georg yells at Maria and she says he needs to be more loving and he tells her to pack her things and go and she says fine, then Georg hears his kids singing &quot;Doe a Deer&quot; to the Baroness and Max and his heart grows threes sizes that day and he sings along with them and loves them again. Phew. Max is some kind of agent or something and he wants to sign the Brady kids as a musical act but Georg refuses to allow them to sing in public. &amp;nbsp;He asks Maria to stay and she does. The kids and Maria put on a puppet show for Georg, the Baroness and Max, as Maria taught the children advanced puppetry at some point during the day in-between bicycling and singing.&lt;br /&gt;Then they all make cotton candy snowmen in the fields and literal sunshine beams from their asses as they snort dandelions and all get blown by Bambi. Finally, there&#39;s some big party at the von Trapp household and the children all do a performance to say goodnight to the guests. So long, farewell, auf wiedersehen, adieu. Of course, the movie&#39;s only half over, so they&#39;re a bunch of fucking liars.&lt;br /&gt;The Baroness is threatened by Maria and tells her that she can tell that she and Georg are in love with each other and Maria should leave because Georg is with her. Maria&#39;s all flustered and feels bad and runs back to the convent.&lt;br /&gt;Georg is sad but tells the kids Maria is gone and the Baroness is going to be their new mother and everybody please line up to awkwardly kiss the Baroness on the cheek and run up more screen time. Maria goes back to the nunnery, but the head nun still doesn&#39;t want her there, and when Maria says she left because she had feelings for Georg, the nun encourages her to go back and marry him. So Maria does, and the children laugh and sing and crap and then Georg is happy and tells the Baroness to hit the bricks and he tells Maria he wants to marry her. So he does.&lt;br /&gt;Yay! &amp;nbsp;Happy Ending! Oh, fuck. There&#39;s like forty five minutes left. What now? Oh yeah, the Nazis. &amp;nbsp;Fucking Nazis.&lt;br /&gt;So this is set during the beginning of WWII, did I mention that? And Hitler takes over Austria and the Nazis want to assure the people that nothing will change. They demand all households put up Nazi flags, but Georg rips his up. Max wants the children to put on a show, but Georg still doesn&#39;t want them to sing in public, and on the night of some big Talent Show, Georg gets a draft notice from the Nazis to join their army, and he and Maria and the kids try to sneak out of the house at night and flee to Switzerland. But the Nazis catch them pushing the car down the driveway, and Georg quickly says the car wouldn&#39;t start and they were actually just going to the Talent Show to perform. The Nazis think this will be a good way to show the Austrian people that nothing has changed during the bloodless takeover of their country and the Talent Show should go as planned. With Georg in it.&lt;br /&gt;Ha ha! He didn&#39;t want the kids to sing in public for no reason, and now he&#39;s doing it, too! &amp;nbsp;Oh, the contrived dramatic irony!&lt;br /&gt;So they sing and do &quot;Doe a Deer&quot; and &quot;So Long, &amp;nbsp;Farewell&quot; &lt;i&gt;again&lt;/i&gt;, and then win the contest but don&#39;t show up to get their prize because they&#39;ve fled again.
