The Nazis drive after them and Maria goes to her old convent and asks the nuns to help them hide. &lt;i&gt;(Psst. Maria. Asking the Catholic Church to help you hide from the Nazis may not be the best course of action. Just sayin&#39;). &lt;/i&gt;So they hide among the statues and the &amp;nbsp;Nazis search with flashlights and lil&#39; Cottontail wants to cheer everyone up by singing about her favorite things again and Maria shushes her and the Nazis search upstairs, but Rolfe, the eldest daughter&#39;s old boyfriend, hears something and sees them. He moves to blow his whistle, but Georg tells him he&#39;s not one of &lt;i&gt;them, &lt;/i&gt;not really, and to join them in fleeing. Rolfe is tempted, but finally sounds the alarm. Georg and the family drive off, and when the Nazis try to pursue, we learn the nuns stole some of their car parts.&lt;br /&gt;The last scene is the von Trapp family in Switzerland hiking some fucking hill and singing some more.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;A couple of the songs are mildly entertaining. The last scene at the church was mildly suspenseful. The kids sucked. The story sucked. The running time &lt;i&gt;suuuuucccked.&lt;/i&gt; The end was fine.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;One out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Dr Strangelove&quot; and then &quot;The Treasure of the Sierra Madre&quot;, both of which will be better than this as long as they&#39;re not totally fucking horrible.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1717627518390343377/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/40-sound-of-music-1965.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1717627518390343377'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1717627518390343377'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/40-sound-of-music-1965.html' title='#40 The Sound of Music (1965)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4Sy_WXhDw1w/TqSJ0h0hiVI/AAAAAAAAAHw/RkjAe2QLq8Q/s72-c/music.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7548065031013097189</id><published>2011-10-17T14:57:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-17T14:57:07.810-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#41 King Kong (1933)</title><content type='html'>&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7RbquTFULWo/TpxhWNxBQVI/AAAAAAAAAHc/cRycO8l3-sQ/s1600/king.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7RbquTFULWo/TpxhWNxBQVI/AAAAAAAAAHc/cRycO8l3-sQ/s1600/king.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Carl Denham makes moving pictures, see. Why, he&#39;s one of the best in the business. He&#39;s about to film a new top secret film right now.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;23 skidoo! &amp;nbsp;Buy bonds! Flappers! Better dead than red! Four score and twenty years ago! Et tu, Brutus. Etc.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The plan is to hire a ship and have the crew sail him and his movie crew out to a distant island. On the island are natives who maintain a huge wall that surrounds the middle of the island. What&#39;s on the other side of that wall? Well, never you mind about that, buckaroo. Never you mind.&lt;br /&gt;But he needs an actress to play the love interest in his film that has no other characters or script. And the movie studios won&#39;t let a girl go on a ship to a dangerous island because girls have cooties. So Carl finds a non-actress, a woman at a coffee shop named Ann Darrow (the girl, not the coffee shop) &amp;nbsp;and offers her the job.&lt;br /&gt;The First Mate, Jack Driscoll, is furious that a girl is on his ship and he yells at her a lot and she tries not to get her girl juice on him, but can&#39;t help it.&lt;br /&gt;After six weeks, they reach the island, and Carl&#39;s crew sneak off the boat and creep up to see a bunch of natives doing a ritualistic dance. They are actually black actors, to my relief, and not white people with shoe polish. Carl films them from behind the bushes, planning to make them part of the movie...somehow...but they catch him and point their spears at the crew and say &quot;oonga bonga&quot; and Carl&#39;s AD fortunately speaks their pretend language and oongas back at them interprets that they want to rape and pillage all over the blonde girl.&lt;br /&gt;Carl says no way, and they leave and go back on the boat. On the deck, Jack tells Ann he&#39;s glad she&#39;s safe and there&#39;s no way she&#39;s going back on the island to film anymore, no matter what Carl says. Then they crank the Olden Times WTF meter up to 11 with this exchange:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Ann: &lt;/b&gt;You care about me? But Jack, you hate women!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Jack:&lt;/b&gt; Yeah, but you ain&#39;t &#39;women&#39;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I...don&#39;t know.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So Jack leaves the deck and the natives appear over the side of the boat and grab Ann and pull her into the water. They go back to shore and tie her up and continue on, chanting and dancing and drafting socialistic health care bills and they tie her up and put her on the other side of the giant wall.&lt;br /&gt;The chanting and dancing stops and they wait. Something approaches. What could it be?&lt;br /&gt;Why it&#39;s a giant claymation ape-like thing! &amp;nbsp;Ann sees it and screams her head off. King Kong grabs her and is magically able to instantly turn her into claymation, too! Amazing! He runs off with her.&lt;br /&gt;Back on the boat, Jack goes to Ann&#39;s room too...say goodnight (?)...and knocks on the door. No answer. He discovers she&#39;s not on the ship and he Carl, and the movie crew row ashore and to rescue her. They go deep into the jungle and discover several scary dinosaurs who eat several of them. Meanwhile, Kong takes Ann back to his cave atop a cliff for a little private time. He looks in her eyes. Andy Serkis must be having an off day, because his expression is quite unreadable. Finally, he just leaves her there and goes stomping off randomly. He happens upon the men crossing a fallen tree that&#39;s made a makeshift bridge. He picks up the tree and flings it. Everyone goes flying and dies horribly, much as my GI Joes often did. &amp;nbsp;Everyone but Carl and Jack ,that is. They&#39;ve managed to jump off the tree before Kong threw it.&lt;br /&gt;Carl goes back to the ship to get knockout gas, while Jack follows Kong&#39;s trail to try to rescue Ann. Kong fights several dino monsters who try to eat Ann and Ann screams &lt;i&gt;a lot&lt;/i&gt;, constantly while he does so. When he&#39;s distracted, Jack rescues her and they run off. Kong stomps after them, and even after Jack and Ann run through the door in the wall, Kong busts through it, breaking the native&#39;s homes and eating them as spirit moves him.&lt;br /&gt;But Carl saves the day by throwing the knockout gas and putting Kong out.&lt;br /&gt;The ship&#39;s crew just want to leave, now, but Carl insists they tie up Kong and put him on the boat so they can make money off him back home. Somehow they do this, despite the logistics being totally impossible.&lt;br /&gt;Back in New York, the elitist liberals all gather in their fancy clothes to come and gawk at the giant ape. Carl bills the show as &quot;Beauty and the Beast&quot; and opens the curtains on the world&#39;s biggest stage to reveal Kong all chained up. Don&#39;t worry, those chains will hold. Kong sees Ann and freaks out and breaks the chains and everyone runs and screams and Kong goes marching down the street and Jack and Ann run away and I guess go into a random building and talk about how they&#39;re totally safe now here on the twentieth floor. And Kong randomly climbs that same building, looking in all the windows for Ann. In one bit of hilarious dark comedy, he sees a woman asleep in her bed, and busts his hand through the window, grabs her, pulls her outside, sees that she&#39;s not Ann, and then casually tosses her to her death, screaming all the way. What a way to wake up. But then he finds Ann, and puts his hand through the window again. Jack tries to fight him off with a chair, but the chair breaks harmlessly and Jack goes splat on the floor. Heh. Stupid Jack.&lt;br /&gt;So Kong grabs Ann and naturally climbs the Empire State Building because it&#39;s more dramatic than just running away and the planes come and shoot him down and Carl gets to say &quot;it was beauty killed the beast&quot; in a far less melodramatic reading than Jack Black&#39;s.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Not anywhere near as bad as I was expecting. Kudos especially to whoever conceived of this now very familiar story. It&#39;s really quite fun and (at the time) very original. I had already seen Peter Jackson&#39;s movie, and it&#39;s a testament to the original story that Jackson basically didn&#39;t change anything at all. Although that did make this kind of boring to watch. The effects were...what they were. Not as bad as what I was expecting, either. And many times Kong ate people and picked them up and you could see they really went to the trouble to make a giant Kong head and hand, both of which had to move, and I&#39;m sure that wasn&#39;t easy. The acting was a bit dodgy, and Fay Wray&#39;s scream was unbelievably annoying, though. It also wouldn&#39;t have hurt them to develop any other characters besides Jack, Carl, and Ann. But whatever. It&#39;s certainly watchable, over all.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;The Sound of Music&quot; and then one I&#39;ve been waiting for...&quot;Dr. Strangelove&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7548065031013097189/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/41-king-kong-1933.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7548065031013097189'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7548065031013097189'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/41-king-kong-1933.html' title='#41 King Kong (1933)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7RbquTFULWo/TpxhWNxBQVI/AAAAAAAAAHc/cRycO8l3-sQ/s72-c/king.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-925039118431258238</id><published>2011-10-16T17:38:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-16T17:38:30.418-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#42 Bonnie and Clyde (1967)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-wT1XznrufjY/Tpopn-3iRCI/AAAAAAAAAHM/JC1-5_Ch_m0/s1600/bonnie.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-wT1XznrufjY/Tpopn-3iRCI/AAAAAAAAAHM/JC1-5_Ch_m0/s1600/bonnie.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;In the 1930&#39;s, during The Great Depression, Clyde Barrow was a small-time bank robbing crook. He wasn&#39;t particularly good or memorable as a crook, and history would&#39;ve long forgotten him, were it not for his choice of partner in crime.&lt;br /&gt;Bonnie Parker was a spoiled, bored child of apathetic parents and had an apparently busted moral compass.&lt;br /&gt;They Meet Cute when Bonnie catches Clyde trying to steal her mother&#39;s car. She playfully reproaches him, but isn&#39;t really upset, and they go riding off in it together. Clyde tells her he&#39;s a bank robber, but she doesn&#39;t believe him, so pulls a job in town right in front of her. They go speeding off, fleeing the pursing bank employees.&lt;br /&gt;They pull off into a field to count the loot, and Bonnie&#39;s so hot and bothered, she starts making out with Clyde right then and there. He reciprocates begrudgingly, and when it becomes clear she wants to round all the bases he gently and then not-so gently rebuffs her. She&#39;s embarrassed, and just wants to go home. He tells her that he doesn&#39;t want her to go home. So she doesn&#39;t.&lt;br /&gt;They travel the countryside for awhile, stopping off occasionally for money that isn&#39;t theirs and swapping cars when it seems like it&#39;s time. Once, while robbing a convenience store, Clyde is attacked from behind by a customer, and they barely escape, after Clyde&#39;s forced to beat the guy senseless. They&#39;re both genuinely confused. They met the man no harm, why&#39;d he have to make it so difficult?&lt;br /&gt;They decide they need to recruit a getaway driver, so they literally take their car in for repairs and tell the car mechanic that they rob banks, and would he like to join them? Yes, he would. That was...remarkably easy.&lt;br /&gt;The mechanic&#39;s a youngish 18 or so, named C.W. Moss, and he agrees to wait outside a bank while Bonnie and Clyde enter it. But a car comes up behind C.W., who is blocking the road and honks at him. C.W. is nothing if not a courteous driver, and politely parallel parks about a block away.&lt;br /&gt;In my lifetime, I have driven a getaway car exactly zero times, and yet I can anticipate a problem here.&lt;br /&gt;Sure enough, our &quot;heroes&quot; come tearing out of the bank and there&#39;s no car. They run around desperately, then hear C.W. honking. A banker runs out with a gun. Some cops run up. C.W.&#39;s still trying to get out of his spot, wedged between two other cars. Finally, he does so, but not after Clyde winds up shooting and killing a bank employee. They get away, but Clyde declares they need to lay low somewhere out of state until the heat dies down.&lt;br /&gt;They wind up visiting Clyde&#39;s brother Buck and his shrill and unlovely wife, Blanche. Buck&#39;s a recent parolee and he knows a perfect cabin where they can all hang out for the winter. Blanche is annoying and clingy and hates Bonnie on site, who feels mutually.&lt;br /&gt;They hide out in some cabin in the outskirts of town, but still have groceries delivered. Meanwhile, the radio reports that the bank robber/killer was one Clyde Barrow, and he was with an unidentified blonde and driver. The grocery delivery boy is suspicious when he sees the windows covered with cardboard and when Bonnie won&#39;t let him bring the groceries inside.&lt;br /&gt;The next thing you know, a couple of cop cars pull up outside the cabin. Clyde motions for everyone to be quiet and play it cool, but immediately Blanche starts screaming. The cops take that as a sign to start shooting, naturally. Buck, Clyde, C.W., and Bonnie shoot their way out the door, while Blanche literally just runs and screams while flapping her arms around. Buck kills a couple cops. They all jump in the car and speed off, picking up Blanche who has run down the road. Bonnie screams at her and she screams back and Clyde says family doesn&#39;t yell at family and Buck says they&#39;re all in this now.&lt;br /&gt;After a while on the run and pulling jobs, a Texas lawman tries to ambush them, but is caught by Buck. They tie him up and take pictures with him in ridiculous poses, &amp;nbsp;with Bonnie pretending to smoke a cigar and stroke his face. Everyone&#39;s having a grand old time. They leave him tied up with the roll of film in his pocket.&lt;br /&gt;The papers call them the &quot;Barrow Gang&quot;, and give them false credit for many jobs they didn&#39;t even pull, and eventually Bonnie is positively identified as well as Buck and Blanche. Only C.W.&#39;s identity is a secret to the public.&lt;br /&gt;Bonnie grows despondent with the new shitty life she&#39;s made for herself. She&#39;s homesick for her family, and still wonders why Clyde won&#39;t have sex with her. In a heartbreaking scene, Bonnie manages to convince Clyde to let her visit her family, so Bonnie&#39;s mom and siblings meet her in an open field where Clyde tells Bonnie&#39;s mom that he takes real good care of her and won&#39;t let her go on any robberies that seem too dangerous and one day they&#39;ll retire and she and Bonnie can be neighbors. Mom cuts through the tremendous pile of bullshit Clyde&#39;s slinging and says she hopes that Bonnie is never her neighbor, because that would mean the cops could find her and kill her. Then she senses that that&#39;s the best exit line possible, and leaves.&lt;br /&gt;One night, they&#39;re staying in a cheap motel and Bonnie asks Clyde that if they could wipe the slate clean and start over, would he do it? Clyde says yes, no doubt. First thing he&#39;d do differently, is never commit any robberies in his home state. Always go across the border. &amp;nbsp;Clyde seems to have missed the point of the question.&lt;br /&gt;That same night, C.W. and Blanche go into town for supplies and the store keeper sees a gun on C.W.&#39;s hip. He narrows his eyes forebodingly. &lt;br /&gt;A bit later, the cops pull up to the motel silently. They knock on Buck and Blanche&#39;s door. Everyone panics. Buck and Clyde burst out shooting. There&#39;s chaos as everyone races to the car. Several cops are shot. One manages to get Buck in the head. He goes down. Blanche screams even louder. She and Clyde drag him into the car. The window next to Blanche bursts, shattering glass and cutting her face. Bonnie, in the driver&#39;s seat, races off.&lt;br /&gt;They drive for a bit and manage to lose the pursing cops. They speed off into the woods. Buck&#39;s muttering incoherent nonsense, but still alive. They finally pull off into a field and get out. They bandage up Buck&#39;s face the best they can, and Blanche turns her gaze to the heavens and with blood streaming down her face, begs God to save her husband&#39;s life. God&#39;s response is straight-up Old Testament, as Blanche suddenly begins screaming anew. &quot;I&#39;M BLIND! &amp;nbsp;I&#39;M BLIND!&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Bonnie crawls over to her and holds her as she weeps.&lt;br /&gt;The next morning, Buck is dead, and Blanche lay curled up in Bonnie&#39;s arms, sunglasses on her face.&lt;br /&gt;Aaand the cops are back. They start shooting on site, and Bonnie fully abandons blind Blanche and jumps in the car with Clyde and C.W.&lt;br /&gt;Clyde gets shot in the arm while driving and crashes the car about half a mile away. The three of them jump out and begin running in earnest. They reach a river bank. Bonnie gets shot in the should. She cries out, but they keep going. Eventually, somehow they get away.&lt;br /&gt;After traveling for awhile, they steal another car and C.W. drives them to his father&#39;s house. The father is shocked to find two shot up people traveling with his son, but takes them in anyway.&lt;br /&gt;In the meantime, an arrested Blanche is questioned by the very Texas lawman who they tied up months earlier. He asks Blanche the name of the fifth member, the getaway driver, and she gives it up freely, without even realizing the implications.&lt;br /&gt;After more time has passed, Bonnie and Clyde are healed mostly from their gunshot wounds, and agree amongst themselves to quit the life. You know, no harm done and all. They even finally have sex, which was surprising because I figured Clyde was impotent.&lt;br /&gt;They decide to go into town the next day with C.W. and get supplies. C.W.&#39;s dad tells C.W. to ditch them once they get into town. He&#39;s made a deal with the police. C.W. will only get a few years if he can bring the cops Bonnie and Clyde. C.W. confidently says that no one will ever get them.&lt;br /&gt;But in town, he follows his father&#39;s orders and gets lost. Bonnie and Clyde attempt to search for him, but then see a cop car in town and decide to drive back home to the father&#39;s farm and pick C.W. up later.&lt;br /&gt;On the way home, they see C.W.&#39;s father on the side of the road. His hood&#39;s up, and he&#39;s waving for help. Clyde pulls over and walks over to him. Something wrong with your car?&lt;br /&gt;C.W.&#39;s father nods, then suddenly throws himself on the ground and rolls under his car. Clyde looks confused. A flock of birds suddenly takes flight. He looks up. Sees about twenty lawmen emerge from the bushes. They fire, engulfing both lovers with enough bullets to take out a T-9000.&lt;br /&gt;The end.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;Or is it?&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Yes.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;There&#39;s sort of a crushing, heavy feeling of inevitable shit that&#39;s hovering over the entire proceedings. However you feel about these kinds of movies, where there&#39;s no real &quot;heroes&quot; and where we&#39;re asked to identify with the villains, will obviously influence your enjoyment. This isn&#39;t a Walter White type deal either, where our anti-hero becomes a flat-out villain over time; these people are just bad from the start. So you have to look at this as a character study, and it works really well as that. I like these types of movies, where you watch people make bad decisions, one after another in a slow-moving car wreck kind of way. And despite it all, some of the characters do engender a small amount of sympathy, particularly Bonnie and C.W., who both became enamored of Clyde and didn&#39;t really understand the implications of the lives they were choosing until it was too late. (And C.W. never really did). And I could definitely see how a character as whiny as Blanche would be off-putting to many, but that&#39;s her function in the story. Everything is going pretty okay for the group until she and Buck enter the picture and she winds up ruining everything by screaming and giving them all away. Estelle Parsons (Roseann&#39;s mom on &lt;i&gt;Roseanne&lt;/i&gt;) really knocks it out of the park in this role, and deserves her Oscar win. The scene where she goes blind is the most chilling in the whole movie.&lt;br /&gt;I was also pleasantly surprised that it turned out to be an ensemble movie, with five gangsters instead of two, like I expected. No particular reason, I just like ensemble movies best. Especially if some monster is killing them off one by one. Those are awesome.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;King Kong&quot;, and then the hills come alive and I throw myself down them in a vain attempt to avoid &quot;The Sound of Music&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/925039118431258238/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/42-bonnie-and-clyde-1967.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/925039118431258238'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/925039118431258238'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/42-bonnie-and-clyde-1967.html' title='#42 Bonnie and Clyde (1967)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-wT1XznrufjY/Tpopn-3iRCI/AAAAAAAAAHM/JC1-5_Ch_m0/s72-c/bonnie.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7942897174898583979</id><published>2011-10-09T17:10:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-09T17:10:18.915-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#43 Midnight Cowboy (1969)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-IF69SywHd7g/TpEVa0oE2JI/AAAAAAAAAHI/yKuYql73vxA/s1600/cowboy.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-IF69SywHd7g/TpEVa0oE2JI/AAAAAAAAAHI/yKuYql73vxA/s1600/cowboy.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Joe Buck lives in Texas, works at a diner, lives a life of quiet desperation, deserves something more. Joe Buck wants out. He plans to go to New York City and become a hustler, bedding beautiful, older rich women. He dons his cowboy hat and brown leather jacket with those frilly things and his trusty boots. He&#39;s got a cowskin suitcase and a small radio and a bus ticket. He&#39;s running from his life, fast as he can, but with a smile. The bus ride is long and uncomfortable, and people are sometimes rude to him &lt;i&gt;(in the middle of the night, he sits next to an old lady who has her overhead light on and he reaches up to turn it off and she snaps, &quot;I want it on!&quot; and I laugh so hard I have a coughing fit) &lt;/i&gt;but he endures it all because the good life, a life without worries or horrible memories is just around the corner.&lt;br /&gt;He arrives in New York, gets a shitty hotel, unwisely overtips the bellboy, flexes shirtless in the cracked mirror, then goes out on the town. New York is scary and exciting and the chance to start over is real. After several failed attempts to hit on older women, one finally asks him up to her apartment. After sex, she asks for cab fare to get across town. Joe awkwardly says he was kind of hoping she&#39;d be giving him money, on account of...you know...The woman bursts into tears &quot;that&#39;s what you think of me?! I&#39;m so ugly I&#39;d have to pay for it?!&quot; and Joe counters no that&#39;s not it at all, so sorry, here&#39;s cab fare, five bucks okay? Ten? Twenty? Okay, I&#39;ll be going now.&lt;br /&gt;Joe goes to a local bar and sits next to an ugly, squirrelly cripple named Rico Rizzo. He tells Rizzo that he&#39;s attempting to make a living as a hustler, but has had no luck. Rizzo promises to set him up with a pimp, for a nominal fee. A scuzzy gay guy approaches and calls Rizzo &quot;Ratso&quot;, and warns Joe that he&#39;s only after his money. Rizzo runs the guy off, complaining loudly at the faggots overrunning the city. Rizzo charges Joe twenty bucks for his services and leads him to an apartment where the pimp lives. &lt;b&gt;&quot;Hey! &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m walking here! &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m walking here!&quot;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Joe&#39;s so excited, he promises to give Rizzo a cut of his future earnings, and wants to know where Rizzo lives. Rizzo gives him the name of a hotel, then splits.&lt;br /&gt;Joe goes inside the apartment, and an earnest bald man tells him he&#39;s &quot;perfect&quot; and they&#39;re going to achieve a lot together. So let&#39;s get on our knees! Knees?&lt;br /&gt;The bald man opens his closet to reveals a gaudy, glittery crucifixion and demands Joe pray with him. Joe finally realizes he&#39;s been had, and bolts out of the apartment, but Rizzo is nowhere to be found.&lt;br /&gt;The days turn into weeks and finally Joe&#39;s out of money and locked out of his hotel. He roams the streets of New York, unable to find any willing women. He looks into a public bathroom mirror and says, &quot;you know what you have to do&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;He finally puts the cowboy outfit to good use and goes trolling into the homosexual neighborhoods. Nearly immediately, a teen with dorky glasses (Bob Balaban! Wow, he&#39;s young!) gives him a nod. They go into a movie theatre. The teen nuzzles his neck and puts his arm around Joe, then lowers his head. Joe closes his eyes and thinks of Annie, his one true love and the life they once and together before everything was destroyed.&lt;br /&gt;After it&#39;s over, the teen says he has no money. Enraged, Joe throws him against a mirror, threatens to beat him, then takes his watch. The kid says please don&#39;t take my watch, my parents will kill me! Joe relents, stomping out of the bathroom with a glare.&lt;br /&gt;Worst. Whore. Ever.&lt;br /&gt;Then one day, Joe happens to see Rizzo in a diner. He grabs him, demands his money back, but of course it&#39;s gone now, Joe agrees that Rizzo is a rat like the faggot said, Ratso is your name!&lt;br /&gt;Ratso says he can come home with him, as an apology he can live with him for a while. He leads Joe to an abandoned building, behind a chain link fence. Ratso lives in a squalid, hollowed-out seedy enclave. They&#39;re no lights or windows, but there&#39;s a hot plate and a bed and Joe just really needs somewhere to sleep.&lt;br /&gt;Over the weeks and months, an uneasy alliance forms. Ratso teaches Joe the fine art of low-level thievery. They pick pockets, steal food from fruit stands and the like. They barely eke out an existence that is focused entirely on the next meal, the next need. Finally, they hatch a plan for Joe to make money hustling. They stand outside an escort service, and when a man receives an assignment on a slip of paper, Ratso steals it from him and sends Joe there instead. Joe excitedly walks into the hotel where the woman is staying, and Ratso believes that this is their ticket to a better life. He imagines building a future and a life with Joe somewhere else, down south, in Florida. They&#39;ll run on the beach together, be together forever, leave all this behind. But the lady takes one look at weirdo cowboy Joe and throws him out. Back to square one.&lt;br /&gt;Times get rougher. Winter comes. Ratso&#39;s cough gets worse and worse and they get hungrier and hungrier. Ratso&#39;s having more trouble walking, standing.&lt;br /&gt;Some weirdos approach Joe in the diner and take his picture. They then give him a piece of paper, which is an invitation to a party in a loft that night. Ratso scoffs that &quot;guys like us&quot; don&#39;t get invited places, and Joe reminds him that &lt;i&gt;he&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;wasn&#39;t invited. Ratso&#39;s wounded, desperate and angrily lashes out. Joe backtracks, apologizes, says they&#39;ll go together and if the people don&#39;t like it, they&#39;ll leave together. Outside the loft, Ratso has trouble making it up the stairs. He&#39;s sweating, his hair&#39;s mussed. Joe straightens out his hair tenderly. Ratso holds him for balance. Just holds him. They gently ascend the staircase and find themselves at a crazy party filled with the assorted fruits and nuts and Andy Warhol castoffs. There are dozens of people running about snapping pics, taking drugs, looking at art, drinking and eating. Drinking and eating. There&#39;s a table out with food. Lots and lots of food. Ratso starts filling his pockets, while Joe begins to socialize. He&#39;s given a joint and hilariously doesn&#39;t puff puff give, thinking it to be a regular cigarette. Soon Joe is very high, and hits on a woman. Ratso steps in and sets up a fee for Joe&#39;s services; she wants to know if they&#39;re a couple. Joe goes home with the woman as Ratso slips and falls down the stairs he previously could barely climb. Hey fella, you fell. Ratso, are you all right? &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m fine. Go. Just go.&lt;br /&gt;Joe can&#39;t get it up at first, but when she calls him gay he angrily gets the job done. She gives him twenty and sets him up with another woman on Thursday.&lt;br /&gt;Joe excitedly comes home with food and medicine for Ratso and tells him things are finally taking off! Ratso&#39;s sweating and terrified. He tells Joe he can&#39;t walk. Joe says he&#39;ll get a doctor. No doctors! I need to go down South. Down to Florida! Take me to Florida. Joe complains that just when he&#39;s finally starting to make it, things fall apart again.&lt;br /&gt;He goes out that night, finds an old man and they go up to a hotel room. The old man says he can&#39;t hurt his wife this way, never mind, but Joe insists that he be paid. The man offers ten bucks, but Joe screams that&#39;s not enough!. He beats the man and steals all his money.&lt;br /&gt;He carries Ratso in his arms, and they board the bus together. Through tears, Ratso begs him: when we get to Florida, no one there will know my name&#39;s Ratso. No one will call me that. Please don&#39;t tell them that name. Tell them Rico. My name is Rico. Joe promises that he&#39;ll call him Rico.&lt;br /&gt;They reach Florida, just a few hours away from their final stop in Miami. Joe gets off the bus, and buys some regular clothes. The shopkeeper asks him where he&#39;s from and he says New York. He throws away all his cowboy shit, and gets back on the bus.&lt;br /&gt;You know, Ratso? I mean, Rico. I don&#39;t want to be a hustler anymore. I can get a regular job. We can have a good life down here.&lt;br /&gt;But Rico&#39;s gone.&lt;br /&gt;Joe tells the bus driver, who is less than devastated and says they might as well ride into Miami and handle it there. The other passengers gawk at Rico&#39;s body. Joe pushes his eyes closed, then puts his arm around his friend defiantly, proudly. The bus rolls on.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;This movie hit me on a number of levels. First, the acting is top notch, but Voight and Hoffman are amazing. Hoffman in particular is entirely sympathetic in a role that might evoke only revulsion in the audience if played wrongly. The entire story is so great! The friendship, or perhaps love, that evolves between the two is natural and organic and utterly engrossing, in part because of their drastic physical and personality differences. The movie&#39;s hard to watch a times, you want to step in a grab them and tell them to fucking shape up already, but all you can do is watch in horror and hope that somehow they figure it out. The directing was great too. Throughout the movie, we get rapid flashbacks&amp;nbsp;of the horrible life Joe led, a life that led him to believe that his only real option was to go far away and sell his body for money. &amp;nbsp;We see&amp;nbsp;how his mother abandoned him and he grandmother had man after man in the house, and later how he and his girlfriend were caught having sex in a car and some thugs beat and raped Joe in front of her. We get glimpses &amp;nbsp;And he winds up suffering so much, yet somehow is always so optimistic and hopeful. The beginning of the movie with that great theme song &quot;Everybody&#39;s Talking At Me&quot; intercut with depressing images of Joe&#39;s home life was a great ironic juxtaposition that set the tone for this weird, off kilter and very daring for its time movie. It&#39;s rated X, but it&#39;s really only an R by our standards. The gay content is what put it over the top back then.&lt;br /&gt;And talking about that part. Though by today&#39;s standards, the movie can hardly be seen as gay friendly, I think Rizzo was pretty clearly gay and while we&#39;re meant to pity him and be disgusted by him to some degree, there&#39;s no denying his basic humanity, which was a pretty radical idea to mainstream America in 1969. Though I doubt mainstream America saw this freaky movie.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Bonnie and Clyde&quot;, which I&#39;m pretty excited about and then 1933&#39;s &quot;King Kong&quot;, which I&#39;m not.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7942897174898583979/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/43-midnight-cowboy-1969.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7942897174898583979'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7942897174898583979'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/43-midnight-cowboy-1969.html' title='#43 Midnight Cowboy (1969)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-IF69SywHd7g/TpEVa0oE2JI/AAAAAAAAAHI/yKuYql73vxA/s72-c/cowboy.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8796638488440214736</id><published>2011-10-08T09:47:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-08T15:34:45.470-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#44 The Philadelphia Story (1940)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-FNjNm_oBcok/To_OgZOmWtI/AAAAAAAAAHE/jIOQG5Xhjrc/s1600/hee.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-FNjNm_oBcok/To_OgZOmWtI/AAAAAAAAAHE/jIOQG5Xhjrc/s1600/hee.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;We start our screwball comedy with the unhappily married C.K Dexter Haven and his wife, Tracy Lord. They&#39;re fighting. She breaks his golf club. He palms her face and slams her into the ground. No, really. He does. And the music does this sad trombone noise. Wocka Wocka!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Two years later, Dexter and Tracy are divorced, and Tracy&#39;s getting remarried to George Kittredge. It&#39;s two days before the wedding, and Tracy&#39;s mother and much younger sister are helping her get everything ready. Tracy&#39;s sister hates George and wants Tracy to remarry Dexter. Tracy&#39;s sister is like eight and totally precocious and says grown up things, like half of movie children and none of actual children. &amp;nbsp;The Lords are super-uber rich, and the tabloids are interested in their wedding. Why rumor has it, an equally rich friend of theirs got married recently, and some tabloid photogs snuck into the wedding and snapped some pictures. Tracy&#39;s appalled that such a breach of etiquette would occur. I mean, really! &amp;nbsp;Could you imagine living in such a world?!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Cut to the tabloid offices of Harvey Levin and associates. Macaulay Connor and his gal Liz are the top tabloid photographers, and their boss Mr. Kidd wants them to sneak into Tracy&#39;s wedding somehow and get some good shots. They say there&#39;s no way they&#39;ll be able to get in, but Mr. Kidd has their ace in the hole. C.K. Dexter Haven will introduce them as friends of the family and get the Lords to allow them to stay in the home over the weekend.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They show up, and Dexter flirts with Tracy and disparages the new husband and the repartee is witty. Tracy doesn&#39;t believe the cover story, and threatens to throw Mac and Liz out, so Dexter blackmails her instead. He says he has info that proves her father is cheating on her mother with a dancer in New York, and he&#39;ll publish that story unless she lets Mac and Liz cover the wedding for the magazine. So, all three Lords women go along with this, making nice with Mac and Liz, pretending to believe their cover story and Liz keeps snapping pics (winding the camera after every shot. Remember that? &amp;nbsp;Winding?), infuriating Tracy.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They decide to go swimming, and Tracy and Mac flirt after she reads some of his poetry, until Dexter shows up again and she and Dexter fight the fight of two people who truly have some issues to work through and the upshot is, Dexter is resentful at Tracy for being a cold bitch and Tracy is resentful at Dexter for being such a drunken loser that he forced her to be a cold bitch. It&#39;s a pretty cool conversation, and at this point in the movie I honestly didn&#39;t know which guy she&#39;d end up with.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The next day, the father Lord shows up and says enough of this balderdash, we&#39;re telling them the truth, and Tracy says well you&#39;re the reason we&#39;re in this mess and these are the things her father says:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;1) I love your mother, because unlike most women, she understands that when a man is a philanderer, it&#39;s not a reflection on how he feels about her&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;2) The reason why I&#39;ve sought the affections of a younger woman is because you, my daughter, are so unaffectionate&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;3) When you chastise me for cheating on your mother, you sound like a jealous wife&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;4) You&#39;re a perfectly lovely women, but you lack an understanding heart.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;And Tracy takes this in and has tears in her eyes and feels bad because his words struck a chord.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Yes, that&#39;s right. The movie is not making the case that Papa Lord is a sick fuck, it is saying &lt;i&gt;that he has a point.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Wow.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Wow, Olden Times. Wow.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Anyway, moving on. That night, there&#39;s a rehearsal dinner for the wedding, and Mac and Liz are there and Liz is still getting shots, and Tracy decides to get sloppy drunk. She slobbers all over George, who is disgusted and wants to leave. Then Tracy starts slow dancing with Mac and says she feels so free in his arms and begs him to tell her that she has an understanding heart. &lt;i&gt;Run, Mac! &amp;nbsp;Run like the wind!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;But he doesn&#39;t run, and he gets drunk, too, and finally George drags her away, and Mac decides to go to Dexter&#39;s house. He shows up shitfaced and Dexter answers in his robe, and dare I hope this love triangle becomes truly three-sided? Alas no, Mac just gets drunker and stupider and then confesses that he has blackmail info on Mr. Kidd and spills it to Dexter and Dexter says he&#39;ll blackmail Kidd and then he won&#39;t be able to blackmail Tracy with the info about her wonderful father and then Mac and Liz won&#39;t have to cover the wedding. Mac is down with this because he likes Tracy, now.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Then Liz shows up looking for Mac. &amp;nbsp;Dexter wants her to type up the blackmail info on Kidd. Liz says she can&#39;t right now, because she&#39;s got Tracy in the car and she&#39;s drunk and has to go home. Mac says he&#39;ll take her home.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So they get back to the Lord house, and Tracy reveals she and George fought and then she and Mac slow dance, and eventually kiss and then run off to the changing rooms to go swimming. Or &quot;swimming&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Or perhaps just swimming. It&#39;s unclear.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The next morning, the day of the wedding, George comes to find her and sees two champagne glasses and clothes strewn about and then Dexter shows up and they&#39;re both confused, and then see Mac and Tracy approaching. Mac is carrying Tracy in his arms and she&#39;s passed out and he&#39;s singing &quot;Somewhere Over the Rainbow&quot;&lt;i&gt; (Wizard of Oz! &lt;/i&gt;AFI #10! &amp;nbsp;Can&#39;t wait!)&lt;i&gt;. &lt;/i&gt;She nuzzles his neck and Dexter&#39;s smirking while George is fuming and then Mac carries her upstairs to her room and when he comes back down, George goes to punch him, but Dexter steps in and says he&#39;s still technically the keeper of Tracy&#39;s honor/vagina and punches Mac instead. George stomps off, and Dexter says he did it because he&#39;d hit a lot lighter than George.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So, later in the day, Tracy wakes up and they&#39;re prepping the backyard for the reception and everyone&#39;s there for some reason, and Tracy has no memory of the night before until her little sister says she saw her swimming with Mac and Tracy then thinks she slept with Mac and George comes in and says the wedding&#39;s off and then Mac says he only kissed her and swam with her and George says okay that&#39;s fine then, and Tracy says no, you thought I wasn&#39;t virtuous and you obviously don&#39;t think much of me so hit the bricks. And George points out that she &lt;i&gt;also&lt;/i&gt; thought that she slept with Mac, but Tracy comes back with &quot;you should&#39;ve thought more of me than even I thought of me&quot;, which is a pretty good one, really. So George leaves.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Tracy realizes the house is filled with guests expecting a wedding and she&#39;s mortified and Mac says, &quot;I&#39;ll marry you!&quot; and she turns him down and says Liz would feel bad. Did I mention Liz is standing right there? Because she is. So Tracy literally grabs Mac by the shoulders and kind of pushes him towards Liz and he goes willingly and Liz hugs him and smiles, thrilled that the one he wanted has literally pushed him into her arms. I think my brain is breaking.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So Tracy says still though, it&#39;s really embarrassing because all these people are expecting a wedding, and Dexter says why don&#39;t we give them one and they ask Mac and Liz to be the Maid of Honor and Best Man. They go inside and tell the preacher to marry them. He does, and man that must&#39;ve been really shitty and confusing for George&#39;s family and friends sitting there.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Wow, I don&#39;t know. On the one hand, the writing&#39;s very clever, there&#39;s some great one-liners, and Hepburn and Stewart in particular are really great. There&#39;s some fun stuff they explore with class differences, and how Mac and Liz are jealous of the decadent lifestyle the Lords live, and the movie is careful to have both Tracy and Dexter point out how class differences matter less nowadays than a person&#39;s character. I&#39;m assuming this talk had some sort of cultural relevance in 1940 and it&#39;s cool that they put it in there. Tracy&#39;s character arc is strong, too, and her journey towards becoming a more affectionate person is believable.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;BUT-there&#39;s some serious WTF stuff in here, stuff that I don&#39;t think can all be chalked up to the Olden Times way of thinking. I get that female chastity was romanticized to the point of fetishism back then and I can roll with that. But the father&#39;s comments bordered on incestual, and were fucking creepy. And both Mac&#39;s reaction to Tracy rejecting him was totally blase, and even worse, Liz&#39;s reaction to Mac proposing to Tracy in front of her was just plain dumb. It would be fine if this were balls-out farce, but it&#39;s not at all. There are silly, light moments, but just as many serious, character-driven ones. The way the characters acted in the third act made no sense at all. Even Tracy ending up back with Dexter was wrong. She had all the chemistry with Mac, and her marriage was over. But I guess the movie was saying she had to better herself before she was &quot;worthy&quot; of remarrying Dexter, and Mac was part of that process. Again, that&#39;s not wrong, not really, but it was done in a very weird and off-putting way. It just doesn&#39;t always work tonally.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;Midnight Cowboy&quot;, and then &quot;Bonnie and Clyde&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8796638488440214736/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/44-philadelphia-story-1940.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8796638488440214736'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8796638488440214736'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/44-philadelphia-story-1940.html' title='#44 The Philadelphia Story (1940)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-FNjNm_oBcok/To_OgZOmWtI/AAAAAAAAAHE/jIOQG5Xhjrc/s72-c/hee.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7242385317717497243</id><published>2011-10-02T18:56:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-10-02T18:57:13.883-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#45 Shane (1953)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TWjpGiLXh6w/TokDsV5ibuI/AAAAAAAAAG8/IwkJjyKphtw/s1600/shanec.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TWjpGiLXh6w/TokDsV5ibuI/AAAAAAAAAG8/IwkJjyKphtw/s1600/shanec.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So...I weirdly remember reading this book and watching the movie in Mr. Seaman&#39;s class in 8th Grade. &lt;i&gt;(Mr. Seaman was probably my favorite teacher ever, a real stand on the desk and say, &#39;O, Captain , My Captain&#39; kind of guy. He was so awesome, no one even made fun of his name.) &lt;/i&gt;But the problem is, Mr. Seaman was my History teacher. So, why would we be studying this in History? I must be getting some memory wires crossed. At any rate, that little boy yelling, &quot;Shane! Come back, Shane!&quot; made such an incredible impression on me, that every single time without fail, every Shane I&#39;ve ever met since then has reminded me of that movie, and given me no choice but to scream at them in falsetto, &quot;Shane, come back!&quot;, and every single time, every Shane A) knows the reference immediately, and B) is thoroughly unimpressed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;But I shall not be swayed.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s the late 1800&#39;s in Wyoming. Joe and his wife Marian and their little boy Joey live on a farm and raise pigs and cows and cut logs and such. One day, whilst Marian makes pies in the kitchen and little Joey plays with rocks and Joe chews on straw and..let&#39;s say whittles, a stranger comes riding up. He&#39;s just passing through, his name is Shane, his clothes are reminiscent of Marty McFly&#39;s in &lt;i&gt;Back to the Future III,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;and could he trouble the missus for a glass of shitty water in a tin canister?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Just then, the evil Ryker brothers show up and start pestering Joe. They call him a dirty no-good pig farmer and say that he&#39;s a &quot;squatter&quot; and that his land belongs to them and that he better give it to them at some point in the future or else. Or else what? Well, it&#39;s way too early in the movie to get into that now, so we&#39;ll just say a few more ominous things and be on our way.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Joe invites Shane to dinner and then they wind up hiring him as a helper on the farm. Every time there&#39;s a noise outside, Shane reaches for his gun like a crazy person, all PTSD from the Civil War, and little Joey lights up every time, thinking Shane is the cat&#39;s pajamas, or whatever expression came before that. Then Joe asks Shane to ride into town and pick up some work clothes, and Joey also wants a soda pop, so Shane goes into town and while there he goes into the bar and orders a soda pop, and the Ryker brothers and posse are there and they taunt him and throw whiskey at him because they are just that lazily caricatured, but Shane turns the other cheek and walks out.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;That night, Joe meets with other landowners in the area, all of whom have been harassed lately by the Riker brothers. They try to come up with a plan to fight them off, and agree that the next time they have to go into town, they&#39;ll all go together. One mentions he was in town earlier and heard about Joe&#39;s new employee Shane, who backed down from a fight with the Rykers. Joe said he did the right thing, but little Joey gets all indignant and squawks to Shane that no way he&#39;d be that yellow and Shane&#39;s not scared, right Shane, you wouldn&#39;t do that Shane, you wouldn&#39;t be scared like that, right Shane, tell me Shane, tell me you wouldn&#39;t be that scared, Shane, over and over and over and everyone&#39;s just telling the little shit to shut up but he won&#39;t and Shane feels emasculated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So the next day, when everyone goes into town to buy supplies, Shane goes back into the bar to return the soda pop bottle and sure enough, the Rykers are still there. &amp;nbsp;Maybe they live there. Anyway, Shane, throws whiskey at one of them and then they fistfight and little Joey watches all wide-eyed and ridiculous and Shane beats the dude up, but now they all want a piece of him, so little Joey runs back and gets his Pa, and Shane and Joe fight off all of them, like real men should and then they eat at Carls Jr and watch Larry the Cable Guy.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Then everyone has a celebratory party, and the Ewoks show up and blink a lot, and Shane and Marian dance together and I guess are supposed to be attracted to each other, but there&#39;s nothing there, really. But of course, we&#39;re only an hour in, so the Ryker brothers regroup and hire a literally black-hatted Jack Palance to ride into town help them out. Jack Palance is the fastest gun in these parts and one day, one of Joe&#39;s neighbors goes into town and Jack Palance, knowing the guy is a former Confederate solider, talks shit about Stonewall Jackson, and the guy calls him a no good Yankee dirtbag and tries to shoot him, but Jack Palance is faster on the draw and shoots him dead.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They have a funeral, and several ranchers say they&#39;re moving out, but Joe says they have to stand their ground, and off in the distance, they see a fire. The Rykers have burned down someone&#39;s farm, which is weird because it would require them to leave the bar. &amp;nbsp;Joe says he has to ride into town and shoot them all dead, but Marian says no don&#39;t, think of me and little Joey and this whole fucking thing just writes itself, doesn&#39;t it? &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Shane no let Joe go. Shane beat up Joe. Shane go to bar. Little Joey and dog follow. Shane shoot Jack Palance and Old Man Ryker. Ryker brother shoot Shane. Shane shoot Ryker brother. Joey says Shane hurt. Blood on Shane. Blood bad. Shane ride away. Joey says come back. Shane no come back.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;SHANE!! SHANE!! COME BACK, SHANE!!&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Still funny.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Boring, overlong, pretentious, in love with itself. Let&#39;s see, what else? Trite, cliched, dumb. No chemistry between Shane and the mom, even though I remember the book making that a big part about why Shane doesn&#39;t go back, to avoid temptation. The kid is actually pretty good, he&#39;s got the hero worship look down pat, but really this story is boring. And the music soundtrack is re-donk-ulous, all horns and violins and crazy symbol crashes, trying to convince us that Shane riding his horse is the most &lt;i&gt;exciting thing ever! &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;Anyway. &amp;nbsp;Time to press forward.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;One and a half out of five.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;The Philadelphia Story&quot;, and then the X-Rated Oscar winner, &quot;Midnight Cowboy&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Both new to me.&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7242385317717497243/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/45-shane-1953.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7242385317717497243'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7242385317717497243'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/10/45-shane-1953.html' title='#45 Shane (1953)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TWjpGiLXh6w/TokDsV5ibuI/AAAAAAAAAG8/IwkJjyKphtw/s72-c/shanec.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4859381530843446144</id><published>2011-09-30T22:03:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-09-30T22:03:39.000-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#46 A Streetcar Named Desire (1951)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-X0shv8t0W70/ToKAtzHnNpI/AAAAAAAAAG0/wRVp53X47nE/s1600/brando&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-X0shv8t0W70/ToKAtzHnNpI/AAAAAAAAAG0/wRVp53X47nE/s1600/brando&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Blanche DuBois arrives from the plantation in Mississippi to the seedy slums of the French Quarter in N&#39;awlins. She arrives on a streetcar, improbably named &quot;Desire&quot;, to her sister&#39;s doorstep. She&#39;s appalled by her sister&#39;s living conditions, in squalor and filth and penury, and feels the need to point this out to her dear dear sister Stella. She tells Stella that the plantation they owned in Mississippi is gone, disappeared to creditors and debt collectors and other men of ill repute. Stella commiserates with her sister&#39;s troubles and invites her to stay at her home until such time that she can get back on her feet and her affairs in order. Stella also reveals that she is with child.&lt;br /&gt;Stanley Kowalski arrives home from bowling; finds the cheap dizzy broad in his living room sucking on his liquor and spitting out five dollar words and thinks her story is bull. He&#39;ll confront her; but first, time to take off his shirt. That&#39;s better. The Napoleonic Code says that whatever belongs to the wife also belongs to the husband and vicea versa, so if Stella was swindled by this babe, then so was he. He goes through Blanche&#39;s luggage and sees lots of fancy dresses and shiny jewelry and thinks he&#39;s been had. Stella says they&#39;re all fake, but what does she know?&lt;br /&gt;Blanche comes out of the boudoir, having needed the hot steam to settle her nerves over the long and arduous journey and is confronted by the brute Pollack, accusing her of common thievery and deception. She has all the appropriate papers and is able to prove that her story is true, momentarily throwing Stanley off-guard.&lt;br /&gt;Some time later, Stanley and the boys are playing poker while the crabby neighbor lady upstairs angrily bangs pots and pans around, pissed that they&#39;re still up this late. Blanche and Stella arrive home and go off into the separate room. One of Stanley&#39;s pals, Mitch, catches Blanche&#39;s eye and he goes into the other room to chat with her. Meanwhile, Stanley gets drunker and more brutish, and yells at Mitch to stay in the game. Mitch refuses and he and Blanche talk about fine china and the ballet and how virtuous she is. She turns on the radio, and Stanley loses it. He bursts into the room, grabs the radio, and throws it out the window. He rants and raves and Stella attacks him and rips his shirt and all the men leave and Blanche runs away. It&#39;s like &lt;i&gt;Cops&lt;/i&gt;, but the trashy guy with no shirt is actually hot.&amp;nbsp;Stella goes upstairs to the neighbor lady&#39;s house, and Stanley stands out in the cinematic moonlight, with a soaking wet and ripped shirt and screams her name over and over while holding aloft a giant boombox, and Stella comes back downstairs and they have really hot make-up sex while playing Rhianna songs.&lt;br /&gt;Blanche returns the next morning while Stanley&#39;s out getting breakfast and tells Stella that she needs to run away, get away from this common Pollack before it&#39;s too late. Stella says she&#39;s not going anywhere. She loves his violent outbursts and his passion and he&#39;s always really nice later. Blanche insists loudly that he&#39;s scum, and Stanley comes home at this time and overhears their conversation. He plays it cool, though. Coming back in and making out with Stella while being polite to Blanche.&lt;br /&gt;Blanche meanwhile gets closer to Mitch, and confesses to him that she was once married and that the boy she married was &quot;soft&quot; and &quot;shy&quot; and she told him one day she didn&#39;t like him and he ran off and killed himself. &lt;i&gt;(Actually no, that makes no sense. In the play, he was gay, and she caught him with another man and called him a disgusting pervert and he killed himself. But of course, the Hays Code won&#39;t allow that to be stated outright, so it just sounds dumb instead).&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;More time has passed, and now Stella&#39;s nine months along, ready to blow at any time. Blanche lays in the tub again, getting ready for another date with Mitch, but Stanley tells Stella that Mitch won&#39;t be coming. Why not? Because Stanley&#39;s done some digging, and it turns out that before Stella arrived from Mississippi, she lived in a town called Auriol and lived at a residential hotel where she earned quite the reputation. What sort of reputation? The whorish one. In fact, it got so bad she was asked to leave the hotel. Stella doesn&#39;t believe this story (but really totally believes this story) and is appalled that Stanley told Mitch about it.&lt;br /&gt;But Mitch doesn&#39;t arrive and after Stanley and Stella go out, Mitch finally shows up and Blanche pretends to be cross with him for being late and pretends not to notice he disheveled appearance and anger and he confronts her about Stanley&#39;s stories and she denies it and he says he googled it and it was true and he calls her a no good whore and then he kisses her and she says &quot;WTF, LOL!&quot; and he says, &quot;well, I don&#39;t want to &lt;i&gt;marry &lt;/i&gt;you now, but...&quot; and she screams to high hell and kicks him out.&lt;br /&gt;Stanley comes back and sees Blanche in her silly costume gown, fluttering about and dancing to music. He tells her Stella went into labor and he&#39;s waiting for the call to return to the hospital. She tells him she received a telegram from an old suitor, Lord Sir Fakey Bullshit, who has a private yacht and has invited Blanche on a cruise. Stanley briefly pretends to believe this while subtly mocking her and then when that doesn&#39;t rattle her, he changes tacts to outright mocking her and telling her she&#39;s full of it, and no one is coming to get her and she&#39;s worthless but still doable and why not right now and he leers over her, all sweat, abs, and intimidation, and she tries to run and defend herself with a broken bottle that he bats away easily and smashes a symbolic mirror with it.&lt;br /&gt;Stella and the neighbor lady pack up Blanche&#39;s things while Stanley, Mitch and the rest of the boys play cards. Blanche bathes in the tub and is cuckoo for cocca puffs, now. Stella and the neighbor discuss how sending Blanche &quot;away&quot; is the best thing for everyone, and how her story can&#39;t possibly be true, Stanley would never do that, and the men in the white coats come and Blanche thinks it&#39;s Lord Sir and his cruise but then realizes it&#39;s a stranger which works out because she&#39;s always depended on the kindness of strangers. Her exit is so pathetic, that immediately everyone turns on Stanley. Stanley says he didn&#39;t touch her, but Mitch takes a swing at him and Stella takes the baby upstairs with the neighbor and says this time she&#39;s not coming back no way. Stanley yells out her name again as we leave this white trash tableau as we found it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;For some reason, our Drama teacher in high school had us all study this play and act out scenes from it, so if the internet had existed back then, their might have very well been youtube videos of my obese, pimply, gay self saying &quot;Tiger, tiger, drop the bottle!&quot; while pretending to rape one of my freckle-faced female classmates. Any way, suffice to say that the actors here did a better job. Vivian Leigh was really amazing, coming into the movie playing up the old actors stereotypes; very mannered and encased in glass. But of course, that&#39;s all artifice, that&#39;s Blanche acting, not Leigh. And when those walls finally come crumbling down and we see the real woman beneath, Leigh is absolutely amazing. Now of course, there&#39;s Marlon Brando. On the one hand, the phrase &quot;raw animal magnetism&quot; has never been more apt &amp;nbsp;(I mean &lt;i&gt;damn&lt;/i&gt;), and contrasting his method acting with Leigh&#39;s stylish stuff is very interesting. But on the other hand...I know it&#39;s sacrilege, but Brando&#39;s mumblecore-style delivery does not match at all with Tennessee Williams&#39; purple prose. Not only can you just not understand him half the time, but the words as spoken are rarely convincing, even cringe-worthy sometimes. Stanley is much more raw and convincing when he&#39;s not talking. The story is great, though, and the Hollywood ending where Stella leaves (in the play she stood by Stanley, while knowing he was probably guilty) doesn&#39;t hurt it too much. Besides, when I watched it now, my cynical grown up self decided she&#39;d probably be back within a day or two anyway.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Shane&quot; and then another Katherine Hepburn movie (yay!), &quot;The Philadelphia Story&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4859381530843446144/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/46-streetcar-named-desire-1951.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4859381530843446144'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4859381530843446144'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/46-streetcar-named-desire-1951.html' title='#46 A Streetcar Named Desire (1951)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-X0shv8t0W70/ToKAtzHnNpI/AAAAAAAAAG0/wRVp53X47nE/s72-c/brando" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-5593486863077422829</id><published>2011-09-26T13:19:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-09-26T13:19:31.906-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#47 It Happened One Night (1934)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-U21Yi63MrMM/Tn6dx3S10NI/AAAAAAAAAGw/6Nal_Yatocs/s1600/it-happened-one-night-walls-of-jerico.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;235&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-U21Yi63MrMM/Tn6dx3S10NI/AAAAAAAAAGw/6Nal_Yatocs/s320/it-happened-one-night-walls-of-jerico.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;&lt;i&gt;She &lt;/i&gt;is Ellie Andrews, famous Paris Hilton-like socialite, whose father is a bajillonaire. &amp;nbsp;She elopes with a man named Westley against her father&#39;s wishes. He and his boy friday kidnap her before she can consummate the marriage (so it doesn&#39;t count!) and puts her on a boat headed back to New York. She flips out and stamps her feet and Daddy slaps her face and she jumps off the boat and swims ashore.&lt;br /&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;He &lt;/i&gt;is Peter Warne, he&#39;s a newspaper reporter who just got fired by his boss and is busy getting soused at a bar with his now-former co-workers. He has a creepy John Waters mustache and is aggressively unattractive.&lt;br /&gt;They meet cute on a bus in Georgia headed for New York. They sit on a seat squished next to each other and he pegs her as snob and she pegs him as a ruffian. He smokes a big smelly pipe and she pats her hair. Oh, these two hate each other! &amp;nbsp;I bet they&#39;ll just sit in silence for the whole ride and then never talk to each other or think about each other ever again.&lt;br /&gt;The bus takes a fifteen minute break, so everyone gets off. Ellie puts her suitcase down and turns away, and a man takes off with it. Peter chases after the man, but is unable to catch him. He tells Ellie that they&#39;ll report the theft to the bus driver, and the company will replace the bags. &amp;nbsp;They will?! &amp;nbsp;Wow, the Olden Times were incredibly accommodating! But Ellie doesn&#39;t want to file a report and use her real name, so she refuses. She says she only has four dollars left because all her money was in her suitcase.&lt;br /&gt;They get back on the bus, and Ellie falls asleep on Peter&#39;s shoulder and is embarrassed when she wakes up the next morning nuzzling his neck. The driver announces a thirty minute breakfast break, and when Ellie says she&#39;ll need an hour, the guy just sneers, &quot;Oh, yeah?&quot; and she doesn&#39;t pick up on the sarcasm at all and just says, &quot;yeah&quot; and gets off the bus. Peter knows she&#39;ll miss the bus, so he gets off, too. An hour later, the bus is gone, and they&#39;re both stranded, with another bus not coming for twelve hours. Ellie offers to pay him Tuesday for a hamburger today, and he instead gets super offended and goes into a &quot;rich, spoiled women like you&quot; speech and says she should&#39;ve just asked for help instead of offering to pay him back (?) and it&#39;s all weird and I can&#39;t tell if this is just a rich vs poor thing or a men vs. women thing. Anyway, Ellie runs off, and Peter calls his former boss collect and tells him that he&#39;s working on a big scoop. He&#39;s on a bus with the famous Ellie Andrews, last seen swimming away from her father. &amp;nbsp;DUN!&lt;br /&gt;Ellie returns after twelve hours, and they both get back on the bus, but she won&#39;t sit with him, and instead sits next to some other annoying dude who starts immediately chatting her up and when she&#39;s cold to him, he says something about how he loves cold mammas, &quot;because when they get hot, oh boy do they sizzle&quot;, and then he makes sizzle noises and it&#39;s really funny. Like, I laughed out loud and shit. So Peter sees she&#39;s in agony, so he goes over to the guy and claims they&#39;re married and tells the guy to scram, &quot;before I sock you in the nose&quot;. Why don&#39;t people use &quot;sock&quot; as a verb anymore?&lt;br /&gt;They&#39;re on the bus for awhile, and Ellie tries to buy chocolate from a &quot;boy&quot; selling concessions, and Peter takes her purse and says, &quot;this morning you had four dollars, and now you have 1.65. &amp;nbsp;What happened?&quot; She rightly says that&#39;s none of his business and she takes her purse and puts it in his luggage and says, &quot;from now on, you&#39;re on a budget&quot; and when she protests, he full-on tells her to &quot;shut up!&quot; and she does, because broads just have to learn their place sometimes.&lt;br /&gt;That night, they stop at a hotel for two dollars a night. Ellie doesn&#39;t have enough money and it starts to rain.&lt;br /&gt;So Peter pretends they&#39;re married and they get a room together. Ellie says no thank you, she&#39;ll sleep on this bus. But she doesn&#39;t leave. He tells her that he knows who she is and promises to get her to New York in exchange for an exclusive story. And then this fucking fantastic scene happens: Peter puts up a rope in the middle of the room and drapes a blanket over it. He invites Ellie to go over to her side of the blanket and gives her some of his pajamas to wear. But she doesn&#39;t move.
