That fucking Hobbit movie.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/9137727387442113047/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/52-taxi-driver-1976.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/9137727387442113047'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/9137727387442113047'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/52-taxi-driver-1976.html' title='#52 Taxi Driver (1976)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-s6RayYO7Dbg/TmL_h0d3dOI/AAAAAAAAAGE/ogbNgbYwM0o/s72-c/jimm.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3459234685062805490</id><published>2011-09-06T17:43:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-09-06T18:46:45.806-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#53 The Deer Hunter (1978)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-oYGn6VD9NWk/TmaUBw-0srI/AAAAAAAAAGM/PKdxhxDfnqE/s1600/deer.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-oYGn6VD9NWk/TmaUBw-0srI/AAAAAAAAAGM/PKdxhxDfnqE/s1600/deer.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;In a small town in West Pennsylvania, six friends gather with their families to marry off one of their own. Steven is getting married to Angela tonight, and is going to have a lavish Russian wedding that the whole town seems to be involved in. But first Steven and his pals Michael, Nick, Stanley, John, and Axle head off to the bar after work for a final bout of drinking before the big event. They share a warm and easy camaraderie that comes with years of friendship. They start to play pool, down shots, talk excitedly of their impeding military service in Vietnam. Well, that&#39;s just for the lucky three of them; Michael, Nick, and Steven. The other three stand on the opposite side, what with their knee injuries and obesity and what not. The song &quot;You&#39;re Just Too Good To Be True&quot; comes on the jukebox and everyone sings loudly and joyously, because this moment, this day, is exactly that. Then Steven&#39;s future mother-in-law comes in and grabs him by the ear and hits him with a rolling pin and drags him out and the other guys sing louder.&lt;br /&gt;One of the bridesmaids is Linda, she&#39;s exquisitely beautiful and also Nick&#39;s girlfriend. She lives at home with her drunken father, who belts her across the face when she tries to help him into bed.&lt;br /&gt;She goes to Nick and Michael&#39;s apartment, and asks Nick if she can live there while he and Michael are away in Vietnam. Nick says of course, hugs her tight, Michael looks on inscrutably.&lt;br /&gt;The wedding is a raucous wild time with a live band, boisterous Russian dancing (the kind with endless leg squats) &amp;nbsp;and lots and lots of booze. Everyone is in a beautiful, drunken frenzy. You know. You&#39;ve been there. It&#39;s so great, isn&#39;t it?&lt;br /&gt;Throughout the reception, Michael and Linda exchange looks of Unrequited Longing while Nick&#39;s back is turned. They even dance a bit, but are broken apart by Stanley and his date. Then Stanley&#39;s date dances with another dude who grabs her ass. &amp;nbsp;Stanley thinks that&#39;s disrespectful so he...punches his girlfriend in the face. Yeah. The other dude splits and the girl stands up, points to her cheek and pouts theatrically and he kisses her boo-boo. A pox on them both. Then the boys see a genuine Vietnam vet at the bar and pepper him with questions, bragging a little, wanting to be accepted into his club, we&#39;re shipping out in a few days, what&#39;s it like? &amp;nbsp;The vet sneers, stares straight ahead. Fuck it, he says. &lt;br /&gt;Michael&#39;s slipped through the Not Actually Fun Anymore alcohol rabbit hole and is fully on the other side. He drunkenly slurs at the vet&#39;s perceived disrespect and tries to start a fight with him, while the others hold him back. &quot;Fuck it&quot; Michael repeats drunkenly, mockingly. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Fuck it!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Makes it into a toast. Drinks some more.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, Steven and Angela cut the cake and drink wine from connected goblets, as per tradition, if they drink it all without spilling a drop they&#39;ll have good luck in their marriage. No one sees the drop that ruins Angela&#39;s white dress.&lt;br /&gt;Steven and Angela drive off in their car, and Michael runs along side them, stripping naked, too drunk to care. Nick chases after him and after awhile, they sit on the ground and Nick makes Michael promise that no matter what, he&#39;ll never leave Nick &quot;over there&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;The next morning, the guys minus Steven go hunting. Michael expouses his theory that a good hunter kills a deer in &quot;one shot&quot;. In the woods that day, he does exactly that, sneaking up on a deer and taking it down. The boys strap it to the hood of their car and drive back home, stopping at the local pub to celebrate. They&#39;re the only ones there. Then Axle sits down at the piano and begins to play a beautiful melancholy song. The others listen serenely, caught up in the moment.&lt;br /&gt;And then we&#39;re in the middle of Vietnam. Some North Vietnamese are raiding a village, killing women and children. Michael, covered in soot has been playing dead. He suddenly leaps up with a flame thrower and burns one of the Viet Cong alive. Reinforcements arrive, including Steven and Nick. And then just like in a nightmare, we&#39;re plunged somewhere else. Michael, Steven, Nick, and some other American and South Vietnamese soldiers are caught, imprisoned in a barbwire cage in about four feet of water. Rats crawl over them impunity. Above the men is a small hut where about half a dozen Viet Cong with guns are forcing their prey to play Russian Roulette. Two South Vietnamese men are &quot;playing&quot; the game, as Michael and the others watch through the slats in their prison ceiling. Steven begins to completely crack up, screaming and making guttural animal noises, and Michael grabs him, holds him, whispers in his ear, does what he can. This works until they hear the shot above them. One prisoner is dead, and the other is put back in the cage. Now, Michael and Steven are playing the game. Steven can&#39;t do it. Michael says he must, or they&#39;ll kill him. Micheal pulls the trigger. The gun clicks. It&#39;s Steven&#39;s turn. He holds the gun at his temple, but then at the last second moves it at an angle. It blows a hole in the hut&#39;s roof. &quot;You did it, Steven&quot; Michael says proudly. But the Viet Cong aren&#39;t impressed and throw him into the penalty box, a completely submerged bamboo cage where dead soldiers are floating. Steven can barely keep his head above the surface and is fading fast. Michael goes back down below while others play. He concocts a plan with Nick; they play the game and insist on three bullets instead of one. Then they&#39;ll each play one round and then shoot their captors with the remaining bullets. Nick doesn&#39;t know if he can do it, but they have no choice. They play again. Nick fires at his own temple, it clicks. Michael does the same, screaming in fear and rage as he does so. Then he fires at the main Viet Cong and two others. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a flurry of Michael Bay style editing here where we can&#39;t tell what&#39;s going on as Michael and Nick overpower and take out all six men, because of course that&#39;s impossible. They stagger over to Steven and free him from his cage, then pretty rudely ignore the rest of the prisoners. They grab onto a tree branch and start floating down the river, seeking to eventually float to American&#39;s side of the line. An American chopper spots them and hovers nearby. &amp;nbsp;They float into a rickety old wooden bridge and climb onto it. The chopper can get close to them and are able to boost Nick up and get him on board. Michael and Steven grab onto the undercarriage part and dangle helplessly and the chopper takes off. They try desperately to pull themselves up, but aren&#39;t strong enough. Finally, Steven lets go and falls back into the river and Michael follows him down. Michael pulls Steven out of the river; both of his legs are broken and smashed to hell. He puts Steven on his back and begins resolutely marching them back to safety. Eventually, they reach an American camp where Micheal puts Steven on a medical truck just as it drives off.&lt;br /&gt;Nick recovers in a VA hospital in Saigon. He believes his friends are dead, and is unable to answer any questions about who he is. He tries to call Linda, but hangs up the phone before he can. Sometime later, he wanders the streets of Saigon and encounters an alleyway where a French guy is tossing dead bodies in a pile. The guy tells Nick they&#39;re players in a most unusual game. Nick is disgusted, says he&#39;s not interested, is interested. He follows the man back inside a building where people are betting on the outcomes of &quot;professional&quot; Russian Roulette matches, sponsored by Home Depot. Michael&#39;s there in the crowd, he sees Nick. Nick grabs the gun and pulls the trigger at one of the players. It clicks. Then he pulls the trigger at his own temple, and it clicks again. He runs away, and several members of the crowd pursue him. Michael does as well, but Nick doesn&#39;t see or hear him.&lt;br /&gt;Eventually Michael goes back home to PA. He avoids the surprise party everyone has planned for him and hides out a hotel until the next morning when he goes to see Linda. They discuss the fact that Nick is AWOL. Linda laments that he never even called her. Michael walks her to work, she&#39;s desperate for him to take her in his arms, and he&#39;s desperate for that too, but they know they can&#39;t. The guys reveal that Steven&#39;s alive. He&#39;s at a VA hospital and down to one working limb, his right arm. Michael calls him, and says &quot;how&#39;re you doing&quot; and when Steven with answers with a totally transparent &quot;great&quot;, my eyes get a little misty. &amp;nbsp;Steven abruptly hangs up on Michael when the conversation gets too painful.&lt;br /&gt;He greets the other guys but now Michael can&#39;t talk to them. They go deer hunting, but when an opportunity presents itself in the form of a beautiful slow-moving buck, Michael can&#39;t bring himself to shoot it.&lt;br /&gt;Michael goes to the hospital to take Steven home, but Steven doesn&#39;t want to go. He reveals that someone from Saigon has been sending him money every week and Michael knows it must be Nick. He doesn&#39;t want to leave him over there.&lt;br /&gt;He flies back to Saigon and finds the Frenchman and pays him thousands of dollars to be in the game as a player. Turns out the American Nick is a famous player, now. Michael insists that they play. Before the game begins, Michael pleads with Nick to leave with him now, but there&#39;s no recognition in Nick&#39;s eyes, and there are track marks up and down his arm. They play one round. Nick fires the gun. No bullet. It&#39;s Michael&#39;s turn. Do you really want me to do this, do you? &amp;nbsp;Nick doesn&#39;t react. So Michael fires, and even though I&#39;m not looking at the screen at this point, I hear the telltale safe &quot;click&quot; and exhale. Suddenly, recognition dawn&#39;s in Nick&#39;s eyes. He stares at Michael. Michael smiles. Nick?&lt;br /&gt;One shot?&lt;br /&gt;Yes Nick, one shot.&lt;br /&gt;Nick fires. &amp;nbsp;The shot explodes his skull and he falls forward. Michael screams, grabs his head and weeps.&lt;br /&gt;After Nick&#39;s funeral, Michael, Steven, Stanley, Linda, Angela, Axle, and John head back to Linda and Michael&#39;s apartment. John begins humming &quot;God Bless America&quot; and the others join in, singing along. Fuck it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;But Lord, this was an ambitious flick. So many great set pieces, beautiful landscapes and cinematography. There&#39;s so much to love here. The first act with the wedding was so real and so much fun, it was completely believable and practically a movie in its own right. The chemistry that all six men had together was totally real and enhanced the movie and also made it all the more heartbreaking when Michael returned in the second half and no longer could really interact with the three who didn&#39;t go. Everyone is great acting-wise, but DeNiro in particular hits it out of the park. I had heard about the nail-biting Russian Roulette scene, and thought I was prepared for it, but I wasn&#39;t, really. The intensity of that whole sequence was something I&#39;m not sure I&#39;ve ever seen equaled in a movie before. I was tearing up watching it, feeling totally helpless and unable to turn away. DiNero and Walken really sold it, and John Savage as Steven did, too. Odd that his career didn&#39;t take off like the other two&#39;s did.&lt;br /&gt;The jump cut into Vietnam with no explanation was freaking brilliant. The idea I believe was to replicate a living nightmare, and a nightmare has no sense of linear time, and pushes you into the middle of the action without warning.&lt;br /&gt;I feel like I can&#39;t say this movie was perfect, though. Like I already said, I knew the Russian Roulette scene was coming, but what I didn&#39;t know was that it was going to be the main plotline for the second half of the movie. I thought the idea that Nick was somehow a champion Russian Roulette player, winning often enough to be sending money to Steven for weeks and weeks, possibly months, was too impossible to believe. It think the one scene with the forced Russian Roulette was great and should&#39;ve stood alone. Showing it over and over again reduces its power. It&#39;s also just...well, bizarre. If the movie is trying to be the seminal Vietnam movie, why pick an event that most, maybe even all, Vietnam vets didn&#39;t experience and can&#39;t identify with? I understand its a metaphor; a pointless and destructive game that represents a pointless and destructive war, but in my view a metaphor only works like that if is used sparingly and doesn&#39;t become a major plot point. Nick should&#39;ve been involved in some other highly illegal and dangerous pursuits, something that was more grounded in reality.&lt;br /&gt;And I&#39;m not sure what to make of the final scene and the final song. They all sing &quot;God Bless America&quot; with total sincerity. &amp;nbsp;But it&#39;s gotta be ironic, right? I just can&#39;t say for sure. Maybe its supposed to be vague.&lt;br /&gt;But really, I don&#39;t wish to mislead anyone. I loved this movie. It was great. My problems with it are minor, and I&#39;m very glad I saw it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, two movies about the mean, gritty streets of New York: &quot;Taxi Driver&quot; and then &quot;West Side Story&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3459234685062805490/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/53-deer-hunter-1978.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3459234685062805490'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3459234685062805490'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/53-deer-hunter-1978.html' title='#53 The Deer Hunter (1978)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-oYGn6VD9NWk/TmaUBw-0srI/AAAAAAAAAGM/PKdxhxDfnqE/s72-c/deer.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7468135191124865896</id><published>2011-09-03T16:48:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-09-03T16:49:00.485-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#54 M*A*S*H* (1970)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-my0ZjjYWdOk/TmKoXLRsVfI/AAAAAAAAAGA/y2XtKgZzUHw/s1600/mash.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;135&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-my0ZjjYWdOk/TmKoXLRsVfI/AAAAAAAAAGA/y2XtKgZzUHw/s320/mash.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So, those who know me now might know that my Very Favorite TV Show Ever is &lt;i&gt;The Wire. &lt;/i&gt;This designation was granted sometime in 2010, and is still going strong. &amp;nbsp;Those same people probably know my prior Very Favorite TV Show was &lt;i&gt;Battlestar Galatica, &lt;/i&gt;which had a brilliantly blinding and bright but all-too-brief run at the top of my list from 2009-2010.&lt;br /&gt;Those who&#39;ve known me awhile know there was another Very Favorite TV Show Ever which had a phenomenally impressive run at the top of the heap. &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Cheers, &lt;/i&gt;which lasted first in my heart from 1990-2009.&lt;br /&gt;But what few, if any know, is that &lt;i&gt;Cheers &lt;/i&gt;wasn&#39;t my first Very Favorite TV Show. &amp;nbsp;Oh, no. That honor belongs to a little show called &lt;i&gt;M*A*S*H*, &lt;/i&gt;from 1981-1990. &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;(There was also a brief several month period where the title almost switched to Soap, but then Elaine Lefkowitz the mobster&#39;s daughter died in Danny Dallas&#39; arms and I cried and cried so much my mom wouldn&#39;t let me watch the show anymore)&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;I loved Hawkeye, BJ, Margaret, Trapper, Col Blake, Col Potter, Klinger, Frank, Mulcahey, Radar and especially Charles more than I loved my own family. (&lt;i&gt;Not true, but go with i&lt;/i&gt;t). I preferred Potter, BJ, and Charles over Blake, Trapper, and Frank, thought Seasons 6-8 (after Charles arrived, before Radar left) were the &quot;Golden Years&quot;, liked that the final seasons stopped trying to be funny and just wanted to teach, and bragged to my friend Lynette on the bus that I had seen all the episodes, even though she had too. I bought the Jamie Farr autobiography, &lt;i&gt;Just Farr Fun &lt;/i&gt;at the Roseville Square bookstore and read it cover to cover several dozen times, even the boring stuff about when he was on &lt;i&gt;Super Password.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;And then one day, when I was 13 or so, while pouring through the back of my cable guide looking for Rated R movies marked with an &#39;N&#39;, and hoping it wouldn&#39;t once again be just another movie with boobs, I found out about the &lt;i&gt;M*A*S*H&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;movie, which I had never heard of and thought it was a movie Alan Alda and the gang had made after the show had ended. &amp;nbsp;I excitedly turned it on...and turned it off after about half an hour. &amp;nbsp;These people were not my friends. &amp;nbsp;They had nothing to teach me about the Hell of War. They were weird, cold impostors. Plus the &quot;N&quot; stood for boobs yet again. &amp;nbsp;Sigh. And so it is with great trepidation that I watch this movie today...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;The very familiar music strains begin, this time with lyrics, reassuring us that suicide is painless, as helicopters begin their decent upon the M*A*S*H 4077th, bringing incoming wounded.&lt;br /&gt;But first, we meet a not Alan Alda version of &amp;nbsp;Capt. Hawkeye Pierce. He&#39;s supposed to wait at Jeep in Seoul until another Captain and a driver show up to go the 4077th. Capt Duke Forrest (not in the show) arrives, mistakes Hawkeye for the driver and orders him to drive him into camp. Hawkeye plays the part and the two drive off. The MP&#39;s see them go and literally run into each other and fall down trying to run after them. Oh boy. They arrive at camp, Hawkeye reveals his ruse, Duke laughs. &amp;nbsp;They go into the mess hall where Lt Col Henry Blake (not McLean Stevenson) greets them and his company clerk Radar (&lt;b style=&quot;font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;still &lt;/b&gt;Gary Burgoff! &amp;nbsp;Yay!&lt;i&gt;) &lt;/i&gt;anticipates everything Henry is going to say and says it seconds before Henry does. It&#39;s cute. &amp;nbsp;It was cute for eight seasons. They go to their tent and meet their third bunkmate, Maj Frank Burns (not Larry Linville) who is teaching a Korean teen boy named Ho-Jon how to read the bible. Pierce and Forrest say hello to them both and unfortunately Ho-Jon does not say &quot;annyong&quot; back to them. Frank is deeply religious and reads the bible a lot and prays out loud and Pierce and Forrest can&#39;t have that and immediately petition Henry to move him out of &quot;their&quot; tent, which Henry does. Okay. &amp;nbsp;Were we supposed to side with them? &amp;nbsp;Because Frank really hadn&#39;t done anything wrong.&lt;br /&gt;So then the next surgeon shows up and it&#39;s Trapper John of course. &amp;nbsp;He blows bubbles with his gum over and over and he&#39;s a thoracic surgeon and he has anachronistic sideburns and he&#39;s wacky like the other two. &amp;nbsp;They torment Frank, show Ho-Jon porn mags, ignore Henry&#39;s commands, act like jackasses, but are good at surgery. At one point, Frank berates an orderly and is a jerk to him and Trapper punches Frank in the face. &amp;nbsp;Henry orders an MP to put Trapper under arrest and when the MP tries, Trapper just says, &quot;Oh, come off it, George!&quot; and stomps off. &amp;nbsp;Heh.&lt;br /&gt;Then sexy statuesque Maj Margaret Houlihan (not Loretta Swit) shows up. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s no-nonsense &quot;regular army&quot; and rubs all the men the wrong away (as opposed to rubbing them in the right way. &amp;nbsp;Zing! &amp;nbsp;Up top!) except of course &quot;regular army&quot; cohort Frank Burns. Then Henry goes away to a medical conference or something, and Frank is in charge. Everyone ignores him and Trapper even &quot;jokes&quot; in the mess hall loudly in front of everyone that he&#39;d like to strip Margaret naked and fuck her right then and there. But Margaret totally deserves it because she&#39;s kind of uptight.&lt;br /&gt;Margaret and Frank compose a letter to the general, complaining about Henry and the lack of discipline in camp. &amp;nbsp;Then they get so turned on by the letter that they start making out. Somehow, Radar is just outside with a PA system microphone and sneaks it in the tent with them. The rest of the guys listen to them fucking while hovered around the PA system in main office, and hear Margaret say, &quot;Oh Frank, kiss my lips. &amp;nbsp;Kiss my hot lips!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Then they broadcast it to the whole camp, which allows Frank and Margaret to hear themselves, so they freak out and stop. &amp;nbsp;The next day Margaret is humiliated and forever christened &quot;Hot Lips&quot;, and Hawkeye taunts Frank until Frank lunges at him and punches him out. &amp;nbsp;He gets carted off by the MPs in a straight jacket. &amp;nbsp;Ha...ha?&lt;br /&gt;Some time later, Father Mulcahey tells Hawkeye that another doctor nicknamed &quot;Painless&quot; is having severe emotional problems that Mulcahey can&#39;t talk about because he learned them in confession, but he encourages Hawkeye to talk to him. &amp;nbsp;Turns out Painless is having trouble getting it up with women, so he decides he&#39;s a &quot;fairy&quot; and is going to kill himself, as you do. So Hawkeye and Trapper et al pretend to go along with this and give him a &quot;black pill&quot; with which to kill himself. &amp;nbsp;But first they have a final meal, or a last supper you might say, creating a mildly amusing but also meaningless tableau. As Painless &quot;dies&quot;, a solider sings the beautiful &quot;Suicide is Painless&quot; song again, and I kinda think this should&#39;ve been the first time we heard this song. The black pill is actually a sleeping pill of course, and when Painless awakens, a friendly nurse named Michelle Bachmann is there to cure him of his impending fairydom.&lt;br /&gt;Later still, the guys are laying out in the sun talking about whether or not they think Hot Lips is a natural blonde. They bet 20 bucks, then all go to the showers. &amp;nbsp;Hot Lips and the other nurses are about to go into the shower tent, and the guys distract the other nurses so that Hot Lips goes in alone. Then as she&#39;s showering, they pull the tent apart. She screams and falls to the ground naked and covered in soap as everyone cheers. &amp;nbsp;She lies on the ground, screaming and weeping and slithers back to her robe and puts it on. She races to Henry and threatens to resign and Henry says, &quot;fine, whatever&quot; and waves her off. But she totally deserves it because she doesn&#39;t get along with everyone that well. I can&#39;t wait until they gang rape her for not using the proper utensils in the mess hall.&lt;br /&gt;Then, in the next episode of M*A*S*H, Trapper learns that a congressman&#39;s son was shot and he&#39;s requested to go to Japan and fix him up. He looks at the X-Rays and lies and says the injuries are more severe than they really are. He insists he needs back up from Hawkeye. &amp;nbsp;They go to Japan, fix the son, fuck around for a couple days, then help a Japanese-American baby who has colic or something. The evil general catches them using the operating room for non-army personnel and threatens court martial, so they knock him out with anesthesia and take naked pictures of him with a Japanese prostitute for blackmail. It apparently doesn&#39;t occur to the general that he could have them arrested for that. Then when Trapper and Hawkeye get back to camp they catch Duke sneaking Margaret out of their tent and laugh at him.&lt;br /&gt;Then finally, another general shows up and challenges the 4077th to a football game. Um...huh? So they agree to it, but Trapper has a plan for Henry to hire a ringer, a black man nicknamed...sigh...Spearchucker Jones who is also a former player for the 49ers as a well as a current neurosurgeon and army captain. In 1951, you couldn&#39;t swing a dead cat without hitting a black man named Spearchucker who was a former professional football player as well as a neurosurgeon.&lt;br /&gt;Spearchucker shows up, they all play the game, and Margaret is there as a cheerleader, having had the meanness totally fucked out of her by Duke apparently. But Margaret is really stupid now and Henry keeps calling her a blithering idiot for not knowing how to play football. They play and play and play and there are hijinks and our guys win in the end when there is no time left on the clock and blah blah blah fuck you MASH. &amp;nbsp;Football?! &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Really?!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Then Hawkeye and Duke get their discharge papers and go home, without even having to dress like chicks.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Okay, part of my displeasure with many parts of this movie was the fact that I&#39;d already seen nearly all of it acted out on the TV series in the first three seasons. Other than the football game and stripping Margaret, all the plotlines were covered in the TV show. I realize that the show came after the movie, but in my defense, all of the movie&#39;s stories were very &quot;sitcom&quot; ready and had a sitcom feel. There wasn&#39;t one cohesive plot or story at all. It was basically a bunch of short stories about the war strung together. To be fair, there were things I liked: the suicide is painless interlude, the guy on the PA always messing up whatever he was supposed to be reading, the Col Blake and Radar banter, the Father Mulcahey character who was allowed to be religious but not mocked, unlike Frank, and I really liked the fact that the camera was unflinching in showing the bloody wounded soldiers all throughout the film. There were many, many realistic operating scenes where the camera would linger on the dead or wounded solider while we would just hear Hawkeye and the gang quip back and forth to each other. That was cool, the way it commented on the horror of the surroundings without making a thing about it. There&#39;s also an interesting moment when the southern Duke doesn&#39;t want Spearchucker Jones living in their tent, but then Hawkeye and Trapper basically ignore him and the plotline is thrown away. Which brings me to...&lt;br /&gt;Things I hated; Hawkeye, Trapper, and Duke. They were sociopaths and generally shitty people. In the TV show, the guys were crazy because they were lashing out at a crazy war. These movie characters would act exactly the same way if they worked at a pizza joint. Also, Frank had no point, and was totally wasted as a villain. Also, &lt;i&gt;football?&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp; The final half hour of a war satire movie was a &quot;we&#39;ve got to beat the other team by one touchdown in the last second&quot; sports movie?! &amp;nbsp;WTF, Robert Altman. &amp;nbsp;WTF.&amp;nbsp;And finally, the treatment of Margaret was just disgusting. She was a bitch, sure, but she in no way deserved the harsh humiliating treatment she received and it was not at all funny. And even worse, her eleventh hour transformation from bitch to bimbo came out of nowhere, wasn&#39;t earned, and somehow degraded her character even more. I actively feel sorry for Sally Kellerman.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, it&#39;s a Bobby-athon with &quot;The Deer Hunter&quot;, and then &quot;Taxi Driver&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7468135191124865896/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/54-mash-1970.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7468135191124865896'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7468135191124865896'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/09/54-mash-1970.html' title='#54 M*A*S*H* (1970)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-my0ZjjYWdOk/TmKoXLRsVfI/AAAAAAAAAGA/y2XtKgZzUHw/s72-c/mash.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1135522765422357572</id><published>2011-08-31T15:57:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-31T16:24:07.828-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#55 North by Northwest (1959)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vRIxPujUdTM/Tl58f8WirVI/AAAAAAAAAF8/MTRRZQUa4_0/s1600/aa.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vRIxPujUdTM/Tl58f8WirVI/AAAAAAAAAF8/MTRRZQUa4_0/s1600/aa.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;So this is Hitchcock, huh? &amp;nbsp;I thought he&#39;d be fatter.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Roger Thornhill is a snappy ad exec with two ex-wives and a cavalier devil-may-care twinkle in his eye. (Think Roger Sterling). &amp;nbsp;He rides a cab over to a restaurant for an important meeting with some clients, then remembers that he needs to send his secretary a telegram. At the same time, some shady men enter the restaurant and ask the waiter to page a &quot;Mr. George Kaplan&quot;. &amp;nbsp;The waiter does so, just as Roger raises his hand to call the waiter over. &amp;nbsp;He asks the waiter to send the telegram, which is something that happened in 1959 I guess, and the shady men think he&#39;s responding to the page. Thornhill gets up to follow the waiter to the...let&#39;s say Telegram Room, and the shady men block his path and then stick a gun in his ribs and order him outside. They pull him into a car, call him &quot;George Kaplan&quot; repeatedly, and all the while Roger seems mildly annoyed but not nearly as scared as he should be. He makes several cracks about asking to be kidnapped another time when he&#39;s not so busy. They take him to the house of Lester Townsend. Townsend interrogates him about being a CIA spy, and Roger says he&#39;s not a spy, but they don&#39;t believe him and finally force him at gunpoint to drink an entire bottle of bourbon and after he passes out, they put him in the front seat of a car and start it so that it&#39;s about to drive off a cliff. &amp;nbsp;But Roger suddenly wakes up and drunkenly turns the car around and starts down the road, swerving wildly. &amp;nbsp;Heh. The bad guys follow him, but Roger passes a local policeman who pursues. Roger looks up at the cop car behind him and gets a drunken irritated look on his face and keeps driving, until he finally slams on his breaks at a Stop sign, causing the cops to rear end him. The bad guys drive away as Roger&#39;s arrested.&amp;nbsp;The next morning, Roger&#39;s mother bails him out and he&#39;s instantly on trial just like in &lt;i&gt;Sullivan&#39;s Travels. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;I refuse to believe the judicial system worked that way. Roger claims some bad guys kidnapped him and forced him to drink and drive and no one believes him of course, not even his mother. They go to the house and a woman who was there last night calls Roger &quot;George&quot; and tells the cops he drank too much and borrowed someone else&#39;s car when no one was looking and they were very worried. &amp;nbsp;Roger demands to talk to &quot;Townsend&quot; who was there last night, but the woman says Townsend works at the UN and is there right now. &amp;nbsp;The cops drop the whole thing and let Roger go because clearly nothing at all fishy is going on here.&lt;br /&gt;Roger and his mother somehow learn that the real &quot;George Kaplan&quot; is staying at a hotel (??) and they go there to confront him. There&#39;s a friendly maid and a valet who talk to Roger and think he&#39;s George even though they admit they&#39;ve never seen him before. This goes on for a while, with Roger and his mom just hanging out in George&#39;s hotel room after stealing a key and then just looking at each other not knowing what to do. Roger sees a day planner or something and sees that Kaplan has a meeting the next day in Chicago. Finally, the phone rings, and Roger for some reason answers. It&#39;s the goons from last night, calling to see if &quot;George&quot; is in. &amp;nbsp;Roger says he&#39;s not George, but that claim is pretty hard to believe at this point.&lt;br /&gt;He and his mom book it to the elevator and get on just as the goons are getting off. &amp;nbsp;They double back and get on the elevator too. So now Roger, his mom, the goons, and a bunch of extras are all on the elevator. Roger keeps looking at his mom and trying to indicate to her that those are the bad guys and finally she gets it and says, &quot;You&#39;re not really going to kill my son, are you?&quot; &amp;nbsp;Everyone in the elevator stares at her in awkward silence. The elevator opens, and Roger dashes it, fully ditching his mom and runs outside and into a cab. &amp;nbsp;He heads for the UN where he finds Townsend, who is not the man from last night. He explains to Townsend that someone else is in his home pretending to be him, and suddenly someone throws a knife in Townsend&#39;s back. He falls over into Roger&#39;s arms. &amp;nbsp;Roger: A: Grabs the knife. &amp;nbsp;B: Pulls it out of Townsend&#39;s back. C: Brandishes it as people scream and D: Stands still while a nearby photographer takes his picture. Then he throws down the knife and runs out. Roger is dumb.&lt;br /&gt;Then there&#39;s a weird exposition scene where a bunch of CIA guys stand around and talk about how poor Roger Turnhill is an unfortunate fall guy who is taking the rap for being a spy named George Kaplan when George Kaplan doesn&#39;t exist. &amp;nbsp;The &lt;i&gt;real&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;spy is some other mystery person who is spying on a guy named Van Damme who is Russian or something and bad (feel free to imagine Jean-Claude, because it&#39;s fun). The goons work for him, and he was the one earlier pretending to be Townsend. Then the CIA people stare at the camera and say, &quot;Is everybody clear on that?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Roger, wanted for the murder of Townsend, decides to flee by train to Chicago and confront Kaplan. He sneaks onboard without buying a ticket and when the conductor chases him, a sexy blonde woman named Eve sees all this go down, and protects him by telling the conductor he got off.&lt;br /&gt;Then they have dinner on the train, and she&#39;s all super sexy Jessica Rabbity, and he hilariously says that he hates the part where men have to converse with beautiful women and pretend they don&#39;t want to sleep with them and she says why pretend? &amp;nbsp;Eve says she recognizes his picture in the paper and knows he&#39;s wanted for murder but doesn&#39;t care. He says he would invite her to his place but doesn&#39;t have one. She invites him to stay at hers. The double and triple entendres are all doing it doggy style at this point.&lt;br /&gt;Back at her private car, they make out on the bed awhile until the porter comes and Roger hides in the bathroom while the porter cleans the car or something. &amp;nbsp;There are a lot of maids and service people in this movie. Then Roger comes back out, all &quot;where were we?&quot; They kiss some more, but the camera lingers on her lying female eyes of deception that DO NOT CLOSE even while kissing.&lt;br /&gt;Outside, the porter knocks on another car, and it opens and it&#39;s Van Damme and his goons. The porter hands them a note from Eve that says, &quot;I&#39;ve got him. What are your orders?&quot; &amp;nbsp;DUN DUN DUN.&lt;br /&gt;At Chicago, Eve gets off the train with Roger dressed as a train employee, carrying her luggage. In fact, every passenger has a red-capped train employee carrying their luggage. If this movie has taught me nothing else, it&#39;s that people where really lazy in the Olden Times.&lt;br /&gt;The cops are in Chicago with pictures of Roger, looking at all the passengers, but Eve and Roger in costume breeze on by. Roger says he has to get to a phone booth and call Kaplan and arrange a meeting. Eve says she better do with while he changes. Roger agrees. Suddenly, a tied-up train employee in his underwear jumps off the train and says he was robbed. The police start frantically searching each train employee, but there are dozens of them among hundreds of departing passengers, and Eve and Roger manage to slip away.&lt;br /&gt;Later, Eve the LIAR says she talked to Kaplan and they&#39;re to meet at a bus stop on the highway. But she looks all super conflicted and stuff. Roger goes there by himself and gets off the bus. It&#39;s a totally empty long stretch of highway. He stares for awhile, not sure what to do, while a few cars pass him by. Suddenly, a low flying and cinematic crop duster plane starts trying to dive-bomb him and also firing at him. He runs and dives and runs more and the plane keeps going around in circles lining up for another shot and Roger runs into the street where a giant oil truck almost hits him and then the crop duster crashes into the oil truck and everything goes boom. Roger runs off.&lt;br /&gt;Roger hitches a ride to Kaplan&#39;s hotel, having figured out Eve lied to him and tries to confront Kaplan there, but he already checked out (and doesn&#39;t exist). &amp;nbsp;But Eve is there. He pretends to not know she lied and asks her to dinner. She gets a phone call and writes down an address on a scrap of paper on a notepad and then tears it off and says she has to leave now for an important meeting. Roger lets her leave and then uses a pencil to scribble on the notepad and see what she wrote. Clearly, this is what &lt;i&gt;The Big Lebowski &lt;/i&gt;was riffing off of with the penis drawing, so that&#39;s cool. He follows her to an auction, where she&#39;s all schoompy with Van Damme. &amp;nbsp;Van Damme is buying a special statue thing that has secret microfilm in it that will maybe destroy the world or something. Perhaps &quot;lasers&quot; are involved. Roger confronts them both and calls her a fucking whore like ten million times but in polite Olden Times language and her eyes burn with shame and tears because girls are weak. Van Damme signals his goons who wait by the doorway to grab Roger and kill him dead. But Roger&#39;s new plan is to make a bunch of crazy bids that are both way too high and way too low on the auction items and cause such a spectacle that the cops arrest him, which they do. &amp;nbsp;No sooner is he arrested that the cops are informed by radio to take him to blah blah place where he meets the exposition CIA guys from earlier who explain to him the whole plot including the new fact that Eve is the super secret real spy! But now Van Damme is suspicious of her and so they concoct a plan for him to confront Eve in front of Van Damme and company in a public place and she&#39;ll shoot him with a gun with blanks and then run away. They do this and it all works out. So now Van Damme trusts Eve and will take her on his secret spy trip with her to wherever where she can find out his secret plans to whatever and kill Americans probably. But now Roger doesn&#39;t want her to go, and angrily confronts the CIA guys about sending a &quot;girl&quot; to try and stop the bad guys. The CIA guys look duly ashamed for employing and training an attractive blonde woman. But they insist Eve carry out the mission she trained and signed up for and still right now is telling Roger she wants to do, almost as if she has her own agency and autonomy. They check Roger into a hospital, as he&#39;s supposed to have been shot, but he breaks out and goes to Van Damme&#39;s hideout, which is a giant house right by Mt Rushmore, because sure it is.&lt;br /&gt;He stares in the window while a goon talks to Van Damme and Eve just hangs out pretending to still be Van Damme&#39;s girl. He continues to...just stare and watch because there&#39;s literally no fucking reason for him to be there, and if he&#39;s discovered he&#39;ll expose Eve and this is just super dumb. They talk about how they&#39;re taking a private plane to wherever in a few minutes and soon they&#39;ll have taken the statue to wherever and then they&#39;ll win! But then Eve goes to the bathroom and lucky for Roger the goon tells Van Damme he doesn&#39;t trust Eve and then shoots Van Damme. &amp;nbsp;But Van Damme isn&#39;t killed, because the gun had blanks and the goon explains it was the gun that Eve used to &quot;shoot&quot; Roger. Now Van Damme knows Eve&#39;s a double agent and Roger knows he knows so &lt;i&gt;now&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;there&#39;s a point to him being there. Still dumb. Van Damme&#39;s plan is to take her up in the plane and then throw her out, which is way more dramatic than just killing her right now. But Roger warns her and they mange to overpower Van Damme and steal the magic statue and run away. They dramatically attempt to climb down Mt Rushmore as the goons and Van Damme give chase. At one point, a goon catches up to him and leaps upon ad exec Roger and fights him while CIA agent Eve screams like a girl and watches, doing nothing. Roger pushes the goon off and down he goes off Roosevelt&#39;s nose and into oblivion. Another goon falls as well. Then Van Damme struggles with Eve and tries to push her off, but Roger punches him out, but she falls anyway, and barely clings to the ledge. Roger tries to pull her up, but slips himself. Now he&#39;s holding the ledge with one hand while holding Eve with the other. Van Damme walks forward all cocky and steps on Roger&#39;s hand, but is suddenly shot by the CIA agents, who have magically materialized, perhaps summoned by the statue. Eve is slipping...slipping...Roger pulls...and suddenly, a jump cut and they&#39;re back on the train, married, and he&#39;s pulling her into bed on the top bunk. &amp;nbsp;Nice.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;There&#39;s a lot of good stuff here, a lot of fun humor, some great sexual chemistry between Grant and Eva Marie Saint, who was particularly great. &amp;nbsp;Lots of quotable lines, and the crazy bidding at the auction was something almost straight out of &lt;i&gt;Naked Gun.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;Made me laugh a lot. I guess the funny/not funny demarcation line for me is sometime before 1959. The plot was complicated and dizzying, which was fun, but also super sloppy and lazy at times, which was not. Very reminiscent of &lt;i&gt;Dexter, &lt;/i&gt;actually. The statue and the microfilm inside it and its purpose was maddeningly vague and an obvious macguffin. It really just seemed like Hitchcock wanted to do &lt;i&gt;this &lt;/i&gt;cool cinematic scene and &lt;i&gt;those &lt;/i&gt;funny or sexy lines of dialog, and didn&#39;t really care how we got there at all. The pacing was weird, too. Sometimes things were way too rushed, and other times they took forever cluing is in on stuff we had long since figured out. It&#39;s the rare movie that is actually less than the sum of its parts. But the parts were admittedly pretty great.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;MASH&quot;, with a Hawkeye, Trapper, Henry, and Hot Lips who I don&#39;t know at all. And then &quot;The Deer Hunter&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1135522765422357572/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/55-north-by-northwest-1959.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1135522765422357572'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1135522765422357572'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/55-north-by-northwest-1959.html' title='#55 North by Northwest (1959)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vRIxPujUdTM/Tl58f8WirVI/AAAAAAAAAF8/MTRRZQUa4_0/s72-c/aa.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4928699671549747972</id><published>2011-08-30T19:32:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-30T19:32:15.601-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#56 Jaws (1975)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bAOk_HVx798/Tl2E_mPrSWI/AAAAAAAAAF4/eqDOZt2Lh5Q/s1600/jaws.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bAOk_HVx798/Tl2E_mPrSWI/AAAAAAAAAF4/eqDOZt2Lh5Q/s1600/jaws.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In the summer of 1975, while I learned to hold my head up without assistance, (um...because I was an infant, not because of some tragic accident) Steven Spielberg went about creating the summer blockbuster.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;On the sleepy hamlet of Amity Island, a group of teenage hippies are having a drunken beach party. &amp;nbsp;A pretty girl asks a pretty boy to go skinny dipping, and they race off to the beach, shedding clothing as they go. The girl is like the world&#39;s fastest runner, swimmer, and clothing remover, and is in the water and swimming far out even before the boy reaches the shore. He struggles with his shirt, giggles drunkenly, then passes out. The girl calls to him, laughs playfully, then she somehow misses the super scary orchestral music which indicates an impending shark attack, and is first nibbled on and dips slightly into the water. &amp;nbsp;She cries out, more scared really than in pain. It&#39;s pretty awesome. Then she&#39;s grabbed again, and the shark has a sense of the dramatic and thus spins her around in circles for awhile while she screams and the sea bubbles and turns red, and then finally pulls her under.&lt;br /&gt;DUN DUN DUN!&lt;br /&gt;The next day, the boy reports to the new sheriff Martin Brody that his girlfriend has gone missing, and he suspects she drowned. Martin and the boy quickly discover her chewed up body on the beach, however. Which is weird, given the size of Jaws. Shouldn&#39;t she have been completely eaten? &amp;nbsp;Anyway...&lt;br /&gt;The coroner rules the cause of death to be a shark attack, so Brody shuts down the beaches as a safety precaution. Very quickly though, his decision is overruled by the Greedy Mayor who doesn&#39;t want to scare away tourists during the summer season and lose a bunch of money. He strong arms the coroner into saying the girl died in a boat accident, and Brody agrees to keep the beaches open based on the coroner&#39;s revised findings, even though he knows or strongly suspects that the coroner is full of it.&lt;br /&gt;The next day at the beach, everyone&#39;s swimming and having a good time, except Brody. &amp;nbsp;He sits on the beach, scanning the water worriedly, not letting his kids swim. There are potential targets everywhere. The shark music starts up again, and people weirdly still don&#39;t freak out. We see shark POV and see all the dangling, yummy legs and feet ol&#39; Jaws has to choose from. Suddenly, a little boy (!) on a raft cries out while the water gets all bubbly and red around him. &amp;nbsp;Brody sees him from the beach and jumps up. &amp;nbsp;He screams at everyone to get out of the water, and everyone does, except of course the little boy. &amp;nbsp;After a moment, a scared woman in a bathing suit steps forward uncertainly, calling out her son&#39;s name, while everyone else stares at her, clinging to their loved ones. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s pretty heartbreaking.&lt;br /&gt;There&#39;s a town meeting where a bunch of townspeople are talking all at once, screaming at Brody and the Greedy Mayor. Brody announces they&#39;re closing the beaches, and the townspeople...object. &amp;nbsp;Huh? &amp;nbsp;What is this, Springfield? The Greedy Mayor says they&#39;re only closing for 24 hours, which upsets Brody. Everyone starts yelling again, until some guy starts literally running his nails along a chalkboard. Everyone turns and looks at the live action version of the Springfield&#39;s Sea Captain, named Quint. He talks all folksy and dramatically and has a beard and offers his services to catch the shark for a hefty fee. &amp;nbsp;Everyone just stares at his weird ass mutely, then go back to yelling at the Greedy Mayor. If you think his character is fun and over-the-top, or if you think he&#39;s stupid and over-the-top, you&#39;re right.&lt;br /&gt;So, the little boy&#39;s mom puts up a $3,000 dollar reward for the corpse of the shark who killed her son, which sends a bunch of yahoos into the water. In one pretty cool scene, two old men on a dock manage to hook Jaws with some bait and wind up breaking apart the dock, leaving one of the men stranded in the water. He barely manages to swim back to shore without being eaten.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Brody hires science marine biologist guy expert Matt Hooper to show up and say science things. Richard Dreyfus is only two years older here than when he was playing a high school senior in &lt;i&gt;American Graffiti, &lt;/i&gt;and kudos to him for the convincing transformation. Then some yahoos manage to catch a tiger shark, and bring it ashore. Brody and the Greedy Mayor are thrilled, but Hooper thinks the bite marks aren&#39;t big enough, based on the marks left on the girl. He suggests opening up the shark to see if the boy is still in his stomach, as sharks take several days to digest their food. The Greedy Mayor has a point for once, as he thinks a little boy &quot;spilling out onto the dock&quot; would be slightly upsetting to some. And of course the Greedy Mayor wants to reopen the beaches for the 4th of July the next day, so he wants desperately to believe they have the right shark. &amp;nbsp;Brody has his doubts, but is &amp;nbsp;overruled.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, the beaches full of people who at first don&#39;t want to swim until the Greedy Mayor basically orders his lackey to take his family into the water. It&#39;s pretty funny. &amp;nbsp;Other people get in as well. &amp;nbsp;Then, a couple of kids pull a prank and go swimming with a fake cardboard fin. &amp;nbsp;Everyone screams and gets out of the water, but while that&#39;s been going on, in another part of the beach, the real Jaws shows up again and chomps a dude right in front of Brody&#39;s kid.&lt;br /&gt;In the aftermath, the now Humbled Mayor swears he thought everyone was safe, and feels super guilty. Brody manages to get him to pay Quint&#39;s fee, and then hires Quint to go off in a boat with him to get the shark. Matt Hooper also goes along. &amp;nbsp;The plan is to harpoon the shark and then drag him close and inject him with strychnine that Matt brought.&lt;br /&gt;Matt and Quint don&#39;t get along because Quint is Salt of the Earth and Matt is some know-it-all elitist liberal, and Brody&#39;s stuck in the middle. At one point, Brody tosses chum into the water without looking and suddenly the shark emerges. I can totally hear the 1975 theatre audience screaming right there. Brody&#39;s stunned, walks backwards a bit and says the famous line, &quot;we&#39;re going to need a bigger boat&quot;. &amp;nbsp;They manage to hook the shark with a harpoon attached to a yellow barrel. They try to use the barrel to track him, but he takes the barrel underwater. That night, the three of them drink and tell tales and bond as men do. Quint tells a long rambling monologue about how he and his fellow navy men were on a boat that sank in the Pacific during WWII and they were surrounded by tiger sharks who picked them off one by one, until two thirds of them were killed. If you thought that monologue was awesome and intense or if you thought is was corny and ridiculous, you&#39;re right. Then they sing the song, &quot;Show Me The Way To Go Home&quot; and are having a great time until the shark attacks. The boat shudders and all that, and this seems like the perfect time for the final battle, but instead they just harpoon it again and it disappears again. &amp;nbsp;Hmm...keep it moving, people.&lt;br /&gt;The next day (sigh), Jaws shows up &lt;i&gt;again&lt;/i&gt;, and they harpoon it again, and Matt says the shark is much too big for the syringe of strychnine to pierce the shark&#39;s skin or whatever, so Quint decides they should drag it into shore and beach it. Brody tries to radio the Coast Guard for help, but Crazy Quint goes all Captain Ahab on his ass, and bashes the radio with a bat. &amp;nbsp;They start trying to pull the shark in, but he&#39;s too heavy and too strong, and causes the boat&#39;s engines to overheat and die.&lt;br /&gt;The next plan is for Matt to be lowered underwater in a flimsy ass metal cage and then throw the syringe into the shark&#39;s mouth when it attacks. This doesn&#39;t work because the cage looks like it&#39;s made of aluminum, and is instantly smashed to hell by the shark. Quint and Brody think Matt&#39;s dead, but he swims over to the sea floor and hides behind some rocks, using his tank to breathe.&lt;br /&gt;By now the boat is falling apart and sinking, so Jaws appears on the hull and OMG, it&#39;s not a shark at all, it&#39;s some crazy rubbery animatronic thing that&#39;s somehow become sentient! What a twist! Quint tries to run away, but the weight of Jaws tilts the hull and forces him to slide feet first into Jaws&#39; waiting open mouth. He&#39;s killed very noisily and gruesomely.&lt;br /&gt;Now, even more of the boat has sunk, and Jaws tries to eat Brody, who&#39;s hiding as best he can against the far wall. He throws an air tank into Jaws&#39; mouth. &amp;nbsp;Then he climbs up onto the mast, which is the only thing not underwater, and gets off a lucky shot with his rifle, exploding the tank and the shark. &amp;nbsp;Horray!&lt;br /&gt;The boat&#39;s completely gone now, so Brody clings to some wreckage and tries to swim ashore. Matt resurfaces now that the coast is clear. &amp;nbsp;Brody&#39;s relieved he survived. &amp;nbsp;&quot;And that&#39;s not all&quot;, says Matt. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, the little boy from earlier also surfaces. &amp;nbsp;Brody&#39;s stunned. &quot;H-How?&quot; &amp;nbsp;&quot;This is a Spielberg movie. &amp;nbsp;Spielberg doesn&#39;t kill kids, no matter how implausible it might seem. &amp;nbsp;Didn&#39;t you see &lt;i&gt;War of the Worlds?&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;Spielberg likes to undermine and ruin his movies with some takesey-backsey bullshit in the third act&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;The kid smiles. &quot;Hey mister, how did you manage to kill that shark with a walkie-talkie?&quot; &amp;nbsp;Brody looks down and sees his rifle has turned into a walkie-talkie.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;I-I don&#39;t understand. &amp;nbsp;This is crazy&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Yes, it is. &amp;nbsp;And stupid. &amp;nbsp;Don&#39;t forget stupid&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Of course, that didn&#39;t happen. &amp;nbsp;The boy died and grown men sometimes carry guns. But this was obviously a less kinder and gentler Spielberg. And this movie was all the more better for it. I think for its genre it&#39;s pretty good, and many of the plot devices here have become enduring staples of most horror movies. Everyone knows the famous story of how the shark didn&#39;t work right, so they had to not show it until the end of the movie, and that served to create suspense, and also set the template for 90+ percent of monster movies that have come after. There&#39;s also the boneheaded politician character who doesn&#39;t care about the people&#39;s welfare, as well as the nerdy guy and the tough guy who must work together despite their differences.&lt;br /&gt;But on top of all that, the suspense here is genuine, the scares are great, the way Spielberg played with expectations, making you wonder who was gonna get it next, all great. It was also smart to change up the movie an hour in, and make it about the main three guys and not the whole town, because there&#39;s only so many times you can plausibly have people keep getting into the water. &amp;nbsp;Quint was...weird. &amp;nbsp;I really can&#39;t decide how I felt about him, or if the movie was making fun of him or not, but I guess he worked in the end as a great foil for Matt, who was my favorite, and it was believable that he would do something stupid and self-destructive like break the radio. At the very least, he wasn&#39;t boring, unlike Brody. And then of course, I can&#39;t not mention the amazing soundtrack, which is perhaps one of the best ever, right up there with &lt;i&gt;Star Wars, Raiders, &lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;Superman.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;All in all, a fun experience, but something I suspect I would&#39;ve liked a lot more a long time ago, before so many imitators.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;North By Northwest&quot;, and then back to Altman again for some fun with the Mobile Army Surgical Hospital.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Also, like my Facebook page:&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.facebook.com/pages/My-AFI-Movie-Blog/210387505681057&quot;&gt;http://www.facebook.com/pages/My-AFI-Movie-Blog/210387505681057&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4928699671549747972/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/56-jaws-1975.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4928699671549747972'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4928699671549747972'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bAOk_HVx798/Tl2E_mPrSWI/AAAAAAAAAF4/eqDOZt2Lh5Q/s72-c/jaws.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3589388446115296045</id><published>2011-08-22T14:33:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-22T14:52:45.086-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#57 Rocky (1976)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Js4zV_kzyck/TlH-kuEH7XI/AAAAAAAAAFw/nrzyFVvVvKc/s1600/bal.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Js4zV_kzyck/TlH-kuEH7XI/AAAAAAAAAFw/nrzyFVvVvKc/s1600/bal.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Gonna fly now....&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Rocky Balboa, the big palooka with the heart of gold, is in the middle of a match with some other dude. The guy full-on head butts him--like, what is this dirty MMA shit?--and Rocky loses it and pounds the guy in the dust, winning the match. During his lengthy walk home through the rather ethereal and calm streets of Philly, he encounters a group of corner boys singing and drinking wine from the bottle. They greet him warmly, he takes a swig, and he continues on his way. At his little home, he greets his pet turtles and fish, and moves the fishbowl over to the turtle container so they can all say hi. Then he changes his shoes and sweater and tells us we&#39;re all very special.&lt;br /&gt;The next day at the pet store, he encounters shy mousy little Adrian, who has glasses which is movie shorthand for ugly and shy, and he tells her a joke he rehearsed the night before. It&#39;s actually really quite endearing. Then Rocky goes to his day job, which is working as an enforcer for a loan shark. He hassles a guy who owes 200 bucks, but can only come up with 130. Rocky&#39;s supposed to break his thumb, but can&#39;t bring himself to do it. &amp;nbsp;His loan shark boss lectures him on being too nice, and Rocky feels bad. He goes to his local gym, to workout and train for his next match. &amp;nbsp;He tries to open his locker, but it won&#39;t budge, causing him to take off his hat and pull out a little slip of paper with the combination, which is an extraordinary detail. Turns out though, the locker has been given to another boxer, and Rocky&#39;s supplies are hanging on a coat hook. &amp;nbsp;Rocky confronts the gym owner Mickey, who spits out pieces of the set and growls some nonsense about Rocky not trying hard enough to deserve a locker, and I&#39;m sorry I just can&#39;t take The Penguin seriously at all.&lt;br /&gt;Rocky&#39;s pissed but doesn&#39;t let it get him down. He hangs out with his friend Paulie, who looks exactly like you imagine he does, and also happens to be Adrian&#39;s brother. Paulie says that Adrian has agreed to go out with him, and they head over to Paulie and Adrian&#39;s house to pick her up. When they get there, turns out Paulie was full of it, and Adrian doesn&#39;t want to go out. She says she&#39;s cooking a turkey in the oven. Paulie goes over to the oven and throws the turkey out the window. Adrian screams at him and runs back down the hall and into her room. Rocky shifts uncomfortably and says that &quot;maybe&quot; this isn&#39;t a good time and he should come back later. Boy, Rocky can really read a room. Paulie though, is adamant that Adrian get the fuck out of the house for a little while and bangs on the door to her bedroom. Rocky walks down the hall, all nervous tics and yos, and says to Adrian that she&#39;ll have a good time, he swears. Adrian finally opens the door and agrees to go out with him.&lt;br /&gt;They go to the ice rink, but it&#39;s Thanksgiving day and the ice rink has closed early. Rocky begs the guy to let Adrian skate for a little bit, and the guy agrees to ten minutes for ten bucks. Aw, Rocky. That&#39;s so sweet, yo.&lt;br /&gt;He runs along Adrian as she skates, talking a mile a minute about his life and hers and his pets and his boxing and the fact that he&#39;s never broken his nose, and explains the history of the term &quot;south paw&quot; (something to do with New Jersey) and basically is so nervous he can&#39;t shut up for a second, while Adrian takes it all in and offers very little in return. She does ask him why he&#39;s a boxer though, and Rocky says it&#39;s because he can&#39;t sing or dance. He beams proudly. &quot;HEYYY-OHHH! &amp;nbsp;Bada bing!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Well, this is upsetting. &amp;nbsp;I think I&#39;m falling in love with Rocky.&lt;br /&gt;They walk back to Rocky&#39;s place, he&#39;s over the top solicitous, asking her if she liked skating, liked dinner, had a good time, enjoyed the weather, the topography, the architecture, Pennsylvania, the earth, the solar system. She says she did. He asks her in. She says no. He cajoles. She goes inside. Rocky sits down, takes his coat off, while Adrian stands in the middle of the room with her arms crossed, trying desperately to resist the irresistible. She says she should go and Paulie will be worried about her. Rocky yells out the window, &quot;Hey Paulie, your sister&#39;s with me!&quot; It should be trashy and dumb but it&#39;s sexy as hell and warm and self-deprecating to boot. She goes to the door. Rocky stands up, kinda blocks her, but not in a way that&#39;s intimidating. He begs her to stay, moving in closer. She resists. He asks her to take off her glasses. She doesn&#39;t, but neither does she resist when he takes them off for her. He takes off her hat, too. They kiss, finally, then sort of fall to the ground in a pile by the doorway as we fade out. &amp;nbsp;Damn.&lt;br /&gt;Some time later, Rocky&#39;s training at the gym when the grizzled Penguin tells Rocky that some men want to talk to him. While all this has been going on, we&#39;ve been treated to a few scenes with the Heavyweight Champion of the World, Apollo Creed, who was supposed to fight another boxer in Philadelphia in about a month&#39;s time, but the guy got injured, and now Apollo&#39;s decided to give an unknown a shot at the belt. He and his entourage poured over countless locals until they discovered &quot;The Italian Stallion&quot;, aka Rocky (the Italian Stallion is his porn name). Apollo&#39;s men approach Rocky and offer him the deal. Terrified, Rocky reflexively says no, but the dude convinces him otherwise, saying that this is the ticket out of the minors, and offering him 150 grand.&lt;br /&gt;Suddenly, Rocky&#39;s real popular. He does a press conference with the arrogant and condescending Apollo, and while the sportscasters make Italian jokes, Rocky sits with now girlfriend Adrian and Paulie and basks in the fame. Mickey comes to Rocky&#39;s house, hat in hand, and tells of his past success as a fighter, and asks to be Rocky&#39;s manager. Rocky turns him down, but then when he leaves the house, Rocky screams at him through the closed door, saying that Mickey never respected him or his abilities, and calls out his transparent ploy. But then he agrees to let him mange him anyway. &amp;nbsp;Not feeling this storyline.&lt;br /&gt;Rocky gets up the next morning, drinks some raw eggs, runs up those famous steps, but can hardly reach the top without gasping and being doubled over in pain.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Paulie gets jealous and lashes out at both Rocky and Adrian, but later proves useful as a PR guy, getting the press to show up and film Rocky training in a walk-in freezer, where Rocky hits cold slabs of hanging meat. Apollo meanwhile preens and showboats and is more interested in finding a cool outfit to wear when he enters the ring than in training. His trainer worriedly watches Rocky on TV, beating the hell out of the meat and bloodying his knuckles, but can&#39;t even get Apollo to turn his head and look.&lt;br /&gt;Then Mickey trains Rocky to run faster, climb higher, do one handed pushups and hit that meat even harder.&lt;br /&gt;Everybody!:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Oh, we&#39;re gonna need a montage/Oh, it takes a montage/show a lot of things happening all at once/remind everyone what&#39;s going on/and with every shot, show a little improvement/to show it all would take too long/that&#39;s why you need a montage (montage)/oh, we want a montage!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;And he climbs those steps two at a time, and the camera swings around and Rocky throws up his hands and runs in place and if your heart isn&#39;t beating just a little bit faster, you&#39;re not human, period. &amp;nbsp;Even with some twee fucking lyrics like &quot;Getting strong now/won&#39;t be long now&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;In the eleventh hour, Rocky&#39;s plagued with self doubt. He visits Adrian, says he doesn&#39;t think he can do it. Adrian: So, what do we do? &amp;nbsp;(&lt;i&gt;Psst: Adrian! &amp;nbsp;You&#39;re supposed to say, &quot;you can do this, Rocky! &amp;nbsp;I believe in you!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Look, do you need me to take over? &amp;nbsp;Because I will do it.)&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Rocky subtly moves the goalposts and says doesn&#39;t care about winning, he just wants to go all 15 rounds and prove he&#39;s a contender.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The match. Rocky wears a robe that&#39;s too big with ads on the back that Paulie got paid for. &amp;nbsp;Apollo Creed enters like it&#39;s the WWF, dressed as George Washington with a giant red white and blue outfit and top hat. He points at Rocky and says &quot;I want you!&quot;, which the announcer hilariously and unnecessarily clarifies is a reference to the &quot;military recruitment poster with Uncle Sam&quot;. Like that was seriously right out of &lt;i&gt;Best in Show.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Round One. &amp;nbsp;Apollo taunts Rocky, making little jabs, dancing around the ring. Rocky eventually lays him out with an uppercut to the jaw. Apollo staggers to his feet. The bell rings. They go back to their corners, and Apollo&#39;s manager tells him that Rocky doesn&#39;t know that this &quot;isn&#39;t a real fight&quot; and that Apollo needs to take him down now.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Round Two. More of the same. Both fighters get in good hits, no clear superior fighter is established. Rounds 3 through 14 pass in a blur, and both Rocky and Apollo are bloody and beaten down and snarling insults at each other everytime they get in a clinch. Rocky&#39;s nose is busted, Apollo&#39;s ribs are cracked. Both mangers want to stop the fight, but neither Apollo or Rocky agree.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Rocky&#39;s eye is sealed shut, so they cut open the lid. Rocky, I think we should see other people.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The fight finally ends, with both men still standing. Rocky bellows &quot;YO, ADRIAN! &amp;nbsp;ADRIAN!!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Adrian races through the throngs of cheering fans.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The announcer says it&#39;s a split decision. Rocky isn&#39;t even listening, just keeps calling out Adrian&#39;s name.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;She reaches the ring, he races to her.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The announcer says Apollo Creed is the winner.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Rocky takes Adrian in his arms, says he loves her. They kiss. &amp;nbsp;Needless to say, Rocky has his own definition of the word.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Wait, what? &amp;nbsp;Rocky lost?! &amp;nbsp;How the fuck did I never know that?! &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s amazing! &amp;nbsp;This is a great movie, you guys. Forgive me, I didn&#39;t know. Stallone has always been sort of a nonentity to me. &amp;nbsp;I never disliked him really, but when pressed I couldn&#39;t exactly think of a good thing to say about him, either. He&#39;s always come across as very polished, very 80&#39;s, very much a cartoon like Arnold or Van Damme or something.&amp;nbsp;I mean, I liked &lt;i&gt;Demolition Man &lt;/i&gt;okay, and &lt;i&gt;Rambo II&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;was fine, and very much of the 80&#39;s. The only Rocky movie I&#39;d ever seen before this was &lt;i&gt;Rocky IV, &lt;/i&gt;where he ends the Cold War by beating up Dolph Lundgren, so I truly had no idea just how far the series had fallen up to that point. There are a couple of weak moments, though. I didn&#39;t like Burgess Meredith&#39;s overacting or the character of Paulie, really, though both those storylines are dealt with okay. Talia Shire did fine. Though how she stumbled into two great classic franchises, I&#39;ll never know. Also, there were a few rough edits, including a scene where Rocky and Paulie exchange two lines of dialogue (&quot;Are you sure she&#39;ll go out with me?&quot; &quot;Yeah, she&#39;s thrilled.&quot;) and then thirty seconds later in they say exactly the same lines again. Bad, bad editing. But of course, the low low budget is clearly part of the movie&#39;s charm.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;I certainly wasn&#39;t at all prepared for how good Stallone would be in this, and how natural and uncalculating and un-cartoon like. And unlike anything Ahnold&#39;s ever done, this movie succeeds in part&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;because&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;of Sly&#39;s presence, not in spite of it. And Rocky the character? Well, he&#39;s just freaking adorable, is what he is, and practically angelic in both looks and deeds. I also didn&#39;t realize the match itself would be tacked on the end almost as an afterthought, and I never thought in a million billion years Rocky would lose. That&#39;s totally brilliant, that he lost but didn&#39;t really care. The writing is sometimes too earnest and sappy, and Rocky is too, but somehow the director manages to make you complicit in the sappiness, very much in the old school Spielberg way, where your heart soars and your nose crinkles simultaneously during certain scenes and lyrics like &quot;getting strong now/won&#39;t be long now/gonna fly now&quot;. &amp;nbsp;But somehow the heart wins out. The triumph of the human spirit is a very appealing notion.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;I can&#39;t believe I&#39;m even asking this, but should I watch any of the other ones, or is this totally the law of diminishing returns? &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, another big one with &quot;Jaws&quot;, and then my first Hitchcock movie ever, &quot;North By Northwest&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml'
