width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8237349745828036412</id><published>2011-08-21T13:54:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-21T15:45:10.015-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#58 The Gold Rush (1925)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-aQV_vs9EHX4/TlFFJYO4tKI/AAAAAAAAAFs/xjOFrhZ5d98/s1600/chaplin.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;232&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-aQV_vs9EHX4/TlFFJYO4tKI/AAAAAAAAAFs/xjOFrhZ5d98/s320/chaplin.png&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Betcha didn&#39;t know there was a gold rush in Alaska in the late 1800&#39;s. &amp;nbsp;Okay, maybe you did. Whatever. &amp;nbsp;What, you think you&#39;re better than me, c&lt;i&gt;ollege boy?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;The Little Tramp is a gold prospector in Alaska in the Olden Times. He&#39;s dressed like he always does, but he also has a little pick-axe or whatever. It&#39;s snowy and cold outside. He has no luck and during a horrible storm encounters&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;The cabin of escaped fugitive, Black Larsen&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;He goes inside and the escaped fugitive himself is eating a turkey leg or something he&#39;s cooked on the fire. &amp;nbsp;He tries to kick the Tramp out, but every time he opens the door to shove him out, the storm hilariously blows the Tramp back in. This happens about twenty times or so. &amp;nbsp;Then a third dude shows up, prospector Big Jim, who recently discovered a mine filled with gold but had to take shelter in the cabin when the storm showed up. Big Jim bullies the supposed bad guy (who &lt;i&gt;owns&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;the freaking cabin for God&#39;s sake) into letting him and Charlie stay there. After a couple days, they&#39;re all starving, so they draw cards to see who will go out and get them food. Poor Black Larsen gets the low card, so off he is sent into the storm, despite &lt;i&gt;owning the freaking cabin.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Then more time passes and Big Jim is so hungry he does that &lt;i&gt;Looney Tunes&lt;/i&gt; thing where he imagines Charlie as a giant chicken and chases him around the cabin and tries to shoot him. Meanwhile, Black Larsen finds Big Jim&#39;s campsite and starts eating his food. &amp;nbsp;Good for you, Black Larsen!&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Charlie tries to get Jim to see that he&#39;s not a chicken, and Jim sometimes realizes this and stops chasing him, and then fails to realize it and starts chasing him again, over and over, and Charlie does physical &quot;comedy&quot; during this that is indeed impressive but not particularly funny at all. Then a bear shows up, so they shoot and eat it. &amp;nbsp;Phew.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;So they part ways and Jim goes back alone to his campsite, where he spies Black Larsen eating his food. &amp;nbsp;They fight, and Larsen knocks Jim out with a shovel and steals his supplies. &amp;nbsp;Then he&#39;s killed by an avalanche. (Black Larsen, not Jim).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;As for the Little Tramp, he goes into town (?!) and goes to a dance hall, where he meets&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Jack, the ladies man&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;and&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;His special girl &quot;Ginger&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Ginger is mad at Jack because he&#39;s flirting with other ladies, but it&#39;s right there in his name, so I&#39;m not sure what her problem is. She tries to make Jack jealous by dancing with the first dude she sees, which of course happens to be Charlie. He falls madly in love with her, and even gets himself a picture of her. &amp;nbsp;(I dunno...there was one lying around on the bar. &amp;nbsp;Maybe she&#39;s a performer?) &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Then he finds a cabin near town. &amp;nbsp;In fact, it&#39;s&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Less than the throw of a stone away&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;which is wonderfully specific, Title Cards, thanks. He sees a man inside eating a big meal, so he pretends to be ill and passes out in front of the man&#39;s door. &amp;nbsp;The man brings him inside and gives him a drink and food and Charlie gobbles it all up and then the man says he&#39;s going a&#39;prospecting for the next few weeks and Charlie is welcome to stay at his cabin while he&#39;s gone. So, faster than you can say &quot;plot contrivance&quot;, Charlie has himself a new place to live. Then, Ginger and her girlfriends happen by, having a snowball fight. &amp;nbsp;I imagine the cabin is less than the throw of a snowball away from where they live. Charlie invites them in for some drinks, and they do so, while Charlie goes to get wood for the fire. Immediately, Ginger discovers the picture of herself under Charlie&#39;s pillow--forcing us to imagine what Little Tramp Onanism might look like--and shows her friends. &amp;nbsp;They all laugh and get all Mean Girls, deciding to mess with him. Charlie comes back and they ask him if he would like to have dinner with them on New Year&#39;s Eve next week at 8:00pm. Charlie says sure and then they leave and he spazzes out and rips up his pillow and feathers fly everywhere and then she comes back in having forgotten her gloves and it&#39;s awkward but kinda funny, I guess.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;So then New Year&#39;s comes, and Charlie has little gifts he&#39;s bought all the girls and dinner plates set up, and we cut back to the dance hall and see Ginger and the girls hanging out with Jack and laughing. Charlie falls asleep and dreams of entertaining the girls by putting dinner rolls on his forks and making them dance in that one &quot;best of Charlie Chaplin&quot; clip you&#39;ve seen on TV all the time. Also, what a terrible dream. Then Charlie wakes up after midnight and trudges into town, just as Ginger decides to go with Jack and the girls to the cabin and fuck with Charlie some more. &amp;nbsp;Man, Ginger just sucks. When they get there, though, Ginger sees the little gifts and the place settings and feels bad and when Jack tries to kiss her, she pushes him away. &amp;nbsp;He gets mad and forces himself on her, and she slaps him. The next day at the tavern, she feels bad and writes a letter,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Sorry for what I did last night. I hope you can forgive me. I love you, Ginger.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Aw...well isn&#39;t that sweet. &amp;nbsp;Maybe she&#39;s not such a bitch...oh. &amp;nbsp;She gives it to Jack. Jack reads the letter and laughs it off, then Charlie shows up and Jack tells the bartender to give the letter to him. Charlie reads it, and is so happy. He rushes into Ginger&#39;s arms, and just then Big Jim shows up. He claims to have found a mine full of gold, but can&#39;t find it anymore because the knock on the head with the shovel that Black Larsen gave him made him forget where it was. He insists Charlie take him back to the cabin right then, and figures he&#39;ll know where the mine is from there. But Charlie just wants to be with Ginger. &amp;nbsp;Fortunately, Big Jim is much stronger and carries him out of the tavern. They get back to the cabin, but there&#39;s another storm and this one blows the cabin partially off a cliff, then there&#39;s &quot;wacky&quot; hijinks, where they almost fall off the cliff and keep titling the cabin like a seesaw and finally they get out and find the mine and then they&#39;re millionaires.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They get on a boat heading back to America all dressed up fancy and whatnot, and Ginger is also on the boat and Charlie sees her while dressed in his old mining clothes for a photo-op, and she thinks he&#39;s a stowaway and offers to pay his fare, and that makes him realize that she&#39;s not pure evil so he reveals that he&#39;s rich and now he has the girl, the money, and everything, even though she was a total bitch so whatever.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I don&#39;t know. &amp;nbsp;This just isn&#39;t funny to me. &amp;nbsp;I really admire the fact that just like last time, there&#39;s a real attempt to tell a full story here with lots of depth and pathos, but just like last time, even at 80 minutes, there&#39;s a ton of filler. This could&#39;ve been a really good 30 minute short. And while Charlie is clearly gifted in the way he can move his body (in a way that Harpo most emphatically &lt;i&gt;is not&lt;/i&gt;) it&#39;s still not really funny. &amp;nbsp;Just interesting. Like watching a circus performer. But have you ever watched a circus act and been impressed for any more than ten minutes or so afterwards? &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a reason why this sort of performance art doesn&#39;t exist anymore, I think. It&#39;s just not that great.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, two enduring classics that I&#39;ve somehow managed to never see (yet feel as if I have): &quot;Rocky&quot; and then &quot;Jaws&quot;. Just when you thought it was safe to blah blah blah blah joke.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8237349745828036412/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/58-gold-rush-1925.html#comment-form' title='1 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8237349745828036412'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8237349745828036412'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/58-gold-rush-1925.html' title='#58 The Gold Rush (1925)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-aQV_vs9EHX4/TlFFJYO4tKI/AAAAAAAAAFs/xjOFrhZ5d98/s72-c/chaplin.png" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8283181258107204681</id><published>2011-08-18T09:13:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-18T17:02:58.729-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#59 Nashville (1975)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l_dLhvg2-pA/Tk0knfoyx8I/AAAAAAAAAFo/HHuy3qlEyr0/s1600/nash.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;135&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l_dLhvg2-pA/Tk0knfoyx8I/AAAAAAAAAFo/HHuy3qlEyr0/s320/nash.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Super great opening credits introduce the 24 person main-character cast with an voice over infomercial-type guy, excitedly explaining to us that we&#39;re about to see &quot;Robert Altman&#39;s &lt;i&gt;Nashville&lt;/i&gt;&quot; without commercial interruption&quot;, and then he says out loud the names of the cast while country music plays, in a way that&#39;s very reminiscent of those old album commercials on TV (A&lt;i&gt;ct now! &amp;nbsp;Get 50 songs of the price of ten!). &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;Very clever.&lt;br /&gt;Then we see a van with VOTE HAL PHILIP WALKER FOR PRESIDENT; THE REPLACEMENT PARTY on it, as we&#39;re treated to a man on a recording blasting out of the van speakers,&amp;nbsp;pledging that he&#39;s not like those other guys and wake up America those Washington fat cats are blah blah and all that Ron Paul third party goodness we love but don&#39;t ever vote for.&lt;br /&gt;We go into a recording studio where we meet the first batch of characters; there&#39;s Haven Hamilton; the old timey boot-in-your-ass country guy, currently recording a song about America&#39;s 200th birthday. &amp;nbsp;His wife Lady Pearl and their adult son are also there. &amp;nbsp;Plus, there&#39;s a BBC documentary filmmaker named Opal. &amp;nbsp;Haven stops the recording and insists that Opal leave the studio, so the son takes her to another room where she watches Linnea Reese (Lily Tomlin, yay!) sing gospel songs with a black choir. Opal speaks excitedly and hilariously racistly about African singers and how they&#39;re just a choir robe away from their primitive dancing and gyrating relatives on the other side of the planet. She&#39;s a just a real peach, that Opal.&lt;br /&gt;Cut to the airport, where huge Nashville singing sensation Barbara Jean is returning home after some time in an out of state hospital being treated for burns caused by an accident involving a firey baton. At the airport, we also meet an old man whose wife is sick in the hospital and his niece Joan, who just flew in from LA and has announced that she&#39;s changed her name to &quot;LA Joan&quot;, which means she really needs to die right now. And we meet the singing trio Bill, Tom, and Mary. &amp;nbsp;Bill and Mary are married and Tom is the womanizing one, played by an inexplicably kinda hot Keith Carradine, way before the years caught up with him and ground him into dust. Lily Tomlin&#39;s husband Delbert Reese is also there to pick up a man at the airport who is Hal Philip Walker&#39;s campaign manager and is trying to get Delbert (who is a manager for several country singers) to get Linnea and others to endorse Walker&#39;s campaign. Okay, and plus there&#39;s a waitress who can&#39;t sing but doesn&#39;t know it and another country singer named Connie White who is a rising star but not as famous as Barbara Jean. Oh, and there&#39;s a military Sargent guy who&#39;s there to watch Barbara Jean get off the plane even though he doesn&#39;t know her. &amp;nbsp;And there&#39;s probably more.&lt;br /&gt;So Barbara Jean gets off the plane and gives a little speech and everyone claps and such. But then she passes out, so her security team and handlers descend upon her and break up the mini-rally. &amp;nbsp;People begin to disperse the airport. As everyone leaves, a few cars get in an accident and clog up the whole freeway, leaving all the main characters in a traffic jam. &amp;nbsp;They chat for a while, and for a moment I get excited, thinking that the whole movie will just be these people having conversations while waiting for the traffic to clear up. But it&#39;s unfortunately over pretty quickly, although we do meet a few &lt;i&gt;more&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;characters, including a black country singer named Tommy Brown, and some goofy guy with glasses who abandons his car in a very ominous &lt;i&gt;Falling Down&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;sort of way. Funniest part of the whole movie: the BBC doc lady is interviewing Lily Tomlin and asks about her kids. &amp;nbsp;Lily says her children are deaf and the BBC lady exclaims &quot;oh, how awful!&quot; and Lily tries to say they&#39;re perfectly happy and she should meet them and the BBC lady says &quot;no, I couldn&#39;t possibly, it would be so sad!&quot; while vigorously shaking her head and I laugh for like five solid minutes.&lt;br /&gt;Then the movie ends.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review (also with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Okay, just kidding, but a play by play just isn&#39;t going to work with this movie. &amp;nbsp;Basically, these people fritter about for three hours, singing endless songs and having interpersonal dramas. &amp;nbsp;A lot of the stories worked for me: Lily Tomlin the bored housewife has an affair with Tom the singer after he relentlessly pursues her for the whole movie, and then is humiliated when he makes his next booty call before she&#39;s even left the hotel room. The waitress is hired to &quot;sing&quot; at a bawdy club and when she gets booed off the stage for not being able to sing, she is forced to strip to earn her pay for the night. &amp;nbsp;Lady Pearl is being interviewed by the BBC lady and gives a hilarious monologue where she laments the deaths of both Jack and Bobby Kennedy, and fights back tears as if recounting the deaths of close family members. Barbara Jean has a scene where she&#39;s clearly still high on drugs from the hospital and she&#39;s supposed to be giving a concert and instead just starts telling endless stream-of-consciousness monologues like a meth head.&lt;br /&gt;A lot of the stories were kind of boring or just underdeveloped: The black country singer is called out and derided by other black characters for being a sellout. There&#39;s a limo driver that doesn&#39;t know his place. &amp;nbsp;The old man&#39;s wife dies in the hospital and he&#39;s sad. &amp;nbsp;LA Joan doesn&#39;t do or say anything interesting at all. &amp;nbsp;The Sargent who seems to be in love with Barbara Jean for some reason. The BBC lady is probably crazy and not even from the BBC. And so on.&lt;br /&gt;And there&#39;s singing. &amp;nbsp;So much fucking singing.&lt;br /&gt;The movie ends with all the main characters at a political rally for Hal Philip Walker and Barbara Jean opens the rally with a song, and the &lt;i&gt;Falling Down&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;guy very predictably shoots her and then is taken out by the marine Sargent guy. Then Haven in a state of shock and possibly shot in the arm himself, hands the mic to Connie White the newbie singer, and insists that she continue singing. &amp;nbsp;And she does! &amp;nbsp;And Lily Tomlin and her gospel choir also keep singing and the rally doesn&#39;t even disperse, as the &lt;i&gt;Falling Down &lt;/i&gt;guy is dragged away. &amp;nbsp;I loved that whole part.&lt;br /&gt;In general, Robert Altman is a mixed bag for me. Didn&#39;t care for &lt;i&gt;Gosford Park, &lt;/i&gt;hated &lt;i&gt;The Gingerbread Man &lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;Cookie&#39;s Fortune,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;thought &lt;i&gt;Dr. T and the Women&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;was just okay, absolutely loved &lt;i&gt;Short Cuts, The Player,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;Streamers. &lt;/i&gt;(Very soon will be seeing &lt;i&gt;M.A.S.H.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;for the first time).&amp;nbsp;His style of filmmaking is obviously incredibly unique and special. &amp;nbsp;Lots of directors put you &quot;there&quot; in a very cinematic way; you&#39;re right next to the main character, or sometimes even seeing through his or her eyes and feeling totally immersed. &amp;nbsp;With Altman, you&#39;re &quot;there&quot; in the sense that would occur in reality. &amp;nbsp;If you&#39;re really &quot;there&quot; at a political rally for example, then you don&#39;t get to hear or see everything. &amp;nbsp;Everyone&#39;s talking at once, no one&#39;s concerned with making sure you understand what&#39;s going on. And while that can be intriguing and engaging sometimes in a movie, it&#39;s also a bit confusing and off-putting, at least for me. &amp;nbsp;I had to watch this movie twice just to get a handle on who the fuck everybody is, and I think that&#39;s a bit much. &amp;nbsp;But I liked parts of this movie a lot, especially the ending. &amp;nbsp;The singing got real old real fast, though.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Um...three. &amp;nbsp;No, three and a half. &amp;nbsp;Yeah. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, more silence with &quot;The Gold Rush&quot; and then I guess I&#39;ll finally see &quot;Rocky&quot;, yo.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8283181258107204681/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/59-nashville-1975.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8283181258107204681'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8283181258107204681'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/59-nashville-1975.html' title='#59 Nashville (1975)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l_dLhvg2-pA/Tk0knfoyx8I/AAAAAAAAAFo/HHuy3qlEyr0/s72-c/nash.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4236531230055880649</id><published>2011-08-10T13:41:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-10T14:58:46.238-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#60 Duck Soup (1933)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-3VhTxzlG_3Y/TkAQjors9PI/AAAAAAAAAFk/B0UJcgBsm34/s1600/duck.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-3VhTxzlG_3Y/TkAQjors9PI/AAAAAAAAAFk/B0UJcgBsm34/s1600/duck.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sigh. &amp;nbsp;All right, so...they&#39;re back. &amp;nbsp;And now there&#39;s a fourth, even less funny one called Zeppo. Let me just make sure Waldorf and Statler are ready to watch with me.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;Well, you gotta give&#39;m credit.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Statler: &lt;/b&gt;Why&#39;s that?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;They&#39;re gonna keep on doing it until they get it right.&lt;br /&gt;BWA HA HA HA HA HA HA!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;There&#39;s a fake country called Freedonia and they&#39;re out of money and some rich lady will loan them money, but only if the king or emperor or whatever resigns and they put in this dude she likes named Rufus T. Firefly (Groucho). &amp;nbsp;Kinda a cool name, so there&#39;s that at least.&lt;br /&gt;So then there&#39;s a big ball or whatever to welcome the new King Firefly. The ambassador of a neighboring country named Tretino (the man, not the country) wants to woo the rich lady Mrs. Teasdale and get money for his country too, but his pretty friend Vera warns him that Mrs. Teasdale has a crush on Firefly so he probably won&#39;t get any. &amp;nbsp;Then they hatch a plan for Vera to seduce Firefly and Mrs. Teasdale will go to Tretino in her grief. Then Mrs. Teasdale introduces Firefly&#39;s secretary (Tretino) to Tretino and they talk about how Firefly is due to arrive any minute now and Tretino sure hopes he isn&#39;t late and Tretino says he definitely won&#39;t be late and then starts singing about how late Firefly isn&#39;t going to be and then everyone in the ballroom starts singing about how Firefly will arrive when the clock strikes ten and then they keep singing and singing and then all line up and face the doorway and the clock strikes and they sing and sing and then the song ends and...OMG. &amp;nbsp;You will not fucking believe it. &amp;nbsp;HE&#39;S LATE. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s funny because they said he wouldn&#39;t be late.&lt;br /&gt;And then he shows up, but comes sliding down a pole in the middle of the room and joins everyone looking in the doorway and then they see him and phew.&lt;br /&gt;Then Mrs. Teasdale talks to Groucho and he calls her fat and stupid and ugly and says &quot;don&#39;t leave in a huff if you take a taxi you can leave in a minute and a huff&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Oh God, this is really happening again, isn&#39;t it?&lt;br /&gt;Then Tretino shows up and Groucho is a dick to him because he thinks he&#39;s after Teasdale&#39;s money and Groucho wants it all to himself. So then Groucho sings about how he&#39;ll be a great new leader and everyone sings and blah.&lt;br /&gt;Next scene. Tretino reveals he has employed two spies to spy on Groucho and figure out a way to unseat him somehow or something. The two spies turn out to be Chico and Harpo. Chico&#39;s the one who is funny because he&#39;s Italian and says horrible puns with a horrible fake accent. &amp;nbsp;Harpo is the one who doesn&#39;t talk and is basically a sociopath. In this scene, Tretino and Chico talk and Harpo honks his horn and produces giant shears which he uses to cut up Tretino&#39;s clothes and white paint that he uses to fuck up various things in Tretino&#39;s office. &amp;nbsp;(Okay, there was a kinda funny part when a lady brings in a telegram and Harpo reads it and gets pissed and crumbles it up and Tratino says &quot;what did it say?&quot; and Chico says, &quot;He just gets mad because he can&#39;t read&quot; &amp;nbsp;I chuckled. &amp;nbsp;Honest to God).&lt;br /&gt;Then the scene ends with Chico promising to spy more on Groucho.&lt;br /&gt;Then they&#39;re outside selling popcorn in a little kiosk in front of Groucho&#39;s castle or whatever and there&#39;s a hot dog vendor there, and Harpo&#39;s a total dick to him for no reason at all and steals the guy&#39;s hat over and over and honks his horn over and over and they all fall down and seriously I cannot fucking believe this shit. The scene ends when Harpo burns the guy&#39;s hat up. And the guy is just like &quot;Why you little....&quot; and all that.&lt;br /&gt;So then Groucho sees them and hires them and tells them to come up to his office and there are more hijinks and Zeppo is also there &amp;nbsp;Harpo keeps cutting shit and also has a bunch of tattoos on his body and he seriously needs to go to jail. &amp;nbsp;Then Zeppo tells Groucho to goad Tretino into slapping him so that he&#39;ll have to leave the country but Groucho winds up slapping him instead which leads to Tretino declaring war on Freedonia.&lt;br /&gt;Then Chico and Harpo are total assholes to the hot dog vendor guy again and burn his new hat.&lt;br /&gt;Then Groucho flirts with Mrs. Teasdale, asks for a lock of her hair. &amp;nbsp;Then he says, &quot;I&#39;m letting you off easy. &amp;nbsp;I was gonna ask for the whole wig&quot;, in a cadence that suggests a joke, but there&#39;s no actual joke. &amp;nbsp;This is a running theme. He also says his father was a little too headstrong and his mother was an armstrong and the Headstrongs married the Armstrongs and that&#39;s how darkies were born, which is a racist word but also doesn&#39;t make any fucking sense as an actual joke.&lt;br /&gt;Then Tretino enlists their help in breaking into Groucho&#39;s house and stealing his war plans. So they break in and lock Groucho in the bathroom and then dress up like Groucho to steal the plans from Mrs. Teasdale. Wacky stuff happens. &amp;nbsp;Then Groucho breaks out and does shtick in front of a mirror with Harpo dressed as Groucho, where they synchronize their movements like on all those Bugs Bunny cartoons and Bette Midler in &lt;i&gt;Big Business&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;and it&#39;s played out now, but it had to be pretty cool in its day, and wasn&#39;t bad now, I&#39;ll admit. &amp;nbsp;Though it goes on too long.&lt;br /&gt;Then Chico and Harpo are arrested as spies. &amp;nbsp;Groucho says they&#39;ll get ten years in Levenworth or maybe eleven years in Twelveworth. Chico says something something rhymes with worth. A military guy runs in and says Tretino has troops on Freedonia&#39;s soil, this means war. A congressman guy says that will raise Freedonia&#39;s taxes. &amp;nbsp;Chico says he has an uncle that lives in Texas. &amp;nbsp;No, taxes! &amp;nbsp;Dollars, taxes. &amp;nbsp;Yeah, he lives in Dallas, Texas! Then there are two hundred thousand more puns.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Statler: &lt;/b&gt;These seats are awful&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;Why, can&#39;t you see anything?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Statler: &lt;/b&gt;That&#39;s the problem, I can see everything.&lt;br /&gt;BWA HA HA HA HA HA HA!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So, then everyone sings a song about going to war, which starts out kind of fun and silly because of the sheer amount of extras all singing and dancing in perfect crazy choreography, but ultimately goes on too long.&lt;br /&gt;Then there&#39;s a war and they keep shooting at each other and Groucho accidentally shoots his own men, and then offers to pay Zeppo five dollars if he&#39;ll keep it under his hat and then takes the money back and says he&#39;ll keep it under his own hat and that&#39;s the fucking joke there. &amp;nbsp;Then the other army invades but Tretino gets his head caught some debris and is stuck like he&#39;s in a stockade and the brothers throw vegetables as him. Then he surrenders and Groucho says, &quot;sorry you&#39;ll have to wait until the food runs out&quot; then they throw shit at Mrs. Teasdale too.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Statler: &lt;/b&gt;Just when you think this show is terrible, something wonderful happens.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;What?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Statler: &lt;/b&gt;It ends.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;BWA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA!!!!!!!!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Better than &lt;i&gt;A Night at the Opera&lt;/i&gt;, if I may damn with faint praise. I actually chuckled a few times, which is a few more than the other movie, and I admire the spirit of the thing, I guess. &amp;nbsp;The mirror thing was pretty cool, too. But Groucho&#39;s jokes for the most part aren&#39;t actual jokes, and he&#39;s the only tolerable one of the whole lot. Chico fucking grates on my nerves and Harpo is a complete overacting, smug, scenery devouring unfunny piece of shit, like Jerry Lewis times a thousand. Fucking hate him. Zeppo was a zero who didn&#39;t even register as a person, but at least he wasn&#39;t offensively horrible like Harpo. &amp;nbsp;At any rate, I&#39;m done. &amp;nbsp;There are no more Marx movies on this list, thank god.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Nashville&quot;, which is pretty exciting, and then &quot;The Gold Rush&quot;, my second of three Charlie Chaplin movies.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" width="72"/><thr:total>2</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1377511048430553086</id><published>2011-08-07T10:43:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-08T09:38:48.571-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#61 Sullivan&#39;s Travels (1942)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tK7H0I7W3c4/Tj61PCpLIWI/AAAAAAAAAFg/Wir2fh73kqA/s1600/bb.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tK7H0I7W3c4/Tj61PCpLIWI/AAAAAAAAAFg/Wir2fh73kqA/s1600/bb.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;We begin &lt;i&gt;in media res--&lt;/i&gt;which is a pretentious hipster phrase I like using--two men are fighting on top a moving train. &amp;nbsp;One man shoots the other several times in the chest and the second man falls onto the first, making him stumble back and they both fall off the train and into the water. &quot;The End&quot; comes onscreen, for we are indeed watching a movie. Movie director John L Sullivan (Sacramento shout-out!) is screening his new movie to two studio executives. &amp;nbsp;They don&#39;t like it because it&#39;s not funny and that&#39;s why people come to see movies nowadays. They need escapism. &amp;nbsp;Sullivan says he&#39;s tired of making shitty comedies from the Olden Times, which immediately makes him my new hero. He&#39;s clearly seen &lt;i&gt;Yankee Doodle Dandy, Swing Time,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;and &lt;i&gt;A Night at the Opera. &lt;/i&gt;He wants to make socially conscious art and adapt from Sinclair Beckstein&#39;s new novel, &lt;i&gt;Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? &lt;/i&gt;while the studio heads want him to make a sequel to last summer&#39;s big hit, &lt;i&gt;Ants in Your Plants. &lt;/i&gt;Heh. But Sullivan&#39;s no sell-out. &amp;nbsp;He wants to make a movie about pain and suffering and the human condition. &amp;nbsp;The studio heads scoff at him and tell him he knows nothing of human suffering, having been born with a silver spoon in his mouth. &amp;nbsp;He realizes they&#39;re right, and sets off to become a hobo for a few weeks until he can learn what it&#39;s like.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;He has his butler get him some shabby clothes. &amp;nbsp;His second butler tells him it&#39;s a really bad idea, and not only is he kinda making light of real homeless people (called hobos or tramps in this movie, so I&#39;ll just go with that, don&#39;t hate me), but he&#39;s also risking a lot. &amp;nbsp;The studio heads convince Sullivan to put his business card in his shoe, should be ever need to identify himself, and to let his staff follow behind him in a big motor home.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Cut to Sullivan walking down the highway with the classic hobo outfit, including a stick with a bag tied to the top while a giant motor home follows behind him by about twenty feet. Heh.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;But then a little kid in a...motorized go kart? &amp;nbsp;Mini-car of some kind? &amp;nbsp;Dunno...offers him a ride. &amp;nbsp;He jumps in and the kid goes barreling down the highway at top speed and the motor home is forced to catch up with him and all the staff in the motor home go crash boom bang and fall on top of each other and the negro chef falls into some batter and looks like he&#39;s doing whiteface and blah blah shitty comedy shitty comedy and in the end the motor home crashes and Sullivan gets out of the kid&#39;s car and tells them he&#39;s going off on his own and will meet them in Las Vegas in a few weeks.&lt;br /&gt;He meets up with a lady and asks her for a dime for dinner but she&#39;s a lonely old widower who takes him home and changes his clothes and takes him out to dinner and a movie and it&#39;s his movie and he&#39;s super bored watching it while a kid behind him kicks the seat, someone else loudly unwraps candy, and a baby cries. Wow, some things really do never change. Anyway, that night he sneaks out of her house through the window and falls into a barrel of water and then is freezing cold. &amp;nbsp;He hitches a ride from a trucker who lets him sleep in the back, and when the trucker wakes him up the next day he discovers he&#39;s right back in Hollywood. &amp;nbsp;He goes into a diner and buys a cup of coffee with his last remaining dime. A beautiful blonde woman there buys him ham and eggs. They chat for a bit, and he learns she&#39;s a failed actress who would like to go back home to the East Coast, but can&#39;t because she has no car and is broke. What he doesn&#39;t learn, ever, is her name. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s known only as The Girl in the credits, which is a pretty refreshing bit of honesty, really. &amp;nbsp;If all Hollywood movies did this, more than half of them would include a token female character named &quot;The Girl&quot;. &amp;nbsp;He tells her he can borrow a car from a friend and gets his own car and starts driving her back, but his butlers report the car stolen and he and The Girl are thrown in jail. &amp;nbsp;He must call his butlers to get him out, and soon he&#39;s back home at the mansion with The Girl. &amp;nbsp;Once she learns who he is and his plans, she says she wants to go with him on his next &quot;pretend you&#39;re a hobo for a day&quot; experiment. &amp;nbsp;He puts up a token protest, then goes along with it. &amp;nbsp;They hitch a ride on a train and find themselves staring at a couple of other tramps. Sullivan says, &quot;hey there, fellas. How do you feel about the current economic condition?&quot; and the tramps hurriedly stand up and step outside and start working their way to the next car. &amp;nbsp;Ha, nice! Anyway, by the next day, Sullivan is sick and sneezes super big and &quot;comically&quot; over and over, and The Girl is starving and when the train slows down, they jump out and make their way to a little diner. &amp;nbsp;They beg for food and the diner owner takes pity on them and gives them coffee and donuts. &amp;nbsp;Sullivan asks what city they&#39;re in. &amp;nbsp;Las Vegas, of course. &amp;nbsp;Las Vegas! &amp;nbsp;Have you seen a large motor home around here? &amp;nbsp;Why sure, right over there to your right. &amp;nbsp;(Oh, fucking come on).&lt;br /&gt;Yes, Sullivan&#39;s whole staff are right there, so Sullivan and The Girl board the motor home and get fresh showers and food and Sullivan&#39;s personal doctor says he&#39;s too sick to continue pretending to be a bum for at least a few days so they all hang out in the motor home until then. &lt;br /&gt;A few days later, Sullivan the The Girl set out to play Tramp House once again, and there&#39;s montage of them walking through Tramp Cities, eating scraps cooked on the bonfire, until one day they&#39;re just sick of it and go racing back to the motor home which had been following them. &amp;nbsp;Total time elapse: three days. &lt;br /&gt;The studio heads reveal they&#39;ve been taking notes and photos of Sullivan&#39;s scary walk on the wild side, and are very excited to make the &lt;i&gt;Oh Brother &lt;/i&gt;movie, now. Sullivan asks The Girl what she&#39;s going to do now, and she hints that she wants to stay with him and have his babies of course, but he reveals that he&#39;s already married. &amp;nbsp;DUN DUN. &amp;nbsp;Actually, they revealed that at the beginning, but I forgot to throw that in there. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, he tells her it was a marriage of convince that his business manager suggested to save on taxes (traditional values FTW!) but now his &quot;wife&quot; who lives elsewhere makes him send her money every month to keep the marriage a secret and won&#39;t grant him a divorce. He can&#39;t get one without her permission because whatever 1941 laws or maybe the movie is full of it, who knows. The Girl is sad. Sullivan says he&#39;s going to go around one last time to Hobo City and give everyone five dollar bills in a gesture to make him feel okay about exploiting them. &amp;nbsp;He does so at night, and one of the tramps sees him and decides he wants more than five bucks. He hides behind a corner, and ambushes Sullivan, bashing him on the head with a bottle. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re right by a rail yard, so he drags Sullivan onto a railcar and leaves him there. Sullivan&#39;s out cold, so the tramp steals the rest of his money and his shoes, then goes running through the rail yard. He trips on a rail and the money goes flying. As he starts to desperately scoop it all up, a train comes barreling down on him and for some dumb reason he tries to outrun it instead of getting out of the way and he&#39;s smashed.&lt;br /&gt;The next day, Sullivan&#39;s staff and The Girl go around town to all the hospitals, police stations, and morgues. &amp;nbsp;At the morgue, they say a man was brought in last night, too obliterated to identify. But they checked in his shoe, and....uh oh.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Sullivan wakes up groggy in another city. He wanders off the train, which is stopped at a railway station. &amp;nbsp;The rail employee gives him shit and starts pushing him. Sullivan is still really put out by his head wound and can barely stand. The guy pushes him again, and Sullivan falls to the ground. He jumps back up, pissed, with a rock in his hand and starts hitting the guy with it.&lt;br /&gt;The next scene, he&#39;s on trial for assault with intent to kill. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s still too groggy, can&#39;t remember his own name, and can&#39;t defend himself. &amp;nbsp;So..the trial was later that day? &amp;nbsp;The Olden Times were really fucking efficient when they wanted to be. He&#39;s sentenced to six years hard labor at some weird work camp/jail hybrid place where Sullivan, now coherent, tries to tell people who he is, but of course no one will believe him. &amp;nbsp;He tries to get a phone call or write a letter, but the Evil Warden (is there any other kind?) doesn&#39;t like his shitty attitude and won&#39;t let him. &amp;nbsp;So all day, he must break rocks with his shirt off and get treated like shit by the other inmates. &amp;nbsp;He sees one guard with a newspaper that says &quot;Hollywood Director Sullivan Mysteriously Killed&quot; and knows no one is even looking for him. &amp;nbsp;His goose is well and truly cooked. The warden announces that that night the prisoners are getting a special treat, a field trip to a local church to watch a movie.&lt;br /&gt;Turns out, it&#39;s a black church, and the pastor tells his parishioners to not be judgmental and that all have sinned etc and they nod and agree and sing a sweet gospel ditty as the prisoners are brought in. The movie they screen is a dumb Disney cartoon where Pluto gets into all kinds of wacky trouble, and Sullivan notices with awe that all the prisoners and the black churchgoers are laughing their asses off. &amp;nbsp;And soon, he is too. &amp;nbsp;Nice twist. &amp;nbsp;Did not see that coming. Though of course the bit players have to ruin it a bit by hamming it up huge and doubling over and almost literally rolling in the aisles at fucking Pluto falling down.&lt;br /&gt;So, the next day Sullivan comes up with a great idea. &amp;nbsp;He &quot;confesses&quot; to the &quot;murder&quot; of famous Hollywood director John L Sullivan. His picture is in the paper, and The Girl sees it and she tells everyone else. &amp;nbsp;Soon, Sullivan&#39;s rescued from jail because also famous Hollywood directors are free to hit whoever they want with rocks, duh. Why do you think Lily Tomlin hates David O Russell so much?&lt;br /&gt;The Girl tells Sullivan that his &quot;widower&quot; married his business manager when they thought he was dead, which means they&#39;re now divorced (uh...okay) and so now he and she can get married and she&#39;ll become Mrs. Girl Sullivan. &amp;nbsp;Yay! The studio heads excitedly tell him that his story got a ton of great publicity and now they can definitely make &lt;i&gt;Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? &lt;/i&gt;into a monster hit. But Sullivan doesn&#39;t want to do that anymore, because he still doesn&#39;t really know about suffering. &amp;nbsp;He only now knows what he doesn&#39;t know.&lt;br /&gt;And what he &lt;i&gt;does&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;know, is people need shitty comedies. &amp;nbsp;Now more than ever. &amp;nbsp;Onto &lt;i&gt;Ants in Your Plants 2! &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Well, not bad at all. &amp;nbsp;Lots of great twists, I really didn&#39;t know where the movie was going at all, which was fun. At first I thought we were just going to see Sullivan and The Girl try and fail to &quot;suffer&quot; over and over, which was cute for a while, but then the third act manages to get Sullivan in real trouble which generally played well. The &quot;insta-trial&quot; was super dumb and embarrassing. They were clearly straining really hard to make it believable that Sullivan would be unable to contact any of his friends and they don&#39;t quite make it, but whatever. Also, some of the early &quot;comedy&quot; scenes were as horrible as they have been in every Olden Times movie I&#39;ve seen save for &lt;i&gt;Bringing Up Baby&lt;/i&gt;, although there was some smart stuff, too. It&#39;s actually kind of frustrating that a movie with some really sharp lines and a knowing grasp of what&#39;s absurd about the shallow Hollywood elites would resort to cheap &quot;people falling down&quot; crap at all. The twist at the end with Sullivan realizing the power and value of the silly comedy was pretty neat and I totally didn&#39;t see it coming. Personally, I find engrossing dramas of human suffering to be as much or even more a form of escapism. But I seem to very much be in the minority on this. I appreciated that the black churchgoers were portrayed with dignity and respect, something that was so rare back then, that the President of the NAACP wrote director Preston Sturges and thanked him for it. (I guess the President politely overlooked the earlier scenes with the dumb black chef).&lt;br /&gt;And yes, the Coen Bros titled their movie based on the fake book in this one.&lt;br /&gt;I&#39;d like to see this remade. &amp;nbsp;Drop the shitty comedy stuff, amp up the smart satire, make the third act more realistic and dangerous for Sullivan, and you&#39;ve got yourself a movie. &amp;nbsp;Maybe even get a real director to star in it. &amp;nbsp;Ooh, I know! Starring Martin Scorsese. Written by Charlie Kaufman, directed by Spike Jonez. &amp;nbsp;Done.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, the fucking &quot;comedy&quot; &quot;geniuses&quot; known as the Marx &quot;Brothers&quot; assault my eyes and ears again with &quot;Duck Soup&quot; and then one I&#39;m really looking forward to; Robert Altman&#39;s &quot;Nashville&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1377511048430553086/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/61-sullivans-travels-1941.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1377511048430553086'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1377511048430553086'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/61-sullivans-travels-1941.html' title='#61 Sullivan&#39;s Travels (1942)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tK7H0I7W3c4/Tj61PCpLIWI/AAAAAAAAAFg/Wir2fh73kqA/s72-c/bb.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1246177599067413562</id><published>2011-08-01T15:01:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-08-01T15:15:01.502-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#62 American Graffiti (1973)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-hzuurFtnAMA/TjbvVBcdkII/AAAAAAAAAFU/XHQkgGf4K-8/s1600/%2527American+Graffiti%2527.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;295&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-hzuurFtnAMA/TjbvVBcdkII/AAAAAAAAAFU/XHQkgGf4K-8/s320/%2527American+Graffiti%2527.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;That is one bitchin&#39; ride, man.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;So yeah. &amp;nbsp;This is the movie that inspired&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Happy Days&lt;/i&gt;, the show everyone in my generation watched and loved until Ted McGinley showed up.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The year is 1962. Four friends have just graduated high school and are going out for one last night on the town before real life intrudes. There&#39;s Steve (aka Richie Cunningham himself, Ron Howard, severely testing my theory that all ginger dudes are inherently hot), Curt (nerdy, overweight Richard Dreyfuss who looks crazy young and yet will play a grown up scientist just two years later in&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Jaws&lt;/i&gt;, I&#39;m interested in seeing how that works), Terry (that ugly old guy &quot;Charles Martin Smith&quot; who&#39;s in every third movie playing ugly old guys, google him), and John (guy I&#39;ve never seen before who&#39;s playing a proto-Fonzie character).&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;At the start, Steve and Curt discuss the fact that they&#39;re both leaving for college the next day while the other two are staying behind. But Curt hedges a bit and says he might not be going, after all. &amp;nbsp;He wants to stay in town and go to Junior college. Oh, Curt. &amp;nbsp;Don&#39;t do it, buddy. &amp;nbsp;I know whereof I speak. Steve doesn&#39;t want to hear that nonsense and insists that they&#39;re going to college together tomorrow, dammit.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Steve announces to Terry that he&#39;s going to let him borrow his car while he&#39;s away at college, which is pretty generous, and Terry immediately wants to take it for a spin. &amp;nbsp;He drives off. Then John drives off in his spectacular yellow car (I don&#39;t know car names) that&#39;s in the pic above. I guess these friends aren&#39;t terribly interested in hanging out on their final night together. Then Steve meets up with his girlfriend Laurie (Cindy Williams, aka&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Laverne and Shirley&#39;s&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;Laverne or Shirley, whichever is the dark-haired one) and tells her quite reasonably that he still wants to go steady with her, but would like to take a break while he&#39;s 3,000 miles away at school, and see other people. Laurie chokes this down and pretends very hard to be okay with it. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Then, everybody goes &quot;cruising&quot;. &amp;nbsp;By which I mean, they drive their gorgeous boat cars up and down the road over and over again and have conversations with drivers in other cars when they&#39;re stopped at traffic lights, like they&#39;re at a bar or something. Thanks for destroying the ozone, dicks.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Curt is riding with Steve and Laurie and he sees a beautiful blond woman (The Thighmaster Suzanne Somers) in another car smile at him and mouth something. &amp;nbsp;He rolls down his window and says &quot;what?!&quot;, but the light turns and she goes around the corner. &amp;nbsp;Curt begs Steve to follow her, but he refuses, so Curt gets out of the car to try to find her on foot.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;From this point on, all four guys are basically separate for most of the movie with their own storylines that are intercut with each other, but I&#39;m just gonna tell each one separately.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;John sees a car full of girls at a light and starts hitting on one of them, and then asks her to get in his car. The girl refuses, and so he asks if anyone in the car would like to join him. &quot;Well, my sister would&quot;. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Great! &amp;nbsp;Your sister, your mother, whatever&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Way to play it cool, John. &amp;nbsp;So, someone in the back of the car who John can&#39;t even see gets out of the car and gets into John&#39;s &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s like internet chatting. Turns out the someone is a 12 year old girl, which makes it even more like internet chatting. John tries to get her to leave, but her sister has already taken off. The girl (Carol) says she&#39;s real mature for her age and wants to make time with a boy. John is rude to her at first, but then defends her when another guy in another car says something mean to her. Then some girls in another car throws a water balloon at John, but he ducks and it hits Carol. They laugh at this, then get out of the car and spray the girls&#39; car with shaving cream. It&#39;s wacky and they bond. John tries to trick Carol into saying where she lives, but she insists that she wants to stay out all night until she finds a man. So he calls her bluff and starts uncomfortably and hilariously trying to hit on her, and she immediately spills her address. When he drops her off, he kisses her on the cheek and it&#39;s quite sweet.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Terry drives Steve&#39;s car around until he meets a girl named Debbie who&#39;s impressed enough to get in. She wants alcohol, so he goes to a liquor store and does the &quot;I lost my ID&quot; thing which doesn&#39;t work with the clerk, so he stands outside the store and asks an old man to buy some booze for him. The old man takes the money, buys some wine, and then disappears out the back door. Heh. &amp;nbsp;Terry borrows more money from Debbie and then asks someone else to get him some liquor. The guy says yes, then disappears inside for a bit. The camera stays on Terry, then suddenly the guy races out with a paper bag with a bottle of booze, throws it at Terry, and then runs away, immediately followed by the clerk who has a gun and shoots at him several times. &amp;nbsp;WTF. &amp;nbsp;Seriously, what just happened? &amp;nbsp;Anyone seen this movie? &amp;nbsp;The guy apparently ran out without paying, I guess? &amp;nbsp;And gave the booze to Terry anyway? &amp;nbsp;He put his life at risk to get some stranger booze, and got nothing out of it but the cost of the bottle? This does not make sense at all.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Anyway, they go to Makeout Hill or whatever, drink a little, then decide to go off into the bushes to have sex instead of the back of the car like proper folk, and by the time they get back, the car is stolen.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Steve and Laurie go to a dance where Laurie starts crying and Steve feels bad and says he no longer wants to see other people and promises to pretend to be monogamous while away at college. A teacher at the dance warns them to stop dancing so close together and Steve triumphantly tells him to &quot;kiss a duck&quot; because he&#39;s graduated already. I say we bring back &quot;kiss a duck&quot;. &amp;nbsp;That is some seriously hardcore shit. &amp;nbsp;But then Steve and Laurie go to a diner and break up again and then make up again while driving away and then break up again at Makeout Hill and Laurie winds up kicking Steve out of her car and driving off, leaving him. He stumbles upon Terry and Debbie and they all walk back into town.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Curt goes on his search for the hot blond, and sits on a car that belongs to some greasers who are in a gang called &quot;The Pharaohs&quot; where they wear matching jackets with their gang name on them, just like the Bloods and Crips do. The Pharaohs make Curt go with them and force him under the threat of violence steal quarters from a pinball machine and then later to tie a chain to a police car which causes the rear axle to come off. The Pharaohs are impressed with Curt&#39;s abilities and try to make him join their knockoff bullshit Disney gang. He politely promises to think about it. He then goes to the local DJ, Wolfmann Jack, and begs him to read a note on the air, asking the mystery blond woman to meet him at the local burger joint in an hour. While there, Curt sits in his car and suddenly this phone that&#39;s attached by a long wire &amp;nbsp;to this giant box starts to ring. Curt walks up to the giant box and answers the phone, even though it&#39;s obviously not his cell. &amp;nbsp;Weird. The person on the phone claims to be the blond, and says she&#39;ll meet with him the next day, but Curt says he&#39;ll be gone off to college the next day. &amp;nbsp;Aw. Go, Curt!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Steve, Terry, and Debbie get back into town and Steve goes off on his own. Terry and Debbie find Steve&#39;s car parked at the burger joint and try to steal it back. &amp;nbsp;The thieves catch them and start beating the tar out of Terry. John drives by at that point and fights both of them off. Then Steve learns from some kids in the diner that Laurie has gone off with Harrison Ford, who is a drag racer who has spent the movie trying to find and challenge drag-racing champion John to a race. Everyone rushes off to find Laurie, who they all agree should under no circumstances be around Harrison Ford. They find them outside of town on a long strip of road. Harrison Ford challenges John to a race, and John agrees. Steve begs Laurie to get out of the car first, but she won&#39;t. Terry says &quot;Go!&quot; and they peel out. &amp;nbsp;Harrison Ford is barely pulling ahead when his tire blows and he goes flying off the road and flips upside down. Everyone runs over and bizarrely, Laurie and Harrison Ford are already out of the car, barely even injured. I guess seat belts are for suckers. &amp;nbsp;Steve pulls Laurie away from the car and John helps Harrison Ford and the car blows up.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next morning. Everyone&#39;s at the airport to see Curt off to college. But Steve isn&#39;t going, because Steve is again back with Laurie and has decided to ruin his life for the chance to knock her up and never amount to anything.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Curt disappears onto the plane and everyone watches it take off. &amp;nbsp;The most depressing title cards ever tell us that John was killed by a drunk driver two years later, and Terry went MIA in Vietnam, and Steve is single and an insurance agent and Curt is a writer in Canada. The End.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;I think this movie invented the &quot;high school kids celebrate their last night of childhood&quot; genre of teen movies, and it&#39;s probably the best of that sad little genre. The individual stories were nice, some better than others, and Richard Dreyfuss stuck out in particular as a very likable and interesting character and he definitely had the most interesting arc. I&#39;m not sure what it added up to though, besides a mildly interesting character study. I mean, Robert Altman does this stuff much better, and spices up the boring parts with Julianne Moore&#39;s crotch. There&#39;s not much really wrong with it (apart from the stupid title cards) I laughed, I cared, but not a lot. I think this is a movie for a specific group of people, namely who were in high school in the 60&#39;s and actually cruised around in those boats. On that level, it&#39;s no doubt a very compelling time capsule, but for the rest of us...eh. A truly great movie puts you &quot;there&quot;, no matter how alien that world is to you in reality. &amp;nbsp;Earlier AFI entries come to mind: &lt;i&gt;The Last Picture Show, The Shawshank Redemption, In the Heat of the Night, Pulp Fiction. &lt;/i&gt;This one kept me at an arm&#39;s length. I know this is the movie that inspired George Lucas to cast Harrison Ford as Han and later Indy, so if nothing else, that&#39;s pretty great. &amp;nbsp;Also, if there were no &lt;i&gt;Graffiti, &lt;/i&gt;there would be no &lt;i&gt;Happy Days&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;and quite possibly no Ron Howard the director. Which would mean that Clint Howard would be under a bridge somewhere, trying to steal your firstborn son unless you give him gold.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;So, there&#39;s more pluses than minuses, is what I&#39;m saying.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;Sullivan&#39;s Travels&quot; (?), and then...oh god. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Duck Soup&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1246177599067413562/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/62-american-graffiti-1973.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1246177599067413562'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1246177599067413562'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/08/62-american-graffiti-1973.html' title='#62 American Graffiti (1973)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-hzuurFtnAMA/TjbvVBcdkII/AAAAAAAAAFU/XHQkgGf4K-8/s72-c/%2527American+Graffiti%2527.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8017814283380529806</id><published>2011-07-29T13:36:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-07-29T13:36:26.051-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#63 Cabaret (1972)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-c7AREc8q-gk/TjL6jgaKuJI/AAAAAAAAAFQ/0S5SpYEJllc/s1600/train.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-c7AREc8q-gk/TjL6jgaKuJI/AAAAAAAAAFQ/0S5SpYEJllc/s1600/train.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So, we&#39;ve finally come to AFI&#39;s token gay(ish) movie, I guess. &amp;nbsp;Couldn&#39;t be &lt;i&gt;Brokeback Mountain, &lt;/i&gt;or &lt;i&gt;The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert &lt;/i&gt;or &lt;i&gt;Philadelphia, &lt;/i&gt;or &lt;i&gt;Were the World Mine&lt;/i&gt;, or &lt;i&gt;In and Out,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;or one of the other dozens of good gay movies out there. &amp;nbsp;Actually, I lied. &amp;nbsp;Those are all the good gay movies out there. All right, fine. I guess this is the only one with Liza.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;i&gt;Wilkomen! &amp;nbsp;Bienvenue! &amp;nbsp;Welcome! &amp;nbsp;The Kit Kat Klub is proud to present, Fraulein Sally Bowles! &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;It&#39;s Berlin, 1931, a totally safe and uneventful time in Germany&#39;s history. &amp;nbsp;American singer Lucille 2 (um..I mean, Sally) performs nightly at the Kit Kat Klub and lives in a little apartment nearby. The Master of Ceremonies welcomes the audience to the Klub, (after the bouncer kicks out a couple of Nazis) and sings as song with the &quot;girls&quot;, mostly men in drag, plus Sally, who is also kinda a man in drag.&lt;br /&gt;After work, Englishman Brian Roberts answers Sally&#39;s ad for a roommate, and the two hit if off fabulously. Brian is stuffy and British and Sally is wild and impetuous and she makes him do crazy, exhilarating things like scream really loud when a train goes by. &amp;nbsp;I guess there was no TV.&lt;br /&gt;Brian makes a living teaching English to foreigners and his first two students, a German Christian named Fritz and a Jewish woman named Natalia immediately form a bit of a love connection that I&#39;m sure will not lead to any problems in the future. Sally had liked Fritz and is a bit jealous to see him with the other more demure woman, so she aggressively hits on Brian. He puts her off, hilariously complaining that it&#39;s a &quot;bit too early in the morning for that sort of thing&quot; until she sarcastically says &quot;maybe you don&#39;t &lt;i&gt;like&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;girls&quot; and his reaction is a dead giveaway. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s stunned, which is silly, because it&#39;s a scientific fact that 90% of British men are at least bi. (Harry, call me!) &amp;nbsp;He says he&#39;s been with only three girls and it was bad every time, and now he&#39;s happy being a woman&#39;s eunuch gay best friend like on &lt;i&gt;Will and Grace&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;So Sally and Brian become besties as any gay man would with Dorothy&#39;s daughter, and more songs are sung in the Klub, and the MC does more crazy stuff on stage and I don&#39;t mind telling you at the risk of being immodest I would &lt;b&gt;kill&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;as the MC in a stage production. &amp;nbsp;But anyway.&lt;br /&gt;Sally dates another man in the show and he dumps her cruelly. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s crying at home and Brian comforts her, and one thing leads to another and they decide together that those three girls &quot;were the wrong three girls&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Uh huh.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile. the Nazis begin growing in power, to the point that Natalia says she no longer feels comfortable dating the German Fritz and she leaves him.&lt;br /&gt;Then, Sally meets a rich and handsome playboy named Maximillan, and the twosome expand their world to make room for three. &amp;nbsp;They go for a weekend trip to Max&#39;s chateau, and on the way they see a couple of Nazis being arrested by the police. &amp;nbsp;Max says the Nazis are useful thugs because they helpfully beat up dirty communists. At the chateau, everyone drinks a lot and Sally starts dancing around and Max swoops in to dance with her, and just as Brian is about to quietly slip out of the room, they pull him into their embrace and the sexual-confusion tension is so thick you could cut it with a threeway. Oh, to be 19 again. I&#39;ve said too much.&lt;br /&gt;But Brian can&#39;t hold his liquor and he passes out and Sally goes upstairs with Max. &amp;nbsp;The next morning, Max wakes up Brian and tells him Sally&#39;s left, but they could totally still hang out. They go to an outdoor park and sit on the grass. &amp;nbsp;A crowd of people are there, hanging out, eating lunch. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, a beautiful, cherubic young blond man begins to sing the song &quot;Tomorrow Belongs To Me&quot;. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s sweet, until the camera pans down to reveals his Nazi uniform. Then, many other young people in the crowd stand up and start singing as well. Turns out, nearly everyone in the park is a Nazi. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s like when you see a couple dozen ants crawling around, and then suddenly your eyes adjust and you realize there&#39;s actually a thousand ants. Ants who commit genocide. Max and Brian quickly motor it back to their car. All the scenes with songs are great, though this is easily the movie&#39;s best scene. (And can I say how much it sucks that that song is probably my favorite? &amp;nbsp;I always felt guilty singing along when I played the soundtrack).&lt;br /&gt;Some time later, Max drops Brian off back at his apartment. Hmm...I want the deleted scene!&lt;br /&gt;Sally doesn&#39;t come home until the next day, and when Brian screams at her, demanding to know where she was, she says she needed to clear her head after spending the weekend with Max, and he lobs her the softball, &quot;Screw Max!&quot; to which she replies, &quot;I do!&quot; and he comes back for the win with &quot;So do I!&quot; &amp;nbsp;They call each other bastards, and she stomps off, feeling whatever the girl version of emasculated is.&lt;br /&gt;She can&#39;t stay mad at him though, and soon discovers that she&#39;s pregnant. She tells him she wants an abortion, until Brian begs to marry her and pretend they know for certain the baby is his. &amp;nbsp;They get crazy drunk and agree to get married.&lt;br /&gt;But in the cold light of day, Sally remembers the way Brian looked at Max and finally can&#39;t bring herself to try to make a family with a man who will never truly be in love with her. &amp;nbsp;She has the abortion and tells Brian about it. &amp;nbsp;He yells impotently at her for a bit, then sees the wisdom in her decision. Unfortunately, once the gay guy makes the girl have to get an abortion, the fun is officially over. He leaves the apartment, heading back to England and probably saving himself from getting fitted for a pink triangle very shortly.&lt;br /&gt;The MC introduces Sally and she sings a final song about life being a silly, carefree cabaret, and on the last note, when the camera swings around to the audience it reveals a packed house of brown shirted goons. And the worst part is, they don&#39;t even clap.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;The songs are all awesome, top drawer stuff. I like how, unlike the play, all the songs took place in the context of the real world, &amp;nbsp;and no one just upped and started singing randomly. And the songs all reflected what was going on in the character&#39;s lives. &amp;nbsp;Liza is a great singer and dancer, and plays the part excellently. &amp;nbsp;Joel Grey as the MC is fine, he definitely can sing, but there&#39;s a manic energy that&#39;s lacking there. (I stand by my earlier assertion that I could do it better, though the singing might be a problem). The &quot;love&quot; story, such as it is, is a very accurate representation of what it&#39;s like to be college aged and stupid and schoompy in all the wrong places, and when I first saw this movie when I was 20, that stuff hit me on an emotional level that it didn&#39;t this time.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;I thought I would definitely give this at least four stars, but as I said, surprisingly, the emotional connection just wasn&#39;t there at all this time around. Maybe it was the chasteness of the storyline; no doubt a character even admitting he was gay in 1972 was really shocking, but now in 2011 it&#39;s more than a little annoying that Sally and Brian get to roll around in bed together but Brian and Max get the fade out treatment.&amp;nbsp;So instead of being emotionally involved, I was much more about judging these fools for getting caught up in all the 90210 crap when the Nazis slowly but surely taking over all around them. I think that&#39;s mostly the point. &amp;nbsp;You could almost look at the Nazis as a metaphor for adulthood, really, the unwanted intruder creeping up when you least want or expect it to. It&#39;s time to stop being polite and start getting real. &amp;nbsp;The freaking Nazis are coming.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;American Graffiti&quot;, and then &quot;Sullivan&#39;s Travels&quot;, which not only have I not seen, but I&#39;ve never even heard of. Haven&#39;t seen &quot;Graffiti&quot; either, unless you count &lt;i&gt;Happy Days.&lt;/i&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8017814283380529806/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/07/63-cabaret-1972.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8017814283380529806'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8017814283380529806'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/07/63-cabaret-1972.html' title='#63 Cabaret (1972)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-c7AREc8q-gk/TjL6jgaKuJI/AAAAAAAAAFQ/0S5SpYEJllc/s72-c/train.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4595845100166999345</id><published>2011-07-27T13:11:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-07-27T13:32:43.135-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#64 Network (1976)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-DWLm7haB7kw/TjBYD9IvVjI/AAAAAAAAAE8/wn7oEyStN-c/s1600/howard.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-DWLm7haB7kw/TjBYD9IvVjI/AAAAAAAAAE8/wn7oEyStN-c/s1600/howard.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;At the time, this was considered a parody.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Howard Beale is the anchor or the nightly news at the realistic sounding &quot;UBS&quot; station. He&#39;s just been given his two week notice by his boss and friend, Max Schumacher.
