We see through his eyes, he&#39;s hunting Clarice, she&#39;s flailing about wildly. He&#39;s toying with her. He aims. &amp;nbsp;Cocks his gun. She hears the gun, whirls around and fires! &amp;nbsp;Fuck yeah!&lt;br /&gt;Several months later, Clarice is promoted. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s at a party, and gets a phone call. &amp;nbsp;Lecter wants to know if the lambs have stopped screaming. &amp;nbsp;Clarice doesn&#39;t answer. &amp;nbsp;He assures her she&#39;s safe, and that he&#39;s having an old friend for dinner. &amp;nbsp;Look, it&#39;s Chilton. &amp;nbsp;How nice, I guess they&#39;ve made up.&lt;br /&gt;Lecter hangs up and walks off into the distance with a crowd, until we can no longer see which one is him.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Of course, this is one of the greatest movies ever, no doubt about it. &amp;nbsp;The writing, directing, and acting were all perfect and in Hannibal Lecter, Anthony Hopkins created one of the most memorable and greatest movie villains ever. &amp;nbsp;Much like Colonel Jessup in &lt;i&gt;A Few Good Men&lt;/i&gt;, Hannibal isn&#39;t actually in the movie a whole lot, but whenever he is, he dominates the proceedings, and casts a creepy deadly pall over every scene he&#39;s not in. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s no time at all that you&#39;re not thinking about him. &amp;nbsp;But consider also Jodie Foster, she had to play a woman who basically for the entire run of the movie was varying degrees of afraid. Afraid of not getting her boss&#39;s approval, afraid of social awkwardness with men hitting on her, afraid of Lecter, and at the end, terrified of Bill. She played that note throughout the movie, but always kept it fresh and interesting. 50% of why Hannibal is scary is Anthony Hopkins, 25% is Jonathan Demme, and the other 25% is Jodie Foster. &amp;nbsp;Lecter could never actually hurt her, because they were always separated. &amp;nbsp;But Jodie&#39;s fear spread to us as easily as if we were there in the cell ourselves. &amp;nbsp;Imbuing another actor with that kind of power and status while still being three dimensional yourself is extremely difficult.&lt;br /&gt;The relationship between Lecter and Starling is a perversion of the classic &quot;Beauty and the Beast&quot; or &quot;opposites attract&quot; cliche in movies. The law of movies says they&#39;re supposed to fall in love. &amp;nbsp;And they do, a little. &amp;nbsp;But never in a way that&#39;s lewd or nasty or insults their character&#39;s dignity.&lt;b&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Also, ten million points for never saying &quot;Silence of the lambs&quot;, in the movie, even though it was sitting right there. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Screaming of the Lambs&quot; is again a delightful perversion.&lt;br /&gt;I honestly don&#39;t have a single beef with this movie. &amp;nbsp;I guess if there&#39;s anything, it&#39;s that at its core, it&#39;s just a monster movie, with no philosophical point of view or message. &amp;nbsp;Normally I won&#39;t give a movie five stars even if it&#39;s perfect, unless it&#39;s saying something, too. But it&#39;s the classiest monster movie probably ever, and that&#39;s enough for me. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid&quot; and then &quot;The Shawshank Redemption&quot;, which I regret seeing for the first time last year, because I could be seeing it now for the first time.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4601366127021403580/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/74-silence-of-lambs-1991.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4601366127021403580'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4601366127021403580'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/74-silence-of-lambs-1991.html' title='#74 The Silence of the Lambs (1991)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2IyjUnDfwQU/TfV48-hPdyI/AAAAAAAAACw/VTNVvnMI4y4/s72-c/hannibal.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-433342439961646169</id><published>2011-06-09T19:00:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-09T19:26:00.276-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#75 In the Heat of the Night (1967)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-32mLkt_FgnY/TfFjdJiQvtI/AAAAAAAAACs/gjeI2yFMXR4/s1600/heat.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-32mLkt_FgnY/TfFjdJiQvtI/AAAAAAAAACs/gjeI2yFMXR4/s1600/heat.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Racism sucks.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Poduck town in Bumblefuck, Mississippi. &amp;nbsp;1967. &amp;nbsp;Deputy Sam Wood is making the rounds in his patrol car; it&#39;s late at night. It&#39;s also hot out. And Sam is in the heat. At night. &amp;nbsp;Hey, wait a minute...&lt;br /&gt;&amp;nbsp;He passes by the a house where he can look in the window and see a beautiful woman standing naked. &amp;nbsp;Then, it&#39;s off the diner to purchase some pie and coffee from the local gomer named Ralph. As soon as that business is taken care of, he nearly runs over a body in the road. He gets out, inspects the dead man, then radios for backup. His superior tells him to search the area, and Sam does so, finding someone at the train station. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a black man, suspiciously sitting there and reading his paper, so Sam calls him &quot;boy&quot;, and handcuffs him, gun drawn. &amp;nbsp;He searches the man&#39;s wallet and discovers 200 dollars. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s enough for an arrest.&lt;br /&gt;At the precinct, Sam brings the man into the Chief&#39;s office. &amp;nbsp;Chief Gillespie asks the man his name. &quot;Virgil Tibbs&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Gillespie asks Sam to step out for a minute, then he softly and confidentially tells Virgil that it&#39;s okay, he can confess. &amp;nbsp;Tell me why you killed that man.&lt;br /&gt;Virgil says he killed no one, and that he was simply visiting his mother and now returning home to Philadelphia. Gillespie wants to know how a negro could make so much money. &amp;nbsp;Virgil reveals he is a police officer. Gillespie looks at his wallet and sees a badge. He calls Sam back in, and shows Sam the badge. Sam&#39;s eyes widen with fear. &amp;nbsp;&quot;YEAH!&quot; Gillespie hilariously bellows. &quot;A cop!&quot; &amp;nbsp;And after laughing for about twenty seconds, I knew this movie had me.&lt;br /&gt;So, Gillespie calls the Philadelphia station to confirm Virgil is a cop, and when the police chief there speaks to Virgil, he tells him to assist Gillespie on their case. Virgil is confident that Gillespie won&#39;t want help, but Gillespie does. &amp;nbsp;He asks Virgil to inspect the body, and when he does, he disagrees with the coroner&#39;s findings that the body died in the last couple hours. &amp;nbsp;He speaks to the coroner and deputy in the way that you speak to people you find incredibly stupid, but you have to be unfailingly polite to anyway. &amp;nbsp;Virgil rattles off some theories about the murder, while Gillespie gets a call about a suspect.&lt;br /&gt;He catches a man seen running from the scene, and he has the dead man&#39;s wallet in his pocket.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, the dead man&#39;s wife, Mrs Colbert, shows up at the precinct and Virgil tells her the news.&lt;br /&gt;Gillespie shows back up with the suspect, Harvey, in cuffs. &amp;nbsp;Virgil asks if he can take a look at him. &amp;nbsp;Gillespie crows that it&#39;s fine, but your services are no longer needed. &amp;nbsp;Virgil feels Harvey&#39;s arms up and down. He determines that Harvey is left-handed, and therefore couldn&#39;t have done it because Mr. Colbert&#39;s head wound was made by a right-handed person. &amp;nbsp;(I wish I was left-handed because I would be exonerated if I was ever falsely accused of murder, according to every crime-based TV show and movie). &amp;nbsp;Gillespie has had enough. &amp;nbsp;He tells Virgil to get his ass back to Philly. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Virgil, that&#39;s a funny name for a nigger up in Philadelphia, what do they call you up there?&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;i&gt;They call me Mr. Tibbs!&lt;/i&gt;&quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Sidney Poitier chews up that line and spits it out, and it&#39;s so sweet. &amp;nbsp;Gillespie&#39;s disgusted, but lets Mr. Tibbs talk to Harvey for a while, and he learns Harvey has an alibi. &amp;nbsp;They change the charge to theft. In the meantime, Mrs. Colbert insists that Mr. Tibbs stay on the case, as he was the only one who kept an innocent man from being charged. Turns out, Mr. Colbert was from up north, and that he had moved here in order to build a factory that will employ thousands of people. Mrs. Colbert tells Gillespie that the factory won&#39;t be made if the murder isn&#39;t solved, and Mr. Tibbs must stay on the case.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Gillespie convinces a reluctant Mr. Tibbs to stay in town and help out, partially by telling him he can prove that he&#39;s better than all these dumb redneck cops. Mr. Tibbs searches Colbert&#39;s car and finds some cotton fabrics. &amp;nbsp;He learns that Eric Endicott is the local plantation owner who was Colbert&#39;s enemy. Mr. Tibbs and Gillespie go to the Endicott&#39;s cotton plantation, passing by hundreds of black employees who are literally picking cotton, and approach Endicott&#39;s giant mansion. Mr. Tibbs questions the elderly, fopish Endicott, who slaps him across the face. &amp;nbsp;Mr. Tibbs slaps him right back. Endicott and Gillespie are stunned, and Endicott wants to know what Gillespie is going to do about it. Gillespie says he doesn&#39;t know. They leave the mansion, and Gillespie tells Mr. Tibbs he has to leave that night, or he&#39;ll surely be killed. &amp;nbsp;But Mr. Tibbs refuses. &quot;I can bring that fat cat down! &amp;nbsp;I can pull him off this hill!&quot; Gillespie smiles in recognition. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Hey, you&#39;re just like the rest of us&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Later, Mr. Tibbs is driving by himself, and a car full of Bos, Lukes, and Cooters tries to ram him off the road. They&#39;ve got a big confederate flag on their hood, natch. They run Mr. Tibbs off the road and chase him into a warehouse. Mr. Tibbs gets a big metal pipe and prepares to do battle, in a truly nail-biting harrowing scene. Gillespie shows up just in time and runs the Duke Brothers off. He tells Mr. Tibbs to leave, now! &amp;nbsp;Mr. Tibbs pretends to agree, but instead goes to Sam and convinces him to take him on the patrol ride and recreate the events that led up to him finding the body. Sam agrees to do so, and eventually Gillespie joins them. The guy Ralph at the diner refuses to serve Mr. Tibbs, literally quaking with self-righteous anger. &amp;nbsp;Fuck you, Ralph.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Mr. Tibbs somehow determines that Sam has gone a different route than he did the other night (still not sure how he figured that out) and calls him on it. Sam denies this, but Gillespie is suspicious. &amp;nbsp;They next day, he checks Sam&#39;s bank records and learns that he deposited 600 dollars the night after the murder. Gillespie decides that Sam killed and then robbed Colbert, and arrests him. Meanwhile, a 16 year old girl and her older brother enter the precinct, and wish to speak to Gillespie privately. &amp;nbsp;&quot;It&#39;s about Sam&quot;. Mr. Tibbs insists on hearing the conversation, which makes the brother furious. He tells Gillespie that Sam slept with his sister and got her pregnant, and wants him arrested for rape. Mr. Tibbs is not buying the story, though. He learns from prisoner Harvey that there&#39;s a colored woman in town who performs abortions on the sly, and goes to visit her that night. He asks her if she has an appointment with anyone. The girl shows up and Mr. Tibbs chases after her. &amp;nbsp;She runs outside and Ralph the diner guy pulls a gun on him. &amp;nbsp;The girl falls into Ralph&#39;s arms, and it all clicks into place for Mr. Tibbs. The girl&#39;s brother and the Dukes show up just then. They tells Mr. Tibbs they&#39;re going to kill him, but Mr. Tibbs says that Ralph is the father, not Sam, and that the girl was going to have an abortion tonight. The girl&#39;s brother searches his sister&#39;s purse, finds the 100 for the abortion, and then points the gun at Ralph. &amp;nbsp;Ralph shoots him first. &amp;nbsp;Mr. Tibbs then overpowers Ralph and holds the gun on Bo and Luke and Cooter.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The case is solved, as Ralph then confesses to killing Colbert to get the money for an abortion, and it&#39;s time for a poignant goodbye. Gillespie walks Mr. Tibbs to the train, hands him his suitcase and tells him to take care. Mr. Tibbs smiles, then boards the train. &amp;nbsp;Racism cured!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Wow. &amp;nbsp;The &quot;murder mystery&quot; element of the case is pretty procedural, but it&#39;s the ambiance that surrounds it, as well as the amazing acting and writing that make this movie as phenomenal as it is. &amp;nbsp;The setting itself is a rich character, a dangerous world, where we feel Mr. Tibb&#39;s alienation as acutely as if we were there ourselves. Every extra, every bit player, including the black characters, look at Mr. Tibbs in his expensive new suit with suspicion and aggression. This could&#39;ve very easily fallen into a preachy, after-school special place, where we learn about the evils of racism in a didactic way, but that doesn&#39;t happen. It&#39;s not just an &quot;important&quot; film. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a good one, too. &amp;nbsp;And we get a story we can sink our teeth into, about the relationship between to very different men who begrudgingly come to respect one another. As great as Poitier is, it&#39;s Stieger who really captivates me. He plays Gillespie as a man who has great intelligence somewhere deep inside him, but almost can&#39;t let it be shown, for fear of being shunned by the community he serves. It&#39;s simply wonderful to see him slowly come around on Mr. Tibbs, and it&#39;s never done in a &quot;hugging, learning&quot; type of way where you think they&#39;re going to be Facebook friends one day. There was also the danger of making Mr. Tibbs the noble saint, who suffers these fools in silence. But Poitier doesn&#39;t play it that way at all. &amp;nbsp;He still knows &quot;his place&quot; in the sense that he can&#39;t be as free to do or say what he wants as he probably would be back home, but he has a line, and won&#39;t let anyone cross it. &amp;nbsp;Apparently, in the original script, Endicott slaps him, but he doesn&#39;t slap him back, but Poitier lobbied to have it changed, and had it put in his contract that no theatre would cut it out. The character&#39;s also fallible, at first focusing on &quot;taking down&quot; Endicott, despite their being no real evidence of his guilt. It&#39;s also interesting to me to read that there was a lot of nervous jokes by white audiences around the country at the time of the release. The movie&#39;s unofficial nickname became &quot;Super Spade vs. The Rednecks&quot;, even by well-meaning liberal types. &amp;nbsp;Reminds me of &lt;i&gt;Brokeback Mountain&lt;/i&gt;, the first mainstream gay movie, that broke the same type of ground that this movie did forty years earlier. For about a year, every talk show host thought that they idea of two cowboys in love was the funniest thing ever. &amp;nbsp;When people are uncomfortable, they laugh. Now, I think a movie like that would come and go without comment. &amp;nbsp;(Like &lt;i&gt;I Love You, Phillip Morris&lt;/i&gt;, which also starred two big name actors).&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;Silence of the Lambs&quot;, and then &quot;Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid&quot;. &amp;nbsp;I&#39;ve seen one of those before. If you can&#39;t guess which one, then you must not know me very well. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/433342439961646169/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/75-in-heat-of-night-1967.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/433342439961646169'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/433342439961646169'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/75-in-heat-of-night-1967.html' title='#75 In the Heat of the Night (1967)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-32mLkt_FgnY/TfFjdJiQvtI/AAAAAAAAACs/gjeI2yFMXR4/s72-c/heat.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7825245785347372626</id><published>2011-06-06T19:18:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:44:15.300-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#76 Forrest Gump (1994)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7ltfhgvfOMw/TemwHLImTVI/AAAAAAAAACc/dp1G4xFp84A/s1600/forrest.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7ltfhgvfOMw/TemwHLImTVI/AAAAAAAAACc/dp1G4xFp84A/s1600/forrest.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Ah, we meet again. &amp;nbsp;My old nemesis. &amp;nbsp;Aka--the first time I became disillusioned by the Academy Awards. You, Mr. Gump, killed the believer in me. &amp;nbsp;The believer in all of us. &amp;nbsp;Was it worth it?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;A CGI metaphor floats down from the sky while the opening credits roll. &amp;nbsp;It lends at Forrest&#39;s feet. &amp;nbsp;Forrest picks it up and puts it in his Curious George book inside his briefcase. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s at a bus stop, dressed in a dapper blue suit. &amp;nbsp;A woman gets off the bus and sits down next to him. He introduces himself to her, offers her chocolate and a pithy expression. &amp;nbsp;She declines the chocolate, but this doesn&#39;t stop Forrest from talking. &amp;nbsp;He proceeds to tell her the story of his life, and she neither tells him to cram it nor gets up and walks away, so we know this story isn&#39;t set in California.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest grew up with his Momma. She put braces on his legs so he would walk straight, and insisted he go to a regular school, even though his IQ was only 75. All the kids at school made fun of him, except the pretty girl named Jenny. &amp;nbsp;They were instantly in love. Well, he was, anyway. Jenny asked him if he was stupid or something, but kindly. &quot;My momma always says, stupid is as stupid does&quot;. Wait--what the fuck does that mean? &amp;nbsp;Stupid is...hold on...you mean like...how does &quot;stupid&quot; do something? &amp;nbsp;YOU&#39;RE MOVING TOO FAST FOR ME, FORREST.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;At any rate, Forrest and Jenny grow up to high school age and look like Tom Hanks and Robin Wright. &amp;nbsp;Some bullies chase Forrest and Jenny tells him to run Forrest, run. &amp;nbsp;Forrest blows through the football field and the coach puts him on the team. &amp;nbsp;He gets a full ride scholarship into college despite being a moron, because that&#39;s fair somehow.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The team wins the national championship whatevers and they get to go to the White House and meet the President of the United States, John F. Kennedy. &amp;nbsp;Forrest tells Kennedy he has to go pee (which was in the commercial, which I repeated over and over again in 1994, even before I ever saw the movie, &quot;I believe he said he had to go pee&quot;) .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;As Forrest&#39;s life improves, Jenny&#39;s gets worse. Her father molested her as a child, and as an adult she became bitter and rudderless. She grew apart from Forrest and disappeared with the evil hippies. Before she goes, Forrest tells her he&#39;s joined the military. She warns him if there&#39;s ever any trouble to just run, Forrest, run.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest goes to Vietnam, where generally things are not nearly as bad as other movies would have us believe. He meets Bubba, a fellow &quot;slow&quot; person, who enjoys shrimp and talks about it constantly. He and Forrest agree to start a shrimp company after they leave the war. He also meets Lt. Dan. &amp;nbsp;Lt Dan&#39;s ancestors have each died in every war preceding this one, and Lt Dan expects to die here.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Eventually, some guy named Charlie attacks and men in Forrest&#39;s squad are getting slaughtered. &amp;nbsp;Lt Dan calls for a retreat, and Forrest runs. &amp;nbsp;He runs so fast, he&#39;s quickly out of danger, and also alone. &amp;nbsp;So he runs back, searching for Bubba. He stumbles across several other men who are wounded, and he rescues them one by one. &amp;nbsp;He encounters Lt Dan, who&#39;s legs have been blown to bits. &amp;nbsp;He rescues Dan and goes back again, finally finding Bubba. &amp;nbsp;Bubba&#39;s insides are outside, and there&#39;s nothing Forrest can do. &amp;nbsp;He runs back out of the jungle, getting shot once in the buttocks.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;At the VA hospital, legless Lt Dan is angry and bitter and wishes he weren&#39;t alive, while Forrest enjoys ice cream, and doesn&#39;t really seem to miss Bubba anymore. One night, Lt Dan crawls over to Forrest&#39;s bed, and pulls him to the ground, angrily cursing him out for saving his life. &amp;nbsp;&quot;What do I do now, Forrest?!&quot; Forrest doesn&#39;t have an answer.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest goes to the White House again to receive the Medal of Honor. He moons President Johnson. Also, while in DC, he stumbles across a huge anti-war protest at the Capitol. The hippies are thrilled to see a man in uniform convert to their side, so they usher him up stage to give his opinion about the war. Just as he&#39;s about to speak, someone cuts the mic, so we never learn Forrest&#39;s position on the topic. &amp;nbsp;Which is more than a little cowardly, movie, but whatever. The upshot is, Jenny&#39;s in the crowd. &amp;nbsp;She rushes over to greet him and the hug in the fountain while everybody cheers. That night they go to a Black Panther party, where Jenny&#39;s douche hippie boyfriend slaps her. &amp;nbsp;Forrest whales on the dude, and the Black Panthers kick them both out. Forrest begs Jenny to go back to Alabama with him, but she says she can&#39;t. She leaves with the dickbag hippie the next day.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;In the meantime, Forrest learns that he has a natural affinity for ping pong, just like he did for running. &amp;nbsp;The army decides he&#39;s best served as PR rather than as a grunt back in Vietnam. After a game, he happens to stumble upon Lt Dan. Dan is angrier than before, with long hair and a beard. He&#39;s an alcoholic living on welfare and in squalor. Forrest takes all this in stride.&amp;nbsp;He becomes the national champion best ping pong guy whatever thing, and it&#39;s time to go to the White House. &amp;nbsp;Again. &amp;nbsp;And meet the President. &amp;nbsp;Again. President Nixon recommends Forrest stay at a nice hotel called Watergate, and that night Forrest happens to witness five men with flashlights looking for something. Wah-wah.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Finally, the war is over. Forrest goes back home to Momma, who immediately pimps him out as a ping pong paddle spokesman. He earns 25,000 dollars for the commercial, which he spends on a boat to start his shrimping company. Lt Dan shows up, to Forrest&#39;s delight, and agrees to be his first mate. They have no success at shrimping until a hurricane comes and destroys every other boat in the area but theirs. God is just kind of mean sometimes. After not dying in the hurricane, Lt. Dan and God come to some kind of understanding and Dan learns to let go of the bitterness.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest becomes hugely successful as a shrimp boat captain, becomes a millionaire, goes on the Dick Cavett show with John Lennon, inspires the lyrics to&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Imagine&lt;/i&gt;, and is generally set for life. &amp;nbsp;Momma dies from cancer, but has the grace to do it off-camera.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;So Jenny comes back to fuck things up for Forrest again. She&#39;s utterly broken and depressed, and of course Forrest is just thrilled to see her, and invites her to live in his and Momma&#39;s old house with him. They live there for a time, until one night Forrest abruptly proposes to her. She turns him down gently, but Forrest is still depressed. &amp;nbsp;To make it up to him, she sneaks into his bed, tells him she loves him, has sex, and then leaves the following morning before he wakes up. &amp;nbsp;Jenny sucks out loud.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest wakes up the next day, and starts running. He doesn&#39;t stop at the end of the driveway, the street, the town, or the state. &amp;nbsp;He runs from one coast to the other and then back again. He acquires a following, a bunch of people who run with him, wanting to know what he&#39;s running for. He inspires one man to create the slogan &quot;SHIT HAPPENS&quot; and another to create the smiley-face &quot;Have a Nice Day&quot; T-shirts. Finally, after three years of running, Forrest has processed his grief enough and stops. &amp;nbsp;He decides to go home. His fellow runners are confused, and don&#39;t know what to do.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Back at the bus stop, it&#39;s present day. &amp;nbsp;Forrest is talking to a different lady than before. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s really engaged in the story. Forrest reveals that he&#39;s here today waiting for the bus because Jenny wrote him a letter saying she wanted to see him. He gives the lady the address, and she tells him it&#39;s only six blocks away, and he needn&#39;t take the bus. He runs off, thanking her.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;He arrives at Jenny&#39;s apartment. She&#39;s looking quite together, and even has a job. Oh, and a kid. &amp;nbsp;Named Forrest. After his dad. &amp;nbsp;Forrest Gump. &amp;nbsp;Forrest is stunned. His lips trembling, he asks Jenny &quot;is he...like me...or is he...?&quot; &amp;nbsp;&quot;He&#39;s very smart, Forrest&quot;, Jenny assures him. &amp;nbsp;Forrest gasps with relief and blinks back tears. &amp;nbsp;By far the most effective moment in the movie. Jenny then tells Forrest she has a virus and is dying. She needs Forrest to raise little Forrest Jr as if he were his own kid. &amp;nbsp;Uh, I mean, because he totally is his own kid.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Jenny dies from AIDS and courteously as Momma died from cancer, and Forrest and his son are left alone.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Forrest takes little Haley Joel to the bus stop for his first day of school. &amp;nbsp;He gives Forrest Junior his old Curious George book. The metaphor falls out. Forrest Junior gets on the bus, waves goodbye to his dad. &amp;nbsp;Forrest waves back. &amp;nbsp;The metaphor floats back up into the sky, and we leave this strange fever dream world behind.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;I didn&#39;t catch this movie at the theatres. &amp;nbsp;I saw it about six months or so after, on VHS, after hearing for six months non-stop about how it was the best movie ever in the history of cinema. When I finally watched it, I thought it was fine, but was in no way bowled over. And then of course, it beat out&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Pulp Fiction&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;for the Oscar, and I became enraged, and my earlier &quot;not bad&quot; assessment turned into &quot;fuck that movie!&quot;. I hadn&#39;t seen it since 1994 until last night, and this time around I liked it a lot more. It really is more satirical than sincere. At first viewing, I cringed a bit at the ridiculous coincidences and the corny jokes (&quot;imagine there&#39;s no Heaven, it&#39;s easy if you try&quot;), and thought the movie was trying way too hard. But I see now that that was the joke. Unlike in many movies, Forrest didn&#39;t&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;really&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;have any special Retarded Person Magic Knowledge. He was just living his life like everyone else, and it was the other people in the story who imbued that Magic Knowledge onto him. &amp;nbsp;Lt Dan screams at Forrest, &quot;What do I do now?!&quot; and Forrest has no answer. &amp;nbsp;Forrest &amp;nbsp;was asleep and just wants to go to bed. The runners at the end of the movie think Forrest is running for some deep and symbolic purpose, but he&#39;s just running because he&#39;s sad about Jenny. They&#39;re the ones who have fallen for the movie cliche, but the movie itself has not. I really enjoyed how we were always encouraged to see the world through Forrest&#39;s eyes, which is why Vietnam didn&#39;t really seem all that bad, and Jenny&#39;s father was just a little mean, and Lt Dan was just a bit grumpy, and those men in the Watergate Hotel just were playing a game with flashlights. Every horrific moment was constantly being downplayed and given a light touch.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;And of course, the movie also plays it totally straight much of the time, telling just a very simple story about a simple man who accidentally inspires those around him. Lt Dan really does have it out with God and make peace with Him, and the movie doesn&#39;t wink at that.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;And then there&#39;s the extremely frustrating Jenny, who uses and abuses Forrest at every turn. &amp;nbsp;I hated her in 1994 and I still hate her now, thought I must admit I understand her a bit more this time around. There but for the grace of God, and all that.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;I don&#39;t think the movie would be what it is without Tom Hanks, finally. He makes the movie and creates a character so indelible and perfectly realized. It&#39;s impossible to imagine anyone else doing the role better, or even half as well. &amp;nbsp;Tom Hanks deserved the Oscar, and it&#39;s this movie where he cemented himself as one of the greats, I believe.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Four and a half out of five. (Can&#39;t do it. &amp;nbsp;Can&#39;t give it the same rating as&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Fiction&lt;/i&gt;).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;In the Heat of the Night&quot; and &quot;Silence of the Lambs.&quot; &amp;nbsp;Yum!&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/7825245785347372626/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/83-titanic-1997.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7825245785347372626'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/7825245785347372626'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/83-titanic-1997.html' title='#76 Forrest Gump (1994)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7ltfhgvfOMw/TemwHLImTVI/AAAAAAAAACc/dp1G4xFp84A/s72-c/forrest.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3559138201986548013</id><published>2011-06-03T22:29:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2012-07-01T18:11:33.181-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#77 All the President&#39;s Men (1976)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1Zkgp2oNAK0/TeWIMu7QpII/AAAAAAAAACY/MEo-p-cPXV4/s1600/pres.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1Zkgp2oNAK0/TeWIMu7QpII/AAAAAAAAACY/MEo-p-cPXV4/s1600/pres.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Real life footage of Nixon on the floor of Congress. &amp;nbsp;The entirety of the House of Representatives, his cabinet, and assembled guests rise to their feet and applaud boisterously at his entrance. Jack Nicholson&#39;s in the front row with those shades. &amp;nbsp;Billy Crystal and Bruce Villanch are backstage coming up with some crazy one-liners. Nixon beams from ear to ear, even though he&#39;s even though he is a crook and a criminal, because he is a sociopath. Fade out.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Some time earlier, some hoodlums are caught breaking into the Watergate Hotel, at the DNC Headquarters. They&#39;re arraigned in court. Devastatingly handsome&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Washington Post&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;reporter Bob Woodard is dispatched from his newspaper to check out the arraignment. (He would never need to offer&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;me&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;a million, I&#39;ll tell you what). &amp;nbsp;He finds it fishy that the common criminals have a high-priced lawyer at the ready to defend them. He wonders if they&#39;re more than common criminals and perhaps they were trying to bug the DNC headquarters. &amp;nbsp;Ooh. &amp;nbsp;Watergategate!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;A source at the jail calls Woodward and tells him that &quot;Howard Hunt--W House&quot; was found in the address book of one of the criminals. Sneaky. &amp;nbsp;Is that a Wishing House? &amp;nbsp;A Wine House? &amp;nbsp;A Wintercoat House? &amp;nbsp;So many possibilities! &amp;nbsp;Woodward&#39;s not only prettier than me, but much smarter, and calls the White House and learns that Howard Hunt works closely with Charles Colson, Special Counsel to the White House. &amp;nbsp;He calls Howard Hunt and asks him why his name was in the address book? &amp;nbsp;Howard says &quot;Good God!&quot; and hangs up immediately. &amp;nbsp;Howard shouldn&#39;t play poker. Eventually, they learn Hunt used to work for Charles Colson and also the CIA. &amp;nbsp;Woodward asks the White House rep what exactly Hunt did at the White House and they volunteer that there&#39;s no way Hunt had anything to do with the break in. &amp;nbsp;Sheesh.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;There&#39;s a lot of investigating and names being thrown about, and then Bernstein gets involved. &amp;nbsp;They Meet Cute when Bernstein takes Woodward&#39;s copy and rewrites it on some sort of computer keyboard that doesn&#39;t have a monitor. Woodward likes Bernstein&#39;s moxie and they start working together.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;They go to a place with lots and lots of books and archived newspapers and stuff. &amp;nbsp;Near as I can tell, it&#39;s like some kind of real-life version of google. &amp;nbsp;I don&#39;t know. &amp;nbsp;The seventies were weird.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Woodward then decides it&#39;s time to call his favorite source, the enigmatic Deep Throat. &amp;nbsp;Deep Throat will only meet in secrets and shadows in an undercover parking garage. He asks Deep Throat to give him more info on Watergate. &amp;nbsp;Deep Throat won&#39;t tell him what he knows, he&#39;ll only tell him if he&#39;s on the right track or not. &amp;nbsp;He tells Woodward to &quot;follow the money&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Deep Throat is a total drama queen.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Eventually, Woodward and Bernstein do more investigating and learn that the Committee to Re-elect the President (CREEP. &amp;nbsp;Yes, that&#39;s what they actually called it) funneled money to the accounts of the five arrested guys. They run the story, despite their editors not liking that an anonymous source tipped them off to the investigation. &amp;nbsp;They also think it&#39;s silly that Nixon would break the law when he was going to easily beat McGovern anyway. Indeed. &amp;nbsp;What kind of paranoid lunatic would do such a thing?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;A female co-worker who once dated a Nixon staff member gives Woodward and Bernstein the names of those who worked for CREEP. &amp;nbsp;They go through a litany of former CREEP employees, looking for a lead. They eventually question Hugh Sloan Jr. &amp;nbsp;Sloan was the CREEP treasurer. &amp;nbsp;He says he&#39;s a Republican, but that what Nixon did was wrong. He admits that he and White House Chief of Staff Halderman engaged in a &quot;ratfucking&quot; campaign to discredit Democratic candidates. They feared that Edward Muskie would win the Democratic primary and wanted an easier opponent like McGovern, so they published a fake letter that they claimed Muskie wrote. &amp;nbsp;It was called the Canuck Letter, and it was supposedly from Muskie and in it he said racist things about French-Canadians. This lost him the nomination, though the letter was later proven a forgery. I remind you, this is not fiction.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;They publish this article and the White House issues a non-denial denial, attacking the paper, but not denying the story. Woodward and Bernstein press on.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Woodward meets up with creepy weirdo Deep Throat again. He tells him about &quot;ratfucking&quot; and wants to know if that&#39;s all there is to the story. &amp;nbsp;Deep Throat says there&#39;s more, but won&#39;t say what. &amp;nbsp;But Woodward has had it with Deep Throat&#39;s stupid games, and demands answers, dammit! Deep Throat finally admits that everyone all the way up to Nixon new about the &quot;ratfucking&quot; campaign and the break-in and the &quot;entire intelligence community&quot; helped. &amp;nbsp;He leaves the garage, and Woodward walks back to his car in the dark, entirely spooked and for the first time wondering about his safety. &amp;nbsp;Great scene.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;TV footage of the Republican National Convention blare on in the foreground of the the&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Washington Post&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;as Nixon accepts his nomination. &amp;nbsp;In the background, Woodward and Bernstein are working hard, typing away on their monitor-less keyboards. We see a series of typed article headlines, that catch us up all the way to Nixon&#39;s resignation. &amp;nbsp;Fade out. &amp;nbsp;Whatever;&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Gawker&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;and&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;TMZ&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;would&#39;ve figured that shit out in half the time, and would&#39;ve been way snarkier.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Okay, so...abbreviated summary this time, for a couple reasons. &amp;nbsp;A) I watched the movie a week ago, and didn&#39;t get a chance to write about it, so it&#39;s not fresh in my mind and B) It was really fucking confusing and complicated and mostly just had people talking a lot. I suppose it&#39;s commendable that the movie didn&#39;t talk down to the audience, and maybe I should be a little embarrassed that I needed to be talked down to so much, but damn. &amp;nbsp;I guess I needed to know more than just the broad strokes of the whole Watergate scandal before going into this. &amp;nbsp;I imagine in 1976, all the names and details were familiar to most people, so a lot of hand-holding and exposition weren&#39;t required.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The movie itself was intriguing, even when I was confused. I can scarcely wrap my head around the idea of Bush or Obama standing on the floor Congress and resigning because of some newspaper reporters. That must&#39;ve been mind blowing to be alive at the time and watching that shit go down. Unfortunately, the movie doesn&#39;t really linger there. &amp;nbsp;The typing montage at the end briefly discusses the missing tapes, Angew&#39;s resignation, the White House stonewalling, and eventually Nixon resigning all in about thirty seconds. &amp;nbsp;Those are the scenes I really wanted to see, not Bernstein manipulating some politician&#39;s wife for info on ratfucking. Though I realize those scenes probably wouldn&#39;t have much of the dashing Bob Woodward in them.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The stuff we got, while undeniably interesting, was also a bit dry, and by rote. &amp;nbsp;Almost no info was provided about anyone&#39;s private life. Woodward tells an interviewee late in the movie that he&#39;s a Republican. &amp;nbsp;The news comes as a surprise, though thinking about it, he may have been lying to her. &amp;nbsp;Who knows? &amp;nbsp;The movie doesn&#39;t seem to think that&#39;s important, but to me it would give him credibility as someone seeking the truth rather than seeking to bolster an agenda. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s also some initial lip service in the beginning to how Bernstein and Woodward have different approaches to writing, and don&#39;t really get along, but we really never even see that. In the end, save for one awesome spooky scene with Woodward and Deep Throat at the end, it was almost like a documentary with actors. &amp;nbsp;I think I would&#39;ve liked a documentary more.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;I think ultimately, the movie is the epitome of being something that is &quot;of its time&quot;. &amp;nbsp;If I weren&#39;t in diapers in 1976, I probably would&#39;ve found it to be excellent. &amp;nbsp;As it is, I can at least appreciate it.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next up, &quot;Forrest Gump&quot;, (which I still haven&#39;t forgiven for beating&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Pulp Fiction&lt;/i&gt;, so be prepared) and then &quot;In The Heat of the Night&quot;.&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3559138201986548013/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/76-forrest-gump-1994.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3559138201986548013'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3559138201986548013'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/06/76-forrest-gump-1994.html' title='#77 All the President&#39;s Men (1976)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1Zkgp2oNAK0/TeWIMu7QpII/AAAAAAAAACY/MEo-p-cPXV4/s72-c/pres.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3273987873471105201</id><published>2011-05-31T18:51:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:40:39.435-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#78 Modern Times (1936)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9o8uNBb7k5U/TdcmWI5yvJI/AAAAAAAAACU/fZgsIX7B_wY/s1600/images.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9o8uNBb7k5U/TdcmWI5yvJI/AAAAAAAAACU/fZgsIX7B_wY/s1600/images.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;So finally we meet, Little Tramp.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Factory worker Charlie Chaplin works all day at the Widget Factory, tightening screws with a giant wrench. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s working so fast, that even when it&#39;s time to stop for a break, he keeps swiveling back and forth and tightening widget screws in his mind, to hilarious effect. &amp;nbsp;Some men come in wanting to talk to The President of the company. They&#39;re trying to sell him a new machine that feeds people. They ask The President for a volunteer worker, so they can demonstrate how it works. &amp;nbsp;Charlie is picked, of course, and he is strapped into this weird thing that has robot arms that feed him a full course meal. &amp;nbsp;But unfortunately, the machine malfunctions and gets food all over Charlie, to hilarious effect. Then later, when he&#39;s tightening widgets again, he accidentally falls onto the conveyor belt and gets sucked into the machine, to hilarious effect. After they pull him out, he goes crazy and starts spraying everyone in the face with oil, but fortunately it&#39;s the kind of oil that can be sprayed into your face with no ill effects, only hilarious ones. Eventually they chase him around until they catch him and put him on the paddy wagon headed for Crazyville.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Some time later, our hero is cured...but no longer has a job.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;We see ol&#39; Charlie leave the mental hospital and wander around aimlessly, bothering people. &amp;nbsp;No one can offer him a job. He walks down the road, and sees a truck drive off. &amp;nbsp;A flag falls off the back of the truck and Charlie grabs it and runs after it, waving the flag back and forth. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, a giant crowd of evil communist Clifford Odets reader&#39;s spring up around him, waving their flags and holding signs protesting the capitalist regime. &amp;nbsp;The cops descend upon the crowd, and mistake Charlie for their leader. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s promptly arrested. In jail, he first keeps bumping into his large inmate, and then knocks shit over. Did I mention the hilarity? &amp;nbsp;The other inmate growls and acts mad but doesn&#39;t give the Tramp the beating he so richly deserves. &amp;nbsp;Later, they&#39;re eating lunch in the prison cafeteria.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;A search for those smuggling the &quot;nose powder&quot;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Then, the Tramp...wait, what? &amp;nbsp;Nose powder? &amp;nbsp;Do they mean...? &amp;nbsp;Is that some sort of old timey slang for make-up? &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;No, indeed. &amp;nbsp;A couple of guards start searching inmates, and the one next to Charlie quickly pours his stash into the salt shaker. Wow. I thought things were supposed to be all innocent and shit in the Olden Times.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Anyway, the inmate is taken away, and Charlie sprinkles the coke/salt on his meal. &amp;nbsp;He even wipes his nose and leaves a powdery smudge on his little Hitler mustache. He of course goes all nutty, and starts spazzing out, stealing bread from another inmate, etc. At this point, some other inmates stage a breakout, and overpower a guard and grab his gun, but coked-out Charlie saves the day by disarming them and beating them up. The cops want to reward Charlie by commuting his sentence and letting him go. &amp;nbsp;Charlie says the world is scary out there, and doesn&#39;t want to leave. They make him go anyway.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;He tries to get several jobs and fails.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, we meet a young woman whose parents have died, leaving her in charge of caring for her younger sisters. She can&#39;t find work, so out of desperation, steals some bread from an outdoor food stand or whatever. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s grabbed by the cops, but Charlie happens by right at that point and declares that he was actually the one who stole the bread. &amp;nbsp;They start to take him away, but then the owner of the food stand emphatically shakes his head and gestures at the woman. &amp;nbsp;She runs off, and the cops pursue. Charlie&#39;s disappointed, but it gives him an idea. &amp;nbsp;He eats a big meal at a restaurant, then informs the waiter he can&#39;t pay by turning out his pockets and doing that pose from Monopoly. &amp;nbsp;The waiter calls the cop over, and they haul him in. &amp;nbsp;On the paddywagon to the Big House, Charlie sees the woman from earlier. &amp;nbsp;She thanks him for trying to take the rap for him earlier. &amp;nbsp;He smiles and spazzes out and I seriously don&#39;t get all the tics and shit at all. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, suddenly the cop wagon crashes, and they spill out the back. &amp;nbsp;They go running off, even though Charlie just tried to get himself arrested, so whatever.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;They wind up basically in a suburb in front of someone&#39;s yard. They sit in the grass and stare at each other. Inside the house, a man leaves for work and his wife kisses him goodbye and waves. &amp;nbsp;Charlie and the girl watch this go down, then Charlie mockingly imitates the woman waving goodbye and the girl laughs bitterly. &amp;nbsp;They then imagine what it would be like to have a home, a job, a good life. After awhile, the fantasy is over and they sit on the grass, miming eating breakfast while smiling sadly. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s shockingly poignant and moving. In the end, they get up and start walking again. &amp;nbsp;They pass by a building and are told that the night watchman just got fired for stealing. Charlie applies for the job. That night, he sneaks the girl into the building. &amp;nbsp;They play for half the night, skating in the toy department, cooking in the kitchen department, and finally Charlie tucks the girl into bed in the bedroom department, while he continues to keep watch over the store.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Some men come in to rob the place. &amp;nbsp;One of the robbers is Charlie&#39;s old co-worker from the factory. &amp;nbsp;He tells Charlie the factory is closed. &amp;nbsp;Charlie decides to let them rob the place, but then the cops show up and arrest the robbers. &amp;nbsp;The manager then fires Charlie.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;He and the girl next apply for a job at a restaurant, where Charlie is required to wait table and also sing as the night&#39;s entertainment. There&#39;s a bunch of crazy wacky shit that goes down as Charlie goes IN the OUT door on his way to the kitchen and OUT the IN door on his way to the dining room, and food gets spilled and none of it is funny, at all. &amp;nbsp;Ever. Then he&#39;s supposed to sing. &amp;nbsp;He forgets the words to the song, so then sings Italian gibberish (this is all dubbed over, of course). The diners love it. The owner of the restaurant wants to hire Charlie full time. &amp;nbsp;He and the girl are elated.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace;&quot;&gt;Now we can buy a real house!&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;Suddenly, the cops show up. They have a warrant for the girl&#39;s arrest, for vagrancy, larceny, etc. She and Charlie make a break for it and run out of the restaurant.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Courier New&#39;, Courier, monospace; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;They barely escape after some wacky slapstick involving chairs or whatever. (Don&#39;t ask). &amp;nbsp;Outside, they stare at each other sadly, and then hold hands. They start walking. &amp;nbsp;We fade out as they march off into the bitter, uncertain sunset.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s...interesting. &amp;nbsp;The pathos and the melancholy are really engaging and personally shocking to me, because I thought the Olden Time movies were usually deliberately light, The fact that this movie came out during the Depression makes it seem particularly counter-intuitive. I thought we go to movies for escapism. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s why&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Pirates of the Caribbean&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;outperforms&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Bridesmaids.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;So, that stuff is good. &amp;nbsp;Real good. &amp;nbsp;The alleged &quot;comedy&quot;...not so much. &amp;nbsp;In fact, of the Olden Times movies I&#39;ve seen so far, the only comedy I&#39;ve liked is&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Bringing Up Baby&lt;/i&gt;, where I&#39;ve liked all the dramas so far. &amp;nbsp;Even this movie, I would&#39;ve loved a 45 minute short film that dropped all the The Little Tramp&#39;s tiresome tics and theatrics. &amp;nbsp;And yes, I realize that&#39;s what made him famous, but it does nothing at all for me. The only Olden Time guy left for me to check out is Buster Keaton, so we&#39;ll see where it goes from there.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Two out of five.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: inherit;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;All the President&#39;s Men&quot; and &quot;Forest Gump&quot;, which only succeeds in making me bitter all over again about the 1995 Oscars.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3273987873471105201/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/77-all-presidents-men-1976.html#comment-form' title='2 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3273987873471105201'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3273987873471105201'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/77-all-presidents-men-1976.html' title='#78 Modern Times (1936)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9o8uNBb7k5U/TdcmWI5yvJI/AAAAAAAAACU/fZgsIX7B_wY/s72-c/images.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>2</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3772967265755487341</id><published>2011-05-23T18:08:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:36:50.182-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#79 The Wild Bunch (1969)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ROyZYCFtFTs/TdGoCkIpTmI/AAAAAAAAACQ/-hQ0t6_wcHo/s1600/wild.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ROyZYCFtFTs/TdGoCkIpTmI/AAAAAAAAACQ/-hQ0t6_wcHo/s1600/wild.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Welcome to the artsy western. &amp;nbsp;Think&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Thin Red Line&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;or some other bit of art house douchery from Malick crossed some piece of shit redneck thing John Wayne was in. Basically, the worst qualities and stereotypes of the red and blue states, mixed together.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;We start out decently enough, with a bunch of children gleefully watching hundreds of red ants overpower and devour a scorpion. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s 1913, and that was probably the best entertainment back then.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Pike Bishop leads his men into a railroad office. &amp;nbsp;Their plan is to hold it up, and steal all the silver. Inside, they bust out the guns and make quick work of scooping up the bags of coins. What they don&#39;t know is that there are a team of bounty hunters on the roof across the street, waiting for them to exit with the silver, and then they&#39;ll start shooting. Pike&#39;s buddy and right hand man (and future masturbating bear) Dutch notices one of them peaking out from behind a ledge. He warns Pike. &amp;nbsp;They decide to push one of the railroad employees out of the building, and hopefully draw fire from the men on the roof, then shoot their way out. &amp;nbsp;Classy.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The shootout begins. &amp;nbsp;Townspeople who have been casually strolling down the road are getting shot left and right. Several members of Pike&#39;s gang get taken out, as do some men on the roof. &amp;nbsp; The shootout goes on for awhile, and is pretty well staged and choreographed. &amp;nbsp;One man gets shot while riding his horse, and does this crazy flip off of it onto the dirt. &amp;nbsp;Well done, stuntman! &amp;nbsp;There are lots of shots of children covering their ears and women crying, and it&#39;s effective but only because I don&#39;t yet know that the whole damn movie is this shit.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Eventually, Pike and about half of his original crew escape. &amp;nbsp;Turns out the men on the roof were bounty hunters, hired by the railroad. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re being led by Deke Thornton, a former partner of Pike&#39;s who was caught awhile back. &amp;nbsp;In order to stay out of jail, he must lead the bounty hunters and capture or kill Pike and his gang.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Pike and said gang meet up at the meeting place and decide to split up their bounty. &amp;nbsp;Besides Pike and Dutch, there are two brothers named Lyle and Tector, a Mexican named Angel, and an old man named Freddy. &amp;nbsp;Freddy is the guy from Westerns who is that old prospector guy with the long white beard and the high voice who calls people &quot;idjits&quot;. &amp;nbsp;They open their bags of silver and it turns out that there are just useless washers inside. They&#39;re super pissed at first and yell at each other. &amp;nbsp;They yell at each other&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;alot&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;in this damn movie. &amp;nbsp;Ernest Borgnine and Bill Holden pretty much have one mode, and that&#39;s&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;yelly. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;This was going to be their Last Job, you see, before they retired in Mexico. &amp;nbsp;Now, they&#39;ll have to do another Last Job. What is it with movie thieves, and their lazy work ethic?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;So, they head down to Mexico to hide out in Angel&#39;s hometown. &amp;nbsp;But the revolution has occurred in Mexico, and Angel&#39;s old town is being run by an evil generalisimo, named Mapache, &amp;nbsp;who drinks wine and whores around a lot. &amp;nbsp;Pike and the gang have no issues with this, and do a lot of drinking and whoring themselves. &amp;nbsp;Also a lot of endless talking. &amp;nbsp;And I bet you&#39;re wondering if there are any douchey artistic shots in this part, like an extreme closeup of a woman breastfeeding her baby, or a horse surrounded by flies? &amp;nbsp;The answer is yes. Yes there are.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;They&#39;re having lunch in the town, and Angel sees the generalisimo making out with a woman who Angel used to date. &amp;nbsp;Angel shoots the woman dead. &amp;nbsp;Mapache&#39;s men all pull out their guns and surround Pike and his men. They swear that Angel wasn&#39;t trying to kill Mapache but just the whore. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s totally okay with everyone, so the weapons are withdrawn. Remember these are the people we&#39;re supposed to like. This&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Ocean&#39;s 11&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;Rat Pack gone sour. Mapache likes Pike&#39;s moxie, so he asks him if he&#39;s interested in doing one Last Job for 10,000 dollars. &amp;nbsp;The plan is to rob a US government train that will be passing through with a ton of rifles. &amp;nbsp;Mapache wants the rifles to use to fight back the natives, who are planning a revolt. Pike and the others are down with this plan. &amp;nbsp;Everyone but Angel, that is. &amp;nbsp;Later, he complains bitterly to Pike and Dutch that Mapache will use the weapons to kill Angel&#39;s family and friends, who are fighting the good fight against the gereralisimo and his men. &amp;nbsp;Dutch responds that if they don&#39;t do it, someone else will and Mapache will have the guns anyway. &amp;nbsp;This is a horrible argument that horrible people use to justify any crime they want. &amp;nbsp;A better argument would&#39;ve been to tell Angel that he&#39;s a hypocritical piece of shit who just murdered a woman because she wouldn&#39;t date him anymore. &amp;nbsp;I mean, seriously. &amp;nbsp;Angel puts his foot down and refuses to join the others. &amp;nbsp;Pike offers a compromise. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re to steal 16 crates of rifles from the train, and they&#39;ll give one to Angel to give to his rebel friends. &amp;nbsp;Angel finds this compromise acceptable.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Then there&#39;s about a half an hour of endless farting around, with artistic shots of the Mexican desert wasteland, lots and lots of closeups of various extras looking authentic, and Bill and Ernest shouting every other line like R Lee Ermey&amp;nbsp;for no goddamn reason.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Finally, it&#39;s time to rob the train. &amp;nbsp;The next twenty minutes or so are as fun and engaging as the first twenty. &amp;nbsp;My god, this movie has turned me into a brainless action junkie. What&#39;s next, a Bond movie?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Turns out, the train they&#39;re going to rob has as its passengers not only Deke and the bounty hunters, but a pack of marshals or sheriffs or whatever as well. &amp;nbsp;Pike and the gang quietly put their guns on the conductor and a couple marshalls. &amp;nbsp;The weapons are on the first car, so they attempt to quietly disengage it from the rest of the train and then ride off. &amp;nbsp;Deke sits with his bounty hunters, only one car back from the rifles. He&#39;s suspicious of the noises up ahead.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The men manage to unhook the first car, and then quickly all jump on and drive down the track. &amp;nbsp;Deke pokes his head out the window and sees him. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, he and the other bounty hunters and the marshals all spill out of the train and jump on their horses that were also on the train and begin a hot pursuit.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The guys are far enough ahead to stop the train at a predetermined point and load the rifles onto a covered wagon they had waiting. &amp;nbsp;The weaponry also includes a rather large machine gun on a tripod. They all get in the wagon and whip the horses, and by now Deke and the others are right behind them. They cross a bridge that they had rigged with explosives. &amp;nbsp;The bridge partially collapses under the weight of the bridge and the wheel gets stuck. &amp;nbsp;Freddy unfortunately had already lit the fuse. &amp;nbsp;Dutch and the brothers push with all their might while Pike and Angel try to hold off Deke and his men. &amp;nbsp;Finally, they free the wheel and ride off. &amp;nbsp;Deke and the bounty hunters chase them...and the bridge blows while they&#39;re crossing it. &amp;nbsp;Men and horses alike fall into the river in artistic slo-mo. &amp;nbsp;I kid, it actually looks pretty awesome.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Pike and the others ride on, but not before Pike looks all sad and conflicted about possibly killing his old partner. Angel&#39;s rebel&#39;s meet up with the Bunch and take their crate of rifles.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Then later, Machape&#39;s men show up, demanding the rest. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a tense moment when Pike thinks they&#39;ll all be killed and Machape will back out of his end of the bargain, so he threatens to blow up the wagon with the weapons. &amp;nbsp;Machape&#39;s men back down and they agree to make the trade tomorrow. &amp;nbsp;Really? &amp;nbsp;Can&#39;t do it right now? Um...okay.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;That night, Pike tells Dutch that he is in fact responsible for Deke getting caught, because he got sloppy one night and accidentally led the sheriff to them or something. &amp;nbsp;Pike got away, but Deke was shot in the shoulder and arrested. He feels guilty blah blah blah.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next day, Pike shows up at Machape&#39;s, and says he&#39;ll give them directions to find two of the cases of rifles for 1,000 dollars. &amp;nbsp;Then after he returns back safely to the others, another man will come and give them directions to two more cases for another grand, and so on until the exchange is complete. &amp;nbsp;They also offer the machine gun as a bonus.
