They do this without a hitch, until on the last exchange, both Dutch and Angel approach the men, take their last thousand dollars, and Machape asks Dutch how many cases were taken from the train. &amp;nbsp;Dutch says 16, but one got lost and fell off the wagon while they were escaping. &amp;nbsp;Machape says that&#39;s a lie, and he knows Angel stole it. &amp;nbsp;The mother of the woman Angel killed came to him last night and told him so. Machape tells Dutch he can go, but Angel stays. &amp;nbsp;Dutch reluctantly rides away.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Dutch tells Pike and the others what happened. &amp;nbsp;They decide to try to buy Angel back. &amp;nbsp;Freddy says to hell with all that and leaves with his share. &amp;nbsp;The other four go back to Machape and offer to buy Angel back for 1,000. &amp;nbsp;They see that Angel is currently being dragged around by a horse, while children throw rotten fruit and firecrackers at him and everyone applauds. &amp;nbsp;Machape says no deal, and he wouldn&#39;t be much use to them now, anyways. &amp;nbsp;Pike says he insists. &amp;nbsp;Machape tells his men to bring Angel over. &amp;nbsp;Angel is bloody and can barely stand. &amp;nbsp;&quot;&lt;i&gt;Levanta, Angel. &amp;nbsp;Estas libre&quot;&lt;/i&gt;, Machape says, cutting his ropes. &amp;nbsp;Then he slits Angel&#39;s throat. Dutch and Pike shoot Machape dead. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a stunned and pretty cool moment where everybody stares at everyone else, too shocked to move. Then, a firefight breaks out. &amp;nbsp;It goes on for awhile, and would be cool except by now this movie is dead to me. The upshot it, Pike, Dutch and the brothers put up a helluva fight, especially after Pike commanders the machine gun, but eventually are all killed, though they took out about a hundred or so &quot;bad&quot; guys. &amp;nbsp;Badder guys, let&#39;s say.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;After this, Deke and the bounty hunters show up. &amp;nbsp;The bounty hunters giggle and start looting the bodies, while Deke looks all pensive and conflicted and Stares Meaningfully at Pike&#39;s dead body. &amp;nbsp;Then Freddy shows up with some of Angel&#39;s rebels, and asks Deke to join them in fighting the good fight against the federales. Yeah, I don&#39;t know. &amp;nbsp;Deke of course goes with them and then there&#39;s an insanely shitty ending montage where he see the smiling, laughing slo-mo faces of The Wild Bunch, one at a time, in earlier clips from the movie. &amp;nbsp;Bleh. Credits. &amp;nbsp;Thank God.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;I pretty much said it all, already. &amp;nbsp;Boring. &amp;nbsp;Overwrought. &amp;nbsp;Pretentious. &amp;nbsp;Melodramatic. &amp;nbsp;Overacting. And normally I like Ernest Borgnine, who was awesome in&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Poseidon Adventure&lt;/i&gt;. &amp;nbsp;(I say this even though he explicitly has stated his hatred of&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Brokeback Mountain&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;and the gays in general. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s 92, I&#39;ll give him a pass). There were a few great scenes that keep this from being a total loss, but mostly I&#39;m less than impressed.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;One and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;Modern Times&quot; and then either &quot;Titanic&quot; or &quot;All The President&#39;s Men&quot;.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3772967265755487341/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/78-modern-times-1936.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3772967265755487341'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3772967265755487341'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/78-modern-times-1936.html' title='#79 The Wild Bunch (1969)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ROyZYCFtFTs/TdGoCkIpTmI/AAAAAAAAACQ/-hQ0t6_wcHo/s72-c/wild.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-348897855457988316</id><published>2011-05-16T19:53:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:35:24.973-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#80 The Apartment (1960)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-iU8lKotk0M8/Tc8eOGSrpdI/AAAAAAAAACM/n2ablWlQIbk/s1600/apartment.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-iU8lKotk0M8/Tc8eOGSrpdI/AAAAAAAAACM/n2ablWlQIbk/s1600/apartment.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Hays Code?&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp; I don&#39;t care about no stinkin Hays Code! I got your Hays Code right here!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;CC Baxter is a youngish cubicle dweller (sans cubicle) who works in New York City. &amp;nbsp;There are 9 million people in New York City. &amp;nbsp;If you laid them all end to end, they&#39;d reach Pakistan, and that&#39;s with an average height of 5&#39;6&#39;&#39; (my, how we&#39;ve grown since 1960). &amp;nbsp;At Baxter&#39;s job, Blah Blah Inc, there are over 30,000 employees, and there are several thousand who work on Baxter&#39;s floor, in a freaking gigantic room that would give Stanley Kubrick a giant boner, with endless rows of desks and phones, and office drones to man them. Baxter stays late every night at the office, putting in hours of overtime. &amp;nbsp;Not because he&#39;s a good employee, but...how can I put this delicately? &amp;nbsp;Because his apartment is a block away from the office and his bosses like to use it as a place to bring women to fuck around on their wives with.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;On one such night, Baxter&#39;s supervisor&#39;s special lady is taking her sweet time, and even though they were supposed to be out by nine (!); the light&#39;s are still on when Baxter comes walking down the block.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Finally, the pair dance out onto the street, and Baxter slinks up to his apartment. &amp;nbsp;His neighbors are a lovely couple of Jewish stereotypes who think he&#39;s&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;meshuggah&lt;/i&gt;, what with all the ladies he brings around! &amp;nbsp;And drink like a fish, he does. &amp;nbsp;Oy! &amp;nbsp;Jewish husband is a doctor and warns Baxter he&#39;ll die young with all the drinking and whoring. Of course, Baxter doesn&#39;t want the neighbors to know the truth, that his supervisors walk all over him. &amp;nbsp;He would rather the neighbors think he&#39;s a tomcat than a pussy.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Later that night, a phone call wakes Baxter up. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s two am, and another manager just met a lovely lady in a bar down the block, and does Baxter mind giving up the place for forty five minutes? &amp;nbsp;The lady does a sexy little dance at the bar. &amp;nbsp;Make that thirty minutes! &amp;nbsp;(This manager is played by none other than Ray Walston, aka the great Mr. Hand. &amp;nbsp;He still looked old in 1960). &amp;nbsp;Baxter grumbles a bit, but does as he&#39;s told, after the manger implies a promotion may be forthcoming.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next day at work, Baxter juggles appointments with four different supervisors who each have &quot;needs&quot; on different nights and afternoons. &amp;nbsp;Hey, one of them&#39;s Larry Tate! &amp;nbsp;Hey, Larry! &amp;nbsp; Baxter gets a message that the big boss man, Mr. Sheldrake, wanting to see him right away. &amp;nbsp;Baxter thinks that his &quot;roommates&quot; must&#39;ve put in a good word, so he skeedadles over to the elevators to head up the the top floor. &amp;nbsp;The elevator operator is Fran Kubelik, a pre-crazy Shirley MacLaine. &amp;nbsp;They know each other and flirt a bit.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Mr. Sheldrake cuts right to the chase: He knows what&#39;s been going on at the apartment, and he&#39;s very disappointed. &amp;nbsp;Baxter fumbles and stutters and says it will never happen again. &amp;nbsp;But of course, Sheldrake would very much like for it to happen again. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s a got a girl, you see... &amp;nbsp;He gives Baxter two tickets to&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Music Man&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;and tells him to clear out for the evening. Oh, and also, how would he like the corner office? &amp;nbsp;Baxter leaves the office and wanders back to the elevator, walking on the clouds. &amp;nbsp;He asks Ms. Kubelik out for the evening. She says she already has a date. &amp;nbsp;He tells her to end it quickly, and meet him at 8 for&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Music Man.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;She&#39;s charmed by Levine&#39;s hard sell, and agrees to meet him.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;But first she has that other date. I wonder who with? &amp;nbsp;I doubt it&#39;s anyone import-oh.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Kubelik sits across from Sheldrake, sipping her soup. &amp;nbsp;She wants to know if the relationship is going anywhere. &amp;nbsp;She wants to know if he&#39;ll ever leave his wife. &amp;nbsp;She wants to know how someone as ugly as he could get someone like her, anyway. &amp;nbsp;Oh wait, that&#39;s me. Anyways, Sheldrake says all the right things, and they commence to Baxter&#39;s apartment for some fucking, while Baxter stands outside the theatre, two tickets in hand. Cue sad trombone. &amp;nbsp;Nobody has any love for old Gil, dangit! &amp;nbsp;Hours later, Baxter returns home and sees a compact with a cracked mirror that was left at his apartment by Kubelik. &amp;nbsp;He brings it to Sheldrake the next day.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Six weeks later, office Christmas party. &amp;nbsp;Everyone is drinking and carousing and basically reenacting&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Mad Men&#39;s&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;season one finale. &amp;nbsp;We learn that Baxter has closed off apartment privileges to everyone but Sheldrake.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Baxter&#39;s getting pretty loaded at the party, and he sees Kubelik at the elevators and starts chatting her up. &amp;nbsp;She says she thought he was mad at her for standing him up, but he claims to be over it now. &amp;nbsp;He drags her over to the main party, runs off to get drinks. &amp;nbsp;Kubelik&#39;s stuck making conversation with Ms. Olson, Sheldrake&#39;s secretary. &amp;nbsp;Olson drunkenly slurs that she knows all about Kubelik&#39;s encounters with Sheldrake, and that she&#39;s just one girl in a very long line.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Baxter returns with the drinks. &amp;nbsp;Kubelik is stunned and wants to get out of there. Baxter takes her into his office, where he models for her a new bowler hat he just purchased. &amp;nbsp;That bowler hat is pretty bitchin. &amp;nbsp;Isn&#39;t it time hats came back for dudes? &amp;nbsp;I say yes! &amp;nbsp;Who wants to start? &amp;nbsp;He wants to know what he looks like in the hat, so Kubelik hands him her compact, and....the synapses start firing for Baxter. &amp;nbsp;He politely disengages from Kubelik, who of course is totally distracted by this point anyway.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Later that evening, Christmas Eve, Baxter&#39;s at a bar getting snokered. &amp;nbsp;Some weird lady hits on him by asking him what he thinks of Castro. &amp;nbsp;&quot;What&#39;s a Castro?&quot; says Baxter, in a bit of unintentional real-life foreshadowing.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, at Baxter&#39;s apartment, Sheldrake and Kubelik are having it out. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s sobbing uncontrollably and tells him what Olson said, while he says douchey shit like I love you, but now&#39;s not the right time, and you&#39;ve wasted our hour, I&#39;ve got to go catch the train now and be with my family. &amp;nbsp;Kubelik says she needs to wash up first. &amp;nbsp;He leaves. She goes into the bathroom, scrubs her face, then looks in the medicine cabinet. &amp;nbsp;She sees some prescription sleeping pills. &amp;nbsp;She grabs the bottle, and gets some scotch as well, and heads into the bedroom. &amp;nbsp;Whoa. &amp;nbsp;Hey, wait a minute. &amp;nbsp;I thought this was some silly comedy. &amp;nbsp;What&#39;s this all about?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Baxter and the lady are dancing around the bar, cheek to cheek. The bartender eventually kicks them out. &amp;nbsp;Baxter checks his watch and says his apartment is clear now. &amp;nbsp;They arrive, and the lady starts making drinks, while Baxter puts on a record. &amp;nbsp;They chat about a bunch of idle nonsense, and the whole time my heart&#39;s in my throat. &amp;nbsp;Finally, Baxter notices a woman&#39;s pair of gloves on the table. &amp;nbsp;He scoops them up, then looks around for a place to hide them. &amp;nbsp;Finally, he heads to the bedroom, opens the door, and throws them in. &amp;nbsp;He does a double take after seeing Kubelik on the bed. &amp;nbsp;He tries to wake her up, sees the empty bottle, then dashes over to the neighbor&#39;s. He tells Dr. Jew that his lady next door took too many sleeping pills. &amp;nbsp;The doctor races over: Baxter immediately kicks the other girl out.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;In a rather lengthy and intense scene, with no music on the soundtrack, the doctor forces Kubelik to vomit, then injects her with something, gives her smelling salts, coffee, and slaps her hard about a half a dozen times. Baxter lies and says they had a fight and she went home early and then he found her that way. &amp;nbsp;Dr. Jew asks why he brought another woman home. Baxter reiterates lamely that they had just had a fight, after all.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&quot;You know, Mr. Baxter. &amp;nbsp;You&#39;re a real sweetheart.&quot; Dr. Jew snarls.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Finally, Kubelik is more or less okay, and Dr. Jew says she must have bed rest for 48 hours, and to also grow up and be a&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;mensch&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;already! &amp;nbsp;Oy! &amp;nbsp;Baxter wants to know what a&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;mensch&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;is. &amp;nbsp;&quot;A human being!&quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;He finally leaves and Baxter makes a &quot;person to person&quot; call to Sheldrake and tells him what happened. &amp;nbsp;Sheldrake is less than sympathetic and tells Baxter to handle it.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next day, Kubelik and Baxter bond over gin rummy and stories of depression and unrequited love. By the second day, Kubelik&#39;s brother-in-law comes looking for her and takes her back to his place, after making the wrong assumptions about Baxter and popping him in the jaw. Meanwhile, Sheldrake fires Ms. Olson and her big mouth. &amp;nbsp;Olson and her big mouth make a call to Mrs. Sheldrake before leaving with her things.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next day, Baxter decides to go into work and tell Sheldrake that he wants Kubelik for himself. &amp;nbsp;And since Sheldrake clearly doesn&#39;t want her himself, it should be fine. &amp;nbsp;Except that now Sheldrake has changed his tune. &amp;nbsp;Why? &amp;nbsp;&quot;Well, if you must know, I fired Ms. Olson, and she saw to it that my wife fired me&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Baxter wearily congratulates Sheldrake on finding love again so quickly. &amp;nbsp;Sheldrake makes it clear that Kubelik is still for fun, but he needs a date on New Year&#39;s Eve, anyway. &amp;nbsp;He tells Baxter he&#39;ll need the apartment that night, as all the great New York hotels are no doubt already booked. &amp;nbsp;Baxter tells him to cram it. &amp;nbsp;Sheldrake says who do you think you are? &amp;nbsp;&quot;I&#39;m a mensch!&quot; &amp;nbsp;he storms out, and that really fucking cracked me up.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;And in the end, on New Year&#39;s Eve, Kubelik learns that Baxter quit rather than let Sheldrake take her there, and she ditches Sheldrake right then and there and runs back to the apartment and into Baxter&#39;s loving arms. &amp;nbsp;Of course now that&#39;s he&#39;s unemployed, he&#39;ll be evicted in a month or two, but let&#39;s let these two crazy kids have their moment.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;First off, totally totally shocked at the subject matter. &amp;nbsp;Wiki says the Hays Code was enforced from 1934 to 1968, and depictions of adultery were banned during that time. But apparently, there were a few hits like&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Some Like it Hot&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;and&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Suddenly Last Summer&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;that came out in the late fifties, that defied the Code and still did gangbusters at the box office, so by the time&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Apartment&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;came around, the code was weakened. &amp;nbsp;Of course, in 1968 it was replaced by its evil younger brother, the MPAA. &amp;nbsp;Second, the tonal shift from light-hearted sex romp to full-on near-suicide tragedy was completely unexpected, but entirely welcome. &amp;nbsp;It was almost at the exact half way point, and though I was enjoying the fun dialog and original premise (how has this never been remade?), I still thought I could pretty much predict the rest of the movie and every last beat in it, and was starting to tune out. &amp;nbsp;The suicide attempt shocked me out of my complacency, and got my attention for the last half of the movie, even though it did ultimately end in more or less a &amp;nbsp;rom-com cliche.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;There was a lot of nuance here, with great performances by everybody, and Jack Lemmon and Shirley are extremely winning and charming. The movie has a message that on paper seems kinda trite (stand up for yourself!) but played out in a very poignant way. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s one of those chicken or egg things that I&#39;m not versed enough on old movies to know, though: &amp;nbsp;was the ending a worn-out cliche at the time, or has it just been emulated enough times since then that it seems that way now? &amp;nbsp;Either way, I was mentally tuning out in the last twenty minutes or so, and half to dock half a star for that. &amp;nbsp;Rules are rules. &amp;nbsp;But the fun laughs of the first third and the shock of the second third more than make up for it. &amp;nbsp;Black and white movies, perhaps I&#39;ve misjudged you a bit.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;The Wild Bunch&quot;, and I&#39;m probably going to have to break down and buy &quot;Titanic&quot;. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/348897855457988316/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/79-wild-bunch-1969.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/348897855457988316'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/348897855457988316'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/79-wild-bunch-1969.html' title='#80 The Apartment (1960)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-iU8lKotk0M8/Tc8eOGSrpdI/AAAAAAAAACM/n2ablWlQIbk/s72-c/apartment.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2775515826273100502</id><published>2011-05-14T19:17:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:33:27.304-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#81 Spartacus (1960)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vlws-v-Z3Oo/Tcm1rvfNO4I/AAAAAAAAACI/1c7yTUwekRg/s1600/kurt.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vlws-v-Z3Oo/Tcm1rvfNO4I/AAAAAAAAACI/1c7yTUwekRg/s1600/kurt.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Voice over narration (that quickly goes away, thankfully) tells us that Rome was a mighty and powerful empire that consolidated its power with slavery. &amp;nbsp;We see Spartacus, a rebellious slave, who fights back when the guards whip him. &amp;nbsp;He was born into slavery and apparently is still pretty bitter about it.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;A fop named Batiatus, who owns a Gladiator arena, is making the rounds, scouting out slaves to buy and use in his Gladiator games. &amp;nbsp;(Batiatus is played by Peter Ustinov, a name I&#39;ve heard before, but I don&#39;t think I&#39;ve ever seen in a movie. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s hilarious in this, and won a well deserved Best Supporting Actor statue. Sadly, however, I must acknowledge a truth I had not known until today: one of my favorite shows growing up was&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;MASH&lt;/i&gt;, and my favorite character on that show was Charles Winchester, played by David Ogden Stiers. &amp;nbsp;But now I see that Stiers just completely cribbed the character from Ustinov/Batiatus, right down to the fey quasi-British accent, the snobby demeanor, and condescending tone of voice. &amp;nbsp;For shame, David Ogden Stiers! &amp;nbsp;For shame!) &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Anyways, Batiatus buys Spartacus and his training begins. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus meets other gladiators, like Crixus, who is some ugly balding dude. &amp;nbsp;As a fan of the Starz TV show, (uh..because of the great writing, I swear), I&#39;m very disappointed with the quality of these alleged &quot;gladiators&quot;, most of whom are pretty scrawny and clearly just random cattle-call extras. &amp;nbsp;Also, Kirk Douglas was already 43 when this movie was made. &amp;nbsp;Not exactly a spring chicken. &amp;nbsp;Batiatus tells the new recruits that they will be trained to fight, and then will have battle to the death with other gladiators when the time comes. &amp;nbsp;They supply the gladiators with women slaves to do with as they will and get their aggressions out. Well, that&#39;s certainly thoughtful. &amp;nbsp;A woman named Varinia is &quot;assigned&quot; to Spartacus, but when they&#39;re in the room together, soft lovey-dovey music plays and they instantly fall for each other. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus refuses to defile her, because everyone knows women only have worth when they&#39;re virgins, so the guards take her away.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Montage of workout scenes. &amp;nbsp;Eventually, Kirk Douglas has a pretty impressive chest on him. I wonder if they shut down production for awhile, a la&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Raging Bull?&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;The trainers declare him ready for battle.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Batiatus gets news that an important Roman Senator, Crassus, is arriving with an entourage. &amp;nbsp;Batiatus tells his slaves to break out &quot;the second best wine! &amp;nbsp;Actually, make it the best wine, but...small goblets&quot;. &amp;nbsp;That line doesn&#39;t read funny on paper, but trust me, Ustinov nails it. Crassus is played by that super famous actor guy, Sir Lawrence Oliver, whom I&#39;ve literally never seen in anything before, but have been told he&#39;s the greatest actor in the whole wide world forever and ever ahem. &amp;nbsp;He wishes to see some gladiators fight to the death, and the two women with him pick out Crixus and another slave to fight, as well as Spartacus and an Ethiopian slave named Draba. Batiatus can&#39;t refuse a senator, so the battle is planned. &amp;nbsp;Crassus also takes a liking to Varinia and tells Batiatus to have someone deliver her to Rome the next day. &amp;nbsp;The four gladiators wait inside the holding area, waiting for their turn. &amp;nbsp;Crixus fights first and wins. &amp;nbsp;Then its time for Spartacus and Draba. &amp;nbsp;They fight while the noblemen watch from up above. Varinia also watches nervously. &amp;nbsp;The fight goes on for awhile, until Draba gets the better of Spartacus and disarms him. &amp;nbsp;He puts his sword at Spartacus&#39; neck. &amp;nbsp;Damn, this is going to be a short movie. But instead of killing Spartacus, Draba angrily looks around at the laughing nobles, who are screaming for blood. &amp;nbsp;He charges Crassus and his friends, throwing the sword at them. &amp;nbsp;The guards quickly overcome him and kill him. &amp;nbsp;(This is the earliest movie I&#39;ve seen so far where a black character isn&#39;t treated as a joke). In the excitement, everyone forgets that Spartacus was supposed to die.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;But Spartacus doesn&#39;t. &amp;nbsp;The next day, after Crassus has left, he charges one of the guards and overpowers him. &amp;nbsp;Other gladiators join in. &amp;nbsp;When Batiatus learns his slaves have rebelled, he jumps on the wagon that was just about to take Varinia away and hightails it out of there.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Very quickly, the gladiators overtake the entire house, and drive out or kill all the guards.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They frolic and drink and make merry, celebrating their newfound freedom. &amp;nbsp;But Spartacus has a plan. &amp;nbsp;He wants them to march to the ocean, and make their escape out of Italy, where they can truly be free. Along the way, they&#39;ll free other slaves and let them join in. Everyone thinks this is a swell plan.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, in Rome. &amp;nbsp;News of Spartacus&#39; uprising has the royals upset, and Senator Gracchus suggests they dispatch the army general guy named Glabrus to lead a small group the squelch the growing Spartacus rebellion. &amp;nbsp;And who will take Glabrus&#39; place while he&#39;s away? &amp;nbsp;Some dude named Julius Caesar. This is a power play by Gracchus, who is allied with Caesar, while Glabrus is allied with Crassus. Crassus expresses concern that Caesar will not be willing to give up his position as head army guy when Glabrus returns, but obviously that&#39;s ridiculous. &amp;nbsp;Hail Glabrus!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Crassus also purchases for himself a slave &quot;washing boy&quot;, named Antoninus. &amp;nbsp;He sits in a giant tub while Antoninus bathes him. Crassus asks Antoninus if he eats oysters. &amp;nbsp;Yes, my lord. &amp;nbsp;Do you eat snails? &amp;nbsp;No, my lord. &amp;nbsp;Do you think eating oysters is moral, and snails immoral? &amp;nbsp;No, my lord. Good. It is simply a matter of taste.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;I like oysters&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;and&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;snails.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;(Apparently, the studio heads or MPAA or whoever saw through this extremely subtle metaphor and nixed the scene. &amp;nbsp;It was restored in 1991).&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Antoninus dries off Crassus and thinks about what it will be like to eat snails for the first time. &amp;nbsp;Crassus tells him that Rome is mighty and unstoppable and all should quake in awe of her. &amp;nbsp;He turns around and sees that Antoninus has run away. &amp;nbsp;He laughs to himself and then probably goes back to the slave auction for more snail hunting.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;While freeing some slaves and encouraging people to join their army, Spartacus happens across Varinia. &amp;nbsp;He knows it&#39;s her because their lovey-dovey theme music starts playing. &amp;nbsp;He says he thought Crassus bought her. She explains that she ran away from Batiatus on the way there, and he was too fat to catch her. &amp;nbsp;Both of them lose their shit laughing at how fat Batiatus is. &amp;nbsp;(Answer: pretty fat). &amp;nbsp;Antoninus also joins up with them.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Spartacus&#39; army encounters Glabrus and his men. The battle takes place offscreen (Boo!) and in the end, Glabrus is defeated. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus sends him back to Rome, and says to tell Rome they won&#39;t be defeated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The Roman senate demands Glabrus resign in disgrace, and Crassus also resigns, for supporting Glabrus. &amp;nbsp;The senate don&#39;t actually want him to resign, though, as they value his expertise. &amp;nbsp;Senator Gracchus and Caesar realize that Crassus&#39; resignation is just a ploy to get them to beg him to come back, should the threat of Spartacus&#39; army grow too strong.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Spartacus makes plans to purchase some boats from some Arab boat-maker guy. &amp;nbsp;The guy assures them that one they reach the ocean, the boats will be ready. They keep marching on, winning more and more battles until finally the Roman senate is beside themselves, and offer Crassus full dictatorial powers to do with as he pleases, so long as Spartacus is killed. Crassus summons Batatius, who is now a pauper living in Rome. &amp;nbsp;He asks him to identify Spartacus for him, once they defeat his army.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Batatius reminds Crassus that he already met Spartacus, back in the gladiator house. Crassus can&#39;t remember him. &amp;nbsp;Batiatius says he&#39;ll help identify him, if he can be allowed to sell the rest of the gladiators back into slavery once they&#39;re recaptured. &amp;nbsp;Crassus is fine with this.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, the Arab boat guy tells Spartacus that the deal is off, and that another army, the Cilicians, are approaching from the ocean, per Crassus&#39; request. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus knows he can&#39;t keep running and now must turn around and fight the Roman army directly.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Okay, here we go! &amp;nbsp;Battle porn! &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Spartacus&#39; army and Crassus&#39; army meet in the middle of a giant field. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s no CGI, folks. &amp;nbsp;And there&#39;s got to be a least a thousand extras, on either side, facing each other. All I can think about is how busy craft services must&#39;ve been that week. They charge each other, and Spartacus&#39; men have these giant rolling logs that are&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;on fire&lt;/i&gt;, and they roll them down the hill to smash and burn the advancing Roman army. &amp;nbsp;Badass! &amp;nbsp;We basically see a bunch of stuntmen get rolled by a log and lit on fire. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus&#39; army appears to be winning, but unfortunately, at that moment, the Cilician army arrives and joins up with the Roman one. &amp;nbsp;They crush Spartacus&#39; men, killing Crixus, as well as most of the others. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus and Antoninus and a few hundred others are captured alive.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Crassus approaches them and tells them they will be kept alive if they tell him which one of them is Spartacus. &amp;nbsp;Otherwise, they will be crucified and hung on crosses. &amp;nbsp;Spartacus stands up, opens his mouth to call out. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, Antoninus leaps to his feet. &amp;nbsp;&quot;I am Spartacus!&quot; he yells. &amp;nbsp;Others do the same. &amp;nbsp;Soon, everyone is yelling &quot;I am Spartacus!&quot; Fuck yeah! &amp;nbsp;A single manly tear rolls down Sparty&#39;s cheek. He&#39;s actually the only one who&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;doesn&#39;t&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;yell &quot;I am Spartacus!&quot;, so that should&#39;ve been a dead giveaway.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Batiatus approaches Crassus and says what&#39;s all this business about crucifiction? &amp;nbsp;I thought I was going to sell them back into slavery. &amp;nbsp;Crassus says the deal&#39;s off. &amp;nbsp;He then sees Varinia, who has survived the battle, and her newborn son, Michael Douglas. She tells them Spartacus is dead. Crassus is taken by her beauty and tells some soldiers to take her back to his place. She will be his new slave. Crassus then looks over the newly reenslaved gladiators, and recognizes his former snail-hating washing boy, Antoninus. &amp;nbsp;He also finally recognizes Spartacus. &amp;nbsp;He orders them to fight to the death. &amp;nbsp;The winner will be crucified. Spartacus and Antoninus try in earnest to kill each other, each one wanting to give the other a quicker, less painful death. Spartacus wins.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;When Graccus learns of Varinia&#39;s fate, he bribes Batiatus into kidnapping her and bringing her to him. He wants one last shot at sticking it to Crassus. &amp;nbsp;Batiatus does as he&#39;s told, then Graccus grants Varinia her freedom. &amp;nbsp;He asks Batiatus to take her out of Rome. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Batiatus does so, and as they travel down the road, they pass dead gladiator after dead gladiator, all hung on crosses along the road every twenty feet or so, like telephone wires. Well, that&#39;s just gross. Finally, they come upon Spartacus, not yet dead. &amp;nbsp;Varinia tells Spartacus that she and their son are finally free, and then she rides off in the sunset with ol&#39; fatty, while Spartacus slowly dies. All&#39;s well that ends well.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Sweeping epics tend to make me a bit itchy, and this one was no exception. &amp;nbsp;Something about the grandiose nature of the thing, makes it appear to insist upon itself, (thank you Peter Griffin). That said, there&#39;s a lot to like here. &amp;nbsp;Kurt Douglas, Olivier, and Ustinov are all great. &amp;nbsp;Most of the cast is, in fact. &amp;nbsp;Except for the day players. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re all very &quot;60&#39;s&quot;. &amp;nbsp;They have that weird sort tone of voice when they yell that makes them all sound the same. Difficult to explain, but close your eyes and imagine someone in a sixties movie saying &quot;hey! &amp;nbsp;What&#39;s the big idea?&quot; and you&#39;ll get the picture. The writing is really sharp. &amp;nbsp;Lots of great one-liners, especially from Ustinov, and no lines at all that stick out as clunkers. The plot here is far more detailed than I expected, with lots of Senatorial scheming and backstabbing that I mostly skipped over in the summary. &amp;nbsp;There were a surprising amount of subplots, and nearly every character was nuanced and somewhat sympathetic; even cowardly villains like Batiatus were somewhat redeemed by the end. And the battle scenes were pretty great too, rivaling any CGI thing we&#39;d see nowadays. &amp;nbsp;I love practical effects, and I wish CGI were only used sparingly, and not as such a crutch. &amp;nbsp;There are also lots and lots and lots of sweeping, panoramic views of the Italian countryside that look pretty damn spectacular.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Now: Stanley Kubrick. &amp;nbsp;Not as big a fan as I feel I probably should be. &amp;nbsp;Which sucks, because he&#39;s one of those &quot;cool&quot; directors you&#39;re just supposed to love, and...I really don&#39;t. I think he makes interesting films, but his pacing is always problematic for me, as it is here. &amp;nbsp;The third act always seems to go on for too long. &amp;nbsp;The climax of the movie is the big battle between the two armies, and yet, when that&#39;s over there&#39;s still a good thirty minutes left. &amp;nbsp;I hate that shit. He does it in&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;2001&lt;/i&gt;, too. &amp;nbsp;Haven&#39;t seen&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Dr. Strangelove&lt;/i&gt;, so we&#39;ll see about that when the time comes.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/2775515826273100502/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/80-apartment-1960.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2775515826273100502'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/2775515826273100502'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/80-apartment-1960.html' title='#81 Spartacus (1960)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vlws-v-Z3Oo/Tcm1rvfNO4I/AAAAAAAAACI/1c7yTUwekRg/s72-c/kurt.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4113943083426676620</id><published>2011-05-10T17:56:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-12-25T02:31:45.028-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#82 Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Shh!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Of course, we&#39;ve all seen this one countless times, so there&#39;s no need to really get into it too much.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;So, my first ever silent movie starts out with a woman getting dressed up all slutty and wearing black. &amp;nbsp;She puts on make up and lipstick (WHORE!) and then leaves her home. &amp;nbsp;She appears to live in a small village community. &amp;nbsp;The other townspeople are put off by her high-flautin&#39; ways, but she doesn&#39;t care. She approaches a home where through the window she sees a man sitting on his couch watching TV. &amp;nbsp;Or, I guess not. &amp;nbsp;Listening to the radio, maybe? &amp;nbsp;Man, what did people do when they were sitting on the couch back then? &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s barely even a reason to have a couch. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, she whistles to the man and he goes outside to greet her. &amp;nbsp;They run off together. Back in the house, the man&#39;s wife appears, and looks around for him, sad.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;We see two gossiping women &quot;talking&quot; about the man and his wife.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;HE GOES OUT ALL DAY WITH THAT WOMAN....AND HIS WIFE STAYS AT HOME&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;background-color: white; font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Several shots of the wife sad and staying at home and taking care of their baby, while weeping intermittently. The man and the black-dressed bimbo go off into the woods together and engage in several tight hugs and closed-mouth kisses. The taloned temptress asks the man to run away with him to the city. In the sky, we see images of the city they imagine. There&#39;s a kaleidoscope of crazy Big City images; a brass band, people dancing in the streets, Model T&#39;s roaring by, causal racism, etc.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The man shakes his head, points at his ring. But the heavy-lidded harlot has an answer for that.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;WHAT IF SHE WERE TO....DROWN?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Then the words sink into the bottom of the screen and disappear. &amp;nbsp;Cool. &amp;nbsp;The man is horrified by the suggestion, and tries to push the evil jinxed Jezebel away, but she persists, showering his face in more closed-mouth kisses, until he&#39;s finally won over. Her plan is for him to tell his wife he wants to take her by rowboat to the big city and then when they&#39;re halfway there, to dump the boat into the river and let her drown. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;ll save himself from drowning as well by taking a bundle of sticks with him to hold onto and use to stay afloat. He&#39;s down with the idea. &amp;nbsp;They collect a bunch of sticks and tie them together. They promise to meet the next night after the deed is done.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The man gets home and lies down in his single bed about five feet away from his wife. Perhaps that&#39;s why they&#39;re having these marital problems. He stares creepily at her, unable to fall asleep. &amp;nbsp;The next morning, he&#39;s finally dozed off. &amp;nbsp;The woman pulls his blanket up to his chin and then proceeds to churn the butter or maybe do something with a spindle or whatever it is that people did then. Suddenly, the man wakes up and is overcome with self-doubt. He sits up and imagines the evil Eve touching him, caressing him, until he finally gets enough nerve to tell his wife about the big plan to go rowing to the city that day. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s ecstatic, thrilled that he&#39;s finally being nice to her again. &amp;nbsp;She gives the baby to a neighbor, and they set off rowing for the day. &amp;nbsp;As they walk down the little trail to the boat, their dog starts barking furiously at the man. &amp;nbsp;Wow, even in 1927, the &quot;animals are magic&quot; thing was out there. As they row away, the dog jumps into the river and swims up to their boat. The woman lets him on. &amp;nbsp;The man turns the boat around, rows back to the shore, and walks the dog up to the house, looking super scary and grim. &amp;nbsp;The woman watches from the boat for a while, until the man slowly walks back down the trail, sans dog. &amp;nbsp;For the first time, she feels a little uncertain. &amp;nbsp;The suspense here is actually crazy good, with the symphony soundtrack provided great ominous music. They start to row away again, and the man just looks angry the whole time, clearly trying to work himself up to dumping her. &amp;nbsp;The woman gets more and more terrified. Finally, he gets up and looms over her, his hands clenched. &amp;nbsp;He lunges at her. She screams and curls into a ball. He stops, horrified at himself. &amp;nbsp;He quickly sits back down and rows them to shore. &amp;nbsp;As soon as they dock, she runs off, terrified. He follows her, calling out apologizes. She gets on a trolley that heads into the city, and he manges to catch it too. &amp;nbsp;He stands next to her the whole ride, as she cowers in terror. &amp;nbsp;As soon as they reach the city, she runs off again, into traffic. &amp;nbsp;Several cars almost hit her, but the man saves her. &amp;nbsp;He guides her into a restaurant. &amp;nbsp;They sit down and he offers her bread at the table. &amp;nbsp;She takes a piece, bites into it, then collapses into tears. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s really quite moving, surprisingly. They see a wedding taking place across the street and the man takes her inside. They sit in the back and watch a couple get married (the original Wedding Crashers!) and the priest talks about how the man protecting his bride from harm is the most noble thing he can do. &amp;nbsp;The man is overcome with guilt and begins crying. &amp;nbsp;They hold each other and cry, and shockingly, no one kicks their rude asses out of the chapel.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;They decide to make a day of it in the city. The man gets a shave and a haircut while the woman watches. &amp;nbsp;A pretty lady comes up to the man while he&#39;s being shaved and offers him a manicure. The woman watches, all scared that he&#39;ll start banging her right there in the barber shop, I guess. &amp;nbsp;But the man screams &quot;NO!&quot; at her and she walks away. &amp;nbsp;The woman is relived. Another dapper gentleman sits next to the woman and hits on her, and puts his arm around her. She moves away from him, but the man sees this happen and approaches the dapper gentleman. &amp;nbsp;He pulls a knife and jabs it at the guy&#39;s throat, stopping just before hitting him. The music is all dark and scary, but the woman seems unconcerned and they go walking off together, leaving the dapper gentleman to sigh with relief and tell all his friends about the psycho who almost killed him for no reason.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The rest of the day is filled with fun adventure, carnival games, and dancing.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;That night, they decide to row home. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;HEY, REMEMBER THIS MORNING WHEN I ALMOST KILLED YOU IN THIS VERY BOAT?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;CRAZY, HUH?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;No, he doesn&#39;t say that unfortunately. So they row home, but halfway there, there&#39;s a big storm. &amp;nbsp;The rowboat is rocked to and fro and the man&#39;s oars finally break and when it looks like the boat will soon sink, the man busts out his bundle of sticks and tells his wife to hold onto them for dear life. &amp;nbsp;Aw...that&#39;s really cool and ironic, and unexpected. The boat sinks. &amp;nbsp;The man tries to hold onto his wife, but they&#39;re soon separated by the current.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The man eventually washes ashore, back at his home village. He looks around desperately for his wife, but can&#39;t find her. &amp;nbsp;He rushes into town, waking everyone up, calling for help. They all run out to the river and get in row boats, looking for her.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, the hard-hearted hussy skulks about in her home, smiling. &amp;nbsp;She of course thinks that the plan has gone off with out a hitch.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The man is on a boat with a rescue team, and the discover a broken-up bundle of sticks, but no woman. The man is devastated. &amp;nbsp;They row ashore, and he goes back home, where the neighbor lady is still taking care of the baby. She weeps and hugs him, and he just stoically stands there in total shock. &amp;nbsp;Eventually, the neighbor leaves, and immediately, the witchy wench arrives at the house. &amp;nbsp;She triumphantly throws her arms around the man and starts in with the trademark closed-mouth kisses. But this time, he throws her off and immediately begins choking the shit out of her.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Meanwhile, other rowers apparently haven&#39;t given up so quickly because they find the woman washed ashore, and she&#39;s still alive. &amp;nbsp;They hurriedly carry her into town.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The fornicating floozy is still choking and dying, while she struggles in vain to break free. &amp;nbsp;But off in the distance, the man hears the villagers&#39; call. &amp;nbsp;He throws the manipulative minx down and runs out of the house. &amp;nbsp;He rushes over to his wife, who is coming around. &amp;nbsp;He scoops her up, and she throws her arms around him and they kiss, while the triumphant symphony music rises. &amp;nbsp;Fade out. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Hopefully by the time they get back to the house the other lady has cleared out of there.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;WAY better than I was expecting, though to be fair, my expectations couldn&#39;t have been lower. The silent film is truly such a different art form, it almost doesn&#39;t really even count as a movie. &amp;nbsp;The difference between silent movies and &quot;talkies&quot;, I think is a much wider gap than between black and white and color. In early talkies, the actors clearly didn&#39;t know what they were doing, that&#39;s why the voices sounded so artificial and off putting, and that&#39;s why I can&#39;t really get into those types of movies. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re too unreal. &amp;nbsp;However, the silent films are&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;so&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;unreal, it&#39;s like they&#39;re in a different category altogether. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s more like a fever dream than a movie. &amp;nbsp;You can&#39;t expect it to be realistic. &amp;nbsp;It would be like going to a play and saying that the walls on that house don&#39;t look stable. And yet, even though the actors played &quot;big&quot;, it didn&#39;t feel that way, because how else can you play it? &amp;nbsp;For whatever reason, it&#39;s easier to buy this movie as real than it was to buy into movies just ten years later. The music, which was a constant symphony, was also pretty great. &amp;nbsp;The scary moments were made scarier, the happy moments happier. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s also cool to hear that kind of music again in a movie. &amp;nbsp;I don&#39;t think we&#39;ll ever get back to recording a huge live orchestra in a movie soundtrack again, they&#39;re just too cost prohibitive.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;And finally, the story itself was really compelling. &amp;nbsp;The irony of the sticks being used to save the wife in the end was excellent, and totally something I didn&#39;t predict. &amp;nbsp;There was a lot in the middle I skipped over, though. &amp;nbsp;A lot of &quot;country rubes in the big city&quot; shtick was not only not that great, but was also a huge digression from the main story. When the man threatened to knife the guy in the barber&#39;s shop, I thought the movie was making the case that the man is still a psycho and his wife was better off without him lest he go nuts again one day and try to kill her again, but they never brought it up after that, which seemed like a missed opportunity.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;But I did definitely like it, on the whole. &amp;nbsp;And my education continues...Can&#39;t way to see one with that &quot;Charlie Chaplin&quot; guy I keep hearing so much about. Although I think he stole that character from Maria from Sesame Street.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Three and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Next, &quot;Spatacus&quot; and then &quot;The Apartment&quot;.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4113943083426676620/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/81-spartacus-1960.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4113943083426676620'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4113943083426676620'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/81-spartacus-1960.html' title='#82 Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-sUI4-WEt93w/Tcbiih4KS2I/AAAAAAAAACE/39EXLXjgY-k/s72-c/sunrise.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3553151691712284297</id><published>2011-05-08T16:53:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-06-08T22:49:06.821-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#83 Titanic (1997)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/--LReB7LrjwQ/Te1-1OdUieI/AAAAAAAAACg/kzw3izNqlWo/s1600/Titanic-titanic-16680057-1197-774.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;206&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/--LReB7LrjwQ/Te1-1OdUieI/AAAAAAAAACg/kzw3izNqlWo/s320/Titanic-titanic-16680057-1197-774.jpg&quot; style=&quot;cursor: move;&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers):&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;An earring wearing Bill Paxton and his merry men are going on a deep sea expedition to search the sunken ship Titanic. They&#39;re looking for a diamond necklace called the &quot;Heart of the Ocean&quot;, which was owned by a villainous cartoon character named Cal Hockley. &amp;nbsp;They locate Cal&#39;s safe and bring it up onto their boat, but when they open it, there&#39;s no diamond.
