There is, however, a drawing of a naked woman wearing said diamond.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Said naked woman is Rose Dawson Calvert, and she&#39;s 101 years young nowadays. &amp;nbsp;She was 17 when she boarded the Titanic. She contacts Bill Paxton to tell him the story of the necklace. &amp;nbsp;Actually, she just jerks him around for three hours and then drops the necklace into the ocean, because old people are mean.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Rose&#39;s story:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;She&#39;s from a wealthy family, but the family is secretly poor now. &amp;nbsp;She needs to marry a rich man and according to her mother, the only thing she has of value is her family name. &amp;nbsp;So, she is betrothed in an arranged marriage to Cal Hockley, and she and her mother are heading to America with Cal and a bunch of other rich snooty people for the wedding. &amp;nbsp;In this movie, James Cameron would like you to know that rich people are evil and poor people are tragically noble. &amp;nbsp;And then James Cameron will give you a shiny new nickel and a pat on the head before flying to Belize to get a print copy of the latest positive review of&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Avatar.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Jack and his irrelevant Italian friend (let&#39;s say...um, Gino) win tickets to the Titanic at the last minute in a poker game. &amp;nbsp;They race onto the ship and board it just in time. &amp;nbsp;Not sure how Rose knows about that part, since she wasn&#39;t there, but anyways...&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Jack is king of the world!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Rose wants to kill herself. She climbs around to the outside of the bow of the ship, and looks down. &amp;nbsp;Jack happens upon her and talks her out of it, in part by scaring with her tales of how cold the water will be. He attempts to pull her back over the railing, but she slips and almost falls into the ocean. He holds onto her tight, but her cries alert others including Cal and his evil Henchman Spicer Lovejoy. &amp;nbsp;Wow, really? &amp;nbsp;Spicer Lovejoy. Okay, James. Cal and Spicer Lovejoy show up just in time to see Jack pulling Rose back over the railing. &amp;nbsp;Cal accuses Jack of trying to push her over, but Rose says that she just slipped. As an expression of gratitude, Cal invites Jack to have dinner with them the next night.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;At the dinner, Jack is uncomfortable around all the rich people, but Rose and the rootin&#39; tootin Unsinkable Molly Brown put him at ease. After the dinner, Jack passes Rose a note suggesting they meet down in steerage for a &quot;real&quot; party.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Because poor people are awesome and rich people suck, Rose meets Jack down in steerage and all the third-class people &amp;nbsp;carouse and dance and drink and share stories about how noble and long-suffering they are.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The next day, Cal somehow learns that Rose was down there in steerage and slaps her face. &amp;nbsp;Hard! &amp;nbsp;Then he twirls his mustache and looks around in vain for a railroad track to tie her to. Rose&#39;s mom gets in on it, telling Rose that they&#39;ll be destitute if she doesn&#39;t marry Cal.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;When Jack encounters Rose the next day, she&#39;s conflicted and resists him for twenty seconds or so, before running off with him.&amp;nbsp;Then they run all around the ship from Spicer Lovejoy, because he is crazy or something.&amp;nbsp;Then Rose allows Jack to draw a nudie sketch of her, because there was no TV back then, and then later fucks him in the back seat of a old-timey car. (The sweaty hand print on the window is admittedly pretty awesome). While they&#39;re on the deck, the ship sort of barely grazes a giant iceberg. Well, it&#39;s about damn time! &amp;nbsp;What is this, Titanic or&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;The Love Boat?&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;!&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Am I right, guys?! High five!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The ship shudders a bit, but mostly seems okay. &amp;nbsp;People have snowball fights with the snow left by the iceberg. No one is concerned until Rose and Jack overhear the Captain and some crew members talking about the damage down below.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;Finally, Cal and Spicer Lovejoy catch up to the lovebirds and Cal surreptitiously slips the Heart of the Ocean necklace into Jack&#39;s pocket and then accuses him of stealing it. They search him and find it, then Spicer Lovejoy &quot;arrests&quot; Jack and handcuffs him to some metal pipe. &amp;nbsp;Rose is distraught, but goes along with it. She sees the ship&#39;s designer on deck looking all distraught. She confronts him and he confesses to her that the ship will sink in about an hour. Unfortunately, this will play out in real time. So, Molly Brown and Rose&#39;s mom get on a rescue boat, and Rose herself is about to board when someone tells Cal that there aren&#39;t enough lifeboats on the ship and only about half the people will live. &quot;Yeah...the better half,&quot; says Cal, because that&#39;s how people actually talk. &amp;nbsp;Rose then realizes that Cal sucks and so therefore Jack must be innocent. She runs off. Cal chases after her, as Molly and mom are lowered into the sea.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Rose goes down to the lower decks and finds Jack handcuffed. &amp;nbsp;She eventually locates an axe and frees him. The water is high now and they swim around until they reach a higher deck. They come across Gino and the noble poor people in third class, who are locked down below. &amp;nbsp;Jack frees them and they all run around for awhile, accomplishing little. On deck, chaos reigns as boats are being lowered despite being half full, and a full-blown panic erupts. &amp;nbsp;All of this still looks pretty cool, and is excellently blocked and directed.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Jack gets Rose to another rescue boat, but she won&#39;t board it without him. &amp;nbsp;Cal shows up and puts his coat around her, and of course the necklace is in the coat. &amp;nbsp;D&#39;oh! &amp;nbsp;Cal tells Rose that he&#39;s made arrangements for he and Jack to get on another boat, and for some reason Rose believes this and gets on. &amp;nbsp;As the boat is being lowered, she suddenly realizes that of course Cal wouldn&#39;t do that and she jumps off. &amp;nbsp;Jack runs down to her and is angry at her for not getting on the boat. &amp;nbsp;Cal sees them embracing and goes into full psycho mode. &amp;nbsp;He pulls out a gun and starts shooting at them. They run away, going lower into the sinking ship.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;More awesome stuff on deck as people start falling to their deaths. Cal kidnaps a kid and tells a crew member it&#39;s his, in order to get on a boat.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;By the time Jack and Rose get back on deck, the boat starts to break in half. &amp;nbsp;As it raises up, people die. &amp;nbsp;As it lowers, people die. Lots of people die, awesomely. Rose and Jack hang on the outside of the railing as the boat is at a ninety degree angle to the sea, and it looks as awesome as you remember. Finally, the whole boat sinks. Jack locates Rose and and puts her on a piece of the boat he found. There&#39;s not room enough for two, so he just clings to it beside her.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;On one of the survivor boats, Molly Brown shouts that they should row over and start rescuing people. The crew member says that it would be too dangerous. Molly tries to get the other women to rise up against the guy and start saving people, but none of them back her up. She sits down, defeated.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Finally, a rescue boat does move in to get people. Rose sees the boat and tries to get Jack&#39;s attention. But he&#39;s dead from hypothermia. She tries to call out to them, but can&#39;t raise her voice above a whisper. &amp;nbsp;She lets go of Jack&#39;s dead hand and as he sinks into the sea, she jumps over to a dead crew member with a whistle around his neck. &amp;nbsp;She blows the whistle as hard as she can, and attracts the rescue boat to her.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Back in the present, Bill Paxton and his crew are sad and feel bad about themselves for not caring more about a bunch of strangers who would be dead by now, anyway.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;We learn that Rose took Jack&#39;s name and created a whole new life in America. She also inexplicably kept the necklace the whole time, even though it had nothing to do with Jack and in fact belonged to a man she hated. She throws it into the ocean so that Bill Paxton will never realize his life&#39;s work.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;You&#39;re up, Celine. &amp;nbsp;Play us out.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;James Cameron does certain things really well. &amp;nbsp;I watched&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Avatar.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp; I enjoyed the hell out of&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Avatar. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;But even as I was watching it, my brain was saying, &quot;you know that writing is terrible, don&#39;t you? &amp;nbsp;You know these characters are cardboard cutouts, don&#39;t you?&quot; &amp;nbsp;&quot;Shut up, brain! &amp;nbsp;Pretty colors! &amp;nbsp;3D!! Giant scary monster things that fly! &amp;nbsp;WHEEEE!!!&quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;The problem with that is, of course that even the most special of special effects become less special with age. One day,&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Avatar&#39;s&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;effects will look as lame as say,&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;King Kong&#39;s&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;do now. The trick in making people forgive that is to have a good story and good writing and good characters. &amp;nbsp;These are things that James Cameron does not do well.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;Titanic is a good example of that. I saw it in the original run, and sat slack-jawed in wonderment with the rest of my theatre-mates went she sank into the sea. Even as I watched it today, I still got goosebumps at the wonderful vertical boat POV with Jack and Rose on the railing. &amp;nbsp;14 years later, the effects still hold up surprisingly well, so my theory doesn&#39;t have to be tested, yet. &amp;nbsp;But I wonder what will happen 14 years from now. &amp;nbsp;Because of course, the love story is trite. &amp;nbsp;The &quot;class warfare&quot; nonsense is simplistic and pandering. &amp;nbsp;Billy Zane is just flat-out horrible and utterly unconvincing as a human being. &amp;nbsp;In reality, the real Molly Brown really&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;did&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;commandeer the rescue boat with the help of other women and saved lives that night. Cameron rewrote history...why? &amp;nbsp;Because somehow making the character utterly useless and pointless was preferable? &amp;nbsp;Ugh. I really just wish Cameron would have the humility to understand what he does well, and what he doesn&#39;t, and just become the world&#39;s greatest technical director, and leave the story up to someone who knows what they&#39;re doing. I bet a Spielberg/Cameron collaboration would be pretty great, in fact.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Two and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Up next, we&#39;re back on track with &quot;In the Heat of the Night&quot; and &quot;Silence of the Lambs&quot;.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-top: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: &#39;Helvetica Neue&#39;, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3553151691712284297/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/82-sunrise-1927.html#comment-form' title='3 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3553151691712284297'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3553151691712284297'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/82-sunrise-1927.html' title='#83 Titanic (1997)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/--LReB7LrjwQ/Te1-1OdUieI/AAAAAAAAACg/kzw3izNqlWo/s72-c/Titanic-titanic-16680057-1197-774.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>3</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8233645166078428107</id><published>2011-05-06T19:40:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-05-08T13:19:08.405-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#84 Easy Rider (1969)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-eAws3fvBM10/TcSXKBp7TXI/AAAAAAAAACA/953rU_MXAA0/s1600/jack.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-eAws3fvBM10/TcSXKBp7TXI/AAAAAAAAACA/953rU_MXAA0/s1600/jack.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;We begin with our heroes, hippie weirdos Wyatt and Billy, buying drugs in Mexico. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt&#39;s the more laid-back of the two, and he&#39;s making the transaction, speaking to the drug guy in Spanish, while Billy says &quot;si, bueno&quot; and giggles. Then, they&#39;ve crossed the border in America, where they sell the drugs to Phil Spector outside of an airport. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt puts the money in a cylindrical tube and puts it inside his motorcycle. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;In a first of many &lt;i&gt;many&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;long shots, we see Billy and Wyatt driving their motorcycles along endless highways, while bitchin&#39; classic rock plays on the soundtrack. While getting gas, they encounter a farmer and his family. &amp;nbsp;The farmer invites them to have lunch, and they do, explaining to him that they&#39;re driving to LA by way of New Orleans, with a stopover for Mardi Gras. &amp;nbsp;The farmer doesn&#39;t even know what &quot;L. A.&quot; is, but is genial and friendly. &amp;nbsp;His wife is Native American and their kids are half white and half Native American. By which I mean, they cast three kids who are clearly white and three kids who are clearly Native American, which I&#39;m pretty sure is not how genetics goes. &amp;nbsp;At any rate, the purpose of this lunch was so that Wyatt and Billy could tell us (through the farmer) where they&#39;re from and where they&#39;re headed, so now that that is done, lunch is over. &amp;nbsp;They hop back on their bikes and another classic tune starts up. Finally, it&#39;s nighttime, and they try to get a room at a hotel, but the owner won&#39;t even talk to them, on account of them being hippie freaks. &amp;nbsp;They wind up sleeping out in the desert by a warm fire, smoking their doobies and talking about how messed up society is, man.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The next day. &amp;nbsp;More picturesque views of America, more classic rock. &amp;nbsp;They pick up a hitchhiker, who remains nameless. &amp;nbsp;That night, they huddle around the fire again and smoke out some more. &amp;nbsp;Billy asks the hitchhiker where he&#39;s from. &amp;nbsp;&quot;It&#39;s hard to say&quot;. &quot;Hard to say?! Ha, what&#39;s that mean, man?&quot; &quot;I have trouble pronouncing it.&quot; Christ, it&#39;s the Marx Brothers all of a sudden. But the guy says it so deadpan, it&#39;s pretty funny. &amp;nbsp;Billy laughs. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt asks the man if he ever wanted to be anyone else. &quot;I&#39;ve considered Porky Pig&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Totally deadpan and quite hilarious.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The next day, they drop off the hitchhiker at his hippie commune, which is basically a couple of shitty looking tents and about twenty or so people running around playing guitars and putting flowers in their hair and letting the sun shine, the sun shine in. &amp;nbsp;Billy and Wyatt hang out with them for a while. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s even a little theatre troupe of about five of them, who wear tights and sing songs. &amp;nbsp;There are a handful of children too, which makes me a little sad. &amp;nbsp;The hitchhiker explains to Billy and Wyatt that they&#39;ve lived here for about a year. &amp;nbsp;They came here last summer, and everything was fine, but then when winter came and people were starving to death. They lost about half their numbers. &amp;nbsp;This year, they&#39;ve resolved to plant crops and save them and live off them through the next winter. &amp;nbsp;Or you know, they could just move. Wyatt sees several dirty hippies pacing back and forth and throwing seeds onto the ground. &amp;nbsp;Billy points out that the dirt is sand, not soil, and nothing will ever grow. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt confidently (and stupidly) grins that he&#39;s sure they&#39;ll do just fine. Billy&#39;s kind of had enough of these weirdos, but Wyatt&#39;s taken a shine to one of the hippie chicks, and eventually he, Billy, and two girls wind up skinny dipping in some of the grossest, dirtiest water I&#39;ve ever seen. &amp;nbsp;Which is fine by me, because it at least prevents us from seeing any nakedness from Peter Fonda or Dennis Hopper. &amp;nbsp;Afterwards, the hitchhiker gives Wyatt some acid or maybe LSD and tells him to take it when &quot;the time is right.&quot;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Then they finally leave. &amp;nbsp;More classic rock. &amp;nbsp;More classic American scenery. &amp;nbsp;This movie is really two parts travelogue, 1 and a half parts music video, and one-half part actual movie.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;All of a sudden, we&#39;re watching a parade in a small town. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a marching band walking down the middle of the street, and Wyatt and Billy join them, driving their motorcycles. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re promptly arrested. &amp;nbsp;The jail cell looks like an old English castle or something, with wrought iron bars and stone walls. &amp;nbsp;Billy yelps and cries out and finally wakes up another prisoner. &amp;nbsp;Jack Nicholson! &amp;nbsp;Thank God. &amp;nbsp;Save this movie, Jack!&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Jack&#39;s name is George in this movie, but we&#39;re calling him Jack anyway. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s wearing a suit and complains about how he must&#39;ve had a wild night last night if he wound up here. &amp;nbsp;Billy tells him to keep his mouth shut. &amp;nbsp;Jack yawns theatrically, and does that weird shit with his eyes. &amp;nbsp;I love you so much, Jack. &amp;nbsp;Finally, the cops come and offer Jack some coffee. &amp;nbsp;Billy asks the cop for a cigarette, but the cop says no until Jack tells him it&#39;s okay. &amp;nbsp;After the cop leaves, Jack tells them he&#39;s a regular at the jail, as he often gets drunk and blacks out, but he&#39;s also a lawyer for the ACLU and a respected person in town. &amp;nbsp;They ask him if he can get them out of jail. &amp;nbsp;&quot;I suppose I can, as long as you haven&#39;t killed anybody. At least, nobody white.&quot;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Cut to, them leaving the jail. Billy says &quot;thanks, dude&quot; and Jack doesn&#39;t know what that word is, so they explain it to him. Then they tell him they&#39;re going to Mardi Gras and invite him along. He mentions that one time a client told him about a brothel in New Orleans that he&#39;s always wanted to go to, but he&#39;s never managed to leave the state lines. He&#39;s down with it. Wyatt asks if he has a helmet. &amp;nbsp;He does. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;It&#39;s a large gold football helmet, and kind of a weak joke, but Jack sells it with That Look, and I giggle in spite of myself.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;So now it&#39;s time for Jack Nicholson, Dennis Hopper, and Peter Fonda to smoke pot and improvise a scene around a campfire. Jack&#39;s character has never smoked pot before and resists at first until Wyatt does the smallest amount of arm-twisting. Billy says he saw movement in the sky, like maybe a spaceship or something, and Jack calmly explains that he saw a formation of about forty ships flying over Mexico the other night, and that this has been a fairly regular occurrence in America ever since the government fired radar beams at the moon in 1946. He goes on to explain that they are very advanced, with no racism or bigotry, no wars, no monetary system, and no leaders. &amp;nbsp;Everyone is free to live as they please. Wyatt doesn&#39;t believe him and wants to know why the aliens don&#39;t reveal themselves to us. Jack says that that&#39;s because our leaders prevent it, because they&#39;re scared of becoming obsolete. But fear not, because the Venutians have contacted people in all walks of life--&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;And here, Jack Nicholson completely breaks character and starts laughing. &amp;nbsp;And they left it in the movie. They cut to Dennis Hopper, who looks interested in what he&#39;s saying, and then cut back to Jack, who actually starts the line over again. &amp;nbsp;WTF. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;He talks more nonsense about how we&#39;ll all transcend one day, and finally everyone goes to bed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;The three of them go to a diner the next morning, and are hassled by the locals who call them fags because of their hair and threaten to beat them up. Eventually, they leave without getting breakfast. One of the locals says he doubts they&#39;ll make it across the parish line.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;More scenery. &amp;nbsp;More classic rock. &amp;nbsp;Nighttime. &amp;nbsp;Campfire. &amp;nbsp;Am I watching Groundhog Day? &amp;nbsp;Billy wants to know what&#39;s wrong with America these days. &amp;nbsp;Jack says that the very people who praise America for its freedom are usually the ones who want to take it away from others, because true freedom scares them. &amp;nbsp;Damn, that&#39;s a pretty astute observation, made slightly ironic given that that line was probably written by Dennis Hopper, who eventually became a Republican.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Later that night, the goons from the diner rush in and start beating Jack with baseball bats. Billy pulls a switchblade and frightens them off, somehow, even though there were three of them with bats. The scene is horribly edited, like most of this movie. Anyway, Jack&#39;s dead, and I&#39;m bummed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;In a weird voiceover/bad overdub, Billy convinces Wyatt to go with him to the brothel that Jack was talking about once they reach New Orleans, which they conveniently do immediately. They pair off with different women at the brothel, but Wyatt&#39;s feeling despondent about Jack and doesn&#39;t want to have sex with the girl. &amp;nbsp;They decide to go out to Bourbon Street and get their drink on. &amp;nbsp;The street looked about the same forty years ago as it did when I last saw it, and makes me nostalgic. &amp;nbsp;Eventually, it&#39;s morning, and they&#39;re drunkenly traipsing through a graveyard. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt decides the time is finally right, and produces the acid. &amp;nbsp;They all take it.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Turns out, it&#39;s a very bad trip, and the weird jumpy editing finally pays off, with a great extended sequence of Wyatt screaming at a statue of the virgin Mary, one of the prostitutes exclaiming over and over that she doesn&#39;t want to die and then later declaring that she&#39;s already dead, the other prostitute naked and weeping and rolling in the dirt, etc. It&#39;s a pretty phenomenally creepy scene, coming way too late. After a few minutes it&#39;s over, and Billy and Wyatt hop on their bikes again. Billy says he can&#39;t wait till they get back home and they can retire with their drug money, but Wyatt says they &quot;blew it&quot;. &amp;nbsp;No idea he&#39;s talking about, don&#39;t care.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;They&#39;re riding along on their bikes, and a truck with two rednecks in it see them up ahead. One redneck says to pull up along side Billy and &quot;scare&quot; him, by aiming a shotgun at him. They do so, and the redneck yells a Billy to get a haircut. Billy gives him the finger. &amp;nbsp;The redneck shoots him. &amp;nbsp;He falls off his bike and crashes. Wyatt stops and turns around and runs over to Billy, while the truck keeps driving. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt promises to get help, then jumps on his bike. &amp;nbsp;The redneck tells his friend to turn around. The truck turns around, heading towards Wyatt. &amp;nbsp;Wyatt rides his bike right by the truck without fear, even though he &lt;i&gt;just saw&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;them shoot his friend in cold blood. &amp;nbsp;They of course shoot him as well, and we&#39;re done.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Well...it was an interesting idea. &amp;nbsp;There are a lot of good ideas here, and the story has an authenticity to it that&#39;s pretty hypnotic and inexplicably compelling at times. Most of the locals in the story aren&#39;t professional actors and it shows with their bad line deliveries, but you just accept it anyway, and convince yourself that that&#39;s just how those characters talk. &amp;nbsp;(Think the Native American secretary from Northern Exposure). &amp;nbsp;The improvised campfire scenes sometimes popped really well, and Jack was a total delight. &amp;nbsp;But, there was a lot there that felt overdone and self-indulgent, even given the ninety five minute running time. &amp;nbsp;Apparently, Dennis Hopper&#39;s original cut was a four hour epic, which would&#39;ve been unwatchable. As it is, I barely made it. The editing is sometimes just shamefully bad, with cuts that make no sense at all and muddle the already anemic narrative , and lots of obvious overdubbing. &amp;nbsp;I got the feeling that maybe a lot of the time this was &quot;guerrilla&quot; filmmaking, without proper lighting or sound, and very few scripted lines. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s oftentimes too much of a mess to take seriously, especially when it so desperately wants us to do so. &amp;nbsp;And the ending was just embarrassingly awful, and made zero sense with respect to how humans actually behave. It was also over-the-top earnest melodrama, where most of the movie up until that point played it cool. &amp;nbsp;All in all, this feels like a movie I should hate unreservedly, but somehow I can&#39;t quite. If it were forty five minutes, and I saw it in an art film appreciation class, I&#39;d be all over that shit, trust me. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two and a half out of five.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;No, man.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Next, my heart will go on and on and on, just as soon as I can find a damn copy of &quot;Titanic&quot; (stupid Very Long Wait), and then my first silent film ever; &quot;Sunrise&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8233645166078428107/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/84-easy-rider-1969.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8233645166078428107'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8233645166078428107'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/84-easy-rider-1969.html' title='#84 Easy Rider (1969)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-eAws3fvBM10/TcSXKBp7TXI/AAAAAAAAACA/953rU_MXAA0/s72-c/jack.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-2682422806059706165</id><published>2011-05-02T19:57:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-05-02T19:57:02.274-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#85 A Night at the Opera (1935)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-LjxI317Iqxs/Tb9ZZSgK_FI/AAAAAAAAAB8/iCbi0DuIDyg/s1600/three.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-LjxI317Iqxs/Tb9ZZSgK_FI/AAAAAAAAAB8/iCbi0DuIDyg/s1600/three.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Okay, so...remember how on &lt;i&gt;MASH&lt;/i&gt;, Hawkeye would sometimes wear a funny pair of glasses and mustache and then run around making even more really bad puns than he normally did? &amp;nbsp;Well, turns out, he didn&#39;t invent that character. &amp;nbsp;It was based on someone called &quot;Groucho Marx&quot;, who worked with other guys referred to as his &quot;brothers&quot; and did movies they called &quot;comedies&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Never seen one until today.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Groucho Marx (playing a character whose name absolutely doesn&#39;t matter) is sitting in a restaurant having dinner with a comely young blond lady. &amp;nbsp;At the table behind him is an older woman, who complains that her date (Groucho) never showed up. &amp;nbsp;They finally see each other, and she harrumphs that he&#39;s late for dinner and he says something like &quot;nonsense, I already had dinner!&quot; and here we go. &amp;nbsp;He then sits at the table with the lady (named Mrs. Claypool). &amp;nbsp;Turns out Groucho is some kind of...agent, maybe? &amp;nbsp;Or PR guy, who is supposed to help Mrs. Claypool become famous or at least accepted in polite society. &amp;nbsp;Or something. &amp;nbsp;They talk for a while, and Groucho basically calls her fat and old a bunch of times and she just glowers. &amp;nbsp;And he&#39;s always crossing his eyes; you know, for the comedy of it. &amp;nbsp;Jerry Lewis swears by this. Wait, is his mustache &lt;i&gt;drawn&lt;/i&gt; on his face? &amp;nbsp;Weird. &lt;br /&gt;Another well-to-do man (Herman) shows up and attempts to woo Mrs. Claypool away from Groucho. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s also a life coach, or whatever &amp;nbsp;Groucho is. &amp;nbsp;Groucho says, &quot;Ah, no you don&#39;t, I saw her first. Well actually, her mother saw her first, but let&#39;s not bring the Civil War into this&quot;. &amp;nbsp;BA DA CHING! &amp;nbsp;Thanks, ladies and germs! Tip your waitress! &amp;nbsp;And then they make plans to go to the opera that night, all three of them.&lt;br /&gt;At the opera, we&#39;re backstage. &amp;nbsp;A weirdo is trying on layers of clothes, including a dress. &amp;nbsp;A man walks into his dressing room, sees the weirdo and starts whipping him with a whip. &amp;nbsp;No, I did not accidentally put on a gay porn. &amp;nbsp;The man is famous opera singer Lasspari, and the weirdo is another Marx brother, called Harpo. &amp;nbsp;I guess his shtick is he doesn&#39;t talk. &amp;nbsp;He totally looks like Teller, too. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, Harpo is Lasspari&#39;s dresser, but Lasspari keeps whipping him, and finally fires him for trying on the clothes. &lt;br /&gt;Later, during the actual Opera, we see Lasspari singing to the female lead, Rosa, while Groucho, Herman, and Mrs. Claypool watch from the box seats. &amp;nbsp;Now, you may ask yourself; are there hijinks? &amp;nbsp;You betcha!&lt;br /&gt;At the end of the opera, Herman says he wants to procure Lasspari and manage him, using Mrs. Claypool&#39;s money. &amp;nbsp;Or connections. &amp;nbsp;Or something. &amp;nbsp;The upshot is, the two of them are somehow going to manage Herman. &amp;nbsp;Look, none of this matters, the wiki plot summary is sparse, and I&#39;m not watching this movie twice! &amp;nbsp;Who are you to judge?! Groucho decides he wants to manage Lasspari instead, after he hears Lasspari can make $1,000 a performance.&lt;br /&gt;So after the show, he goes backstage to approach Lasspari and sign him with Herman&#39;s company. &amp;nbsp;But first, we meet Ricardo, and the last brother, Chico. &amp;nbsp;Chico is Ricardo&#39;s manager, and Ricardo is a newbie singer. &amp;nbsp;Ricardo loves Rosa, and flirts with her blah blah. &amp;nbsp;They go off together, leaving Chico alone. &amp;nbsp;Harpo and Lesspari come running in, Lasspari&#39;s still got the whip (yeah, I don&#39;t...) and he&#39;s telling Harpo he&#39;s still double-dog fired or whatever. &amp;nbsp;Harpo knocks Lasspari out with a mallet, then exits. &amp;nbsp;Groucho shows up, sees Chico looking at Lasspari, and thinks Chico is his manager. &amp;nbsp;He tells Chico he wants to sign up his client with Herman and he&#39;ll make...ten dollars a night. &amp;nbsp;Chico thinks this is great. &amp;nbsp;They figure Chico will need a cut of 3 dollars, and the IRS five, and then Groucho needs his cut of course. &amp;nbsp;Punchline: If he doesn&#39;t do too many performances, he should break even. &amp;nbsp;Groucho then unfurls two long contracts. &amp;nbsp;He gives Chico a copy. &amp;nbsp;They start talking about &quot;the party of the first part will hereby be referred to as the party of the first part&quot;. &amp;nbsp;&quot;What part says that?&quot; &amp;nbsp;&quot;The second part&quot;. &lt;br /&gt;I begin to get very tired.&lt;br /&gt;They continually rip out the parts of the contract they disagree with; the scene is clearly improvised, BADLY, and then at the end they&#39;re left with tiny slips of paper that Chico agrees to sign, but he doesn&#39;t have a pen and Groucho says he&#39;ll take his word for it. &amp;nbsp;Then Chico wants to know what the fine print is and Groucho says it&#39;s the &quot;sanity clause&quot; and Chico says, say with me now, &quot;THERE&#39;S NO SUCH THING AS SANITY CLAUSE&quot;. &lt;br /&gt;Then Lasspari finally wakes up and Groucho thinks to say, &quot;what happened to your client?&quot; and Chico explains that his client is Ricardo...and scene.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;Wake up, you old fool. &amp;nbsp;You slept through the show.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stadler: &lt;/b&gt;Who&#39;s a fool? &amp;nbsp;You watched it. BWA HA HA HA!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Oh sorry, I must&#39;ve dozed off. &amp;nbsp;I think I dreamed that the old men from the Muppets here heckling this movie.&lt;br /&gt;So then, Lasspari is hired by Herman to sail on a boat and go to New York and be a famous opera singer. &amp;nbsp;He gets Herman to also hire Rosa. &amp;nbsp;He tells Rosa the news as she is talking to Ricardo. &amp;nbsp;Rosa doesn&#39;t want to go, but Ricardo encourages her to follow her dreams. &amp;nbsp;She agrees to go with Lasspari, and soon the two of them, plus Groucho, Herman, and Mrs. Claypool are on the boat. &amp;nbsp;The crowd below to see them off include Chico, Harpo, and Ricardo. &amp;nbsp;Everyone asks Rosa and Lesspari to sing as they drift away. &amp;nbsp;Lasspari refuses, as he&#39;s not being paid. &amp;nbsp;Rosa says she will. &amp;nbsp;She sings from the boat, while Ricardo sings from the dock. &amp;nbsp;Harpo mugs and runs around and does a bunch of shit that Jim Carrey would characterize as &quot;trying too hard&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Finally, the scene is over. &lt;br /&gt;We see Groucho with a giant suitcase being pushed on a dolly by a steward. &amp;nbsp;He first goes to Mrs. Claypool&#39;s room, and insists that she meet him for dinner at his room in ten minutes. &amp;nbsp;She refuses at first, until he says he won&#39;t leave unless she agrees. &amp;nbsp;She finally does, and he says, &quot;if you&#39;re not there in ten minutes, I&#39;ll be back here in eleven. &amp;nbsp;With squeaky shoes!&quot; &amp;nbsp;(???????)&lt;br /&gt;He goes to his room, which is extremely small. &amp;nbsp;He can barely fit in his giant suitcase next to the bed. &amp;nbsp;He opens the suitcase, and it turns out, Ricardo, Chico, and Harpo have stowed away. &amp;nbsp;Harpo is sleeping. &amp;nbsp;They put him on the bed, then Ricardo and Chico beg for food. &amp;nbsp;Groucho says he&#39;ll get them food, but they have to eat and leave quickly, because he has a date in ten minutes. &amp;nbsp;Then, he tells them to be quiet, because if they&#39;re caught stowing away, they&#39;ll be arrested. &amp;nbsp;He exits the room, and a waiter is right outside. He orders food. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Three steaks. Medium done, well done, and over-done. &amp;nbsp;And pineapple juice, orange juice, and tomato juice.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;From the room, Chico calls, &quot;And two hardboiled eggs&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;Groucho says, &quot;and two hardboiled eggs.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;Harpo honks his horn. &lt;br /&gt;Groucho says, &quot;make that three hardboiled eggs&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;And then he goes on to order about half a dozen different unfunny things, and after &lt;i&gt;each one, &lt;/i&gt;Chico calls &quot;and two hardboiled eggs&quot; and Groucho repeats it and then Harpo honks his horn and Groucho says &quot;make that three hardboiled eggs&quot;. &amp;nbsp;I mean, &lt;b&gt;that&#39;s the fucking joke.&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp; The &lt;b&gt;actual fucking joke&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;is &quot;make that three hardboiled eggs&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Oh, and then on the last one?! &amp;nbsp;Harpo honks his horn a whole bunch of times, like for about twenty seconds, while Groucho rolls his eyes and then finally it stops and then Groucho says, &quot;Make that &lt;i&gt;twelve&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;hardboiled eggs.&quot; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;THAT&#39;S THE JOKE. &amp;nbsp;THEY CHANGED THE NUMBER FROM THREE TO TWELVE AND THAT&#39;S THE JOKE. &amp;nbsp;SOMEBODY WROTE THAT DOWN AND SAID &quot;HERE, TELL THIS JOKE&quot;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway. &amp;nbsp;They place the order. &amp;nbsp;Then two maids show up to clean the room. &amp;nbsp;They can barely fit. &amp;nbsp;Then a plumber comes to fix something in the room. &amp;nbsp;Then a manicurist. &amp;nbsp;Then a plumbers assistant, who is morbidly obese. &amp;nbsp;Then a woman offering a manicure. &amp;nbsp;Then a woman looking for her Aunt Lily. &amp;nbsp;(Okay, that made me chuckle). &amp;nbsp;Then, like three other people. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re all stuffed in the room, and it&#39;s kinda funny, I guess, or more accurately, would be funny, if I hadn&#39;t already turned against this thing. &amp;nbsp;Finally, four waiters show up with all the food they ordered, but we don&#39;t see them actually fit inside the room. &lt;br /&gt;Cut to outside the room, Mrs. Claypool approaches. &amp;nbsp;She opens the door, and twenty people spill out. &amp;nbsp;Cute, I guess. &amp;nbsp;I&#39;ll give the movie that. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s the only scene that works, even a little bit.&lt;br /&gt;Later, Groucho is having dinner with Mrs. Claypool while the other three hide out in the room. &amp;nbsp;They decide to sneak out and try to get more food. &amp;nbsp;At the dinner, Mrs. Claypool and Herman point out three men with long beards, who are the guest of honor on the boat, and are supposed to make a speech or something when they get to New York. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re famous aviators. &amp;nbsp;(Groucho&#39;s actual joke is, &quot;if they&#39;re aviators, what are they doing on a boat?&quot;). &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;Did you get us tickets?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stadler: &lt;/b&gt;Yeah, they&#39;re for out of town! &amp;nbsp;BWA HA HA HA HA!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sorry, dozed off again. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, moving along. &amp;nbsp;The other three sneak into the dining hall and hilariously eat big piles of food. &amp;nbsp;You would not &lt;i&gt;believe&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;the comic antics Harpo gets up to with a bowl of spaghetti! &amp;nbsp;Then, Rosa shows up, and Ricardo reveals himself to her, and they sing. &amp;nbsp;This takes forever, but at least when there&#39;s singing, there&#39;s no &quot;jokes&quot;. The captain or security guy or whatever sees them singing and goes after them. &amp;nbsp;With Groucho&#39;s help, they escape, and then happen across the room where the aviator&#39;s are staying. &amp;nbsp;They three of them are all asleep in one bed. &amp;nbsp;Harpo magically pulls some scissors out of his pocket and...we fade out.&lt;br /&gt;...fade back in, and we&#39;re in New York. &amp;nbsp;Harpo, Chico, and Ricardo are dressed like the aviators and have the beards glued to their faces. &amp;nbsp;What happened to the actual aviators? &amp;nbsp;One can only assume they were brutally murdered and stuffed into Groucho&#39;s suitcase. &amp;nbsp;At least that would be an interesting plot development. &lt;br /&gt;Okay, moving quickly now. &amp;nbsp;The fake aviators are supposed give a big speech about flying, but they can&#39;t so they stall and it&#39;s &quot;wacky&quot;, and finally they run off with Groucho. &amp;nbsp;Later, we see them living with Groucho at his apartment in New York. &amp;nbsp;A police officer comes and says he hears Groucho is harboring three fugitives (boy, they really take stowing away seriously). &amp;nbsp;Groucho&#39;s apartment as two rooms. &amp;nbsp;The cop sees the bedroom has four beds, but then Groucho distracts him while the other three take the beds away one by one and I&#39;m not even going to get into it. &amp;nbsp;It just goes on and on with everyone running back and forth between the two rooms and even Benny Hill&#39;s like, &quot;enough!&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&amp;nbsp;Moving on! &amp;nbsp;Mrs. Claypool sees Groucho hanging around with the other three and fires him. &lt;br /&gt;They all plan their revenge. &amp;nbsp;At the opera that night, Harpo and Chico kidnap Lasspari, while Groucho distracts Mrs. Claypool and Herman, and Ricardo replaces Lesspari and sings a duet with Rosa. &amp;nbsp;The crowd loves it. &amp;nbsp;Finally, Herman and Mrs. Claypool rescue Lasspari, who had been tied up. &amp;nbsp;They order the arrest of all four of them, but when Lesspari tries to go out and sing the final number with Rosa, the crowd boos him. &amp;nbsp;Herman begs Ricardo to go out there instead. &amp;nbsp;He says he will, but only if they let everyone go. &amp;nbsp;Herman agress, and Ricardo and Rosa sing. &amp;nbsp;Oh, and Harpo&#39;s wearing a dress again, and he rips Herman&#39;s coat for no reason.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stadler: &lt;/b&gt;They aren&#39;t half bad.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Waldorf: &lt;/b&gt;Nope. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re all bad. &amp;nbsp;BWA HA HA HA HA HA!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I really don&#39;t know what to say. &amp;nbsp;I can&#39;t understand a world where this is considered funny.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;One half out of five, because the &quot;crowded state room&quot; scene was pretty clever.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;NO.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next, &quot;Easy Rider&quot; and then my heart will go on with &quot;Titanic&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Hmm...a cast swap would be interesting.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br width="72"/><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-4587146082201092428</id><published>2011-05-01T12:40:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-05-02T01:15:39.082-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#86 Platoon (1986)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-bVchBONYV3M/Tb10-6BhmuI/AAAAAAAAAB4/TMH1zuN6bM4/s1600/aaa.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-bVchBONYV3M/Tb10-6BhmuI/AAAAAAAAAB4/TMH1zuN6bM4/s1600/aaa.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;War is bad. &amp;nbsp;But what about sanctimonious directors?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Chris Taylor and some other new recruits arrive in Vietnam, in a station near the border of Cambodia. &amp;nbsp;They see their first casualty, a dead body in a bodybag, being loaded onto a chopper. &amp;nbsp;Some veterans pass by with catcalls and derision. &amp;nbsp;You don&#39;t know what you&#39;re in for, and all that. &amp;nbsp;Taylor&#39;s immediately frightened. &amp;nbsp;He meets Staff Sergeant Barnes, who&#39;s all hardass and shit. Then there&#39;s Sergeant O&#39;Neill, who&#39;s Barnes&#39; lackey, and Sergeant Elias, who&#39;s more laid back. &lt;br /&gt;Chris voice overs--uh, I mean, writes a letter to his family back home--that the veterans don&#39;t talk to the newbies like him much because they don&#39;t trust them yet, and besides don&#39;t really see the point of getting attached. &amp;nbsp;Chris somewhat patronizingly talks about how they&#39;re all just &quot;regular guys&quot; who are uneducated and have no hope or lives to return to, but hey, at least here they&#39;re heroes. &amp;nbsp;Or something like that. &lt;br /&gt;Finally, there&#39;s a mission. &amp;nbsp;They go out into the Cambodian jungle to...find some Viet Cong and attack them, I guess. &amp;nbsp;Maybe take over a base? &amp;nbsp;Yeah, that&#39;s probably it. &amp;nbsp;In the jungle, Chris is besieged by red ants who bite up his neck and then endless rain and hiking and misery. &amp;nbsp;They settle in for the night, and Chris is a sniper rifle and told to stand guard for the next four hours while everyone sleeps. &amp;nbsp;Cut to four hours later, Chris wakes up a veteran grunt, Junior, and tells him it&#39;s his shift. &amp;nbsp;Junior barely opens his eyes, but takes the rifle from Chris. &amp;nbsp;Chris hunkers down, pulls the hood over his face, and tries to sleep. &amp;nbsp;He doesn&#39;t see that Junior has immediately gone back to sleep himself. Uh-oh.&lt;br /&gt;Sometime later, Chris wakes up. &amp;nbsp;The rain has stopped. &amp;nbsp;He senses something&#39;s amiss. &amp;nbsp;He looks over and sees Junior and the rest of the guys sound asleep. &amp;nbsp;He peers off into the distance. &amp;nbsp;Far off, he sees movement. Someone with a gun is approaching. &amp;nbsp;Then some more shadows behind him. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re getting closer. &amp;nbsp;Chris pulls the hood tighter onto his head, and just gapes, unable to move or sound any kind of alarm. &amp;nbsp;(This is by far the best sequence in the movie). &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, gun fire rings out from Chris&#39; camp. Obviously, someone else is awake. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s a firefight; Chris gets grazed in the neck, another newbie gets killed by a grenade. &amp;nbsp;Chris thinks he&#39;s dying and another solider King, holds him and comforts him. &amp;nbsp;Junior screams that it&#39;s all Chris&#39;s fault, that he was supposed to be guarding! &amp;nbsp;Barnes reads Chris the riot act. &amp;nbsp;Chris tries to defend himself, but no one will listen. &amp;nbsp;The mission is scraped, and they head back to base.&lt;br /&gt;Chris, King, and another dude are doing grunt work. &amp;nbsp;King asks Chris for his backstory, and Chris reveals that he&#39;s rich and that he volunteered to come here. &amp;nbsp;King and the other dude are poor, and were drafted, and can&#39;t believe anyone would ever come here on purpose. &amp;nbsp;Chris says they&#39;re all in the same boat now, but King points out that after the war is over, Chris has options and opportunity, while they have none. &amp;nbsp;Then he says some more twee shit about the differences between rich and poor people, then Oliver Stone appears, looks into the camera, and says &quot;The More You Know&quot; and recommends everyone read the Communist Manifesto. &lt;br /&gt;Later that day, Chris is invited to a party. &amp;nbsp;A pot party, to be precise. &amp;nbsp;Everyone&#39;s toking up, Chris says he&#39;s never tried it before, so they give him a toke. &amp;nbsp;Someone is hotboxing with a gas mask. &amp;nbsp;Heh, awesome. &amp;nbsp;A shirtless Sergeant Elias lounges on a hammock. &amp;nbsp;He casually gets off and saunters over to Chris, joint tangling from his lips. &amp;nbsp;He stares at Chris, who&#39;s so high he&#39;s rocking back and forth. &amp;nbsp;To say that Willem Dafoe is unattractive is to say that The North Pole is kinda chilly. &amp;nbsp;Add to that a &quot;Chris&#39;s pot-fueled POV&quot; camera angle, and I&#39;m just about ready to go to Vietnam right now, just to avoid having to keep looking at Dafoe&#39;s face. &amp;nbsp;Yeesh. Elias lifts up his gun, and points it at Chris, who doesn&#39;t flinch. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Put your mouth on that,&quot; he says, leering. &amp;nbsp;Chris does so. &amp;nbsp;Yes, he sucks on the end of Elias&#39;s gun. &amp;nbsp;Holy shit. This is gayer than &lt;i&gt;Brokeback Mountain&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;(which should be on this list, dammit!). &amp;nbsp;Elias inhales, then blows the smoke into the gun, which Chris greedily sucks up. &amp;nbsp;Everyone laughs at their insanely gay Reefer Madness.&lt;br /&gt;And we&#39;re at another gathering, where Sergeants Barnes and O&#39;Neill are hanging out with some of the other troops, including a badass and disturbingly hot Kevin Dillon (Bunny) and blink-and-you&#39;ll-miss-him Johnny Deep. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re playing cards and drinking alcohol, like real men. &lt;br /&gt;Lt Wolf shows up and tries to ingratiate himself with the guys. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re polite, but clearly don&#39;t want him there, according to movie lore that says sergeants always hate and resent lieutenants. After a short bit, Wolf leaves, leaving O&#39;Neill to remark that he&#39;s a shitstain, and that he&#39;ll never make it out of Nam alive. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Some guys, you just know. &amp;nbsp;You have a feeling, they won&#39;t make it, you know?&quot; &amp;nbsp;Barnes looks at O&#39;Neill, who looks down at his cards. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s clear Barnes has the same feeling, but not about Wolf. &lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s time for another mission in the jungle. &amp;nbsp;Some more time has passed, Chris&#39;s neck wound has healed, and he&#39;s a more confident solider now. &amp;nbsp;After a night in the jungle, they wake up and one of their soldiers is missing. &amp;nbsp;They split up and do recon, &amp;nbsp;Eventually, Barnes and some others find the soldier tied to a tree and mutilated, dead. &amp;nbsp;Everyone is overcome with anger. &amp;nbsp;They stumble across a small village, still feeling angry and scared. Most of them are screaming at the elderly men and women and children, some of whom are hiding in holes dug in the ground, all of whom are weak and terrified. &amp;nbsp;Bunny shoots a couple of pigs out of spite. &amp;nbsp;Chris finds an old man with one leg and his wife hiding in a hole under the floor of their hut, and he drags them out. &amp;nbsp;He starts screaming at them both. &amp;nbsp;Bunny joins him, laughing hysterically. &amp;nbsp;Finally, Chris starts shooting the ground at the man&#39;s foot, telling him to dance. &amp;nbsp;After a moment, he starts to come to his senses, and realizes how he&#39;s losing control. &amp;nbsp;He starts crying. &amp;nbsp;Bunny&#39;s disgusted with that, and in a fit, hits the old man with the but of his gun until the man&#39;s head is split open. &amp;nbsp;He makes a comment about the man&#39;s brains looking gross. &amp;nbsp;Fuck you, Johnny Drama! &amp;nbsp;Chris is horrified, and runs out of the hut.&lt;br /&gt;Outside, the women and children are being rounded up and questioned. &amp;nbsp;Barnes keeps yelling at one old guy, certain that the guy knows where the Viet Cong are hiding in the area. &amp;nbsp;The old man swears he doesn&#39;t know. Suddenly, his wife starts lunging at Barnes, trying to attack him, spitting at him. &amp;nbsp;The other soldiers easily hold her back. &amp;nbsp;Barnes ignores her at first and keeps questioning the man, and she keeps squawking. &amp;nbsp;Finally, he turns, raises his gun, and shoots her in the head. &amp;nbsp;The old mans starts screaming. &amp;nbsp;The other soldiers look at him in horror, but say nothing. &amp;nbsp;Barnes then grabs a little girl, and points the gun at her head, warning the old man to spill it, or she&#39;s next. &amp;nbsp;Elias comes out of a hut. &amp;nbsp;He sees what&#39;s going on, screams at Barnes to stop, then punches him in the face. &amp;nbsp;They brawl for a little while until Lt. Wolf shows up. &amp;nbsp;He orders them to stop fighting and to burn down the village. &amp;nbsp;Chris, having witnessed the whole thing and clearly ashamed of his own inaction, looks off in the distance and sees Bunny, Junior, and two other guys raping a villager. &amp;nbsp;He runs over, and tells them to stop and helps her to her feet. &amp;nbsp;They call him a fairy and a cocksucker, because real men drink beer &lt;i&gt;and&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;rape Vietnamese villagers.&lt;br /&gt;Back at the camp, Elias reports the murder Barnes committed to the base leader, a captain. &amp;nbsp;The captain says a full investigation will occur and if an &quot;unauthorized killing&quot; took place, there will be court martials. &amp;nbsp;In the meantime, however, it&#39;s business as usual. &amp;nbsp;Chris gives another voiceover, I mean, writes another letter to a rando family member, and says the business between Elias and Barnes has led to a &quot;Civil War&quot; at camp, between those who back Elias and those who back Barnes. &lt;br /&gt;We see Junior and Bunny discussing pot. &amp;nbsp;Bunny thinks pot is a plot by the gooks to make us all pacifists, and he don&#39;t play that. &amp;nbsp;In case this is too subtle, Oliver Stone would like you to know that people who smoke pot are good and nice and people who don&#39;t are rapists and murderers. &lt;br /&gt;Suddenly, a report comes in from up ahead that a huge platoon of Viet Cong are heading this way for an attack. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s too many of them to fight. &amp;nbsp;They jump into action, working together despite their differences. &amp;nbsp;Elias has a plan to take Chris and two other soldiers...to like some other part of the jungle, where they will attack the Viet Cong from the side, and provide a distraction maybe?, while the others get out. I didn&#39;t really get it, because it was only four of them, and I&#39;m not watching it again. &amp;nbsp;Anyway. &amp;nbsp;Barnes thinks that idea&#39;s just swell, and in the meantime, the rest of them will continue their retreat. &amp;nbsp;Elias says don&#39;t forget to pick us up before you leave. &amp;nbsp;Barnes says totally, don&#39;t sweat it, what possible motive would I have to do otherwise?&lt;br /&gt;The battle commences, and nearly everyone has retreated at this point. &amp;nbsp;Chris and the other two get separated from Elias, and stumble across Barnes. &amp;nbsp;Chris tells Barnes they lost Elias. &amp;nbsp;Barnes says he&#39;ll find him, then orders Chris and the others to retreat. &amp;nbsp;He goes further into the jungle. &amp;nbsp;About halfway back to the camp, Chris, feeling suspicious, tells the other two to go without him, then heads back into the jungle. &amp;nbsp;Barnes discovers Elias in a clearing. &amp;nbsp;They both raise their guns. &amp;nbsp;Elias sees that it&#39;s Barnes, smiles, and lowers his gun. &amp;nbsp;Barnes doesn&#39;t lower his. &amp;nbsp;Too late, Elias sees the look in his eyes. Barnes fires, three times in the chest. &amp;nbsp;Elias falls over dead. &lt;br /&gt;Barnes heads back to camp and runs into Chris, going the other way. &amp;nbsp;He tells Chris that Elias is dead, and they need to retreat now. &amp;nbsp;The Viet Cong got him. &amp;nbsp;Chris doesn&#39;t look like he believes him, but goes with him anyway. &amp;nbsp;They run back to the base, and get on the last chopper. &amp;nbsp;While they&#39;re in the air, Elias comes running through the jungle, the Viet Cong right on his heels. &amp;nbsp;Barnes is stunned, and so am I, since he was shot three times in the fucking chest. What is this, &lt;i&gt;Friday the 13th&lt;/i&gt;? Chris wants to land and pick him up, but Barnes, looking totally worried, says it&#39;s too dangerous. &amp;nbsp;Sure enough, the Viet Cong quickly finish Elias off.&lt;br /&gt;At the new base, Chris is talking to King and some of the other pot smoking good guys, voicing his suspicion about Elias&#39;s death, and trying to get them to &quot;do something&quot; about Barnes. &amp;nbsp;Barnes suddenly appears, having been spying on them. &amp;nbsp;He taunts them all, says the pot smoking has killed their brain cells, then says none of them would ever have the guts to try anything with him. &amp;nbsp;Chris attacks him at that moments, swinging wildly, but Barnes quickly gets the upperhand and beats the hell out of him. &amp;nbsp;He points his gun at Chris&#39;s head, until King softly says there&#39;s no way he&#39;d get away with this kill and would go to jail for sure. &amp;nbsp;Barnes sees the wisdom in that, and lowers his weapon. &amp;nbsp;He walks out.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, it&#39;s the Third Act, so there&#39;s one final battle to be had. &amp;nbsp;The soldiers are nervous and jittery, feeling something in the air, the quiet before the storm. Junior&#39;s foot is swelled up and infected. &amp;nbsp;He says he can&#39;t walk, and needs to be E-vac&#39;d out of there. &amp;nbsp;Barnes threatens to put a scorpion down his pants if he doesn&#39;t walk. &amp;nbsp;The orders come down from the brass that King&#39;s tour of duty is up, and he can leave on the next chopper. &amp;nbsp;He and Chris hug it out, then King takes off. &amp;nbsp;O&#39;Neill begs Barnes to let him on the same chopper, just to go back to the mainland for three days R &amp;amp; R. &amp;nbsp;Barnes refuses. &amp;nbsp;O&#39;Neill is despondent. &amp;nbsp;He has a feeling, you see. &amp;nbsp;That something wicked this way comes.&lt;br /&gt;King flies away on the chopper and I fully expected a Henry Blake scenario where the chopper blows up or something, but apparently he made hit home safely as the movie never mentions King again. &amp;nbsp;Good for you, King.&lt;br /&gt;Later that night, a &quot;surprise&quot; ambush. &amp;nbsp;A surprise to them, but not to us, as there are only about twenty minutes left, and this needs to end on a big battle scene. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s nighttime, and the fighting and shooting go on for awhile. &amp;nbsp;The Viet Cong have the numbers, and are killing our friends left and right. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a pretty detailed and effects-laden and fantastic set piece, though I&#39;m mostly bored at this point. &amp;nbsp;O&#39;Neill hides in a foxhole under several dead bodies and manages not to get spotted. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s probably the most memorable part. Finally, towards the end, we see the military brass decide to just cut their losses and carpet-bomb the whole area, killing Viet Cong and US soldiers alike. Back on the battlefield, Barnes stumbles across Chris, who&#39;s bloodied and panting in a hole, and jumps on him. &amp;nbsp;He raises his machete, ready to slam it into Chris&#39;s chest. &amp;nbsp;Chris screams &quot;NO!&quot;, but not in that horribly cheesy way Darth Vader did, and suddenly the whole sky lights up with fire. &amp;nbsp;Fade to black&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s daytime now. &amp;nbsp;Chris is still alive. &amp;nbsp;He staggers to his feet and limps along. &amp;nbsp;There are hundreds of bodies everywhere, littering the landscape. &amp;nbsp;Magically, he stumbles across Barnes who is also still alive, but severely wounded. &amp;nbsp;He barks out an order for a medic. &amp;nbsp;Chris just stares at him for a moment, then shoots him dead. &amp;nbsp;The rescue soldiers rush in right then (of course), and ask Chris is he&#39;s okay, etc. &amp;nbsp;They carry him out onto a stretcher and then into a helicopter. &amp;nbsp;As they take off, Chris surveys the devastation and begins to weep. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a very powerful moment that could only be ruined if there&#39;s yet another voiceover where Chris spews some badly written Maya Angelou-esq glurge lamenting the human condition. &amp;nbsp;Oh, here we go:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&quot;I think now, looking back, we did not fight the enemy. &amp;nbsp;We fought ourselves. The enemy was in us. &amp;nbsp;The war was over for me now, but it will always be there, for the rest of my days. &amp;nbsp;Just as I&#39;m sure Elias will be, fighting with Barnes for the possession of my soul. &amp;nbsp;There are times since, I&#39;ve felt like a child, born of these two fathers. But be that as it may, those of us who did make it have an obligation to build again. &amp;nbsp;To teach others what we know, and to try with the rest of our lives to find a goodness and a meaning to this life&quot;.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And then Oliver Stone starts masturbating.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I was harder on it during the summary there than I planned to be. The truth is, there are a lot of powerful and compelling moments in this, but also a lot of vapid moralizing and telling not showing. And the pro-pot propaganda was just embarrassing. &amp;nbsp;I don&#39;t know, maybe in the eighties no one had done this kind of movie about Vietnam before. &amp;nbsp;Maybe it was shocking or whatever. &amp;nbsp;But really, the setting happened to be Vietnam, but this story could&#39;ve been about any group of people anywhere, struggling to remain good under adverse conditions. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s a worthy topic for a movie, I just wish it had been told better. &amp;nbsp;Also, Charlie Sheen? &amp;nbsp;Not a good actor. &amp;nbsp;Not noticeably terrible or anything, but certainly can&#39;t hold a candle to Berenger or Dafoe or even Kevin Dillon, and it shows. &amp;nbsp;One of the easiest things to do as an actor is yell and scream and act really mad, but Sheen can&#39;t even really put much teeth behind that. &amp;nbsp;Very weak.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Three out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;No.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next up, &quot;A Night at the Opera&quot; and then &quot;Easy Rider&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Also, I want props for not making a single Charlie Sheen joke.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/4587146082201092428/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/86-platoon-1986.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4587146082201092428'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/4587146082201092428'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/05/86-platoon-1986.html' title='#86 Platoon (1986)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-bVchBONYV3M/Tb10-6BhmuI/AAAAAAAAAB4/TMH1zuN6bM4/s72-c/aaa.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-7785864048822954677</id><published>2011-04-27T19:27:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-04-27T19:33:38.414-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#87 12 Angry Men (1957)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vrKQ2aexF8s/TbeTBnqaFcI/AAAAAAAAAB0/S7ZShkP9PGU/s1600/12.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vrKQ2aexF8s/TbeTBnqaFcI/AAAAAAAAAB0/S7ZShkP9PGU/s1600/12.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I&#39;ve seen this as a play, and part of an 80&#39;s TV Movie with Jack Lemmon. &amp;nbsp;But I hadn&#39;t seen this version before, of course. &amp;nbsp;The black and white kept me away. &amp;nbsp;Let&#39;s see if it was for a good reason.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;A bored judge instructs a jury of twelve not-really-all-that-angry men about the seriousness of the crime alleged (murder), the severity of the penalty (death) and the need for their verdict to be unanimous. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s got his fist propping up his head, and can barely stay awake as he recites his jury instructions from memory. &amp;nbsp;The twelve men nod dutifully and then get up to begin deliberations. &amp;nbsp;We see a shot of the accused, a young kid, only eighteen, who looks to be Latino or perhaps Middle Eastern. &amp;nbsp;(The play I saw never showed the kid, which I think is a better way to go). &lt;br /&gt;In the jury room, the men futz around for a bit; one man tries to plug in a fan that doesn&#39;t work, several talk about how damn hot it is, a few others mention the waste of time the trial was and comment on the obvious guilt of the defendant. The Jury Foreman (# 1) finally calls everyone together and suggests everyone sit down and begin. Someone suggests they sit down in order of their numbers, which was very helpful for me, since none of them get names. &amp;nbsp;(&lt;i&gt;It also reminds me of the Cylons, of which there were also twelve. &amp;nbsp;Ooh, that&#39;s fun. &amp;nbsp;Imagine the Cylons as you read this. &amp;nbsp;Henry Fonda is number 8, same as Boomer. &amp;nbsp;So go ahead and feel free to imagine Henry Fonda as a hot Asian chick&lt;/i&gt;). &amp;nbsp; Very quickly, slick # 7 mentions he has a ball game he&#39;s planning on attending that afternoon, and suggests they take a quick vote and get this over with. &amp;nbsp;No one seems to have any objections. &amp;nbsp;#1 (&lt;i&gt;Brother John Cavill&lt;/i&gt;) calls out a vote for guilty. &amp;nbsp;Many hands shoot up. &amp;nbsp;He counts. &amp;nbsp;&quot;One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven. &amp;nbsp;And, uh...not guilty? &amp;nbsp;Ah, just the one&quot;. &amp;nbsp;#8&#39;s hand is the only one to go up. &amp;nbsp;Several others express annoyance at this, but #8 quite reasonably says he&#39;s not sure yet, and before one sentences someone to death, there ought to be at least a little discussion. &amp;nbsp;#1 comes up with the idea to go around the table and say why you think the kid is guilty. &amp;nbsp;#2 (&lt;i&gt;Leoben)&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;thinks he just seems guilty.
