width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1566879230311142874</id><published>2011-04-10T16:13:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-04-10T19:07:07.971-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#91 Sophie&#39;s Choice (1982)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-hoyW7S1zSmo/TaIeErIf5hI/AAAAAAAAABk/6aeEELxRThc/s1600/sophie.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-hoyW7S1zSmo/TaIeErIf5hI/AAAAAAAAABk/6aeEELxRThc/s1600/sophie.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s the &quot;feel horrible&quot; movie of the century. &amp;nbsp;Come one, come all.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;The weirdo European dude from &lt;i&gt;Ghostbusters II &lt;/i&gt;announces through some slightly overwrought narration that his name is Stingo, and he&#39;s a twenty-two year old farm boy from Virginia, who has traveled to big bad Brooklyn to find himself and gain an education in life. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s 1946, just a year and a half after the end of the Second World War. &amp;nbsp;Stingo arrives at a large pink house that serves as an apartment complex of sorts. &amp;nbsp;He meets the landlady, and moves in downstairs. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s one other neighbor upstairs. &amp;nbsp;When he gets inside his room, there is a note there from the upstairs neighbors, Sophie and Nathan, who welcome him to the neighborhood. &amp;nbsp;That night, he hears loud arguing, shaking his chandelier. &amp;nbsp;He opens his door and looks outside. &amp;nbsp;Sophie and Nathan are on the stairway. &amp;nbsp;Nathan is screaming at Sophie, calling her a disease, and saying he wants nothing more to do with her. &amp;nbsp;He turns to leave, and sees Stingo standing in the doorway. &amp;nbsp;He sneers at Stingo for &quot;eavesdropping&quot;, then makes some dumb Southern hick jokes and tells Stingo that he&#39;s not pleased to meet him, and thrilled that he will never see him again. &amp;nbsp;He exits the building.&lt;br /&gt;Stingo asks Sophie if she&#39;s okay. &amp;nbsp;She mumbles yes, then runs upstairs. &amp;nbsp;The next day she appears at his door with a tray with dinner on it. &amp;nbsp;She offers it to him as an apology and stammers that Nathan is not normally like that. &amp;nbsp;He asks her about her accent, and she says she&#39;s Polish, and he notices a tattoo with a number on her arm. &amp;nbsp;So I guess she&#39;s a real rebellious type of woman, then, to get a tattoo in 1946? &amp;nbsp;Stingo invites her in, but she declines, leaving the dinner.&lt;br /&gt;Later that night, Stingo walks upstairs with the tray, and leaves it on her doorstep. &amp;nbsp;The door is ajar, and he sees her sleeping inside. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, Nathan comes home. &amp;nbsp;Stingo hides and watches Nathan come upstairs, and curl up at Sophie&#39;s feet. &amp;nbsp;She awakes, and he mumbles apologies and they get all kissy-kissy and all that. &amp;nbsp;Stingo shuffles back downstairs. &lt;br /&gt;The next day, Nathan and Sophie arrive at Stingo&#39;s window, waking him up. &amp;nbsp;Nathan apologizes for the other day, and says they want to make it up to him with a night on the town. &amp;nbsp;Stingo is quite happy to join them. &amp;nbsp;Stingo needs to watch more Oprah and learn how to recognize the signs of an abuser. &amp;nbsp;Stingo meets them later up in the apartment, and they are dressed up with silly hats and canes, and Sophie&#39;s got a fur. &amp;nbsp;Someone throw some red paint on her! Nathan explains that they like to dress up silly from time to time. &amp;nbsp;Farm boy Stingo is utterly enchanted by the two of them and their total trying-too-hard bullshit. Nathan says he is a biologist working on a big secret project. Sophie explains that she knows multiple languages, because her father taught her them growing up in Poland. She says she and Nathan met a year ago when he saved her life, shortly after she was liberated from a concentration camp in Poland. &amp;nbsp;Stingo assumes she is Jewish, but she reveals that while Nathan is Jewish, she is not and is in fact a Catholic. &amp;nbsp;Stingo&#39;s dying to ask how a Catholic ended up in a camp, but remembers that Miss Manners says concentration camp inquires during lunch are rude until after Labor Day. &amp;nbsp;We see a flashback of Sophie arriving in America and learning English. &amp;nbsp;The professor reads to her a poem, by Emily Dickinson, and she goes to the library the next day to read more. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s very weak and her English is poor, and she asks the writer for a book of poetry by &quot;Emil Dickens&quot;. &amp;nbsp;The librarian is a total dick and says there&#39;s no such name, and then she passes out. &amp;nbsp;Nathan rushes to her side, commenting as she lay there about her beauty. &amp;nbsp;He takes her back to his apartment, and says his brother is a doctor and will check her out. &amp;nbsp;It turns out she had a severe iron deficiency, and Nathan slowly nursed her back to health.&lt;br /&gt;Montage of the three of them spending several days or weeks together, laughing at the park, riding a roller coast at the fair, sitting in a hammock together or lounging on the roof of the apartment complex. &amp;nbsp;Stephen Baldwin, Josh Charles, and Lara Flynn Boyle, eat your heart out!&lt;br /&gt;One night, Nathan is late coming home from the lab. &amp;nbsp;Sophie is worried and calls Stingo to come over and wait with her. &amp;nbsp;She considers calling the police, but Stingo talks her out of it. She asks him about the novel he&#39;s writing. &amp;nbsp;He says it&#39;s semi-autobiographical, about a boy who&#39;s mother dies when he&#39;s twelve. &amp;nbsp;She says it&#39;s always hard to lose people you love, and he asks her who she&#39;s lost. &amp;nbsp;She reveals that her father and husband were killed by the Germans when they invaded Poland. &amp;nbsp;She and her mother were allowed to live in their home, but her mother was sick and malnourished and needed meat. &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately, only Germans were allowed to eat meat, but Sophie&#39;s big plan was to steal a ham, stick it under her dress and pretend she was pregnant. Unfortunately, a German solider caught her on the train and arrested her, and that&#39;s how she ended up at the camp. &amp;nbsp;The Germans were quite tough on crime. &lt;br /&gt;During the story, Stingo wipes her tears and strokes her face to the point of annoying distraction. &amp;nbsp;Nathan arrives home, unseen by them. He&#39;s acting creepy and cold, and is clearly suspicious of Stingo&#39;s motivations. &amp;nbsp;Sophie scolds him, and says she invited Stingo over because she was wondering why he hadn&#39;t come home yet, and was worried. &amp;nbsp;Nathan eventually calms down and seems to buy the story. &lt;br /&gt;The next day, Nathan visits Stingo and asks about the novel he&#39;s writing. &amp;nbsp;Stingo shows it to him. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, Nathan gleefully grabs the manuscript and races out of the room, laughing. &amp;nbsp;Stingo playfully chases him. Sophie intercepts Stingo at the door and explains that she will spend the day with him while Nathan reads the novel. &amp;nbsp;Stingo thinks this is a fine deal, indeed. When they return home that night, Nathan links both their arms and runs them out of the apartment. &amp;nbsp;They go running through the streets until they reach a bridge. &amp;nbsp;Nathan reveals he has three glasses and champagne, and the three of them toast to the brilliance of Stingo&#39;s novel and his inevitable success as a writer.&lt;br /&gt;Another scene, Stingo and Sophie are at the park, lying around and eating. &amp;nbsp;Nathan comes running up with several boxes, and says he has amazing news. &amp;nbsp;He grabs them both and dances around. &amp;nbsp;He gives them each a box, and inside are fancy dinner outfits. &amp;nbsp;He says that his lab made an incredible amazing breakthrough at work today, but he can&#39;t tell them what it is yet! &amp;nbsp;He instructs them to wear those outfits and meet him tonight in the apartment. &amp;nbsp;That night, Stingo and Sophie excitedly prepare for their three-person romantic evening, cooking dinner by candlelight in their fancy new digs. Sophie reveals that she bought Nathan an expensive pocket watch that she really couldn&#39;t afford, but hey, Nathan&#39;s worth it. &amp;nbsp;You might have an inkling where this is going.&lt;br /&gt;Nathan arrives home, looking disheveled and moving slowly. &amp;nbsp;The other two don&#39;t notice at first, and pop the champagne. &amp;nbsp;Stingo wants to know what the biology breakthrough was at work. &amp;nbsp;Nathan snarls, and tells him his book is shit, and then accuses Sophie of cheating on him with her boss. &amp;nbsp;He leans over her, slobbering and sweaty, and says it&#39;s very suspicious that she, as a non-Jew, was sent to the camps, and somehow was the only one in her family who lived. &amp;nbsp;She begs him to stop, and finally (FINALLY!) after several minutes, Stingo tries to get him &amp;nbsp;to do just that, grabbing at Nathan. &amp;nbsp;Nathan pushes him off, and throws him out of the apartment, while Sophie stammers apologies. &lt;br /&gt;The next day, both Sophie and Nathan are gone. &amp;nbsp;Stingo asks the landlady where they went, and she says she doesn&#39;t know, but they left separately. &amp;nbsp;Stingo goes to Sophie&#39;s work at the library. &amp;nbsp;The boss there says she isn&#39;t there. &amp;nbsp;Then, in a weird bit of really shitty and clunky exposition, volunteers that he&#39;s from Poland, and that he knew who her father was. &amp;nbsp;Turns out he was a racist and Nazi sympathizer and academic who wrote at length about the Jews and how they were destroying Europe. &amp;nbsp;Stingo is stunned. &amp;nbsp;He wants to know how it was that the father was killed. &amp;nbsp;The boss speculates that sometimes academics were killed without regard to their affiliation. &lt;br /&gt;Stingo returns to the apartment. &amp;nbsp;Sophie is there. &amp;nbsp;She apologizes for Nathan the night before. &amp;nbsp;He gently confronts her with what he learned, and she invites him to watch her flashback story. &amp;nbsp;It seems she worked for her father helping him write speeches about the &quot;evil&quot; plague of Jews in Poland. She was shocked at the terrible speeches he made, but helped write them anyway. &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately, after he was killed, she was sent to the camps for the ham incident. &amp;nbsp;She adds to the story this time, admitting that she had two children. Her daughter was &quot;exterminated&quot;, and her son was sent to a camp for children. &amp;nbsp;We see her at the camp, broken and limping and barely walking upright. They learn she speaks perfect German, so she is brought in from the prison part of the camp, to the Commandant&#39;s house. &amp;nbsp;The German solider walks her past the enslaved and dying prisoners and into the house just a few hundred yards away, where children are dancing and carefree. &amp;nbsp;She is cleaned up and takes dictation for the Commandant. &amp;nbsp;She reveals to the Commandant that she&#39;s not a Jew and says who her father is, and speaks perfect German to him as proof. She begs him for mercy. &amp;nbsp;He is unmoved, saying that even if she&#39;s not a dirty Jew, she&#39;s still a dirty Pol, and what&#39;s the difference, really? &amp;nbsp;She attempts to seduce him. &amp;nbsp;They are interrupted by another solider. &amp;nbsp;After the Commandant gets rid of him, he tells her that she&#39;s very beautiful and German-looking, and that he might have been moved to help her if he weren&#39;t shipping out the next day, anyway. &amp;nbsp;She tries a different tact, mentioning her son at the children&#39;s camp. &amp;nbsp;She says he&#39;s innocent, and looks German like her, and even speaks it. &amp;nbsp;She begs the Commandant to at least free her son and allow him to grow up a young boy in Germany. &amp;nbsp;The Commandant says he will do it. &amp;nbsp;She goes back to the camp the night, elated. &lt;br /&gt;Outside of the flashback, Sophie tells Stingo that in fact, the Commandant did not keep his word and she never saw her son again. &amp;nbsp;She says that&#39;s when she first tried to kill herself, and she would be dead now if Nathan didn&#39;t need her to live for him. &amp;nbsp;Stingo holds her in his arms and asks her to live for him, too. &amp;nbsp;Sophie sees Nathan sitting outside in the yard, and she races out to see him. &lt;br /&gt;All is forgiven yet again, and another quick montage of the three of them playing around fills me with anger. &amp;nbsp;Nobody seems interested in telling Nathan to fuck off. &amp;nbsp;One night, Stingo gets a phone call from Nathan&#39;s brother, the doctor, asking to see him. &amp;nbsp;Stingo meets the man, who reveals that Nathan isn&#39;t a biologist at all, and is in fact, insane and a drug addict. &amp;nbsp;The &quot;job&quot; he stays at late at night is actually a &quot;funny farm&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Stingo is floored. &amp;nbsp;He asks Stingo to keep an eye on his brother. &amp;nbsp;Okay movie, this is the second time you&#39;ve had random characters jump in and reveal key info. &amp;nbsp;Not cool. &lt;br /&gt;He returns home, and finds Nathan and Sophie there, all decked out in Southern apparel. &amp;nbsp;Nathan tells Stingo they&#39;re dressed that way in his honor and they&#39;re going to all take a vacation together in Virginia as a honeymoon after he and Sophie get married. &amp;nbsp;Sophie turns to him in surprise at this, and Nathan proposes. &amp;nbsp;Sophie expresses reluctance at this step, and Nathan gets upset and storms out. &lt;br /&gt;The next day, Sophie and Stingo await his return anxiously. &amp;nbsp;Nathan calls Stingo and screams at him awhile, Stingo just wants to know where he is. &amp;nbsp;He says he&#39;s in a neighboring town, then there&#39;s the sound of a gunshot. &amp;nbsp;Stingo and Sophie go to the town and get a hotel to sleep for the night. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re unable to find Nathan. &amp;nbsp;At the hotel, Stingo blows Nathan&#39;s spot re: the biology lie, but Sophie is unsurprised. &amp;nbsp;Stingo proposes to her, and asks her to go down to live with him on a farm in Virginia (way to ride Nathan&#39;s coattails, dude). &amp;nbsp;She agrees to the farm, but not the marriage. &amp;nbsp;Stingo says in Virginia they won&#39;t abide by a man and a woman living together without being married (behind the curve as always, eh, Virginia?) She says she can&#39;t because she would not make a good mother, and can&#39;t give him any children. &amp;nbsp;He confidently says she&#39;d be a great mother, which prompts Sophie to offer compelling evidence to the contrary. &lt;br /&gt;One last flashback. &amp;nbsp;She lied before about her kids. &amp;nbsp;She stood in line, with hundreds of others, carrying her daughter while her son stood clutching her side. &amp;nbsp;The guards walked by her, sneering. &amp;nbsp;One made eye contact with her, said something snide. &amp;nbsp;She responded in German, said she didn&#39;t belong here, it was all a mistake, she&#39;s not one of &lt;i&gt;them, &lt;/i&gt;she&#39;s pure, please help. &amp;nbsp;The guard asked if she was Christian. &amp;nbsp;Yes, devout Catholic. &amp;nbsp;Did not Christ say &quot;suffer the children&quot;? &amp;nbsp;Choose one. &amp;nbsp;What? &amp;nbsp;Choose one child. &amp;nbsp;One will live, one will die. &amp;nbsp;No, I can&#39;t. &amp;nbsp;Choose! &amp;nbsp;Or they both will die. Please don&#39;t! &amp;nbsp;Guards! &amp;nbsp;Take her children! &amp;nbsp;My daughter, take my daughter!&amp;nbsp;Her daughter was ripped out of her arms and she screamed so loud and so high, the others winced. &amp;nbsp;The guards whisked her away in a flash, leaving Sophie gasping and sobbing and clinging to her son.&lt;br /&gt;Back at the hotel, Stingo and Sophie make love. &amp;nbsp;I would&#39;ve thought that story was the ultimate boner-killer, but Stingo is twenty-two and a virgin, so what&#39;re ya gonna do? &lt;br /&gt;The next morning, Sophie&#39;s gone. &amp;nbsp;Stingo returns to the apartment in Brooklyn. &amp;nbsp;The police are there, as well as a crowd of lookey-loos. &amp;nbsp;Stingo fights his way inside, and is taken by a detective up into Nathan and Sophie&#39;s apartment. &amp;nbsp;He sees them laying there on the bed in each other&#39;s arms, dead from cyanide. She made her choice.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;There&#39;s a lot of movies where the eccentric couple seduce the young newbie into their seemingly carefree and happy life, and soon learn that all is not what it seems. &amp;nbsp;This movie has that, but manages to put such an incredibly unique and dark spin on it, that it almost completely transcends the subgenre. &amp;nbsp;I knew about the &quot;choice&quot; ahead of time, again through pop culture osmosis, and didn&#39;t think I would be anywhere near as shocked and sickened when the time came. &amp;nbsp;The movie surprised me throughout, the reveal of Nathan&#39;s insanity was one of those great movie reveals, the ones where you are simultaneously surprised and smacking yourself on the head for not realizing. &amp;nbsp;Very well done. &amp;nbsp;Peter MacNichol and Kevin Kline are superb, with gravitas to spare, but of course the film belongs to Meryl. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s of course technically proficient and an accomplishment in it&#39;s own right, to speak English with a flawless Polish accent, as well as both fluent Polish and German with what I&#39;m gonna assume is also no accent. &amp;nbsp;But leaving all that aside, the performance is totally raw and believable. &amp;nbsp;If she were an unknown, I would be convinced she was really a foreigner. &lt;br /&gt;That said, the movie did drag a little in a few parts, and the brother and Sophie&#39;s boss were such obviously clunky Exposition Fairies, that it irritated me a lot. &amp;nbsp;But I can&#39;t be too hard on a movie that was trying to tackle such a huge story like the Holocaust and make it so personal and intimate. &amp;nbsp;It very mostly succeeds. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does it deserve &quot;Best 100&quot; status: &lt;/b&gt;Yes, Meryl&#39;s performance puts it over the top.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next up, I see dead people. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Swing Time&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Oh, and also &quot;The Sixth Sense&quot;.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1566879230311142874/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/91-sophies-choice-1982.html#comment-form' title='3 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1566879230311142874'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1566879230311142874'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/91-sophies-choice-1982.html' title='#91 Sophie&#39;s Choice (1982)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-hoyW7S1zSmo/TaIeErIf5hI/AAAAAAAAABk/6aeEELxRThc/s72-c/sophie.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>3</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-947221713913405093</id><published>2011-04-08T12:35:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-04-08T12:57:18.508-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#92 Goodfellas (1990)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-g7B_3GqtMpA/TZ6AejjU-DI/AAAAAAAAABg/a3Nr2RUpIhk/s1600/funny.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-g7B_3GqtMpA/TZ6AejjU-DI/AAAAAAAAABg/a3Nr2RUpIhk/s1600/funny.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I only saw this one for the first time a year ago, so it counts as one of my 31 previously viewed, but only just.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;All his life, Henry Hill wanted to be a gangster. &amp;nbsp;He began working for gangsters as a kid at the cab stand, parking cars while guys like Timmy Two Times and Bobby No Nose would gather at the local watering hole and chat about the daily ins and outs of mob living and how glamorous it all was. &amp;nbsp;The leader was Paulie Cicero, on account of him being the fattest, but Henry idolized Jimmy Conway the most because he was always flashing the dough around and got respect from everybody he met. &lt;br /&gt;One day, Henry&#39;s Irish father got a letter from the school saying that Henry had been truant for three months and so Henry&#39;s dad beat the shit out of him. &amp;nbsp;(Shockingly, Henry had an unpleasant home life). &amp;nbsp;In response, Jimmy and some of the other nudniks threatened to kill the mailman if he ever delivered any mail from the school to Henry&#39;s house ever again. &lt;br /&gt;A short time later, Henry got pinched for a minor crime, but even though the cops pressed him, he didn&#39;t snitch on anyone, he was no rat, and the guys got him acquitted anyway. &amp;nbsp;This was his unofficial initiation into the life full-time.&lt;br /&gt;Cut to twenty years later or so, the 70&#39;s, Henry now looks like Ray Liotta, back when that actually meant something. Henry&#39;s at the watering hole with a bunch of good guys, including the diminutive Tommy Devito, who is in the process of telling a really funny story. &amp;nbsp;Funny how, you may ask? &amp;nbsp;Aw, it&#39;s not important. &amp;nbsp;Boring scene, moving on. &lt;br /&gt;Tommy wants Henry to go out on a double date with him, with some lady named Helen. &amp;nbsp;Henry goes, but is extremely uninterested in his date, and she in him. &amp;nbsp;Tommy pressures them to agree to all go out again next week. &amp;nbsp;Henry agrees, but then stands her up when the time comes. &amp;nbsp;Helen drives around the neighborhood like a crazy person, looking for Henry. &amp;nbsp;When she finds him, she bitches him out for standing her up, and because fictional men (or in this case &quot;fictionalized&quot;) &amp;nbsp;in movies always find shrill and unpleasant women appealing, he is suddenly in love.&lt;br /&gt;He takes her on a date to a club to see the hilarious stylings of Henny Youngmann. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s one of those thrilling long shots as they enter the kitchen and walk through the whole club, that always take me out of the movie due to their showy, high-wire act nature, but I love them nonetheless. &amp;nbsp;Yes, Henry is living the good life on top. &amp;nbsp;And when you&#39;re on top, there&#39;s no where to go but...higher? &amp;nbsp;Is that the expression? &lt;br /&gt;Henry, Paulie, Jimmy, and Tommy pull off a robbery that nets them $400,000. &amp;nbsp;In the meantime, Helen&#39;s neighbor tries to sexually assault her, so Henry beats the shit of out him in his driveway with a gun. &amp;nbsp;He then later asks Helen to hide said gun. &amp;nbsp;That&#39;s when she knew she was in love. Soon after, they get married.&lt;br /&gt;Search warrants become a regular part of Helen&#39;s life as a mob spouse, as well as lots of women named Marie. &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s totally fine with it all, even offering the cops coffee when they come over.&lt;br /&gt;At the bar, another mobster named Billy Batts just got out of prison. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s chatting with Tommy, Jimmy, Henry, and some other guys. &amp;nbsp;He mentions that the last time he saw Tommy, Tommy was a shoe shine boy. &amp;nbsp;Tommy thinks he&#39;s getting mocked, but Billy assures him that he&#39;s just being jovial. &amp;nbsp;Tommy accepts the half-apology, then--pause. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Now go and get your fucking shine box!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Tommy&#39;s livid, and has to be pushed out of the bar by Henry. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy says to Billy that he &quot;insulted him. &amp;nbsp;A little bit. &amp;nbsp;A little bit,&quot; doing his best Robert DeNiro impression. But Jimmy wants to make it all better with another round on him. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy and Billy talk all night until they&#39;re the only two left in the bar. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, Henry and Tommy come rushing in. &amp;nbsp;Tommy and Jimmy beat the shit out of Billy while Henry stands guard. &amp;nbsp;They dump his body into their car, and then stop by Tommy&#39;s mother&#39;s house to pick up a shovel (???). She is awake, and invites them in for dinner. &amp;nbsp;After long and filling meal, they then continue on with the murdering. &amp;nbsp;They bury Billy out in a field somewhere after shooting him a few times, and then pose for a Norman Rockwell painting.&lt;br /&gt;Paulie is asked by the Gambino mobsters about the disappearance of Billy. &amp;nbsp;Paulie has no answer for them, but is suspicious of his boys. &amp;nbsp;Six months later, they learn that the land where they buried Billy is going to be renovated and turned into an apartment complex, so they dig up Billy and move him.&lt;br /&gt;Alas, poor Spider. &amp;nbsp;Spider is the innocent who is too slow to get Tommy a drink one night when they&#39;re all playing poker, so Tommy playfully shoots at the ground by his feet. &amp;nbsp;A bullet playfully rips through his metatarsal and Spider must playfully be taken to the hospital. &amp;nbsp;A couple weeks later, Spider is limping around, still serving the boys. &amp;nbsp;Tommy mocks him for limping, and Spider respectfully tells him to go fuck himself. &amp;nbsp;Bye, bye, Spider. &lt;br /&gt;Because his life is not nearly interesting enough, Henry begins cheating on Helen with a girl named Janice, and even gets her an apartment. Helen learns of this and first goes to the apartment building, children in tow, and sanely and rationally buzzes the intercom of every resident in the building, screeching to every one of them that &amp;nbsp;Janice is a WHORE. &amp;nbsp;She later pulls a gun on Henry while he&#39;s sleeping. &amp;nbsp;He wants out, but Jimmy and Paulie convince him that he can&#39;t divorce her without the risk that she&#39;ll turn him in to the feds, and to be much more careful when cheating in the future. &amp;nbsp;Paulie assigns them to go down to Florida and beat on some guy that owes them money. &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately, the guy in question turns out to be the brother of a woman who works as a secretary for the FBI, and when she learns out what happened, she turns everyone in, even her own brother. &amp;nbsp;Henry winds up with a several year sentence. &amp;nbsp;However, when you&#39;re a made man, prison life isn&#39;t so bad. &amp;nbsp;Paulie cooks dinner for them every night, and there&#39;s always music and soft lighting. &amp;nbsp;You need only bring good conversation. &amp;nbsp;After several years in jail, the Hills are more or less temporarily cut off from the rest of the mob family. &amp;nbsp;Helen&#39;s panicked because they&#39;re getting low on funds, but Henry assures her that this is temporary until he gets out of jail. &amp;nbsp;He decides to sell drugs, because why the fuck not? &amp;nbsp;Even Paulie thinks this is a bad idea, so Henry does it on the sly. &amp;nbsp;When he gets out of jail, he continues to sell drugs, and secretly brings Tommy and Jimmy in on it. &amp;nbsp;Together with a bunch of other mobsters, they plan the Luftansa Heist, and steal about three million from the JFK airport. &amp;nbsp;However, the guy that was supposed to hide the truck afterwards was late, so Tommy shot him. &amp;nbsp;The completely unforeseeable consequence to that is that the truck is discovered by the cops. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy in particular becomes paranoid when this happens and eventually murders each and every mobster involved in the heist (besides his BFFs Tommy and Henry) to prevent the cops from catching them. &amp;nbsp;Meanwhile, words comes down from the mountaintop that Tommy is going to be into a boss himself. &amp;nbsp;All three are elated, knowing that they&#39;ll be on easy street after that happens. &lt;br /&gt;Two goombas take Tommy into a room and...oh, that&#39;s not good. &lt;br /&gt;Sometime later. &amp;nbsp;Henry is now sampling the merchandise far too often when he goes on drug runs, and is a paranoid wreck, convinced a helicopter up in the sky is following him and the cops are listening to his every world. &amp;nbsp;This fails to stop him from selling drugs, though. &amp;nbsp;And indeed, he is caught on that very day. &amp;nbsp;When the police show up at the house to arrest him, Helen hurriedly flushes 60 grand worth of cocaine down the toilet. &amp;nbsp;Henry gets out on bail, and goes back to the house, telling Helen they need to sell the rest of the cocaine and then get the hell out of town. &amp;nbsp;Helen breaks the news that she flushed the cocaine. &amp;nbsp;He screams at her for a while, and then together they collapse onto the floor, clutching each other and weeping uncontrollably. &amp;nbsp;She doesn&#39;t say, &quot;where is your Janice, NOW?&quot;, but I might have. &amp;nbsp;Henry goes to Paulie for some money. &amp;nbsp;Paulie is furious at Henry for selling drugs, and even more angry at him for getting caught. &amp;nbsp;He gives Henry 3200 dollars and tells him to get out of his life forever. &amp;nbsp;Henry is even more despondent, as 3200 won&#39;t get you to be able to spend the rest of your days on an island in the south pacific. &amp;nbsp;He sees Jimmy. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy is warm and friendly to him, and Henry interprets this as a bad sign. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy wants Henry to come with him on a job in a couple days. &amp;nbsp;Hmm...&lt;br /&gt;Henry&#39;s no fool, and knows Jimmy&#39;s gonna whack him. &amp;nbsp;He goes to the cops and offers to do what he refused to do as a kid...snitch on his friends. &amp;nbsp;The feds offer Henry and Helen immunity and entry into the witness protection program if they squeal on Jimmy and Paulie. &amp;nbsp;They do so. &lt;br /&gt;As Paulie and Jimmy are hauled off to jail, where they would eventually die, Henry bemoans his new life as one of the average joes, the square, the chump. &amp;nbsp;But Henry&#39;s still young, maybe there&#39;s a chance he&#39;ll turn his life around? &amp;nbsp;Ah, fuggetabouit. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;As I said before, the first time I saw this was about a year ago. &amp;nbsp;I remember enjoying it quite a bit, but regretted that most of the best bits (&quot;funny how, like a clown?&quot; &quot;Go and get your fucking shinebox!&quot; etc) had long since been spoiled for me and rehashed and parodied on every other movie and TV show in the last twenty years. &amp;nbsp;I had seen half the movie through osmosis, and it cheapened it a bit. &amp;nbsp;This time around however, after having seen the whole movie through actual watching, I enjoyed it a helluva lot more. &amp;nbsp;I could appreciate the utter hypnotic insanity of Joe Pesci as Tommy, one of the greatest characters in all of film. &amp;nbsp;Was the &quot;am I a clown to you?&quot; scene merely Tommy just having fun with Henry, or was there something darker and grosser there? &amp;nbsp;An assertion of dominance that, when acknowledged, turns into &quot;oh, I&#39;m just fucking with you!&quot; He&#39;s this incredibly powerful mobster that&#39;s so insecure he must kill a waiter for talking back to him. &amp;nbsp;A waiter, by the way, who had &lt;i&gt;every right &lt;/i&gt;to be a little bit peeved. &amp;nbsp;The relationships in this movie are all incredibly strong. &amp;nbsp;Ray Liotta really can&#39;t quite compete acting wise with DeNiro and Pesci, but that actually works in the movie&#39;s favor, too. &amp;nbsp;The overriding theme is that Henry, the half-Irishman, never really did quite fully fit in with these people, even though he spent his life trying. &amp;nbsp;The bond between Tommy and Jimmy was always stronger than his bond with them. &amp;nbsp;It made sense, ultimately, that his last act of betrayal confirmed that all the intervening years had just been desperate playacting. &amp;nbsp;And Lorraine Bracco, who I always thought was pretty weak and bland on The Sopranos, is more than awesome here. &amp;nbsp;So often the token girl in these types of movies is either a vapid slut or a saint, and Helen is just a dirty, desperate, and unhinged whirling dervish of a mess, who never stops being fun to watch. &lt;br /&gt;The whole movie clicks nearly perfectly on every level; writing, directing, and acting. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a fucking masterpiece, and I&#39;m gonna slide it in there right under Pulp Fiction as the second best movie on the list so far. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s another one that needs to move way up.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does it deserve &quot;best 100&quot; status: &lt;/b&gt;Fuck you for even asking.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Next up, &quot;Sophie&#39;s Choice&quot;, and then &quot;Swing Time&quot;, which already makes me want to cry.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/947221713913405093/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/92-goodfellas-1990.html#comment-form' title='2 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/947221713913405093'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/947221713913405093'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/92-goodfellas-1990.html' title='#92 Goodfellas (1990)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-g7B_3GqtMpA/TZ6AejjU-DI/AAAAAAAAABg/a3Nr2RUpIhk/s72-c/funny.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>2</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-1613932023769395376</id><published>2011-04-03T17:36:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-04-03T17:36:50.599-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#93 The French Connection (1971)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-IXZyGXZ4Yw8/TZfdiFBICRI/AAAAAAAAABc/m1d-WAYIPrU/s1600/hack.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-IXZyGXZ4Yw8/TZfdiFBICRI/AAAAAAAAABc/m1d-WAYIPrU/s1600/hack.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Police detectives are a troubled lot.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s 1971, and cops in the movies and TV were heroic and flawless and always caught the bad guy and brought him to justice. &amp;nbsp;But Jimmy &quot;Popeye&quot; (ugh...&lt;i&gt;really?&lt;/i&gt;) Doyle is not heroic or flawless. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s a bad egg, obsessed with getting his man, no matter what the cost. &amp;nbsp;Rumor has it he even sleeps with women &lt;i&gt;who are not his wife. &lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;He also swears.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;At the start, he and his partner Buddy Russo bust into a funkadelic club for brothas and collar one guy. &amp;nbsp;Another races out of the club and into the street. &amp;nbsp;Popeye and Buddy pursue. &amp;nbsp;No, fuck that. &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m calling him Doyle. &amp;nbsp;How does one expect to be taken seriously calling oneself &quot;Popeye&quot;? &amp;nbsp;Might as well just call himself Mighty Mouse. Anyways, Doyle and Russo finally jump on the guy, and tackle him, though he manages to cut Russo&#39;s arm with a knife. &amp;nbsp;Russo beats on him a little until he&#39;s subdued, then Doyle wants at him to beat the living shit out of him, but Russo mainly blocks that effort. &amp;nbsp;They bully him and smack him around until he gives up the name of the guy who sold him the drugs. &amp;nbsp;Oh yeah, they&#39;re looking for drug dealers, on account of being narcotics detectives.&lt;br /&gt;Later that night after the arrest is made (Cops 1, Drugs 0; victory is at hand!) Doyle and Russo go out to a club to celebrate. &amp;nbsp;Doyle notices a table full of Godfather central-casting extras and decides that they must be mobster types. &amp;nbsp;The lead guy, a young handsome Italian, is passing money out to the waitstaff like the currency is about to no longer be held to the gold standard and thus soon become useless paper. Doyle knows he&#39;s the leader because he&#39;s at the head of the table and the camera keeps focusing on him. &amp;nbsp;Doyle asks Russo if he wants to work tonight. &amp;nbsp;They decide to follow the guy and see what he&#39;s up to. They follow him all night long, as he and his entourage go from club to club. &amp;nbsp;Finally, the man and his wife are the only two left. &amp;nbsp;They drive around awhile. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Russo follow. &amp;nbsp;This goes on for a while. &amp;nbsp;But I&#39;ll give the movie this, they&#39;re still in the set-up phase. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s not like the whole movie is just going to be Doyle following people around. &amp;nbsp;That would be silly! &amp;nbsp;The man and his wife park their car on the street, then walk a block and climb into a much less fancy car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle smiles. &amp;nbsp;His hunch has paid off, these people are definitely shady! &amp;nbsp;The couple park in front of a convenience store, or actually a little mom and pop grocery store, like you see in movies set on the east coast. They take a bundle of newspapers from out of the car...and then go inside the store, unlocking it. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Russo realize they&#39;re setting up shop for the day, that this is their business. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, in France.&lt;br /&gt;People drive by in little scooters, just like when I was there last year! &amp;nbsp;Ooh, and there&#39;s those little alleyways, and the old buildings. &amp;nbsp;Not much has changed in 40 years, I&#39;ll tell you what. &amp;nbsp;I love the water. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s so beautiful. &amp;nbsp;Oh sorry, the plot. &amp;nbsp;Some French guy kills another guy. &amp;nbsp;A third older French Guy (who Doyle later will refer to as Frog One, and so shall I) meets up the the murdering French Guy (Frog Two). &amp;nbsp;They discuss their recent plan to smuggle heroin into the United States. &amp;nbsp;It involves duping a B-level actor named Henri, who is travelling to New York to be in a movie. &amp;nbsp;Frog One convinces Henri to bring along a car to New York. &amp;nbsp;(Henri is traveling by boat). &amp;nbsp;He tells Henri he doesn&#39;t want to pay all the customs fees and shipping, and if he (Henri) takes the car for him, those fees will be waived by the permit the movie company got. Henri seems to know that something isn&#39;t totally kosher, but doesn&#39;t specifically know about the heroin, and clearly doesn&#39;t want to know.&lt;br /&gt;And back to America. &amp;nbsp;Russo has done some intel on the shopkeeper and his wife. &amp;nbsp;Their names are Sal and Angie Boca, and they have minor criminal records. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Russo watch the shop for a week (off camera, thankfully), and see them meet with a variety of shady characters, including a criminal lawyer named Weinstock, who&#39;s known for being more criminal than lawyer. &amp;nbsp;This is enough for them to beg their captain for a wiretap. &amp;nbsp;The captain grumbles and is reluctant and basically seems to not like catching bad guys before finally agreeing to ask the DA for a warrant. He also assigns another cop named Mulderig to tag along with Doyle and Russo. &amp;nbsp;Mulderig and Doyle have a troubled unspoken backstory, and Mulderig doesn&#39;t want to work with Doyle, and he natters on to the captain for awhile about it. &amp;nbsp;The captain natters back. &amp;nbsp;Their dialog seems weirdly ad libbed, all &quot;I don&#39;t wanna&quot;, &quot;well, you have to&quot;, &quot;yeah yeah yeah&quot; and it goes on forever.&lt;br /&gt;Another black disco club, another bust-in by Doyle and Russo. &amp;nbsp;They rough up the locals, making them give up all their maryjane. &amp;nbsp;Not cool, man. &amp;nbsp;But it&#39;s all just a ruse to allow Doyle to speak in private with an undercover cat with a three-foot fro, who tells Doyle that no one has any hard stuff &amp;nbsp;because it&#39;s all dried up. &amp;nbsp;No heroin in all of Manhattan. &lt;br /&gt;One of the wiretap people (let&#39;s call him Lester Freamon, just for funzies) records a call between Sal and a suspicious frenchman, agreeing to meet at a hotel the next day. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Russo are stoked. &amp;nbsp;The next day, they show up outside the hotel, and see Sal and Weinstock meet up with Frogs One and Two. &amp;nbsp;Frog One gives Sal a briefcase. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Russo split up, Doyle following the Frogs, while Russo follows Sal. &amp;nbsp;This goes on for a while. &amp;nbsp;Doyle is definitely a follower. &amp;nbsp;Finally, Doyle sees Frog One enter another hotel. &amp;nbsp;He watches him go into an elevator, and gets his name from the hotel clerk. &amp;nbsp;Literally, Doyle says, &quot;the guy who just walked into the elevator...what was his name?&quot; Oh, 1971. How adorable.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile Russo follows Sal back to another building. &amp;nbsp;He can&#39;t see what&#39;s going on inside, but Sal and Weinstock have brought their sample of heroin to a truly gross looking drug expert/nerd guy. &amp;nbsp;Seriously, he has like, very black and thin teeth, that look like they would crumble into ash if he tried to eat an apple. &amp;nbsp;The nerd guy tests the heroin and determines that it&#39;s 89% pure, which is still quite a bit less pure than Dial Soap, but plenty pure apparently for heroin. &amp;nbsp;Weinstock approves and recommends that Sal make the buy. &lt;br /&gt;The next day, Russo shows up at Doyle&#39;s apartment. &amp;nbsp;He knocks, Doyle calls out and says to let himself in. &amp;nbsp;Russo uses a credit card to jimmy the lock and enters. &amp;nbsp;Doyle is lying on his bed, his handcuffs are around his ankle and attached to the bedpost. &amp;nbsp;He yawns tiredly, asks for the key on the dresser. &amp;nbsp;Russo gives him the key, then sees a naked girl appear in the hallway. &amp;nbsp;They girl squeaks and runs away. &amp;nbsp;OMG you guys, Doyle is totally a womanizing kinky freak! &amp;nbsp;We know that because he&#39;s clearly into handcuffs and nudity. &lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s time for some more following! &amp;nbsp;Doyle waits for Frog One outside his hotel. &amp;nbsp;He sees him leave on foot. &amp;nbsp;Doyle pursues, hanging back, trying not to look conspicuous. &amp;nbsp;Doyle loses Frog One in the crowd. &amp;nbsp;Fortunately, he&#39;s got a cane with a big golden tip, so he&#39;s easy to spot again. &amp;nbsp;They go in and out of buildings, and finally down into the subways.&lt;br /&gt;Okay, this next part is super awesome and hilarious. Frog One gets on a crowded subway car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle walks past him to the second door, and enters the car. &amp;nbsp;Frog One looks at his watch and suddenly steps off the car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle turns, sees Frog One&#39;s not on the subway anymore, and hurriedly steps back onto the platform. &amp;nbsp;He strikes up conversation with a random confused woman, pretending to have just stepped off the subway with her. &amp;nbsp;Frog One isn&#39;t even looking at them. &amp;nbsp;The subway leaves. &amp;nbsp;Doyle uses the pay phone to call Russo, and learns that Russo has lost the tail on Sal. &amp;nbsp;As he&#39;s bitching out Russo, Frog One walks right by him to a little concession stand. &amp;nbsp;Doyle pretends he&#39;s talking to his boss at the office, and hangs up. &amp;nbsp;Frog One orders a hot dog. &amp;nbsp;Doyle goes to the other side of the stand and orders a candied apple. A new subway pulls up. &amp;nbsp;Frog One leaves the stand without his hot dog, and gets on the the car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle waits until his back is turned, then hurriedly grabs the candied apple and attempts to look casual while speed-walking to the second door again. He gets on. &amp;nbsp;Frog One notices a napkin in his hand from the concession stand, and walks off the car and throws it away in a trash can. &amp;nbsp; Doyle looks over, sees he&#39;s off the car &lt;i&gt;again, &lt;/i&gt;and jumps off himself. &amp;nbsp;Frog One&amp;nbsp;walks &lt;i&gt;back &lt;/i&gt;onto the subway car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle, needing a reason to have left the car, hurriedly runs over to the trash can, throws away his apple, then hurriedly runs back into the doorway. &amp;nbsp;Just as he&#39;s getting back in, Frog One fucking casually walks off &lt;i&gt;again&lt;/i&gt;. &amp;nbsp;He stares at his watch. &amp;nbsp;Doyle sees this as the doors slide closed. &amp;nbsp;He uses his umbrella to keep the doors from closing all the way, and pries them open. &amp;nbsp;Just as he does this, Frog One steps back onto the subway car at the precise moment Doyle steps off. &amp;nbsp;The doors close. &amp;nbsp;The subway starts to move. &amp;nbsp;Frog One gives Doyle a little wave and a smile, while Doyle rages impotently at the cruel and unforgiving sky. I may not have done it justice, but trust me, that scene was fucking hysterical. It was the forced nonchalance of both of them, always inventing a reason to get on and off the subway that sold it. &lt;br /&gt;The police captain tells Russo and Doyle that the wiretap has been removed and the case is dead. &amp;nbsp;Doyle&#39;s pissed all over again. &amp;nbsp;Mulderig taunts him and they almost come to blows.&lt;br /&gt;Meanwhile, Frog One meets up with Sal and Weinstock. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re both spooked, Weinstock having &quot;made&quot; Russo. &amp;nbsp;They want to wait before buying the heroin, but Frog One&#39;s temporary Visa only allows him to stay in New York until Friday. &amp;nbsp;They tell him that&#39;s too soon. &amp;nbsp;Frog One meets up with Frog Two, cursing Doyle&#39;s name. &amp;nbsp;Unbeknownst to both of them, the wiretap is over already. Frog Two volunteers to &quot;take care&quot; of him, if you know what I mean. &amp;nbsp;Bwa ha ha. &lt;br /&gt;Doyle&#39;s walking down the street in public. &amp;nbsp;He passes a woman pushing a baby stroller. &amp;nbsp;A shot rings out. &amp;nbsp;The woman goes down. &amp;nbsp;Damn. &amp;nbsp;Doyle runs for cover. &amp;nbsp;People are screaming and running everywhere. &amp;nbsp;Doyle hides behind a tree. &amp;nbsp;More shots ring out. &amp;nbsp;Doyle sees Frog Two on the rooftop with a sniper&#39;s rifle. &amp;nbsp;He takes another shot at Doyle, misses. &amp;nbsp;Doyle races to the side of the building, then scoots along it until he can get inside. &amp;nbsp;He rushes up the stairs and bursts onto the roof. &amp;nbsp;The rifle is sitting there on the ground. &amp;nbsp;Doyle &amp;nbsp;peers over the top and sees Frog Two running down below. &amp;nbsp;Doyle runs downstairs, and gives chase. &amp;nbsp;They both dash over to a nearby subway station. &amp;nbsp;A subway car is just pulling out. &amp;nbsp;Frog Two leaps onto the subway, Doyle is too far to catch up in time. &amp;nbsp;As the subway starts moving, Doyle calls out &quot;Stop that man! &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s a killer!&quot; &amp;nbsp;A beat cop on the subway car hears Doyle, but doesn&#39;t really know if what he&#39;s saying is legit, or even to whom he&#39;s referring. He looks around at the passengers suspiciously. &amp;nbsp;Doyle runs onto the street and commanders a car. &amp;nbsp;He starts racing down the road underneath the subway. &amp;nbsp;(The subway&#39;s above ground. &amp;nbsp;Is it still called a subway? &amp;nbsp;Maybe a monorail?) &amp;nbsp;Doyle weaves in and out of traffic, in a fairly thrilling and obviously non-CGI sort of way, often on the wrong side of the road. &amp;nbsp;He comes swerving around a corner and sees another woman and a damn baby stroller. &amp;nbsp;He swerves and crashes, but immediately starts driving again. &amp;nbsp;On the subway, the beat cop looks suspiciously at Frog Two, who&#39;s doing himself no favors by looking all squirrelly and sweaty and French. &amp;nbsp;Frog Two stands up to go to another car, and the cop says &quot;excuse me sir, can I help you?&quot; and Frog Two has no poker face at all apparently, because he turns around and shoots the cop. &amp;nbsp;People scream. &amp;nbsp;Frog Two races to the front of the subway, and puts a gun in the conductor&#39;s back, threatening to shoot if he brakes.&lt;br /&gt;Doyle drives below, crashing into random shit all the while.&lt;br /&gt;Finally, another subway employee and some brave tough-guy passengers try to jump Frog Two. &amp;nbsp;Frog Two shoots a couple of them. The conductor passes out in fright, and now the subway is careening towards the end of line, about to crash. &amp;nbsp;The automatic breaks kick in, and everyone is thrown about. Frog Two staggers to his feet, all bloody and weak and climbs out of the subway car. &lt;br /&gt;Below, Doyle brings the car to a stop, having ran into multiple cars and shit at least three or four times. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s also beat up and weak. &amp;nbsp;He sees Frog Two above, getting out of the car. He runs over to the stairway at the same time Frog Two does, and the meet at the stairs. &amp;nbsp;Frog Two sees him, turns around and BAM! &amp;nbsp;Doyle shoots him in the back. &amp;nbsp;He tumbles down the stairs, stopping by Doyle&#39;s feet, and Doyle collapses in exhaustion. &amp;nbsp;Good scene. &amp;nbsp;Well done.&lt;br /&gt;Some time later, (the next day, maybe?) Russo is, yes you guessed it, following Frog One. &amp;nbsp;He sees him leave a parking garage in Henri&#39;s car and follows him to a shady neighborhood in Brooklyn. Doyle meets up with him, and they watch the car for awhile. &amp;nbsp;They see another car circle the block a few times, slowing in front of Henri&#39;s car. &amp;nbsp;They get out and hassle the guys, who turn out to be car thieves. &amp;nbsp;Since their cover is blown, they haul in the car. &amp;nbsp;Doyle&#39;s convinced the car is &quot;dirty&quot;, but the sourpuss captain has his doubts, because he&#39;s just randomly a dickhole. &amp;nbsp;They search the car for four hours, and finally find 125 pounds of heroin inside the paneling. &lt;br /&gt;Henri is waiting at the station to pick up &quot;his&quot; car. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s flustered and angry. &amp;nbsp;Russo appears and gives Henri the keys, &quot;sorry about the wait, sir&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Henri tells Frog One he wants out. &amp;nbsp;Out! &amp;nbsp;Frog One drives the car to meet up with Sal and Weinstock and some burly extras with guns in an old abandoned warehouse outside of town. &amp;nbsp;Creepy ugly teeth guy inspects the heroin with his magic heroin-inspector fluid and determines it legit. &amp;nbsp;Sal makes the deal. &amp;nbsp;Frog One and another associate get in their car to drive away. &amp;nbsp;They drive down the road about a mile, and meet a roadblock of about twenty cop cars. &amp;nbsp;Doyle is out of his car standing in front. &amp;nbsp;He gives Frog One a wave. &amp;nbsp;Because yes, they&#39;ve been followed once again. &amp;nbsp;Frog One flips a U, and drives back to the warehouse where Sal and his goons are celebrating. The cops pursue. &amp;nbsp;Everyone holes up in the warehouse and starts shooting at the cops, and the cops shoot back. &amp;nbsp;Doyle, Russo, and Mulderig sneak into the building and split up. &amp;nbsp;Doyle searches for Frog One desperately. &amp;nbsp;The cops all storm the warehouse, killing Sal. &amp;nbsp;Frog One is nowhere to be found. &amp;nbsp;Doyle sees movement off in the distance, and fires. &amp;nbsp;He races to the body, and sees that it&#39;s Mulderig. &amp;nbsp;He barely reacts, racing off again to find Frog One, if it&#39;s the last thing he ever does. &amp;nbsp;(And yes, he says, &quot;if it&#39;s the last thing I ever do!&quot;) &amp;nbsp;Fade to black.&lt;br /&gt;Really? &amp;nbsp;Wow. &amp;nbsp;Title cards tell us Frog One was never found, and Doyle was soon after reassigned. &amp;nbsp;Most depressing title cards ever.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;Supposedly the grandfather of the modern-day anti-hero action star. &amp;nbsp;The first time a movie attempted to be realistic in its portrayal. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s hard to know how to review stuff like that. &amp;nbsp;Honor its historical importance, or simply give a review based on 2011 sensibility? I&#39;m going with the latter. &amp;nbsp;And besides, I&#39;ve seen Dog Day Afternoon, and it doesn&#39;t come off nearly as dated as this. &amp;nbsp;Though the acting is top-drawer, and the set-piece chase scene was excellent, there was still a lot of silliness. &amp;nbsp;Like if your mom was told to write about the seediest sex scene she could think of, it would probably involve one pair of handcuffs and some alcohol. Vic Mackey and Andy Sipowitz and Jimmy McNulty would think Doyle was a pussy, and would probably beat him up on a regular basis, even though they might not have ever existed without him.&lt;br /&gt;Characters like Russo, Manderig, and the grumpy captain may not have been cliches then like they are now, but there&#39;s still no excuse for them to be so underdeveloped. &amp;nbsp;Doyle and Frog One are the only two people in this whole movie that come off at least as two dimensional.&lt;br /&gt;And the following...so much following. &amp;nbsp; Enough with the following!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Two and a half out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does it deserve &quot;Best 100&quot; status: &lt;/b&gt;Nah. &amp;nbsp;If you&#39;re gonna pick an old-school action movie, why not Die Hard?&lt;br /&gt;Next up, Goodfellas, then Sophie&#39;s Choice. Practically the same movie.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/1613932023769395376/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/93-french-connection-1971.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1613932023769395376'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/1613932023769395376'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/04/93-french-connection-1971.html' title='#93 The French Connection (1971)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-IXZyGXZ4Yw8/TZfdiFBICRI/AAAAAAAAABc/m1d-WAYIPrU/s72-c/hack.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8456834121634857306</id><published>2011-03-29T22:28:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-04-02T03:55:38.217-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#94 Pulp Fiction (1994)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-BOYF75KOyPw/TZETYsj_H1I/AAAAAAAAABU/_fB6DRYviQA/s1600/pulp.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;122&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-BOYF75KOyPw/TZETYsj_H1I/AAAAAAAAABU/_fB6DRYviQA/s320/pulp.jpg&quot; width=&quot;320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So yeah, I&#39;ve seen this one already. &amp;nbsp;Like, only about ten thousand times. &amp;nbsp;Just like you. &amp;nbsp;So let&#39;s do this mother fucker.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;Pumpkin and Honey Bunny are at the diner, discussing the finer points of armed robbery. &amp;nbsp;The banks are too dangerous. &amp;nbsp;The convenience stores don&#39;t have much cash. &amp;nbsp;But last time, Honey Bunny had the idea to rob the customers as they came in. &amp;nbsp;They yielded a bigger bounty than the register. &amp;nbsp;Good call, Honey Bunny! &amp;nbsp;Say, why don&#39;t people ever rob restaurants? &amp;nbsp;Because they&#39;re usually huge with multiple exits and lots of windows and people are always coming in and out? &amp;nbsp;Nah, must be some other lame reason! &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s the perfect plan. &amp;nbsp;Let&#39;s do it! &amp;nbsp;Okay! &amp;nbsp;Kisses! &amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;ANY OF YOU FUCKING PRICKS MOVE, AND I&#39;LL EXECUTE EVERY LAST MOTHER FUCKING ONE OF YOU!!&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Two men in suits, Vincent Vega and Jules Winnfield, are on a leisurely drive in the Valley. &amp;nbsp;Vincent is discussing a recent trip he took to Europe. &amp;nbsp;Jules wants to know if it&#39;s true that hash is legal in Amsterdam. It is, but not just out in the open. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s kind of complicated, and not really the sort of minutiae that movie dialog would ever delve into unless it was really germane to the plot--oh, what&#39;s that? &amp;nbsp;Oh, okay. &amp;nbsp;Well, it seems that it&#39;s legal to grow and it&#39;s legal to smoke, but it&#39;s not legal to have on your person in public, but that&#39;s okay because it&#39;s illegal for cops to search you. &amp;nbsp;Also, there are little differences in Europe. &amp;nbsp;In Paris, they call a Quarter Pounder a &quot;Royale with Cheese&quot;, because of the metric system. &amp;nbsp;Again, I&#39;m not really sure what this has to really do with anything, if we could just move on--oh, sorry. &amp;nbsp;Yes, the Big Mac is called &quot;Le Big Mac&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Not that different, really. Nope, didn&#39;t go to Burger King.&lt;br /&gt;Vincent and Jules arrive at their destination. The open the trunk of their car, and pull out a couple of very large guns. Conversation turns to an associate of theirs, who was recently thrown out a window by their boss, Marcellus Wallace. &amp;nbsp;Seems this associate was caught giving Marcellus Wallace&#39;s wife a foot massage. &amp;nbsp;Vincent agrees that this is excessive, but also thinks the guy was asking for it. &amp;nbsp;Jules thinks that a foot massage is completely non-sexual, and not an issue at all. &amp;nbsp;Vincent asks if he would give a dude a foot massage. &amp;nbsp;Jules says to fuck off. Vincent teases him, and says he&#39;s tired and could use a foot massage right now. &amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;(Quentin Tarantino yells &quot;cut&quot; and John Travolta says &quot;no seriously, could you give me a foot massage?&quot;)&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Having proven his point, Vincent heads over to the apartment door they&#39;re supposed to enter. &amp;nbsp;The appointed time has not yet arrived, so they hang back. &amp;nbsp;Vincent tells Jules that he has an upcoming date with Mrs. Wallace, at Marcellus Wallace&#39;s request. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;ll be out of town for a bit, and wants someone to keep his wife entertained. &amp;nbsp;Vincent assures Jules that there will be no massaging going on, foot or otherwise. &amp;nbsp;Finally, the time has come to enter the apartment. &amp;nbsp;Inside are three guys, one of whom let them in and seems to know they were arriving. &amp;nbsp;Another one is lying on a couch, and another is seated at the table, eating a Big Kahuna Burger. Jules tells the man on the couch to not get up and to keep relaxing. &amp;nbsp;Jules is very polite. &amp;nbsp;He asks the man seated at the table (Brett) if he could have a bite of his burger. Brett says yes. &amp;nbsp;And a soda to wash it down? &amp;nbsp;Jules basically eats Brett&#39;s entire meal, before asking him where the package is. &amp;nbsp;The one he was supposed to deliver to Marcellus Wallace. &amp;nbsp;The guy on the couch directs Vincent to the kitchen. &amp;nbsp;Vincent pulls out a suitcase. &amp;nbsp;Puts in the combination 666. &amp;nbsp;And opens it up. &amp;nbsp;The suitcase glows gold. &amp;nbsp;Are we cool? &amp;nbsp;Yes we are cool. &amp;nbsp;Jules asks Brett what Marcellus Wallace looks like. &amp;nbsp;What? &amp;nbsp;What? &amp;nbsp;SAY &quot;WHAT&quot; AGAIN, MOTHERFUCKER! Does he look like a bitch? &amp;nbsp;NO! &amp;nbsp;Then why are you trying to fuck him like one? &amp;nbsp;Marcellus Wallace doesn&#39;t want to be fucked by anyone except Mrs.Wallace. &amp;nbsp;(So hopefully no one will come along later in the movie and fuck him).&lt;br /&gt;AND YOU KNOW MY NAME IS THE LORD WHEN I LAY MY VENGEANCE UPON THEE! &amp;nbsp;BANG BANG BANG! &amp;nbsp;Brett is blasted.&lt;br /&gt;New scene. &amp;nbsp;Vincent and Jules arrive at Marcellus Wallace&#39;s bar, where a boxer named Butch is being bribed to take a fall. &amp;nbsp;In the fifth, his ass is supposed to go down. &amp;nbsp;Vincent and Jules are wearing dorky T-shirts and board shorts. &amp;nbsp;They have no desire to talk about it. &amp;nbsp;But they have the suitcase, and that&#39;s all that matters.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;New scene. &amp;nbsp;Vincent is hanging out at his dealer&#39;s house, buying heroin. &amp;nbsp;The dealer is quite the salesman and upsells Vincent into buying a more expensive...brand? &amp;nbsp;Mixture? &amp;nbsp;Rock? &amp;nbsp;Vincent shoots up and then irresponsibly drives to the Wallace residence. &amp;nbsp;Shame on you, Vincent! &amp;nbsp;You could kill someone. &amp;nbsp;Mia Wallace greets Vincent by intercom, and soon is ready for their date. &amp;nbsp;The restaurant is fifties themed. Ed Sullivan seats them. &amp;nbsp;Buddy Holly takes their order. &amp;nbsp;Hope they don&#39;t tip him, Mr. Pink doesn&#39;t like tips. Mia filmed a television pilot. &amp;nbsp;She was going to be one of five crime fighting tough chicks, and she was going to tell a corny joke at the end of each episode. No, you can&#39;t hear it. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s lame. &amp;nbsp;In 1994, five dollars was a lot for a shake. &amp;nbsp;Even if they leave that awesome giant silver cup with like, a whole other shake in it. &amp;nbsp;Mia denies the &quot;foot massage&quot; story, and accuses Vincent of belonging to a sewing circle. &amp;nbsp;If Quentin Tarantino made a movie about a sewing circle, I would also watch it. Dance contest. &amp;nbsp;Mia has entered their names. &amp;nbsp;They stand up, go to the stage, and begin to dance the weirdest and craziest and most delightful dance ever. I think some people might of imitated it. &amp;nbsp;I think some people might&#39;ve bought the Pulp Fiction soundtrack and played it every night at the graveyard shift where they worked at Shell gas station while they lived in San Diego and went to junior college. &amp;nbsp;And danced their ass off to all the songs while they stood all cramped in that little booth. &amp;nbsp;Who knows, just spitballing.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;They head back to the house. &amp;nbsp;They dance in through the doorway, holding their first place trophy. The sexual tension is palpable. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Drinks!&quot; Mia says. &quot;Music!&quot; &amp;nbsp;She&#39;s wearing Vincent&#39;s coat. Vincent excuses himself to the bathroom, where he can admonish his boner for a little while. Mia puts on another bitchin song, then sits on the couch, putting her hands in Vincent&#39;s coat pocket. &amp;nbsp;She fishes out the heroin. She thinks it&#39;s cocaine, and tries a line. Immediately, her nose starts to bleed and she falls to the floor. &amp;nbsp;Vincent comes out of the bathroom. &amp;nbsp;Oh, shit!&lt;br /&gt;Drug dealer Lance&#39;s phone is ringing. &amp;nbsp;He ignores it a first, while his girlfriend yells at him, complaining about the lateness of the call. &amp;nbsp;Lance agrees, and answers, preparing to give the caller a piece of his mind. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s Vincent, explaining the situation and begging for help. &amp;nbsp;Lances says to go elsewhere, then realizes Vincent is calling on a &quot;cellular phone&quot; which can be overheard easily by anyone like a CB conversation. Lance hangs up, but too late, Vincent and the unconscious Mrs. Wallace have arrived. &amp;nbsp;One Vincent explains to Vince who it is, and how much trouble he&#39;ll be in if Marcellus Wallace finds out he refused to help, Lance knows he can&#39;t refuse them. He says she needs and adrenaline shot, right in the heart. &amp;nbsp;Do you have a magic marker, a fucking felt pen, a fucking black magic marker?! &amp;nbsp;You have to stab her in the heart with the needle! &amp;nbsp;Three times? &amp;nbsp;No, one time! &amp;nbsp;Ready? &amp;nbsp;One, two, three, GO! &amp;nbsp;Say something! &amp;nbsp;Something.&lt;br /&gt;On the way home, again. &amp;nbsp;Significantly less sexual tension this time. &amp;nbsp;The joke from the TV pilot was that the father tomato murdered his son for walking too slow or something.&lt;br /&gt;A little boy named Butch watches old cartoons when they were probably new. &amp;nbsp;His mother lets a guy as creepy as Christopher Walken into the house to talk to him. Christopher Walken has a watch for Butch. &amp;nbsp;He explains it was Butch&#39;s father&#39;s watch, and his father&#39;s before him, and his father&#39;s before that. &amp;nbsp;When Butch&#39;s father was captured by the Japanese, he hid the watch up his ass for five years. &amp;nbsp;He probably shouldn&#39;t have brought it to a war if it was that important, come to think of it. &amp;nbsp;Christopher Walken had it up his ass for two years after Butch&#39;s dad was killed. And now it&#39;s yours, Butch. &amp;nbsp;Wash it, and wear it with pride.&lt;br /&gt;Present day Butch is amping up for the big boxing match. &amp;nbsp;Round One begins, off camera, and Butch pulverizes the guy, kills him in fact, in the first round. &amp;nbsp;This is not what Marcellus Wallace paid for. Butch escapes the boxing stadium out a window, and hops into a waiting cab. The cab driver asks him what it&#39;s like to kill a man. &amp;nbsp;Butch didn&#39;t know until just now that he had, but he&#39;s okay with it. &amp;nbsp;He calls his bookie at a phone booth, laughing about the dead boxer, saying he shouldn&#39;t have ever boxed in the first place and is excited to learn about all the money he won.&lt;br /&gt;The cab drops him off at a hotel, where he meets up with his European girlfriend Fabienne who expresses a fondness for pot-bellies. &amp;nbsp;(Later interpretations claim she was working up to telling him she was pregnant, and I can see that). &amp;nbsp;Butch asks Fabienne if she got everything they needed from the apartment. &amp;nbsp;She says yes. &amp;nbsp;Butch showers, and I find myself shocked to see more this time than I remember seeing in the theatre. &amp;nbsp;Go, Bruce! &amp;nbsp;They discuss plans to flee south of the border, living the good life. &amp;nbsp;Fabienne is freaking adorable.&lt;br /&gt;The next morning, Butch awakens from a bad dream. &amp;nbsp;They go to back up their stuff. &amp;nbsp;Where is the watch? &amp;nbsp;I packed it. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s there? &amp;nbsp;No, it&#39;s not. &amp;nbsp;Did you really pack it? &amp;nbsp;I believe so. &amp;nbsp;You believe so?!! &amp;nbsp;Unbelievable. &amp;nbsp;A TV is thrown, Fabienne shrinks into the corner. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s my fault, I should&#39;ve told you the ass story. &lt;br /&gt;Butch is gone, heading back to his apartment, leery of any of Marcellus&#39;s men who may be guarding the place. &amp;nbsp;He goes into his apartment. &amp;nbsp;No one&#39;s there. &amp;nbsp;He grabs the watch, looks around. &amp;nbsp;Still nothing. He decides to cook a couple of Pop Tarts in the toaster, because why the fuck not? &amp;nbsp;Nothing to do but wait for Pop Tarts. &amp;nbsp;Guess Butch will just casually look around the room and...say there&#39;s a giant gun right there on the counter. &amp;nbsp;Pretty sure Fabienne didn&#39;t leave it there. He slowly walks over to it. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, he hears a toilet flush. &amp;nbsp;He grabs the gun, aims it at the bathroom (which is right next to the kitchen, ew!) and waits. &amp;nbsp;The door opens and it&#39;s our friend and dancing champion Vincent Vega. &amp;nbsp;He stares at Butch. &amp;nbsp;Butch stares back. &amp;nbsp;The Pop Tarts pop. &amp;nbsp;Vincent is shot two thousand times, and falls into a heap. Guess we&#39;ll never see him in this movie again! &amp;nbsp;Butch forgets his Pop Tarts and scrams. He can hardly believe his luck. &amp;nbsp;He jumps back in the car, smiling and singing along to the radio. &amp;nbsp;He stops at red light. &amp;nbsp;A pedestrian crosses in front of him, and lo and behold it&#39;s the big guy himself, Marcellus Wallace. &amp;nbsp;Their eyes lock. &amp;nbsp;Butch floors it, smashing into Marcellus Wallace, and then getting hit himself in the intersection. &amp;nbsp;Marcellus Wallace gets up first, a crowd around him. He stands, sees Butch getting out of his car about a block away and fires his gun, hitting a random pedestrian. Butch staggers away, Marcellus Wallace in hot pursuit, firing wildly. &amp;nbsp;Butch slips around the corner, and goes into a random shop. &amp;nbsp;The shopkeeper is confused by his bloddy appearance. &amp;nbsp;Butch hides around the door and as Marcellus Wallace staggers by, Butch ambushes him. &amp;nbsp;They struggle, and Butch gets the gun and starts beating him silly. &amp;nbsp;Just as he&#39;s about to shoot him in the face, the shopkeeper cocks his shotgun. &lt;br /&gt;Back away! &amp;nbsp;Put your hands on your head! &amp;nbsp;He hits Butch in the face with the shotgun, and Butch falls to the floor. &amp;nbsp;He grabs his phone, obviously calling 911. &amp;nbsp;Apparently, he knows the 911 operator and calls him Zed. He wants Zed to come over, right away. &amp;nbsp;Hmm...&lt;br /&gt;Butch and Marcellus Wallace are tied to chairs with ball gags in their mouths. &amp;nbsp;The shopkeeper sprays them with water. In walks Zed, a security guard. I don&#39;t think this is proper police procedure. The shopkeeper calls for the Gimp. &amp;nbsp;The Gimp is sleeping. &amp;nbsp;I guess you&#39;re gonna have to wake him up then, won&#39;t you? &amp;nbsp;A person in all leather is removed from a tiny box. &amp;nbsp;They put him on a leash. &amp;nbsp;Who&#39;s first? &amp;nbsp;Eeeny Meeny Miny Moe...oh, well as kids we always said &quot;Tiger&quot;, but you can do your version, I guess. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s your shop. Marcellus Wallace is the &quot;winner&quot;, so he is dragged off to a separate room for modesty&#39;s sake by Zed and the shopkeeper. &amp;nbsp;The Gimp stands guard. &amp;nbsp;Butch easily and quickly breaks free of his bonds, punches out the Gimp, and races upstairs and out of the shop. &amp;nbsp;He stops at the door, hearing a variety of unpleasant noises down below. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s at a crossroads. &amp;nbsp;Do the right thing, or let Marcellus Wallace burn? He goes back into the shop, grabs a sword hanging on the wall, and goes back downstairs. &amp;nbsp;The shopkeeper is sliced and diced. &amp;nbsp;Zed backs away from Marcellus Wallace. &amp;nbsp;Was Sir Mix a Lot around in 1994? I bet Zed would&#39;ve liked that song. &amp;nbsp; Marcellus Wallace stands and shoots Zed in the dick. &amp;nbsp;What happens now?, says Butch. &amp;nbsp;A whole lot of torture. &amp;nbsp;No, between us. &amp;nbsp;Oh, that. &amp;nbsp;You&#39;re free to go. &amp;nbsp;Don&#39;t ever come back to LA again. &lt;br /&gt;Butch leaves the shop of horrors, his redemption arc complete, and sees a motorcycle, I mean a chopper, outside. &amp;nbsp;He picks up Fabienne at the hotel. &amp;nbsp;Zed&#39;s dead, baby. &amp;nbsp;Zed&#39;s dead.&lt;br /&gt;A man is holding a gun, breathing hard. &amp;nbsp;He hears Jules outside the room, talking about Big Kahuna burgers and the big brain on Brett and Ezekiel. &amp;nbsp;AND YOU KNOW MY NAME IS THE LORD WHEN I LAY MY VENGEANCE UPON THEE! Brett is blasted.&lt;br /&gt;The man leaps out of the room, sees Vincent and Jules standing there, and unloads his gun. &amp;nbsp;ONE TWO THREE FOUR FIVE SIX click click click click. &lt;br /&gt;Every bullet misses both Vincent and Jules. &amp;nbsp;They quickly dispatch of the man. &amp;nbsp;Jules is stunned. &amp;nbsp;Vincent hassles Marvin, the last man standing.&lt;br /&gt;On the drive back, Jules insists that the bullets missing them was a sign from God, a miracle, while Vincent, the hash-loving man of science, sneers at this. &amp;nbsp;Vincent wants Marvin&#39;s opinion. &amp;nbsp;BLAM! &amp;nbsp;Marvin just got shot in the face. Both men and the car are covered in blood. &amp;nbsp;Is there anywhere safe to go and hide out from the cops? &amp;nbsp;Jimmy. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy&#39;s house. &amp;nbsp;Jimmy is displeased. &amp;nbsp;&quot;Is there a sign in my driveway? &amp;nbsp;A sign that says &#39;Dead African American storage? &amp;nbsp;Because I don&#39;t see a sign like that. &amp;nbsp;And yet, I have a dead African American in my garage&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Jules calls still-pure Marcellus Wallace, who sends help in the form of The Wolf. &amp;nbsp;The Wolf is dressed in a tux and at some sort of cocktail party at 8:00am, because that&#39;s The Wolf. &amp;nbsp;The Wolf instructs the duo on a bunch of basic common sense stuff, like cleaning the car and washing themselves and Vincent absurdly bitches and grumbles the whole time, like they&#39;re doing The Wolf a favor. Jimmy gives them dorky T-shirts and board shorts. &amp;nbsp;They deposit the car in a junkyard. Let&#39;s go to breakfast.&lt;br /&gt;At the diner, more chit-chat about the filth of pigs, and then Jules tells Vincent he&#39;s leaving the job. &amp;nbsp;Forever. &amp;nbsp;Vincent can&#39;t believe it, calls him a bum. &amp;nbsp;Now if you&#39;ll excuse me, I have to go to the bathroom again. &amp;nbsp;I mean, for the first time, chronologically. &lt;br /&gt;DON&#39;T ANY OF YOU PRICKS MOVE OR I&#39;LL EXECUTE EVERY LAST MOTHER FUCKING ONE OF YA!!&lt;br /&gt;Oh, shit! &amp;nbsp;Honey Bunny and Pumpkin! &amp;nbsp;There you guys are! &amp;nbsp;Honey Bunny surveys the scene while Pumpkin walks around with a trash bag to put all the customer&#39;s wallets in. &amp;nbsp;He approaches Jules. &amp;nbsp;Jules gives up the wallet easily enough, but when Pumpkin also wants the suitcase, Jules refuses. &amp;nbsp;Pumpkin aims his gun at Jules&#39;s face. &amp;nbsp;Orders him to open it. &amp;nbsp;Jules does so. &amp;nbsp;Pumpkin looks down at the beautiful gold glow. &amp;nbsp;Is that what I think it is? &amp;nbsp;It is. &amp;nbsp;Jules grabs Pumpkin&#39;s gun, then produces his own. &amp;nbsp;Honey Bunny freaks. &amp;nbsp;Bitch be cool! &amp;nbsp;We&#39;re just three Fonzies. &amp;nbsp;Vincent finally comes out of the bathroom and points his gun at Honey Bunny. &amp;nbsp;Now we&#39;re three Fonzies and a Vinnie. &amp;nbsp;Jules orders Pumpkin to remove his wallet from the bag. &amp;nbsp;Inside is fifteen hundred dollars. &amp;nbsp;He lets Pumpkin keep it, explaining that today is Pumpkin&#39;s lucky day. &amp;nbsp;Normally, he would already be dead. &amp;nbsp;But this 1500 dollars is buying Pumpkin his life. &amp;nbsp;The passage Jules always quoted from Ezekiel was just something cool he liked to say before he iced a dude. &amp;nbsp;But today...today he realizes that he himself is the tyranny of evil men. &amp;nbsp;But he&#39;s trying to change. &amp;nbsp;Pumpkin and Honey Bunny leave. &amp;nbsp;I&#39;m sure the other customers would&#39;ve appreciated a less costly solution. &amp;nbsp;Vincent suggests it&#39;s time to go. &amp;nbsp;Jules agrees. &amp;nbsp;They tuck their guns inside their board shorts, suitcase in hand, and exit the restaurant.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;So...I think there better be something AMAZING further up this list if it hopes to beat out Pulp Fiction. &amp;nbsp;Like most Tarantino movies, except that awful Death Proof, it works on two levels. &amp;nbsp;You can appreciate it as mindless and wildly entertaining pulp, and on that level, it&#39;s master-class. &amp;nbsp;It has all the necessary crazy violence and action. &amp;nbsp;Plus, no ordinary action movie has dozens of quotable lines, reducing everyone who sees it into acting like they&#39;re the host of The Chris Farley show, saying &quot;remember that one scene...and then he said...oh, that was awesome!&quot; &amp;nbsp;It has multiple story lines that intersect in all the right places, and the playing around with time, while gimmicky in some movies, actually enhances the story here. &amp;nbsp;When he hear Jules tell Vincent that the bullets missing them were Divine Intervention and Vincent scoffs, we already know Vincent winds up dead, so there&#39;s no question as to who&#39;s right and who&#39;s wrong.&lt;br /&gt;One thing that struck me funny this time around, though. &amp;nbsp;I remember how crazy and dark the adrenaline scene was, and how freaked out the audience was in the theatre. &amp;nbsp;The other night I thought it actually was kind of tame. I think kids today would hardly bat an eye if they saw this in the theatre, now in the days of torture porn like Saw and Hostel. &amp;nbsp;Also, a good litmus test for how corrupt you are is how long it took you to figure out what Zed and his friend were up to. &amp;nbsp;I think most teens and twenty year olds would know the score immediately upon seeing the ballgags. &amp;nbsp;My friends and I were confused until Marcellus got dragged into the other room. &amp;nbsp;Times change.&lt;br /&gt;But it works on another level too, about a story of redemption and forgiveness. &amp;nbsp;When Butch kills the boxer in the ring, he doesn&#39;t give a shit, but yet he later takes the time to save his arch-enemy&#39;s life. Jules chooses to let Pumpkin live. Both were tested by God, and both passed. &amp;nbsp;Vincent learns nothing, despite being warned twice, (once with the bullets, and once with Mia) fails and dies. &amp;nbsp;What&#39;s in the suitcase? &amp;nbsp;I dunno. &amp;nbsp;Not sure it&#39;s important. &amp;nbsp;But the religious undertones in this movie would compel you to think it&#39;s related in some way. &amp;nbsp;I&#39;ve heard there are even college courses that teach Pulp Fiction as a class, and I can see that. I think that Quentin gets to stand tall and shoulder to shoulder with Scorsese, Speilberg, Kubrick, and a handful of others. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Five out of five. &amp;nbsp;Can I say six? &amp;nbsp;Oh, fine. &amp;nbsp;Five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does it deserve &quot;Best 100&quot;
