width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-8839117132740196386</id><published>2011-03-18T15:47:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2011-03-20T14:18:16.322-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#99 Toy Story (1995)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-Q6-cGdO5RhI/TYPgW-th6CI/AAAAAAAAAAY/LO-YM4R2lR4/s1600/images.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-Q6-cGdO5RhI/TYPgW-th6CI/AAAAAAAAAAY/LO-YM4R2lR4/s1600/images.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So...this is obviously one of the 31 I&#39;ve already seen. &amp;nbsp;I don&#39;t live under a rock, people! &amp;nbsp;However, I can&#39;t say for certain, but I don&#39;t think I&#39;ve sat down and watched it all the way through since it came out in the theatres fifteen years ago...until today, that is. &amp;nbsp;DUN!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers): &lt;/b&gt;A little boy is hanging out in his room playing with his toys, which include a cowboy, a slinky dog, a potato head, a T-Rex, and a Little Bo Peep porcelain doll, like all the little boys have. &amp;nbsp;The boy&#39;s name is Andy. &amp;nbsp;He grabs the cowboy and bounds down the stairs into the living room, where his mom mentions that he needs to get ready for his birthday party later that afternoon. &amp;nbsp;Andy scurries upstairs, drops off the cowboy toy, and exits stage left. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, the cowboy, previously lying inert, begins to move around. &amp;nbsp;Holy crap, &amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;we were right!&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Just as we always suspected as kids, the toys &lt;i&gt;really do &lt;/i&gt;talk and move around when we&#39;re not looking! &amp;nbsp;I told my GI Joes years ago that I was onto them, and they still never had the class to admit it. &lt;br /&gt;Anyway, the cowboy&#39;s name is Woody, and he snaps to attention, and calls the rest of the toys to order. &amp;nbsp;He attempts to casually announce that today is Andy&#39;s birthday party, a week earlier than expected, because they&#39;re going to be moving shortly afterwards. &amp;nbsp;The toys all panic, because new toys always mean the possibility that the old ones will be replaced. &lt;br /&gt;Plastic green soldiers are dispatched to spy on the party, and see what gifts Andy receives. &amp;nbsp;Most of the gifts are clothes and boardgames, which apparently have yet to gain the power of autonomy and sentience. &amp;nbsp;Andy&#39;s toys are relieved. &amp;nbsp;But wait! &amp;nbsp;One final toy is taken out of the closet as a surprise. &amp;nbsp;Andy opens it and is overjoyed. &amp;nbsp;He and his friends run upstairs to put it in his room. &amp;nbsp;Woody and the rest freeze in their places, because the...I dunno...Toy Governing Body, &amp;nbsp;let&#39;s say, forbids exposing their ability to move around or speak &amp;nbsp;to the humans. &amp;nbsp;(Maybe Toy Story 4 will be a prequel?) &amp;nbsp;Andy bounds into the room, casually shoves Woody aside and off the bed, and deposits his exciting new toy. &amp;nbsp;Then because Andy is exceedingly polite, he goes back down to the party and his guests without so much as touching the new toy. &amp;nbsp;Andy&#39;s mom taught the boy right, despite the fact that she is a single mother and therefore a horrible sinner. &lt;br /&gt;Woody, Potato Head, Rex, and the others climb up onto the bed to check out the new toy. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s a spaceman named Buzz Lightyear. &amp;nbsp;Buzz doesn&#39;t know he&#39;s a toy, and instead thinks he&#39;s a legit superhero. &amp;nbsp;All the other toys are enamored of Buzz&#39;s flashing lights and pop-up wings, while Woody stews in jealousy and worries he&#39;ll be replaced. &amp;nbsp;Tom Hanks does the best acting job of his life pretending to find Tim Allen in any way threatening. &lt;br /&gt;Turns out, Woody&#39;s fears are well-founded. &amp;nbsp;The cowboy-themed posters and &amp;nbsp;bedspreads are replaced by space themed ones. &amp;nbsp;Buzz becomes the toy of choice, residing on the top of the bed, as Woody once did. &amp;nbsp;And all along, Buzz doesn&#39;t even know he&#39;s a toy! &amp;nbsp;One night, when Andy is allowed to just one toy with him to Pizza Planet, Woody knows it won&#39;t be him that&#39;s chosen unless he can hide Buzz by knocking him back behind the desk. &amp;nbsp;He tries to use the remote control car to knock Buzz off the desk but misjudges and winds up knocking him out the window. &amp;nbsp;The car tells the others what happened, and they are furious at Woody, and openly threaten to totally murder him. &amp;nbsp;We are spared learning what that would actually entail, though, because Andy arrives at just that moment, and when he&#39;s unable to find Buzz, takes Woody with him to Pizza Planet. &amp;nbsp;Down in the yard, Buzz sees Woody being carried into the car, and he grabs onto the bumper of Andy&#39;s Mom&#39;s car, Cape Fear style (or Sideshow Bob, if you prefer) and goes with them to Pizza Planet. &amp;nbsp;Mom stops for gas, and Woody escapes from the car, and discovers Buzz. &amp;nbsp;They start a full-on brawl, which ends suddenly when Mom and Andy take off in the car. &lt;br /&gt;&quot;I&#39;m lost!&quot; &amp;nbsp;cries Woody. &amp;nbsp;Buzz, still not accepting his toy status, decides to take off and find his spaceship. &amp;nbsp;Woody realizes he can never return to the playroom without Buzz, sees a Pizza Planet delivery truck and tricks Buzz into hitching a ride on it, so they can meet up with Andy there. &amp;nbsp;While at the pizza place, Buzz sees a rocket ship that is actually one of those games where you can use a claw to grab a toy and win it. &amp;nbsp;Buzz thinks that ship will return him to his home planet (stupid Buzz!) and craws inside. &amp;nbsp;Woody exasperatedly follows. &amp;nbsp;Inside are a bunch of religious zealot rubber aliens who worship the claw as a god and let it decide who stays and who goes. &amp;nbsp;Definitely the movie&#39;s funniest gag. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly a boy shows up at the game. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s Sid, Andy&#39;s neighbor and an evil little shit who tortures and blows up toys. &amp;nbsp;He uses the claw to grab one of the aliens. &amp;nbsp;Then he sees Buzz inside. &amp;nbsp;He uses the claw again, and snags Buzz. &amp;nbsp;Sid is the best claw player in the history of the world. &amp;nbsp;Woody tries to keep Buzz from being pulled up, and is pulled up himself as well. &amp;nbsp; They are taken back home, where the rubber alien is fed to Sid&#39;s evil little pit bull, and Woody and Buzz are left in the room, with an assortment of mute, mangled toys with mixed-up and missing body parts. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re both terrified and attempt to escape the room. &amp;nbsp;Outside the room, the dog chases them, they split up. &amp;nbsp;Buzz wanders into the living room and sees an advertisement for himself on TV. &amp;nbsp;He suddenly realizes he really is a toy. &amp;nbsp;This breaks him psychologically. Sid returns to his room and decides to launch Buzz on a rocket, actually a highly illegal rocket-shaped firework of some kind. &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately for Sid, it&#39;s raining. &amp;nbsp;So he straps Buzz to the rocket and goes to bed, prepared for a launch in the morning. &amp;nbsp;The next morning arrives, and Buzz is taken into the backyard. &amp;nbsp;Woody gathers the other freak toys and announces a plan, although they &quot;may have to break the rules&quot;. &amp;nbsp;The rules established by who? &amp;nbsp;Damn you, Toy Story-verse! &lt;br /&gt;And now for the best scene in the movie. Woody and the rest of the toys sneak outside and spread out, Woody lying in plain view. Sid sees Woody scoops him up, and puts him on the barbeque, planning to have a roast later. &amp;nbsp;He then turns to light the fuse on Buzz&#39;s rocket. &amp;nbsp;Suddenly, the recorded Woody voice begins to speak &quot;reach for the sky!&quot; &amp;nbsp;Sid is intrigued, but thinks the toy is busted. &amp;nbsp;&quot;No, you&#39;re busted, Sid Phillips!&quot; the Woody voice says. &amp;nbsp;Sid is terrified. &amp;nbsp;He goes on to threaten Sid to stop hurting his toys, and the other toys slowly rise up and surround Sid. &amp;nbsp;&quot;We see everything&quot;. &amp;nbsp;says Woody. &amp;nbsp;And then he moves and speaks live. &amp;nbsp;&quot;So. Play. Nice.&quot; &amp;nbsp;Sid screams and throws Woody into the air, and runs inside. &amp;nbsp;There he discovers his little sister holding a doll. &amp;nbsp;&quot;The toys are alive! Keep them away!&quot; &amp;nbsp;The sister gleefully starts chasing Sid around with her doll. &amp;nbsp;Later that day, Sid&#39;s mother found him curled up in the closet, rocking back and forth and silently weeping. &amp;nbsp;She asked him what was wrong. He explained how the toys in his room came to life and threatened him, but his mother didn&#39;t believe him, and wound up taking him to the doctor. &amp;nbsp;After seeing several specialists, the doctors could find nothing wrong with Sid, and said the problem was all in his head. &amp;nbsp;Meanwhile, Sid refused to go near any toys, or indeed anything that even appeared to look like a toy. &amp;nbsp;Was a TV considered a toy? &amp;nbsp;A wristwatch? &amp;nbsp;What about clothing? &amp;nbsp;Literally anything could come alive at any moment! &amp;nbsp;Sid eventually refused to even leave his room, even after clearing it of every inanimate object. &amp;nbsp;Ha, &quot;inanimate&quot;. &amp;nbsp;That was a fucking laugh. &amp;nbsp;Eventually, Sid&#39;s parents had him committed to a mental institution, where he resides today. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s been years, and day by day, bit by bit, Sid gets a little bit better. &amp;nbsp;He uses silverware now, reasonably confident the knives won&#39;t try to cut him, or the forks poke him. &amp;nbsp;There are good days and bad. &amp;nbsp;He met a girl. &amp;nbsp;She thinks she&#39;s Eleanor Roosevelt, but other than that, she&#39;s all right. &amp;nbsp;There might be something there. &amp;nbsp;Sid can go most days now without thinking of toys at all. &amp;nbsp;But every once in awhile, when he&#39;s had too much to eat, or had a bad day in the rec room, he&#39;ll wake up in he middle of the night, bolt upright in his cot, and hear those three little words all over again: &quot;So. Play. Nice&quot;. And then the night terrors come.&lt;br /&gt;Woody and Buzz attempt to dash across the yard, and just miss Andy and his mom in the car. &amp;nbsp;Instead they attempted to chase down the moving van behind them. &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately, Sid&#39;s dog is in hot pursuit. &amp;nbsp;Woody manages to get on the truck, but Buzz is cornered by the dog. &amp;nbsp;Woody finds the remote car and uses it to rescues Buzz, but the rest of the toys still think he&#39;s a toy killer and knock him off the truck. &amp;nbsp;Eventually, they see Buzz and the car, and try to use Slinky Dog to pull them back on. &amp;nbsp;This fails, but then Buzz uses the rocket and blah blah you know the rest. &lt;br /&gt;The end.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stars: &lt;/b&gt;Four out of five.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Review: &lt;/b&gt;I&#39;ll be honest. &amp;nbsp;When I first saw this movie, I was somewhat underwhelmed. &amp;nbsp;I didn&#39;t think it stacked up to some of Disney&#39;s greats, and while the computer graphics were interesting, I didn&#39;t think they would ever look as good as hand drawn stuff. &amp;nbsp;Obviously, hand drawn cartoons are all but gone in the movies now, and CGI has improved by leaps and bounds. &amp;nbsp;(The humans in this didn&#39;t look that great, frankly). &amp;nbsp;When I watched it this time, I liked it a whole lot more. &amp;nbsp;I still think the story kind of drags until the last twenty five minutes or so, but really all the Toy Story movies are kind of like that, even TS3, my favorite of all Pixar movies. &amp;nbsp;TS2 and 3 delved into real human emotions and themes, where here the big emotional moment is Buzz learning he&#39;s a toy, which isn&#39;t really anything we can identify with. &amp;nbsp;It&#39;s not like the fear of abandonment that gets explored in the other two. &amp;nbsp;(I&#39;d bend your ear about how in this movie Andy is a metaphor for a parent, in the second, a lover, and in the third, a god, but that would make me seem weird).&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;I still like this movie a lot, but think it belongs in the bottom tier of Pixar movies. &amp;nbsp;Well, let&#39;s say the top of the bottom. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does it deserve &quot;Best 100&quot; status: &lt;/b&gt;It&#39;s not as good as 2, 3, or a bunch of others. But it was the first. &amp;nbsp;So...yes? &amp;nbsp;I guess. &amp;nbsp;You know what, no. &amp;nbsp;I say no. &amp;nbsp;Give it to WALL E, Up, or Toy Story 3, dammit.</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/8839117132740196386/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/03/99-toy-story-1995.html#comment-form' title='5 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8839117132740196386'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/8839117132740196386'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/03/99-toy-story-1995.html' title='#99 Toy Story (1995)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-Q6-cGdO5RhI/TYPgW-th6CI/AAAAAAAAAAY/LO-YM4R2lR4/s72-c/images.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>5</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-6832023944662780846.post-3324687680202674057</id><published>2011-03-15T21:38:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2012-07-01T14:58:02.014-07:00</updated><title type='text'>#100 Ben-Hur (1959)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style=&quot;margin: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; color: #333333; font-family: &#39;lucida grande&#39;, tahoma, verdana, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.5em; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-O4AZub5mHE4/TYA_rupOoYI/AAAAAAAAAAM/5I0Z0WX7nmk/s1600/images.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-O4AZub5mHE4/TYA_rupOoYI/AAAAAAAAAAM/5I0Z0WX7nmk/s1600/images.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: &#39;lucida grande&#39;, tahoma, verdana, arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 11px; line-height: 16px;&quot;&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: &#39;lucida grande&#39;, tahoma, verdana, arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;background-color: white; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: x-small; line-height: 140%;&quot;&gt;So, as mentioned earlier, it is my personal goal to watch all one hundred AFI top movies in reverse order. &amp;nbsp;#100 was Ben-Hur, a three hour and forty five minute epic flick that I watched over the course of two days. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;Plot summary (with spoilers)&lt;span style=&quot;font-weight: normal;&quot;&gt;:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;A new Roman governor and his second-in-command, Messala, arrive in Jerusalem to throw a parade in honor of the new Governor&#39;s recent promotion. &amp;nbsp;While there, Massala arranges a meet up with his old childhood friend, Judah Ben-Hur. &amp;nbsp;The two are overjoyed to see each other. (Although perhaps Massala is more overjoyed than Ben-Hur. &amp;nbsp;In the documentary&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-style: normal;&quot;&gt;The Celluloid Closet,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;which talks about gay characters in film, Gore Vidal relayed an anecdote and said that apparently the director and the actor playing Massala agreed that his character and Ben-Hur were lovers in their youth, and Massala loved him still. &amp;nbsp;This is&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-style: normal;&quot;&gt;very&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;evident in the actor Stephen Boyd&#39;s portrayal. &amp;nbsp;The funny part was, they both agreed &quot;don&#39;t tell Chuck. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;ll freak out&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Which is also evident, though one wonders why Heston didn&#39;t at some point say, &quot;why do you keep looking at me like with those &#39;fuck me&#39; eyes during our scenes?&quot;).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;They eagerly talk about old times, laugh, reminise, Massala strokes Judah&#39;s arm about a thousand times, says &quot;I missed you&#39; while tearing up and then they drink wine from chalets while interlocking their arms. &amp;nbsp;I mean, seriously, Chuck, you didn&#39;t question any of this? &amp;nbsp;The upshot is, Massala is eager to climb the ranks of the Roman political scene and become governor one day himself, perhaps even beyond that. &amp;nbsp;He knows Judah is a Jew and knows that many Jews oppose the Romans. &amp;nbsp;He asks Judah to spy on other Jews and find out if any of them are plotting against him. &amp;nbsp;Judah refuses to do so. &amp;nbsp;This breaks Massala&#39;s heart, and they part company. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;The next day, the governor arrives in town. &amp;nbsp;Judah and his sister are watching the arrival from their balcony overlooking the road, and Judah&#39;s sister accidently knocks some lose tiles from the roof onto the road, which startles the governor&#39;s horse, causing it to buck. &amp;nbsp;The governor is injured in the fall, and Judah, his sister, and mother are blamed for a deliberate assisnation attempt. &amp;nbsp;They are all three arrested. &amp;nbsp;Judah begs Massala for mercy, saying he should know they would never do such a thing. &amp;nbsp;Massala says he knows very well Judah would never do this, but an example must be made of them anyway. &amp;nbsp;Judah saysn, &quot;please, I&#39;m begging you!&quot; and Massala screams at the top of his fucking lungs, &quot;WHAT ABOUT ME?! &amp;nbsp;I BEGGED YOU!&quot; &amp;nbsp;This makes zero sense without the context mentioned above, but for some reason, Chuck doesn&#39;t question it. &amp;nbsp;Anyway, Judah is chained up and is made to walk across the desert for probably a long time. &amp;nbsp;While Judah is dying of thirst, a strange man whose face we don&#39;t see gives Judah water. &amp;nbsp;Judah is shocked by the man&#39;s compassion, and wonders who it is. &amp;nbsp;(It&#39;s totally Jesus). Then Judah is &amp;nbsp;put on a slave ship and his sister and mother are sent to prison. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;On the slave ship, the captain (Arrius) sees that Judah is the strongest rower and decides he will take him off the ship and make him ride in chariot races. &amp;nbsp;Before this happens, the ship is attacked by...some other country that also has ships, like three of them or so, and they ram the ship Judah is in. &amp;nbsp;The slaves are all chained up and panic, realizing they will drown. &amp;nbsp;Judah manages to choke out a guard, steal the key and swim to safety, clinging to a piece of the boat. &amp;nbsp;He soon discovers Arrius struggling to keep from drowning, and he pulls him onto his little makeshift raft thingy. &amp;nbsp;They float for an indeterminate amount of time until they are rescued by a Roman ship passing by. &amp;nbsp;Arrius is so grateful, he pardons Judah and grants him his freedom, though asks him to hang around still and race with his horses in order to make enough money to get back home to Jerusalem. &amp;nbsp;Judah agrees. &amp;nbsp;After four years, Judah has made enough money racing chariots for Arrius--and a white guy with brown facepaint who calls himself Sheik Ilderi--in order to get back home. &amp;nbsp;He vows revenge on Massala. &amp;nbsp;Some other dude who is friends with the &quot;Sheik&quot; cautions Judah about the futility and evil of hate and advises him to forgive Massala. &amp;nbsp;Judah fears he cannot do that. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;He gets back to Jerusalem and discovers his former home, which is half torn apart and in shambles. &amp;nbsp;Living there is a hot girl named Esther and her father. &amp;nbsp;I forgot to mention he met Esther in the beginning of the movie, and they were all schmoopy with each other. &amp;nbsp;Esther tells Judah that his mother and sister are dead. &amp;nbsp;Judah is sad and is more determined than ever to kill Massala. &amp;nbsp;To that end, a big chariot race is coming up that weekend, and Massala is one of the racers. &amp;nbsp;Judah enters the race. &amp;nbsp; Massala&#39;s chariot wheels have big pointy spikes on them, which should totally be against the rules. &amp;nbsp;During the race, Massala rams the other chariots with his total cheater spike wheels, causing them to crash, and creating an urban legend about dead stuntmen to manifest two thousand years into the future. &amp;nbsp;(Look on snopes, it never happened, and I didn&#39;t realize until just today). &amp;nbsp;Massala tries to ram Judah&#39;s chariot, but he avoids him. &amp;nbsp;He starts whipping Judah with his whip for the horses. &amp;nbsp;Judah manages to grab the whip and yank Massala off his chariott. &amp;nbsp;He is then dragged along the track and then run over by other horses. &amp;nbsp;Judah FTW!&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;In the next scene, they&#39;ve dragged Massala back to his house so he can die in private. &amp;nbsp;Judah visits him. &amp;nbsp;Massala thinks he&#39;s come to make amends, but Judah wants to know where his sister and mother are. &amp;nbsp;(Oh yeah, Esther&#39;s father let it slip that they&#39;re actually still alive, but he doesn&#39;t know where they are). &amp;nbsp;Massala says they&#39;re in the third cave on the right, but &quot;you won&#39;t recognize them&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Then he dies, while, I shit you not, while clutching and stroking Judah&#39;s arm. &amp;nbsp;Judah pushes he dead hand away and makes tracks to the cave. &amp;nbsp;Esther intercepts him and says that she knew all along his family was still alive, but they don&#39;t want to see him. &amp;nbsp;They have leprosy, and have been banished to the caves. &amp;nbsp;Esther says they are too ashamed to have Judah ever see them like that. &amp;nbsp;Judah goes anyway, and tries to take them back home. &amp;nbsp;They&#39;re upset, but agree to go. &amp;nbsp;In the main village, people throw rocks at them and shit, because that&#39;s what you do with lepers. All of a sudden, a parade comes marching down the main road. &amp;nbsp;No, it&#39;s not a parade, it&#39;s a crucifiction. &amp;nbsp;Someone (Jesus) is being crucified right now. &amp;nbsp;He&#39;s carrying his own cross up the road, right past Judah and this family. &amp;nbsp;Judah recognizes him (Jesus) as the guy who gave him water (Jesus). &amp;nbsp;The mysterious man (Jesus) falls down. &amp;nbsp;Judah rushes forward with a cup of water, practically going &quot;remember the water? &amp;nbsp;In the desert, you gave me water? &amp;nbsp;Now I&#39;m giving you water! &amp;nbsp;Crazy, huh?!&quot; &amp;nbsp;The man whose face we don&#39;t see (Jesus) whispers in Judah&#39;s ear and then keeps walking. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;Esther asks Judah what the strange man (Jesus) said. &amp;nbsp;He said &quot;forgive them father, for they know not what they do&quot;. &amp;nbsp;Who the fuck knows why he said this to Judah. &amp;nbsp;Though it seemed to have an affect on him. Later that night, when Jesus is buried, suddenly sister and mother are magically healed! &amp;nbsp;Hurray! &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;Stars:&lt;span style=&quot;font-weight: normal;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;Three out of five.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div align=&quot;LEFT&quot; style=&quot;line-height: 140%; margin-bottom: 0in;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;Review&lt;span style=&quot;font-weight: normal;&quot;&gt;:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small;&quot;&gt;I was absolutely dreading this, but it wasn&#39;t nearly as bad as I feared. &amp;nbsp;The story is quite strong, and the set pieces and design are epic and grand. &amp;nbsp;The ship battle and the chariot race were especially amazing. &amp;nbsp;You&#39;ll never again see a another movie that has real ships lobbing real flaming arrows at each other, not when CGI is so cheap. &amp;nbsp;There&#39;s something viscerally satisfying knowing it&#39;s really up there on the screen and not being drawn by some nerd with a Mac. &amp;nbsp;The acting is uniformly great except for the awful Heston, of course. And most of the dialogue is good too. &amp;nbsp;Weirdly, even though the Arab character is obviously a white guy, he&#39;s still as a character treated respectfully and non-sterotpyically and his friendship with the Jewish Judah is pretty surprising. &amp;nbsp;The first two thirds of this movie were very watchable. &amp;nbsp;It definitely falls apart in the third act, though. &amp;nbsp;Massala&#39;s death should be the end of the movie, as that was what we and Judah were working towards all along. &amp;nbsp;The leper/Jesus stuff is a good forty five minutes and completely anti-climatic. &amp;nbsp;There were also other trims here and there that were needed. &amp;nbsp;All in all, though, I don&#39;t regret seeing it, which surprises me.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;color: #333333; font-family: &#39;lucida grande&#39;, tahoma, verdana, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.5em;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/feeds/3324687680202674057/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/03/100-ben-hur-1959.html#comment-form' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3324687680202674057'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/6832023944662780846/posts/default/3324687680202674057'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://afistop100moviesreviewed.blogspot.com/2011/03/100-ben-hur-1959.html' title='#100 Ben-Hur (1959)'/><author><name>RTR</name><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='16' height='16' src='http://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-O4AZub5mHE4/TYA_rupOoYI/AAAAAAAAAAM/5I0Z0WX7nmk/s72-c/images.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry></feed>
